reviewText:
Early Access Review

Ok, I am in and alive for 13 days -  my best game so far.

I've finally made a good start.

I started slowly.

Gathered supplies from the coastal area, made an empty home my safehouse. Hell, I had a fridge with 40Kg of food. I had so much food I was forced to stuff Chocolate Bars and Cooked Meat in Drawers... I even had a special Cabinet with Dog Food only.

Then I had endless meds... my bathroom was a pharmacy, antiseptics, antibiotics, and so many bandages I could make a blanket with them.

I also had a good trap-thing going on.
Had snares all around the place, bagging game each time I went out scouting. Hares mainly. God, I had three shelves full of raw hare meat, ready to be cooked.
I must have had 50L of water in the Freezer, and another 10L on me...

I've fought wolves barehanded. Many wolves.

I had gathered half the available resources of the game in one house.  MY safehouse.

I could sleep and eat in the house for 40 days straight, without having to go out. I could get that freakin' achievement of surviving for 50 days just by sleeping and eating - I had a good thing going on.

Today, I woke up early - 5:08 to be precise. Thought of going out for a walk, it's so peaceful at this early hour.
As I watched the sun rise in the horizon, I heard a cracking noise below me.
The ice broke.

I died.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Alright, ladies and gentlemen - I have just reemerged back into the real world, after almost 100 days (99 days 18 hours) survival in one playthrough. With that up my sleeve, I'll be bold enough to say that I know a thing or two about this game and ready to try and write an adequate review. So gather round, grab a cup of hot chockolate and have a listen to what uncle Chern's got to tell ya :)

I'll split my review into three sections - pros, cons and things that are considered negative by some reviewers, but not necessarily are.

Let us start with the cons, because this list is the shortest... and because I am grumpy old b*****d who likes to criticize. So...

CONS:

MAP - Map in the current version of the game is not very large. There are only a few points to explore and salvage from. So after you have visited them all (which can... and probably should... be done in the first few days of your survival), the game becomes a bit repetitive. Go find meat - go collect some wood - cook - eat/drink - sleep - repeat from step one. Saying that - it does add to realism. Real survival in the wilderness is far from glorious and comes down to just that - get food, cook, keep sated, hydrated and warm. But still it would be nice to have more areas to poke your nose around :)

LOOT (sometimes) - Loot in the game is mostly random... which is a good thing and adds to realism and replayability value, but at some playthroughs it can get bloody stupid. Sometimes you may have enough ammo to get out of Canadian wilds, venture to Afghanistan and assist several ISAF operations, have three knives, 5 packs of MRE rations, ton of medical supplies and good gear. Sometimes it may be evenly and fairly spread-out - so you find a good bit of everything in moderate ammount... And sometimes it gets silly. On my previous to last playthrough i found 5 can openers, no MREs, no repair tools, one almost broken knife and ton of degraded clothing. I still managed 41 days and died of stupidity (went to bed while freezing, and hoped I'll warm up... I didn't), but be warned - never know what you might get and life isn't always fair :)

LONG DARK - No matter what you do, in the end your character is goind to punch that snuff button and check out. That can be quite depressing, that after toughing it out for 2-3 months, heroically navigating through blinding blizzards, savagely fighting wolves for half frozen (and half eaten) deer carcasses, you still going to die. I know - it wouldn't be The Long Dark" game if you didn't fade into the long dark in the end and it makes this game highly competitive among the players
date: but it would be nice if there was an option for some sort of happy ending to the game. Maybe they'll do it for story mode later on.\n\nFLUFFY - I am not going to spoil it for you. You'll get to know him as you play the game. Be afraid... be very afraid... and never let your guard down. Cause the very moment you think you're safe and relax
recommended: the cruel reality will bite you in the ***... literally.\n\nOther than that - there are no bad things about this game. I wouldn't even use a word "bad" to describe all of the above - there are no bad things
hoursPlayed: just areas for improvement (just please don't change fluffy - leave him where he is - we all love him really... ok

votesHelpful: that we are done with those negative waves

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Edit: I added a short response to negative reviews at the bottom - please read it

You know the warm/thawing feeling you have when you finally get home after walking through a snowstorm for a couple hours? When I stop playing The Long Dark, I feel exactly like that. Not really of course, but my brain believes it. The Long Dark is really immersive.

The difficulty is also something to savour. You don't have to fight a single living thing and can still die an embarrassing death. Just today, I managed to walk in big circles twice. In a game. Jesus.

I was also too afraid to go out at night because of big bad wolves and cold, but then I finally did go out. And the game stunned me with the sky. I wished I could just lie down on the snow and gaze.

Then the music started playing. The beautiful soft music by the amazing Cris Velasco & Sascha Dikiciyan.

I couldn't stay in one spot for too long, though, because I'd freeze soon. So I started walking when, on the horizon, I saw a house! With smoke coming out its chimney, ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, it was beautiful. Should be some food in it so I was definitely not going to die of hunger. At least not tonight.

But then I realized it's the house I took off from. God dammit.

Update: Two negative reviews have gotten to the top and they raise some understandable points with regards to gameplay mechanics and features. I strongly suggest you watch some gameplay videos to see if these issues might be game-breaking for you - you never know. The game cannot be 100% realistic in all manners and makes some adjustments to some of the mechanics such as durability of tools and clothes, etc.

Personally, I really don't mind them because to me, The Long Dark still offers lots of beautiful experiences, great gameplay and immersiveness which I'm oh so enjoying. But, be warned, you might be expecting something a bit different from the game than what it offers and these might not be due to the game being in Alpha but simply a core aspect of the game itself - so read/video up on it and decide for yourself!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I finally got the hang of this game. I fished, gathered wood and even made myself some deerskin boots! But after 8 days I still couldn't find the rifle. I packed my bags with supplies ready for a search of the ravine. Weather was fine and visibility was good.
A wolf soon catches my scent! With my flare to keep him at bay, I make a sprint for the Hydro Dam, phew safe! I hear scratching, I am not alone! I ready my final flare and hold it steady, confident I can repel whatever lurks in the dark. Fluffy comes for me, I ignite my torch... he attacks! I fight for my life and, wounded, the wolf retreats. However I am now left in a crippled state, bleeding. My condition is not good. I escape the Dam only to find myself in a blizzard, I can't go back, I must get back to my cabin! I forge ahead gritting my teeth, I am cold... so very cold. I soon lose my bearings in the whiteout, I'm down to 3% and my vision blurs, 2% I see the silhouette of a cabin, I make it to the door... yes, I survived! But whats this? The cabin does not have a fire! Now at 1% I really start to panic and before I can get out my bedroll I slip into The Long Dark...

10/10 for atmosphere. It really did have me frantic when I realised I was caught in a blizzard with low health.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

After a geomagnetic disaster and a plane crash into the Canadian wilderness, in the barely habitable winter wasteland the only survivor is you. How long can you last against the wrath of Mother Nature until you succumb to the Long Dark?

IntroductionIn The Long Dark, a survival & exploration game, the initial set-up is quite simple. You can choose to begin your story from either the Mystery Lake or Coastal Highway and then maintain your health (condition) by dealing with:
hunger (as displayed by remaining calories)
cold
thirst
exhaustionAt the same time you must explore your environment for critical supplies and beware of wandering too far from a shelter. In this game the worst threat won't be anything living but rather the general inhospitable surroundings. A roaring blizzard, threatening to put you to a cold shallow grave of ice, can be just as deadly to get lost in as to take shelter from in a cabin without any food, water or firewood.

There exists a constant risk/reward status where you must weigh just what can you do and what you MUST do that puts you in a fairly stressful (and even frightening) situation.


Survival mechanics 8/10After a few deaths and then surviving over 50 days, I can say the threats can be tough but are in the end fair. There are multiple ways to greatly enhance your odds of survival, namely finding better clothes and tools, but there's no substitute for exploration and familiarizing oneself to the surroundings. There are no maps or compasses so remembering landmarks is imperative for finding your back to safety...

The balance of staying outside to scavenge, hunt, fish and get firewood for cooking, heating and melting&boiling snow for drinking water while also tending to your clothes, tools and potential medical conditions isn't easy, but perhaps one of the finest points is the slightly reduced need for the tiniest of micro management. Getting firewood, melting snow, fixing, sleeping and even harvesting can be set to take place for a predefined amount of time or quantity, which makes managing your ever-dvindling energy more straight-forward and makes organizing easier.

There's also a day-night cycle and even if the sky is free of clouds, without a flare or lantern it will be all but impossible to see anything once sunlight's gone. During the night it will also be potentially much colder and also harder to spot the hungry predators. The sight of glowing eyes approaching is enough to chill your blood from a whole different reason than the cold...

While it can be easy to survive for some time with scavenging alone, it will eventually be a near must to hunt for your meals. And even then the management of limited resourses like medicine and cloths will potentially either make or break your survival. Luckily you can improve your own effectivity at lighting fires, crafting tools and repairing items to make longer term sustainibility possible but long-term thinking is a necessity to survive.

A bit of a heads-up so your not caught off guard, being in strong wind or a blizzard will wear down your clothes rather quickly even if you take windcover in a broken shack or the hut of an icefisher. Hopefully this will see a change in the future updates as it will limit your range to the vicinity of shelters that can be closed properly.
(Oof a blizzard, I'll take cover from it in this hut with a furnace in it and fish... oops, my jacket, hat, shirt, shoes and everything just ripped from the wind wear in this OBVIOUS wind trap causing me to freeze to death despite a burning hot furnace next to me. -_-)


Asthetics - (9/10)The Long Dark has somewhat stylized graphics, giving it a small pseudo-2D impression that plays very well with warm shades in light and cold shades during dusk. A lit fireplace won't light the surroundings as much as an open flame, but it has its own beutiful profile against an otherwise pitch black cabin. A very impressive view unfolds from high-up, overlooking the costal winterland.

Also, even though there's no story mode, the sandbox mode contains quite a bit of lore on its own. Finding a frozen corpse, collapsed against a tree; an abandoned home with a cooked meat still in its oven or a run-down power-station share their own silent bits of story. There are also multiple named locations around the world, not only to make navigation a bit easier but also dwell futher into the lore of the environment you stroll in.


Music - 8/10This game doesn't have an abundance of varying tracks but if one were to categorize them, they should be call mystical. The somber and somewhat distant-ish music serves as a great auditive tool that greatly supports an image of a seemingly unreal frozen world which might just be a dream. The cues inform you about a dawn breaking, a night approaching, a grievous end or perhaps about a dire situation among many other things that can only be found out by exploring this lonely world.

If I close my eyes, when I wake up all the snow will have disappeared and the town'll look like nothing had happened...



As a closing statement, this game can be surprisingly tense and stressful when fighting against all odds to keep you alive. I recommend this game to anyone interested in asthetics, mythical music and eager for a survival story in the now quite lonely cold world. The most successful survivors have lasted over 100 days. Perhaps there might be salvation if you last long enough...

-This review is from up to v.166 early access and covers the sandbox mode of the time. The upcoming story mode and tweaks / additional features to the mechanics aren't.-

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've played The Long Dark for almost 14 hours and I think I can really say that this is the most realistic survival game out there. This game drops you in all alone with little to no knowledge of how to live (unless you read a bunch of guides like me). The not knowing what to do part of the game is what makes this game the most satisfying when you finally get a couple days in. Ok time to stop writing this like a high school paper I'll make this review a simple bullet point guide of the pros and cons of this game.

Pros
- In depth hunger, thirst and cold stats in game
- Beautiful Graphics (Not much of a machine hog either)
- Immersive HUD (meaning almost no HUD except for little indicators for when you're getting cold or hungry)
- Nice and simple inventory system
- Perfect first-aid system
- Time consuming crafting
- Simple hunting system (Skinning and drying)
- Nice weather system
Cons
- Wolf AI still needs work
- Not many crafting options (I can understand why there isnt a lot but a few more would be better)
- Early Access (bugs)

There is not a lot of cons when it comes to this game but I'm sure there is a few minor cons on this game. I recommend this game to anyone who is sick of zombie survival  games and is looking for a nice hardcore in-depth survival game. (I don't write many reviews so some feedback would be nice thanks for reading)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Steam is telling me I've played 426.8 hrs of this game at the time of this review. As you might have guessed, I am very fond of the game. I've held off on writing a review because I just don't think I can do the game justice, but I'll try.

So what do I love about the game to warrant such an embarrassing amount of hours in the game? I'll try to explain:

The graphics. They are beautiful and with the recent upgrade to Unity 5, the graphics became absolutely gorgeous. The beautiful snow-frosted branches of the trees swaying in the breeze; the stark mountains against a beautiful sometimes stormy, sometimes cloudy, and sometimes sunny skyline; The beautiful, but scary nighttime with the aurora borealis, moon, and stars smattering the sky; the bright green, glowing eyes of the wolves...er wait...more scary than beautiful those critters are. :)

The sound. The voice actors are Mark Meer and Jennifer Hale at the time of this review. Veterans of the industry, with titles such as Mass Effect under their belts. The beautiful stinger music that signals a change in weather or time of day. The haunting, creepy music when you discover a corpse inside a house sometimes. The music is not overdone, perfectly placed, so you don't lose that feeling of abandonment. The sound effects, the creaking and groaning of the trees, the wind, footsteps crunching in the snow, the lonely hoot of an owl, the ringing in your ears when you shoot the rifle indoors, the skin-crawling sighing and muttering when in the creepier" locations
hoursPlayed: and barking of the wolves. The sounds and music in the game are one of my most favorite aspects of the game and it's hard to list them all or describe the feelings of immersion you experience. You must experience them first-hand to truly "get it".\n\nThe game mechanics. You have to be careful
voteText: you have to be smart
helpfulPercent: you have to be patient or you die. I love this
votesHelpful: it's the player in full control
votesTotal: how long you survive is based on the decisions you make. Plan ahead
votesFunny: learn from past mistakes. Unlike most video games I don't mind dying in this game. I don't feel cheated because I learn what NOT to do or how I can do it better. The saying "you make your own destiny" seems applicable to the gameplay. It's a sandbox
commentsCount: there's no linear path you are forced to follow
column16: you can immerse yourself fully and explore to your heart's content. There are three modes of play: easy
column17: medium
column18:
difficult. A fit for everyone- from peaceful exploration to death around every corner.

The developers. The developers have always been very involved in the community on Steam and also on their own Hinterland forum and Reddit. They are AAA title veterans who know what they are doing. The updates to the game are frequent and fun. Hotfixes practically same day. They have a zero tolerance for bugs in their game and it shows in this quality product. It's hard to believe it's an Early Access title. I haven't found a more polished one.

The best part? It's like a free gift everytime there is an update. More fun stuff to check out for free! Another "best part"...the sandbox will remain available even when story mode is released for the people who enjoy it. I'm looking forward to the story mode

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is going to be a long review.

I am by no means a survivalist extrordinaire. I wouldn't last 5 hours in Minecraft. But this game makes you feel like you can survive anything... until you run out of matches.

For example, here is how I last died.
I ran into the Trapper's Homestead, sprinting to get out of the freezing cold wind. I was looking for food; peaches, candy, anything I could get in my belly. I looked through the locker, the box under the bed, the first aid kit on the wall, but didn't find anything but an old can opener. Then I looked up, and I swear I heard a heavenly chorus, because sitting on a rack on the wall was something so much more valuble than a granola bar. As I took the old hunting rifle off the wall, I felt a sense of awe come over me. I looked at the nicks and dents and thought of all the stories that they contain, and how many more tales I would write with this pen of steel and wood. After looking around a little more, I decided to try my hand at cracking the safe I found next to the workbench. After several tries I finally got the code down, and lo and behold, inside was a box of 5 rifle shells. By now I was feeling like Rambo. I would not die to this cruel world!
I survived by hunting the game that I saw in the clearing in front of the homestead that I had claimed as my home, and cooking the meat that I carved off their collapsed frames. I lived this way for about a week, until one very important setback to my otherwise flawless plan - I ran out of matches. But I wouldn't let that tiny detail stop me; I am the great VinyGroundhog! I will not succumb to the meager needs of hunger or cold! And thus my journey begain. I searched from house to house for those tiny life-sticks, but each and every one had been picked clean on a previous venture. I realized that there was only one place where I could find what I needed, one place that I had avoided like the plague. I was going to have to tackle the dam.
As I walked into the dam, flare in hand, I looked for Fluffy the Terrible, Killer of Men and Crusher of Souls. I searched through the entire dam for this beast of legend, but nowhere was she to be found. Not able to contain my exitement, I set about looting the dam with a newfound vigor. I looked in the main room. No matches. I looked in the closet. No matches. I looked in the control room. Still, no matches. Soon I reached the conlusion that I was going to have to go downstairs. I walked down the first set of stairs, and as I rounded the corner, there was a nightmare standing in front of me. I stared at Fluffy, and she at me. We stood at a sort of stalemate for around thirty seconds. And then I ran like a coward. I made it up the stairs and Almost made it out when I was knocked down from behind. As I looked at those menacing jaws that I had fallen to so many times before, I knew that I was nearing my end. We struggled for what  seemed an eternity, and then I finally kicked the evil beast off of me, turning and sprinting through the door as fast as I could. By now it was night, and probably had been for a while. I struggled away from that horrible place, blood dripping down into the snow beneath. I looked around in my pack, and found nothing to treat my wounds. I walked along the train tracks, freezing, starving, dehydrated, and bleeding to death. I looked around and saw that I wasn't going to make it. But I refused. I would not die on the terms of a wolf, no matter that it sent me here. And then I thought of a way that I could stand up to the tyranny of the wolf.
I sprinted to the logging area, and then I found the hill I was looking for. I started up the hill, made it a few yards, and subsequently fell off the hill and sprained my ankle. But I wouldn't let that stop me. I started back up the hill, limping this time, and made it farther, and farther, and farther without falling. And as I hobbled up the last few yards of the hill, freezing, starving, dehydrated, limping, and tired as anything, I saw the sun start to rise. I walked over to the edge of the hill, my vision rolling with every step, and sat down, leaning against a rock. And as my life reached its dusk, the world around me reached its dawn.

That is what this game does to you. It puts you on a high, which lasts a not inconsiderable time, and then it takes away one thing, and you begin this slow descent into your death. And that's why I love it. It's an Emotional rollercoaster. Everything that happens in the game impacts not only your in-game effigy, but you, as a living, breathing human being. However, there are a few things that I wouldn't mind changing...

Hinterland, If you're reading this, Please take note.

The game world is easily the loneliest one I have every encountered. It even beats pre-NPC Minecraft. Please fix this. Give me a dog, or better yet, multiplayer! What I wouldn't give to either help or hinder other players in the fight for survival.

Birds. Everytime I see a bird in the game, all I can think about is the potential meat on those hollow bones. Just give me a way to hunt them, or trap them. a shotgun would be nice.

All things considered, this is a very good buy. It's probably my favorite PC game right now. 10/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Words can't describe how much i love this game. So i'll just give you the lowdown of my favorite playthrough (Of dozens of great ones)

Day 1:
Plane crashed somewhere in the woods near a frozen pond and a hunting blind. I found (much to my joy) two granola bars and a bottle of water. Walking through the cold, i picked up a few sticks and some lichen just in case i needed to start a fire. After about 5 minutes of walking i found an old logging camp with three trailer houses. I scavenged a promising amount of food, got some matches, and even found an out ski jacket to wear over my sweater. Exhausted, i spent the night.

Day 2:
I wake up rested and thirsty as hell. I pop open a soda and head out. It's early morning and freezing, but i need to find a suitable place to bunker down, and those little trailers werent it. Following the snow covered trail through the woods, i pass a forest overpass. It's a long hike up in freezing weather and deep snow so i decide against, moving further down the trail. Right as i start to wonder if i had made the wrong choice, i hit a small frozen lake full of Ice-fishing huts. I dot through them and find a good set of stuff before i decide to bunker down in one for a little rest. After a few failed attempts i get the fire in the furnace going. I hear the wind picking up outside, but thinking nothing of it. I lay out my bedroll by the fire for a few hours sleep.
I wake up to what i was sure to be my death.
That light pickup of wind was a precursor to a blizzard. A bad one. The little hut was shaking and creaking in the storm, the opening (there was no door) let in frigid air and snow, putting out my fire and freezing me to the core. I gather my things in a panic. The storm is so fierce it's picking up snow that had settled on the ground, whiting out everything. I culdn't see five feet in front of me. Knowing staying in the hut would be my end, i blindly push into the storm, assumingly towards some camping lodges i saw when i first arrived. The wind cut straight through my clothes and the snow soaked my jeans, shoes and socks. My body trembled uncontrollably as heat was quite literally ripped from my body. After a few minutes the ice of the lake gave way to snow and i was sure i was close to salvation. I keep walking forward, waiting to see a beautiful log cabin any second.
Then i walk straight into a rock wall.
Panicking and wondering how the hell i got so turned around, i follow the wall, hoping beyond hope to find something to keep me safe until the blizzard gave way. I wasn't going to die yet, not here. I willed myself on, even when i felt so tired from the powerful wind i was ready to just drop. Eventually the rock wall gaveway to a some kind of house. Nearly collasping from relief, i get inside and fall asleep immediately, no energy left for anything else.

Day 3:
Apparentely this used to be a park ranger station. It was obviously abandoned in haste, as plenty of things were still left over. The blizzard is still raging, but im safe inside, with a decent supply to last me a few days. I cut up some furniture for wood with the hatchet i found in the closet and get the fireplace roaring. A get some snow quickly from outside and boil it for water, then i eat a hardy meal of beef jerky and a candy bar. I stay up a bit to assess my gear. Somehow i don't have hypothermia, but my pants looks a little worse for wear. I pathc them up with cloth then call it a day, i'm still exhausted from yesterday.

Days 5:
I'm stuck in the ranger hut for another full day. Finally, on Day 5 since my crash, the storm lets up to beautiful weather. I pack my things and head out, the Ranger station now depleted of useful things for me. I crunch along fresh now and a warm sun for a while, reminded of why i used to love skiing in New Mexico. After a while i find train tracks and few wrecked cars. It must of been carrying aid to somwhere becuase scattered amongst the snow i found antiseptic bottles, bandages, a bottle of painkillers and 3 flares. I rest for a bit and have a snack and a sip fo water, and move on. A little past 12ish i find what looks like an old hydrodam. Knowing there could be emergancy supplies and food inside, i make a beeline towards it and walk in, shutting the old iron door behind me.
The place is pitch black. I have to light one of my flares just to see. I look around for a bit, find a prybar and some other useful items including some workers old scarf (My new scarf now), and decide i'm going to spend the night here.
Wrong decision.
As i preparing to set my bedroll down i hear a growl behind. Spinning around, the light from my flare provides me a eerie and terrifying look down the nearby hallway, where a wolf is looking right back at me, growling dangerously. Slowly, i begin to back out towards the door, and he charges me. I panic and throw the flare at him, which seems to scare him long enough for me to fly out the door and across the snow as fast as my damn legs could carry me. I run into the train tunnel and slow to a walk, trying to catch my breath, thank god the weather was still nice. I come out the other end just as the sun begins to set, and find myself in a massive ravine.
After some hopping and skipping and a scary balancing act on a tree that feel across a 50 foot drop, i find a sheltered area behind a old train car and set up camp. I start a fire and give it enough wood to last the night. As i eat dinner i watch the sun set over the horizon. The light reflecting on far distant snow creates a beautiful allusion of fire, as if the horizon around me was burning briliantly. When it sets i am treated to freezing tempertures and a starry sky. I crawl into my bedroll and shut my eyes, hoping to god the weather treats me well.

Day 6:
I was lucky, i woke up to a light snow and nothing else. Hardly any wind. No wolves dragged me away last night so that was also a positive. Thanking my lucky stars i pack up and begin my journey west, to the coast. From there i planto keep heading down south to warmer weather. After traversing a particuarly large and rickety wooden train bridge (And almost falling to my death twice) i go through another tunnel and break out into the coastline.
It was a beautiful sight. The sun glowing over all that sea ice. I would have watched forever if i wasnt freezing. Crawling down the mountain, i find another small trailer house (For the train unloading crew, i presume) and rest there. It felt nice to be inside again after almost 2 days in the wilderness.

Day 7:
One week after my crash. Woo... Anyway, i woke up to howling this morning. More wolves. I headed further down the hill, another flare at the ready (I didnt even bother wielding an Axe, im not a swordsman). Sure enough, i run into one near the highway. It circles me before charging. I throw the flare at it and it runs away. Relieved, i walk over to pick up the flare when suddenly another wolf turns the corner, running after me full speed. I turned and ran like hell towards a cabin down the road. But right before i got to the door he grabbed my leg and i tried. In moments he was on top of me, ripping at the arm i threw up to defend my body. I hit him over and over until he finally let go, running away and barking angrily. Bleeding and hurt, i crawled into the cabin to treat my wounds, sure this was the end. I treated my wounds with antiseptic, bandged them up and took some painkillers. Then i slept.

I survived, and made my way to a cabin on a small island across the frozen bay. On my way, a white out struck. I couldn't see anything yet again. Walking slowly in hopes of not opening my wounds again. I pressed forward. Little did i know i had long past walked by the island, and was on thin ice.
As the whiteout cleared, I looked up. It was as if every star in the universe was looking down at me. Somewhere in my mind, as the cold enveloped me, i wondered if anyone was out there...
Then I fell through the ice.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Day 1: Looked around and saw a hydro dam. Decided to go in, got jumped by a wolf.

Day 2: Ran out of food, found a deer carcass with sizeable amount of meat left. Got jumped by a wolf after harvesting.

Day 3: After bit of exploring, arrived on a camp office with proper beds and some decent items. Got jumped by a wolf on the way

Day 4: Set out to look for some supplies in the cabins by the lake. Got jumped by a wolf, no bandages...*fades into The Long Dark*

Best wolf attack simulator. 10/10 would get jumped by a wolf again.

Other than the frequent wolf attacks which aren't that hard to fend off, I daresay this is one of the best survival games out there. No zombies, monsters or cannibals, just you against the nature. Hinterlands did a great job on this patch. Can't wait for this to be full release

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The Long Dark. It can and will catch you unawares, even if you consider yourself one of the most prepared.

It was on my 79th day that things started to go horribly wrong. I wandered off from the gas station I had for the past 40 days considered safe haven. I had a gallon of water, a rifle with plenty of ammo, and enough food to last me a night should I get stranded. It wasn't enough.

I always thought it would be the wolves that would get me. They had been traveling in packs of 2-3 lately; if all of them came at me, surely I would take down one, maybe two, but I knew if a pack came at me I would be wolf bait. I was wrong. As I wandered up the coast, it started to get cold, as night drew closer. I heard an eerie baying close by - a wolf. I prepared myself, searching in all directions. It came charging, snarling and snapping its jaws. I took it down, but then I heard more growling - its pack. I knew standing my ground was a death sentence, so I ran, and I ran. To my luck, I came across a sea side cottage, to which I quickly escaped the snapping jaws of death in its enclosure.

I thought to myself I'll just stay the night here

reviewText:
Early Access Review

When it comes to a sense of place, and of being, I don't think I've been as fully immersed in a game as I have in The Long Dark. Here's how it works...

You wake up in the snow after your plane has gone down. WIth no idea as to where you are, cold, shivering, you need to find shelter fast and keep a sharp eye out for predators. Once you've found a cabin or such, you need to start thinking about the basics of survival. Water. A warm place to rest. Food. Clothing that can survive the harsh blizzards. A weapon to fend off wolf attacks. To gain the answer to these problems you must explore. At first you'll find yourself raiding abandoned cars and houses, trying not to think about the dead bodies scattered here and there following an as yet undetailed catastrophe. But the cans of pop and candy bars and such you scavange are only a temporary answer. Soon you'll have to look to be self-sufficient.

Survive the first few nights and odds are you can survive a couple of weeks. Survive those two weeks and you might survive a month. Survive that and... who knows? The genius of the game is that it perfectly balances risk, need, fear and greed. You can get carried away and suddenly discover that you've neglected something vital - something life endangering. Forget to stay stocked with fuel and you could perish from being marooned in a cave by a blizzard. Fail to carry bandages with you and you might bleed out from a wolf bite on the snowy wastes. Dehydration especially is a danger. (And no, like in real life simply eating snow will not save you.)

It can be a punishing game at first. Nothing is explained. I didn't know how to make tinder plugs or melt snow in my first game and quickly died after I ran out of my last can of fizzy goodness. But I made darn sure I figured it out the next game. The more you play, the more you find yourself thinking logically and weighing up the risks. Which is all well and good until you become obsessed about getting a bearskin bedroll and end up dooming yourself to be a chewy snack for DiCaprio's growly chum. Happily there's an excellent forum at the Hinterland website, which is very friendly. I strongly recommend it if you have trouble sussing out the game mechanics.

Lastly I want to talk about what makes this game truly special. It's the marriage of beautifully crafted graphics with to my mind the best sound design since Battlefield: Bad Company 2's War Tapes. At first glance the graphics appear simplistic. But you quickly come to appreciate them as being truly evocative, especially in terms of weather. Seeing the deep tread of your footprints as you hear the muffled scrumpf of snow underfoot. Watching a sunrise from the porch of your farmhouse in the morning; a hot cup of coffee a personal treat to celebrate narrowly surviving a blizzard the previous day, as you finally recognised the tell-tale signs of an oncoming storm. Looking up to see the high altitude trade winds carrying aloft the first wave of a fresh snow. And the chilly haunting fog that closes in as you return home in the late evening, a brace of coneys over your shoulder. Even simple things like waking up in the cabin and hearing the walls creak and the windows rattle as the wind blows outside... man, this game is the most atmospheric I've ever played.

So sure it's tough. And yes, wolves are unnaturally terrifying. But as soon as you come to terms with your inevitable death. As soon as you begin to treat it not as a game but as a real question of survival for yourself. And as soon as you learn to let go of trying to max everything out and just enjoy... existing... in this wonderful world HInterland have crafted. Well, then you'll find you've made something really special. Plus you can keep a journal in game!

Any gripes? Each map could do with a forge, and whetstones really shouldn't break after a couple of dozen uses. (I know, game mechanic, but it's unnecessarily cruel.) Also rifles should have a longer effective range and arrows should be more available. Some items, like the maple needed to make a bow, seem unnecessarily rare and tricky to find.) And there should be a little starter guide with a few early-game lifesaving tips bundled with the game in the main menu. And I wish my character would quit complaining all the time about being hungry! It's good to be ravenous and make supplies last!

Despite these niggles the game as it stands at this point in Early Access really is something quite magnificent. It is a transporting game that will have you feeling terrified at times, proud at others and most of all have you feeling that the little farmhouse in the valley has become a place of your own, a place that you can call home in a hostile world. With a story mode to come this game only looks set to become better, but for now I feel that I've definitely got my money's worth on the entrance fee. Congratulations HInterlands for recognising that surviving the natural world can be more thrilling than surviving yet another rehashed zombie invasion, and that the simple joy of felling a deer and filling one's pantry with venison as significant a victory as saving the planet in a shoot-em-up from the evil Emperors RaxinFraxin and Dixdastardlax.

9/10

P.S: You can find answers to many of those early game vexing questions here: http://hinterlandgames.com/join-the-community/

Early Access Review

It's as good as I expected, and promises more, even with no story mode (still Early Access.)

I loved it from the first moments, and I indeed died quickly from Wolf attacks until I learned to avoid them.

I love the artwork, I love the sound design.  After playing as MacKenzie a few times I switched to the female character and I was surprised how much better I liked the female voice acting.

I've died from wolves of course.  From infection.  Falling through the ice.  From dehydration.  I waited until I survived 5 days in the sandbox before I wrote the review.  Very glad to have picked this up, and looking for more in future updates.  One of the better Early Access titles along with Prison Architect.

Update 2014-11-10:  I killed two wolves today, one with a .303 round (Canadians love that Lee-Enfeld) and one with a hunting knife.  This yielded 10kg of meat, which I cooked over an outdoor fire in a train tunnel to get out of the wind.  I'm trying to get moving from Coastal Highway where I started over to Mystery Lake.

I'd like to add a technical comment.  The game loads quickly.  It is responsive.  I haven't seen many bugs, except one time on the western island of Coastal Highway I found a spot while climbing the hill from the west where I couldn't seem to wiggle out.

Alas, I died on the 45th day.

After growing more desperate due to my dwindling supplies I decided going out in the wild to check my rabbit snares at low health. I spotted a wolf eating my trapped rabbits, So I attempted to scare it off with a road flare (bit of a gamble). Instead it attacked me and although I was able to fight it off I was In poor shape and bleeding out. Rummaging through my pack, I realized I had no bandages with me (idiot). Ok, create bandage from a scrap piece of cloth ... no cloth in the bag. Tear off my hat and rip it to shreds, then create a bandage. Bleeding is stopped, My vision is hazy from the loss of blood, and I realize to my horror that I am freezing (wind has picked up and the wind chill temperature is well below -30 C). I struggle uphill towards my camp in the wind, but there is no use. I die alone in the woods, my body ravaged by hunger, cold, and countless wounds.

Best game I've played in a long time.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Rummaging through garbage is a long and storied tradition in video games. Players have been raiding shelves and garbage cans for decades now, and it's hard to argue the popularity of Elder Scrolls and Fallout games is not thanks in part to the immense amount of junk you can scavenge. The Long Dark feels like an entire game built around looting, giving your lizard brain tingles every time your progress bar is interrupted by a new item. That's selling the game short, and I'll fix that, but when you're on a somber trek through a featureless snowfield, aching for a dresser to upturn, you'll remember I said that.

The Long Dark strands you in the northern wilderness of Canada in the wake of a mysterious geomagnetic event. All the people are dead, all the animals are acting weird, and all the electricity is out. You have four bars to manage if you want to survive: Temperature, fatigue, hunger, and thirst. Scrounging up leftovers and boiling snow will cover the latter two, sleeping in beds and not running everywhere will keep your fatigue down, but traversing the wilderness will freeze you fast, making warmth your most sought-after resource. The game offers a pretty robust survival sim, with many interactions between objects. You can break things down for materials to repair other things, craft tools like bows and fishing lines, and cook and store food. Just making a fire is its own skill, involving starters and fuels and accelerants and chances to fail based on all that and where you're making the attempt. A clean and slick menu interface keeps you from staring at lists too long to accomplish all this, which is some very welcome design.

A big part of the game (at least early on) is indeed finding houses to loot and clicking on all the containers, while being mindful of how much you can carry. In between looting sprees, however, are journeys across the frozen wilds. The Long Dark does not screw around here, as getting lost in the woods or running into some unpleasant wildlife can very quickly be the end of you. You need plenty of daylight for exploring, and if you're lacking warm clothes you really cannot stay out very long. When one of your resource bars, such as temperature, bottoms out, it starts a percentage countdown. When that hits zero, you die. Just being outside on a windy day for an hour or two can take your bar to zero, so you have to plan all your actions carefully. Intensive activities like chopping wood or fishing are abstracted to take up to an hour unto themselves, too. The constant threat makes the game an intense survival simulator, but the barren wastes between shelters that facilitates this design can get kind of boring to traverse.

There are three difficulties to play on, depending on how eager you are to have wolves snap your appendages in half. You can also start in different areas once you find the paths to them from the starter zone, which can change your experience dramatically. The maps are not randomly generated, so having a few hours of exploration under your belt will most definitely help you survive longer. It seems that the game is designed around scavenging and getting your bearings for the first few days, and then transitioning to hunting and foraging for food and wood in true mountain man style to survive further. It's a long road to get there, though, with a lot of traipsing across snowfields and forest paths, but the painted art style and minimalist soundtrack make the solitude meaningful, and give the game a somber, melancholy feel. If you have the patience for planning long, deadly walks through the wastes, this is a solid survival choice.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First time I played this game, I sprained my ankle running away from a Wolf. I got lost, it got dark and cold and I started to freeze to death. With no light source, I saw the silhouette of a cabin and ran straight for it, avoiding all the glowing eyes of lurking Wolves pursuing me. Inside, I fumbled around with a packet of matches, dimly lighting my path as I crawled to the nearest bed and collapsed from fatigue.

Ten hours later I woke up, drank some soda and chomped on a few energy bars before heading outside to a clear, sunny day and continued my journey. I can't think of any other game where that set of events could ever possibly unfold. And if this is what's on offer in early access, I can't wait to see what they come up with in the final release.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Mrs. Tamigochi had survived 14 days without trousers...

But - after surviving countless wolves and even a bear attack, that left her 2% from death -  upon entering pleasant valley she found herself exposed, at night, in a blizzard.

With nowhere to shelter, the temperature fell to -40 degrees, the fire blew out, and she was forced to press on or freeze to death.
In a desperate panic, she forgot her bedroll and, when the storm lamp ran out of gas, fell blindly over the edge of Heartbreak Bridge, twisting her ankle with a sickening snap.

Suffering from hypothermia, using the torn pages of a book found in a car, a few sticks and lighter fluid, she managed built a fire that lasted long enough to burn the coal she brought out of the caves. Fate was smiling, as the light from the fire illuminated a fallen branch, that provided fuel enough to kept her warm until the sun started to rise.

When the blizzard cleared, she laughed with overwhelming joy at the sight of a red building 200m across the field. At 30% condition, exhausted, she slowly dragged herself to the barn.

The laughter soon turned to cursing, as a black bear appeared over a nearby ridge. She dropped all but her essential kit, swallowed the last few painkillers and sprinted for the door, the bear's footsteps thudding behind her.

Here she was able to sleep in an abandoned pick-up, waking occasionally to chew cat-tail stalks and drink soda.

24 hours of nursing later, she is fit to face the outside world once more - Eating the last of the dog food she found inside a tool chest, drinking dirty water, she resolves herself to find a new pair of trousers.

-----

Just as I thought this game was starting to get boring - Mystery Lake isn't very big - I found a door I'd not used before. Now there is 3-4x the game world, much more challenge and a reason to keep going on. The game doesn't want to let me go.
Mrs. Tamigochi hasn't had such badass survival stories since Project Zomboid - this game is as good as PZ.
I've not felt that I've overcome a certain death situation in a game since... Ages...

I got it on sale, £8, after an email about wishlist sales. It is great. I am loving every minute.

Not read a single guide. Posted a few times in the forums about glitch and tech stuff only.

I'd advise NOT reading anything about the gameplay, watching any videos or looking at wikis or whatever - it would destroy the experience...
Still don't know what rosehips are for (not for making tea, it seems). Took two lives dying of thirst to figure out how to melt snow. Can't use moss as tinder... Some pathfinding exploits are possible with wolves and bears... The trousers just broke for no reason when I was looking at them, 50% to 0% with a tearing sound... Haven't found any since...

There are lots of survival games, most with zombies. I've played a lot of them - This one beats them all, I reckon. I hope it lasts as long as (Arma2) DayZ or Project Zomboid, because I still like to fire them up now.

I love, love, love Fallout, but... I'm playing this instead of Fallout 4 right now.

Really nice game - surprisingly immersive and totally absorbing. Hope it gets some kind of headtracker support, and not just oculus rift (who can afford that?).

The most fun I've had without pants since last time my gf stayed over.
(she loves it too).

I will consider changing this to a positive review in time but there are just things I have isssues with. Not everyone does but if you are like me then you may appreciate this reveiw. I have enjoyed my short time playing it and realize the game is alpha. Maybe this will help guide your decision. Reviewed on 12/23/15

Cons:

Its not a real sandbox. Just linear maps with fixed looting spots. You have the border around the map keeping you penned in other than the areas where you transition to the next map. The maps are small IMO.

The crafting is very limited. Stand next to a work bench and you can make only a handful of items and clothing.

There is no building, no making shelters and no tents etc other than fixed cabins and loot spots that you will quickly memorize on the map.

Your goal in game is twofold: At first you will be scavenging all the loot spots for food and items like matches, weapons and tools. There aren't many different items in the game so you are basically looting the same stuff over and over. After you have exhausted your looted resources you should be at a point where you can hunt deer for food using a crafted or looted bow and arrow. That is the second part of the game.

There are no surprises, no rare loot (unless you count the prepper cache that is hidden in every map), no real goal other than to eat, drink, sleep and stay warm. That's it. Period.

Surviving" isn't very logical with some things: You stay warm based on clothing stats
date: so if you have a really nice coat you can go outside with no pants or shoes and still stay warm. You can be full from drinking water and sleep for 8 hours then wake up literally dying of thirst. If you have an inury just bandage it or swallow pain pills and it's instantly healed with no lingering negative effects. An example is I jumped off a 3 foot ledge landed in snow and sprang both ankles. Popped pain pills and instantly cured.\n\nYour very basic gear like bedroll

They eventually die from the fight but far away and you usually cant track them because you are half dead as well. Just once in a while it would be nice if I could stab the wolf to death with my knife. Just once comon.

Everything decays and ridiculously fast. Pick up a box of matches and good luck if they last a couple of months before rotting. Canned food does the same. EVERYTHING you inspect by clicking on it even if you dont pick it up begins to rot. It's dumb really. Guides will tell you not to even inspect the item if you dont need it right away so it doesnt rot before you need it. If I was really surviving I would go out and gather every tool and food item I could find and bring it back to my shelter but the decay in the game makes this impractical.

There's no long term survival. Kill a bear and have tons of meat but no way to preserve it. No salting

Permadeath...

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I bought this game over a year ago, and I've seen it grow and change. It's gameplay mechanics have been altered completely, completely new areas have been added, and I see bug fixes almost instantly. The one thing that hasn't changed, however, is the fear it evokes. The devs completely nailed atmosphere. The music is eerie, the sound of your footsteps crunching on the snow urges you forward, and when it's pitch black and you wake up to a lone wolve's howl, well, it forces chills down your spine. You either press on, or you die. Fire is your best friend. Your attentiveness to the noises around you may save your life. The art leaves you looking forward to the sunrise the next morning, or paranoid as shadows dance over every shape around you.

The gameplay is solid. The hud is minimal. The little details truly make it an immersive game. The voice acting when your character is over-encumbered or thirsty, the descriptions of all the items you pick up, and the first-aid system are all lovely examples.

The Long Dark is personable. It's uniqueness in atmosphere and gameplay leaves you utterly alone and terrified and willing to fight. This is the most immersive survival game I have ever had the pleasure of playing, and I eagerly await story mode.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

When people hear survival game, they usually think something like DayZ, H1Z1, Rust, and -- for whatever reason -- Minecraft. I like to think The Long Dark is the only survival game that does it right. Games like Rust have elements of hunger and thirst, but are also multiplayer games where stuff like that is hard to balance without it being unfair; they become afterthoughts and the real focus of the game becomes the interaction with other players (which, more often than not, just end up in being griefed and losing everything you may have worked for).

The Long Dark is lonely, not because its a singleplayer game, but because of the environment it sets you in. The canadian wilderness, freezing and full of snow, is probably not the most ideal place to be if you aren't smart enough to survive. Within the first ten minutes of playing, your goal should be to find shelter to shield yourself from the cold and scavenge for provisions. Warmth is essential in this game, just like hunger, thirst, and sleep is. Achieving a delicate balance is hard because you are always going to be needing something so you don't end up catching hypothermia, or dying of thirst and hunger.

Those aren't the only threats in the game, however. If you play on the normal difficulty, you'll have a nice grace period before things like wolves and bears start spawning and making it much harder for you to traverse the wilderness. The hardest difficulty has these things up and running right off the bat. Wolves are especially dangerous, because they are more than willing to chase you down to the ends of the earth unless they lose sight of you mid chase. Things like decoys help to distract them but you end up losing food as a result; rifles can also be used to take them out from a distance, but you end up wasting ammuniton which is a precious commodity.

There are small details in this game that show you just how well they crafted this. Things like how the items you carry make different sounds, the way you can interact with your environment like harvesting shelves and tables for wood, and how the more tired you get, the less you can carry until you are well rested. These small things make such a big impact on how you play the game at times.

For whatever price they are asking, The Long Dark is absolutely worth every cent. There is a lot of replayability with the different environments you can play in, and there will be more to do with every update and when story mode finally hits. If you love survival games, or perhaps this is the first time you are going to try one, its essential you pick up The Long Dark.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The Long Dark
The Survival Genre keeps growing on Steam and it has become a difficult decision to put our trust in a game, even worse if it's still being developed after years without knowing a release date. Perhaps we find a dedicated team who is working non-stop on their project, but then we ask ourselves, what do they offer us unlike the other hundred titles?

The Long Dark captivated me since the first time I saw it. The art style looked unique in the genre, and Early Access was going well, so I decided to give it a try.

The game starts with us selecting the mode we want to play (Sandbox is the only one currently available) and then we customize it by choosing the difficulty between: Pilgrim (Easy, meant for exploring and learning the basics), Voyageur (Medium, for intermediate players) and Stalker (Hard, for those who are well known of the game mecanics). Then we get to choose the Region, each one offers a different experience basing on the safe places and resources we can find. After we finished selecting all the options, the game starts.

We are alone without any idea where we might be, there's no map and we only have a few resources in our inventory. We start feeling cold as we walk trough the snow looking for a shelter... and then we wonder if anybody else survived from the plane accident.

In The Long Dark we need to take care of four main needs: Hunger, Thirst, Sleep and our body Temperature. But here's a new addition to the formula: Calories. These are bound to our needs and it will be constantly changing. We regain them by eating and lose them by sleeping, just like real life. They also decrease faster if we are out in the cold, and every action that we perform will cost us calories, such as running or destroying a furniture to obtain wood.
But that's not all, there is also a  tab where we can check the current temperature and how it affects us, the percentage of Windchill, and bonus we get against cold depending on the clothes that we are wearing, among others. And then we have the Condition/Affliction tabs, and they will change if we get hurt or ill, from food poisoning or hyphotermia to name a few.

In terms of Gameplay, there's always a sense of vulnerability when we are out in the open, and not just from the weather. Wildlife is a very important aspect in The Long Dark and it affects both Combat and Crafting. Pack of Wolves and Bears are going to haunt us if they get to see us. If we were lucky enough to find a rifle or a bow and we succesfully defend ourselves, the player gets food and fur, which can be crafted in clothes or even a bedroll.
Also, the animals can interact with themselves and the player can use this in his own advantage. Wolves get terrified when there's a bear nearby, for example.

There is a lot more to know about the Combat and the gameplay itself, but I'm not going to spoil the experience. I want to talk about what  The Long Dark creates around the player. The atmosphere is the best part of the game and something that shouldn't be left behind but get improved in Early Access. Both characters have their own voice with a decent voice acting and they often make a comment while they are performing and action or are in need of something.
But what really shines about The Long Dark it's the Sound and the details.
The game also has Music but it only appears in certain moments (And it does it very well). At first I didn't like this decision, but it really helps creating the atmosphere. Also, the sound of our surroundings is really important in the game.

Finding a place to spend the night and hearing the wind crashing against the windows, starving in the middle of nowhere, hearing Wolves nearby when a few hours ago we fell from a cliff and we still couldn't get patched up, or lighting a Storm Lantern that shows to us a corpse in the ground. This is what the game is all about, our personal experiences with it and the constant feel of desolation and loneliness.

The Long Dark also provides the player with a tab that includes all Stats per day. How long we managed to survived, the locations we came across, the calories we burned and the percentage of how much we have explored. It also has a Notes section, and the player is allowed to write anything in it. It's a great detail for keeping track of details and locations we want to explore next, or just for writing our every day story.

What are the plans for the future?
The Story Mode will be launched in Spring, and it's going to offer around 3 to 4 hours of Storyline. The remaining episodes will be released over the course of 2016. We will get to play as the bush pilot Will Mackenzie, and Dr. Astrid Greenwood, alternating between them and experiencing the story from their own perspectives. This content is going to be free for Kickstarter backers and players who supported the game during Early Access. You can watch the official teaser of the Story Mode here: http://store.steampowered.comhttps://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XzxD7VFVrCw

The game really surprised me, and it's a great choice if you are looking for an alternative in the Survival Genre. How long will you survive in The Long Dark?`

Make sure to follow our Curator Group for more reviews:
Original Curators Group

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The Long Dark, so far, is an amazing survival game. Survival games have been all about zombies or similar creatures, never the pure realistic struggle against nature. That's where The Long Dark comes in. It's not a friendly game despite it's soft art style, you will starve to death, freeze to death or die to exhaustion (not to mention wolves). It uses this kind of cell shading graphics yet it impresses for how much it feels real. The sense of clinging to life is always present when you constantly find new places, train tracks, trailers, a dam, makes you hold on to hope, for a better day tomorrow. There's a lot of potential.

+ Fresh new take on survival games
+ The constant need to keep on your toes
+ Beautiful art style
+ This is just sandbox Early Access, story mode should hopefully be great

- The game can really be unforgivable so expect frustration (I fell on a ravine and got a sprained ankle, I had to walk for hours before finding painkillers to fix it)
- The game needs to be balanced, for example you need to eat way too often

Feel free to check my experience with it:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=i5NXGw06yAM&list=PLBqXrq67D6ooXz_cmVAtDPop4WZ49sGZX

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The craftsmanship of this game is good.  However, the design deserves some discussion: This is not a survival game, but an adventure game with a survival theme, and the design reflects that.

These are just a few things that occurred to me while playing, from the perspective of a survivalist.  Some of these are due to the early development of the game, whereas others are design decisions which reflect the minds of the author.

* Tools degrade in a matter of days; in the real world, they degrade over years or decades.
* Tools, such as knives, can be repaired with wood and scrap metal; actually, you can make a new knife that way, but you cannot repair it in such a manner.
* You cannot make knives or axes with wood and scrap metal.

* Weather can destroy a large sailor’s coat; in the real world, even a hurricane is unlikely to do so.
* The sleeping bag acts like a bivy, but looks like a sleeping bag.  A sleeping bag, outdoors in this weather, would freeze through with body moisture in short order unless put inside a shelter or by a fire, whereas a bivy would be safe.  I’m a bit confused.

* Cordage is made only from gut; normally, cordage can be made from a great many things.

* You cannot manipulate the snow to build a windbreak for a fire, or for yourself, or to build a snow-grave, or a quinzee.
* Regardless of wood on hand, one cannot create either a lean-to windbreak shelter or a kennel-shelter.  The method is simply not in the game.
* All of the trees are tall, old, and bare at the lower trunk.  Normally, there are many smaller trees in the area, especially near rocks, and many bushes.
* The wind seems to be as strong in open areas, such as railroad tracks, as it is among many trees.
* I’m not sure why the land is completely smooth; normally, you’re stumbling over rocks and logs, and chunks of burnable wood.

* If you have newspaper, matches, kindling, and logs, you have a thirty percent chance of failing to start a fire.  I've never been that drunk.
* Starting a fire is equally easy when one is warm or cold; normally, when hypothermia sets it, starting a fire becomes extremely challenging due to freezing fingers.  If you wait until frostbite starts to set in before you build a fire, you waited far too long.
* Firewood is shown as cordwood; normally, I use deadfall almost exclusively, and can easily sustain a fire all night with only a half-hour to an hour of gathering.
* There is no fire-tending skill; normally, tending a fire properly makes it last much longer, and allows for coal banking.
* Dead fires do not make fire-lighting easier; in reality, there are usually lingering coals (especially if properly banked) and there is often charcoal to help ignite the next fire.
* A fire cannot be put out to reclaim the wood; I do this often, to generate charcoal and to conserve fuel when I need to move on, and this allows me to leave behind fires ready to light.
* Firewood takes hours to gather; even in snow, this process generally takes minutes.
* A hatchet speeds firewood collection; in reality, this is only marginally helpful, given that most environments have a great deal of deadfall and standing deadwood that can simply be yanked down.  I rarely have to cut firewood; it’s just under the snow, especially under trees.
* It is possible to freeze to death beside a large fire, or even in a closed (but open-doored) fishing hut beside a large wood-stove with a roaring flame.  This is not realistic.

* Dead bodies are shown clothed; there is no way to salvage their clothing.
* There are many beds; there is no way to cannibalize the mattresses for cloth or to remove the sheets, nor can one lay one mattress on top of another and sleep between them for added warmth.
* One cannot stuff one’s clothing with the batting from mattresses.
* One cannot upgrade the insulation of clothing at all, despite this being a staightforward (if somewhat time-consuming) task in reality.
* One cannot wear multiple sweaters or layer multiple pants.  I do this often in cold weather; one loses some mobility, but it works.
* It is possible to fail to sew a piece of cloth.  I love my Jack Daniels, but I’ve never been too drunk to sew.

This is a very good and fun game, but survivalists should not mistake it for a bushcrafting game, and should not try to use a real-world survival mindset to predict the game's behavior.

Still, as video games go, it's fun, well-crafted, finely drawn, engrossing, and well worth playing.  I would recommend this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'm finally at a point to where I feel like I can leave a fair review for this game.

I'll start with the day one scenario. You load into a world based on a few different spawn points. The weather will be random upon loading in, so depending on a little RNG - you might find yourself in a very bad situation. However, this is a good thing, this lets you know very quickly what your goals are in this game. You have to stay alive.

The game doesn't hold your hand for the most part, and you have to be able to think on your feet, and make life and death decisions on a daily basis. You're contending with the weather, hunger, thirst, and your overall health" - which can change based on injury and various other ailments.

The only RNG I have really seen in the game is when it comes to weather

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI'm not into all these survival sandbox games, but this is what I can call a good one actually. It throws you into the wild nature of snow mountains  and all you have to do is survive by eating food, drinking water, staying in warm places and being healthy. It may sound easy, but believe me - it's not. There are a lot of different ways of dying and you never know what will kill you this time, so the game itself makes you feel nervous. The graphics isn't on a high level, but it's pretty stylish and accurate, sometimes it can demonstrate you some really good-looking sights, and its sound is just fine. A unique atmosphere of being alone in the neverending permafrost leaves a nice aftertaste. Will be waiting for the new updates.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nUnique, immersive, atmospheric first person survival simulation The Long Dark is totally living up to my expectations. The tension of trudging through a blizzard while freezing and starving to death has never been so fun! If you are not interested in a fairly punishing experience of scavenging for food and shelter just to survive then this game is not for you. It is not exactly real life but it most certainly is on the simulation end of the spectrum. There are no supernatural or magical elements; they are going for real life so wolves not zombies. The screenshots capture the beauty of the stylized wilderness in TLD and while it does look good in game, realize that this is the Unity engine and not Cryengine so it is very basic and somewhat grainy and ugly at times. The music certainly adds to the experience and I am excited for the story mode which is acted by veteran voice actor Mark Meer and others. My largest disappointment would have to be the lack of different maps or a system for procedurally generated maps. In sandbox the loot and materials you gather to survive are random, however the layout of the map is designed for the story mode and so it is the same every time. This means that once you learn the map it informs gameplay as you know what items can be where, and you lose that sense of exploration. It's not the end of the world but it is a legitimate gripe however it is understandable for a $20 game from new startup studio who was crowd funded through Kickstarter. Perhaps it can be a DLC addition down the road if everything goes well. Despite this there are still many hours of enjoyment within the game, after only a few play sessions I have survived for around 8-9 hours and am looking forward to many more as the game develops.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

My goodness... this game.
After surviving 54 days and counting, I figured I had enough knowledge about the game to write a review.

First off... If you are looking for a survival game that follows all of the cliches (Zombies, Monsters, punching a tree with your bare hands to get wood, Etc..)  You've come to the wrong place. This is a more realistic approach to the survival genre.  This game pulls no punches when it comes to long term survival.  From the second that you are thrusted into this unforgiving enviroment, you simply have to survive on your own.  No tutorials. No microtrasnactions that give you a leg up. Just the clothes on your back and the will to survive. It's quite refreshing actually.

Obviously there are some things that could be implimented to make gamplay a bit more enjoyable.
(Its early access for crying out loud)

- Co-op Multiplayer (even though the devs refused the idea)
- More firearms
- A bigger map
- Survivor NPCs
- More crafting recepies

But with that said... The sandbox mode alone is worth the $20 pricetag. Imagine what future updates will bring.
The devs have already promised a story mode, and the game is updated pretty frequently.

Fantastic game even in early access.
9/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game has given me a new hope for Early access games,I never thought I would say that,but it really does !!
The Long Dark sat in my wishlist for 7 months and if I would've known how much enjoyment it was going to bring me I would've bought it then and saved the hundreds of dollars I spent on games that held my interest for an hour or two and were then deleted and the next new one played and put aside and on and on. . . .

Very intense gameplay and omfg it's so much fun and what a challenge !!

You can play so many different ways too,you can explore and gather everything you can find or you can try and hunt and gather to survive for the long haul,you can be just a hunter and try to live off of the things mother nature offers or you can set up a cushy home base and go out on re-cons to exhaust all the resources of one area and then move to another and on and on. . . .

And thats just the start of it !! Hinterland Studios has kept their word and give us very regular updates and are always expanding the game,adding new areas to explore and new ways to do things and all of that is in EA !!
We're waiting on the next update and hopefully it's going to be the new story mode I've been researching on the Hinterland forums,it promises to be something very special !!

For now,we have around a 22 km of map to explore,survive in and if its your cup of tea(or coffee or soda) to exploit !!
I cannot express enough in this review,how much pleasure this game has brought to me and it does it all without one single monster,zombie,evil warlords or any other catchy little thing most of todays devs are tossing into survivor type games !! It's all mother nature and her critters !!

So,in a nut shell,buy this game if survival is what your into or if your into hunting or exploring,just buy the game,it's a 20 very well spent !!
Thank you Hinterland Studios,for the best game in my library !!!

And my verdict still stands.In survival you do anything and everything you can to survive. Ofcourse a game has limitations so you will be limited as to your options as to how well you can perform, however The Long Dark puts so many on you, its more about surviving the games mechanics and not the evironment the game puts you in. Also many ask why only a few hours in the game. Simple, its just not fun. Heres why:

-Time passes far to quickly. Hinterland claims it doesnt. However go to a sunny area and just watch the shadows. They are moving incredibly fast as the sun is blazing through the sky. Nightfall in an area like this is almost a death sentence especially if there is a storm. There are not enough hours in the day to prepare for the night. Your already set up to fail here.

- No layering of clothing. If i was stranded in the middle of a frozen mountain and found clothing. Id be wearing it. Regardless if its mens or womens, or a Hello Kitty beanie. I would be wearing it. First rule of cold survival is layering. They keep you warm, and as you heat up you can remove them to avoid sweating.You also come across several beds with blankets on them that you cant pick up and wrap around you. Another way the game has set you up to fail.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

One of the most bug-free early access games to come out in a long time. As it stands, the game is well worth the price tag and has many hours worth of fun to be had but you can easily do everything there is to do in the game within a few playthroughs. This game has the potential to be a very amazing and robust survival game. The best part is... NO ZOMBIES! Yes, a survival game that doesnt involve monsters or zombies. I know, crazy right?

With all that said this game has a lot of potential and the devs have been hard at work releasing update after update and its not even been out to the public for a week yet. I highly recommend this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I really like this game as a whole. It's really hard, atmospheric and visually quite beautiful. It's completely unlike most other survival games: you can't build almost anything, you have practically no weapons (unless you, by some freakish accident, happen to find a rifle, which is completely useless if you don't also find bullets) and are therefore pretty much the weakest ♥♥♥♥er on the bottom of the food chain. You're like the rabbits, except slower.

Learning to survive in the game takes a while: the first few times I played I died within 24 hours or so (couldn't find shelter). I started out with the Mystery Lake map, but  I suggest trying Coastal Highway first, because it appears to be more newbie-friendly.

What sort of bugs me are the wolves. Don't get me wrong, I like them because they make the player super paranoid when walking outdoors, which is absolutely great. The problem is that once the wolf is attacking, it will not give up, no matter how long it takes:
I had this one incident when I was on top of the lookout tower in Coastal Hightway, and a wolf down on the ground spotted me. It attacked, but since I was in the tower it couldn't get to me, so it stayed at the bottom of the tower, running around and waiting for me. This went on for a day or two. Finally I went down and managed to beat the ♥♥♥♥face up, but another two took its place almost immediately. After another day or so I tried to escape the tower but was eaten. This isn't technically a big thing, but it can be a major annoyance. I hope it gets fixed.

But, all in all, I wamly recommed this game if you like a bit of challenge and don't get frustrated easily.
