reviewText:
Early Access Review

Alright, the Long Dark. I'm guessing you have some questions for me about it.

Indeed. We want to know how good it is.
Fair enough. Let's get started.

First off: what is it?
It's a first person survival + exploration simulation, with mild walking simulator and horror elements, in which you're stranded in the middle of the Canadian wilderness, struggling to preserve your life in the bitter environment.
Most of the time you find yourself lost, confused, and unsure of where to go.
So pretty much Life Simulator 2014.

How does the gameplay compare to the other profuse survival games nowadays?
Although there are many survival games that could be dubbed similiar to the Long Dark, nothing is truly like it, and most likely, nothing is as good as it either.
One of the main differences is the environment. It's set in an Artic wasteland. Little shelter. Few supplies. Most survival games are either deciduous forest, or zombie based. This fits into neither of those categories.
The weather is brutal, with harsh wind and immense temperature drops at night. You can fall through ice, get attacked by wolves, and fall off cliffs. But if you're smart, you can survive it.

Another thing that I really love about the Long Dark's gameplay is the exploration. Granted, in the most challenging difficulty settings there is little time for exploration, but the beauty of the world is truly captivating, and it's a joy to wander through the treacherous landscape. Ironic, isn't it?
Finally, the last major gameplay element I'll mention is how incredibly realistic this game is. You have to worry about everything. EVERYTHING. Wind. Temperature. Shelter. Hunger. Thirst. Fatigue. Broken bones. Infections. Hostile wildlife. Giant man eating ducks.
Okay the latter poses much less of a threat than the previous ones but I think you understand what I mean.

They have a calorie counter for crying out loud, what else could you want?

How do the graphics stand?
The Long Dark may or may not be a huge troll. And I'll explain why.
The developers set you up against very difficult challenges, inside a cruel and unforgiving world, but they make it so beautiful. It's like they show you how beautiful the sword is, before they chop off your head. Irony, you see.

But, really, the world is gorgeous. You're not blown away by the realism of it (like you are by the gameplay, more irony, you see), but it sure is stunning. I have the sceenshots to prove it.
The lighting is phenomenal, the textures are masterfully constructed, and the landscape is truly a work of art.
I also really like the almost hand-drawn feel of the visuals. Feels kind of rustic.

I also should mention, though it's not visual based, the sound design of the game. Absolutely brilliant.
The sound mixing is astounding. The way that the sounds of the wind and the distant wolf howls and your foot prints on the snow and the opening of your backpack all blend together so fluidly and dynamically really adds to the experience.

One of the biggest complaints about Early Access games is their bugginess. Does the Long Dark glitch much?
Firstly, I don't think that stereotype really is fair. I've played a decent amount of Early Access in a decent amount of games and have not run into very many bugs.
And this needs to be said: I have never run into any glitches or bugs in the Long Dark.
What more needs to be said? It runs stably and has never crashed on me, even on my horrible laptop, and I'm impressed.

Is the Long Dark worth the $20?
I only have 5 hours on this game, and I honestly don't know why. I think I could spend hundreds of hours on this game. It's got so much room for learning and exploring, especially with regular content updates being released so often. I would say yes, it is worth the money. Especially on sale.
But for the full price, I would say it wouldn't hurt for you to know you like survival games, as you may be frustrated by the brutality of it.

Does it have any replay value?
Well, as of yet, it has no campaign. So I can't really review that yet.
But I can say that I am drawn to continue my game after I survive long enough to actually have to save it and quit.
That doesn't happen often.
The game is addicting, despite it's difficulty, and will draw you back in to continue, or more likely, try again.

So after all these questions, what's the verdict: is the Long Dark a good game?
Yes.
It's phenomenal.
There's a reason why it has Overwhelmingly Positive reviews on Steam, it's absolutely fantastic. A fresh breath of air from the numerous, and mostly far less well designed, survival games out there.
The gameplay is unique and innovative, the graphics are artfully designed, the sound mixing is exceptional, it's not that expensive, and, get this, it's not even done.
It's in Early Access. There's a whole new game mode yet to come out.
I would say buy this now, and watch it grow into it's true, colossal potential.
Then you get to be a hipster: I liked it before it was cool!".

Take a break from Call of Duty
date:
and play this masterpiece.
It's worth your time.

~ caleb4est"

!!!!!!! EDITED 2/11/2015 !!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

pros:
deep crafting system (almost perfect, not too overwhelming without lacking much)
amazing atmosphere
great art style
different game modes (easy, medium, hard, basically)
Runs SO smoothly, obviously it is well-optimized
good voice acting
amazing sound quality
one of the best survival games I've played in a while (no zombies or monsters)
amazing weather patterns (visually pleasing)
it's really relaxing to play when you do Pilgrim mode (easy mode)
devs care about the game and as far as I can tell, the userbase
maps are very fun

cons:
wolves are too small (opinion, they seem a little too small to me!)
tweak the lighting JUST a bit when inside
as far as I can tell, only one save slot
as a survival game, it's GREAT; but it feels like it's missing something.

ideas for the game:
-different interiors for houses
-able to use the axe to break down boarded up doors
-generators / electricity (not sure how it'll work but it'd be a pretty cool addition)
-marking (mark trees, the ground, raise flags and build fencing) so you don't get lost from your base (There are footprints, but I guess if you have eye troubles that would be difficult to see)
-a map (it would be good but it would ruin the realistic feel of getting lost in the woods. So maybe a rare drop on a corpse or in a house?)
-more corpses (maybe journals and diaries so you can see a little bit of story behind them)
-more save slots


THIS GAME IS VERY ADDICTING! When you die, you want to try again, and each time you're more knowledgable of what you did wrong and you last longer.

I re-wrote this review on 2/8/2015 and the game is just getting better and better. I look forward to the storymode!

Early Access Review

Great game, looking forward to story mode!
I survived 67 days, then died.
I was starving, injured and freezing to death, stuck out in a blinding storm, out of supplies. I couldn't see where I was going, too windy for fire, health below 20%,  I figured I wasn't going to make it. Wait...A Cave! It has a backpack, finally found some supplies....food YAY!....medicine YAY!....wood and a shelter to start a fire YAY! Perfect timing because my health is now below 5%.
I start the fire to start warming myself, health now at 3%! As I go to eat the food and take the medicine to get through another night, I accidentally step in the fire and died of burning to death.....yay :-/  Didn't see that coming. LOL

Wish I had that one recorded. :P
Time to start again. :)

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI had a strong playthrough once. I made it to around day twenty, having gone through three of the available areas at the time, and I was doing good, but it was not long lived. My resources were dwindling as I made my way to the last supplied area at the top of a mountain, a lone radio station secluded from the rest of the map. It was starting to get dark, and my body temperture was dropping fast, so I lit my lantern and started to run. Out in the darkness I heard a howl, followed by another that seemed much closer. I put away my lantern and took out my rifle, aiming it towards the origin of the noise. I heard a growl about ten feet away, so I fired a shot. A whimper pierced the whirring of the cold winter air around me, then silence. Not taking any chances, I lit a flare to see what was around me. Five feet in front of me was a pair of wolves, one was bleeding profusely from his gunshot wound, while the other was preparing to leap onto its would be prey. Being only fifty feet from the radio station, I decided to make a break for it. I threw the flare at the wolves face and sprinted away. The rapid stomping of my feet began to slow as my stamina quickly depleted. No heat for miles takes a toll on the body, and I was slowly dying just feet from my salvation. I heard fast taps on the ground behind me as the wolves closed in for the attack. I was almost there, just a few more steps until I could get into the station and shut the door, then the wolf pounced. I was on the ground, hacking it apart with my axe as it took gnawed on my half frozen flesh. It was a bite away from ending my long journey, when I took one last swing with my hatchet and killed it. I got up and limped toward the door, just barely making it into the station before the other wolf had a chance at killing me. I made it. Inside was much needed health supplies, and much needed food. I started a fire and cooked some venison, all the while warming my body temperture to its original state. I then went to sleep in the nearby cot, gaining health, yet also gaining thirst and hunger. My supplies were low, maybe a few energy bars and a few cans of soda, definitely not enough to last a voyage out into the unknown, so I decided that my journey had come to an end. I quit the game and said goodbye, for I knew that if I continued I would surely perish. I couldn't watch my character die, after all we had been through, he didn't deserve to fade into the long dark. So I let him live in that save, untouched and undying, until I decide that it's time for his journey to come to a close. Until that moment, I will always cherish my adventure I had, and I hope that one day I will have the courage to once more venture out into the unknown, making my way through the barren landscape, and surviving the long dark.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Despite being early in development, I was really surprised by how addictive and fun the sandbox mode has been. This is definitely one of the best survival games I've ever played and the Gnu/Linux port is very well done. I haven't encountered a single bug and it's probably the best optimized unity 5 game on Gnu/Linux thus far.

Game Highlights:
Very good voice artist work, though it is minimal as of yet (until the story mode is added).
The audio production is top notch, makes all the difference having well produced audio and ambiance, snow crunches, flares sizzle, wolves howl to send chills down your spine, etc.
Art is stylized (not photo-realistic) but it isn't a negative, I think that only adds to the character and experience. Unique survival mechanism and so on..

Game play:
It can be brutal and punishing! Which I really like, the second time I played it started me in the middle of a fierce blizzard in pitch dark with only one flare to try and save myself - I did manage to find shelter in the Carter Hydro Dam (after a night in relative safety, I made my way to the Camp Office located on the western side of Mystery Lake).

Sometimes you get a nice easy start, sometimes a nightmarish struggle to survive what seems like the impossible! If you fail, there is no reloading a save you've simply got to try again (but you can quit any time and continue on another sessions if you have not perished - so a save of sorts).

I really like the change of pace from all the usual gaming fare, this one makes you think about what you need to do to really survive in the game. Supplies are always in the back of your mind, do you stay put in a comfy cabin with the supplies you have - or risk the outdoors to be proactive in your scavenging to prevent a situation where you could starve or freeze to death? There are no zombies, ghouls, or other such fictional monsters - just you versus the brutal arctic and occasionally a wolf or two (best to avoid them if possible).

Tons of fun if you love a challenge and an open world to scavenge up what you can to survive. I can't wait for the campaign story that will be added later in development - going from the current experience it should be amazing!

I can full heartedly recommend The Long Dark to all of you who are interested in the survival genre.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Was bored on a Thursday night, scrolling through the scarce amount of games that were actually made to run on Linux, when I came across The Long Dark. It was already on my wishlist for some reason so I just bought it. Started playing at about 11:30PM, walked around until I found the dam. Spent a good amount of time there and developed the idea that this was a safe space. It was warm, food and drink everywhere, and plenty of resources. I eventually left, unhappy with the mere 5% of the world I had explored, and sure enough, I died within a day of leaving the dam.

Next playthrough, I spawned somewhere I hadn't been yet, on a large lake with a lot of fishing huts. I liked the dam but this was even better, supplying me with more tools than the dam had. So I set up shop in the camp office for a day or two, then set out exploring again. Figured I'd better stop by the dam just to stock up on supplies before heading into the unknown. I was happily greeted by my two crates at the front door, spent my time with all the lockers in the first room, then made my way to the safe on the first floor. I was listening to music because the game sounds are a bit off putting at 2 in the morning, but I had to pause this in order to crack the safe. Got it open, dissapointed to find only more forsaken newspapers. I turn around to continue looting, when a deafening growl penetrates my earholes, startling me and making me try to light a lantern with no oil in it. As I look to the door I see two little beads floating mid air. After a second I realize it's giant ♥♥♥♥ing wolf, in my ♥♥♥♥ing safe space, and in the midst of trying to climb back into my desk chair and put my headphones back on, then trying to figure out how to light and throw a flare for the first time, the thing flies across the room and tackles me. I manage to fight it off, not that that really does anything except delay the enevitable. I try to make my way to the door, as my safe space has been tainted and I wish to never return. I throw as many flares as I can everywhere, assuming the beast will just go back to wherever the hell it came from. I'm exhausted and carrying twice the appropriate amount of weight so it takes me a minute to get to the door, and despite the several flares creating what I thought was a shield around me, it returned and attacked me right as I was approaching the door. I died a few hours later of the several ailments and lack of clothing caused by the wolf.

Nowhere is safe. Wolves in this game have thumbs. Worse jumpscares than Amnesia/10. Only play when intoxicated.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

After two days of foraging the woods around my trapper's cabin, I was running low on food and decided to strike out. I had uncovered a windfall of about 2kg worth of venison from a wolf kill the day before, and though I wasn't dressed for the weather, I needed to find any sort of food. On day three, I made my way over to the train tracks where I noticed a train that had derailed. A blizzard kicked up shortly after I arrived and I hear howling in the distance, so I lit a fire and huddled down by the derailed train.

The howling came up again and I heard the sound of running. A wolf was right behind me! I grabbed a torch from my fire and ran away from the wolf. Unfortunately, I ran through my fire and burnt off my pants. Fleeing pantsless through the trackless wastelands, I ran across the railroad tracks and over a railway bridge. The wolf must have caught my scent again, or maybe it was one of its packmates - I noticed a wolf charging at me down a hill. I brandished my torch with all the fury I could muster whilst wearing my long underwear and then fled further afield.

This is when I found an old dam. It happened to have two boxes of rifle ammunition, seven knitted wool caps, and no pants to speak of. Realizing that if I wanted to cover my junk, I would have to make my own pants, I loaded up my hunting rifle and set out for vengeance. Against mother nature herself.

11/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Innovation is almost always a good thing, especially in the relatively saturated and homogeneous survival genre. Procedurally generated post-apocalyptic worlds, need wood get wood, build block-based houses, form groups with other human players to survive, these are elements that are as overused as the faded tighty whities that I continue to wear to date. And who can forget the zombies.

It's. Always. Another. Bloody. Ugly. Zombie.

And that is why The Long Dark feels like a drop of pristine water on a wretched pair of lips. Its art-style is bold and deliciously refreshing in a game that is intended to simulate survival in the harsh conditions of the Northern Canadian Wilderness. Its rogue-like elements, such as permanent death and a finite amount of loot in the world, shifts the player's focus from spending hours upon hours developing a character and his or her humble abode, to spending hours upon hours replaying just to beat a previous personal best in terms of the number of in-game days survived. And instead of surviving against zombies, players in The Long Dark are tasked to survive against Mother Nature, which manifests in the form of biting windchills and harrowing blizzards, as well as the wolf denizens that perpetually roam the snowy terrains. The sound design of The Long Dark is also extremely well done. Everything from the crunch of your soles on snow, to the groaning and creaking of wooden floorboards as you scavenge a log cabin for much-needed supplies, to the resounding bellow of your hunting rifle as you fire it at a menacing wolf sounds engaging, immersive, and realistic.

Yes, realism is The Long Dark's home address. Being caught outside while there is a windchill can be devastating, but hiding behind rocks sitting in the path of the direction of the wind can provide temporary relief to slow down the onset of freezing. The game's hunger system is also caloric based. Foods that you may loot from the environment have calories similar to their real-life counterparts (albeit scaled up slightly). Since all activities, including sleeping and standing still, burns calories, in order to survive your character has to consume a certain amount of calories each day. In addition, he or she also has to drink at least 2.2litres of water a day to prevent being dehydrated.

On the other hand, innovation can be a two-faced ♥♥♥♥♥. If taken too far, it can detract immensely from a game's production values and amount to a gigantic waste of a developer's time. Reinventing a tried-and-tested wheel, or removing core gameplay elements of a particular genre for no apparent logical or worthwhile purpose, are typical examples of taking innovation one step too far. As much as The Long Dark is a unique game that stands well apart from the rest in the survival genre, Hinterland Studio has adopted a couple of gameplay design choices that are difficult to comprehend, and for lack of a better word, paradoxical.

The biggest culprit lies in The Long Dark's surprising lack of player interaction with the environment. Besides interacting with the game's various containers that exist in the form of drawers, lockers, cupboards, stoves, starting a fire, and the occasional shooting of a wolf or deer, there is little else that the player can do to change or manipulate the environment.

Necessary activities such as the cooking of food, harvesting of meat from an animal's carcass, or the boiling of snow to make potable water, are reduced to dull and meaningless loading bars that signal the progression of an activity. There is no farming, there is no fortifying of a prefabricated house to better ward off the cold or wolves. I could think of a hundred more things that a player, as a survivor in an icy wilderness, would be expected to do to survive better. Sadly, players in The Long Dark are robbed of those options because the game limits the ways in which they can interact meaningfully with their environment. Why this should be so in a survival game is bewildering. It metamorphoses an otherwise open-world survival game, one that should be a suitable platform for the inception of personal survival stories, whether heroic or tragic, into a linear game of repetitive choices.

This is not to say that The Long Dark is bereft of player-made choices. In spite of the game's limited player-environment interactivity, players still have a good amount of decisions to make that dictates how well or how long they will survive in The Long Dark. For example, constantly traveling in the open when there is a strong windchill will result in your character burning more calories as he or she freezes, thus requiring you to expend more of your limited food supply each day restoring those lost calories. Similarly, being greedy and attempting to carry all of the loot scavenged from your most recent exploration trip will also result in more calories burnt as your character shoulders the heavier load. Making a second trip on another day to carry the remaining supplies back to your stronghold may be a better strategy. Finding a way to make the most out of your limited supplies is an obsession that will occupy players, especially the compulsive ones, for many hours on end.

Nonetheless, the negative effects on the game's longevity as a result of its decision to eschew player interactivity in favor of simplicity and ease of uptake are manifest. Despite The Long Dark currently sporting 3 different maps for players to explore in sandbox mode, the relative constrained size of each map and the finite number of prefabs for players to loot means that each map can support at most 4-5 hours of proper gameplay. Beyond that, the game starts to devolve into a tiresome cycle of hunting for deer or wolf, foraging for wood, cooking meat and boiling water to sustain your character's physical needs, and resting in bed. There is nothing else to do. You cannot build, you cannot farm, all there is left to do is to wait for the inevitable end. A most unfitting conclusion to a game with so much potential.

At its current sale price of USD$19.99 on steam, The Long Dark is barely worth a buy. My suggestion is to wait for a sale before spending some of your hard-earned money on this game. The Long Dark will most certainly become a better game with time. On the other hand, you are also unlikely to regret if you choose to invest in this game now. It is one of the most polished and interesting early-access survival game that is currently available on the market. And if you enjoy a rogue-like survival game that challenges you to do better in each successive game that you initiate, The Long Dark is capable of providing an almost endless number of hours of enjoyment. I am therefore giving The Long Dark the thumbs up.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

310 hours dedicated to this game so far and growing! This game has been one of the most entertaining and immersive games I've played yet and this is just the sandbox. I can only imagine what the final, released version will be like with the story included! This review for now will focus on the early access version of the game.


I can't think of any other games like it. A quiet apocolypse has taken place, technology as we know it is gone. The lights went out, never to return. How long can you survive against nature and everything it has to throw at you? There are no zombies. There are no mutants or aliens. Just you, nature and the need to survive. Scavenge what you can from the abandoned regions, hunt for food and find a warm place to spend the night. Just be aware that beyond the safety of your fireglow, green eyes flash in darkness, waiting for you to give them a chance to send you into the long dark. No one is coming to save you, so you'd best be ready to save yourself.

Features:
=======

+No Zombies, no supernatural, no aliens, no occult! Just nature, and it's brutally unforgiving.

+ A gorgeous art style fairly reminiscent of the Group of Seven. Iconic, refreshing and engaging, it's a nice break from photorealism and proof that games can be beautiful and immersive without being overly heavy on realism.

+ Three modes of difficulty with three vastly different challenges for all types.

+ Crafting of the basic survival needs, like torches and bows, and animal skin clothing

+ Survival simulation with a unnervingly believable feel. Monitor your temperature, hunger, thirst and energy levels. Think carefully about your food choices and plan your routes carefully. even a small injury could lead to much worse if left ignored.

+ Challenge modes for those who work better under pressure. Added in the newest update, these challenge modes give seasoned players a few scenarios to complete. For now there are 2. One involves escaping a relentless bear intent on ending you. The second is an attempt to race from one region to another, retrieve an item and make it to the goal before time runs out.

+Comfortably playable with Mouse and Keyboard or with a controller.

+Extremely well done voiceovers for the basic sandbox characters.

+An out of this world sound experience. Every little sound you hear, from the wind in the trees to the clattering of old shutters, has a purpose and has been meticulously planned. A crow flying overhead may alert you to an approaching storm, a strange clang or clatter in a whiteout can point the way to safety. A growl in the darkness can sound your doom.  All of this atmospheric and immersive sound is punctuated by music tracks that serve to elevate the feel of the moment. Rather than play constantly in the background, these short musical interludes kick in to emphasize something and just as quickly fade out again. (The coming of night, the sun rising, A particularly lonely place, or a Change of weather.)
+The game offers no hand-holding. You are dropped in the world and left to figure it out. You will die many times before it starts to make sense, but each time you fail, you get a better idea of how you can apply what you've learned to the next run.

It should be noted that the only real drawback aside fomr the learning curve to the game is the fact that death is permanent. When you die you start again from the beginning, but even that makes for good compelling gameplay as it pushes you to be more careful about how you go about your survival.

Early access means the game is still undergoing serious developement, but even in this current form, it's hard to believe it's an alpha. It's polished and professional with smooth gameplay and challenge that's well worth the full price. If you like sandbox/survival games, this is a great choice. If you like to simply play the game at your own pace and observe the quiet apocolypse, this game is still a great choice. And when story mode releases, I am certain those who like to play games for the storyline will also love it too. Hinterland is making a great first impression with The Long Dark.

A solid 9/10, most likely a 10 once it hits release.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Not yet.(see 2nd paragraph for my real review) This game has plenty of potential but for now it's simply too lacking.

Do you find yourself freezing in a cabin surrounded  by wooden furnitare and yet unable to find anything to burn? Why not break one of the chairs or the table or perhaps even the counter? But this game says no. Have a Jerrycan filled to the brim with karosen? That's great!  It's too bad you can't use it to start a fire. Find a dead deer and want to drag it back to your cabin? Nope, can't do that either. How about those pesky ever-breaking can openers; god knows I go through 15 of them a month... Or the breakable and weak hatchets and pry bars. Every summer I must spend $15,000 replacing all of them I break. Skinning an animal with a knife? watchout that knife will break into usless shards after four uses... How about using 3 coats to repair the one you're wearing? Nope, better cut those coats up into 1 scrap cloth peice each while needing 2 peices to add 15% more durability.

Review: For a game that is focusing on realism it falls short in too many areas. The game sacrifices realisim for difficulty. The elements and lack of food should make the game hard enough; however, the game sees fit to give you a hatchet and hunting knife that you're not allowed to wield in defense; so you better punch that wolf lungeing for your jugular. The game also surrounds you with logs and wooden furnitare that you're not allowed to burn nor are you allowed to re-ignite fires from active coals from a recently dead fire. And don't even get me started on how quickly duribility on things like you clothes goes. In a matter of days(in-game) you'll see your equiped clothes lose duribility. There are way too many things that need to be fixed and added before this is remotely enjoyable / playable.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It took twenty days, five hours and fifty-six minutes before I stared death in the eyes one final time. It happened slowly, painfully and has stuck with me since it happened forty-seven minutes ago.

It started in the afternoon of the twentieth day. I hadn't had a thing to eat since the morning before, and the Canadian camp-site office building offered nothing more for my famished stomach. The fishing lines had broken and I had no rifle, yet I had twenty rounds of ammunition. With that being said, it was time to take my chance in the wilderness again. I took one step forward and planted my sockless feet down into the snow.

I wandered down the traintracks until I encountered a wreck with two carriages. I snuck into the the first, wary of the several wolves patrolling the local area. By now my health had dropped to around 80%. I knew the risks of entering the carriage with a wolf so close by, but I would have done anything for a granola bar or the like. Unfortunatley the first carriage yielded nothing. As I left, the wolf howled and began chase. I immediatley backtracked and sprinted roughly a hundred metres before running out of breath. He caught up, mauled me, and my health had dropped to 12% before I could fend him off with my hunting knife. I patched my wounds but the painkillers and antiseptic wouldn't bring my health back - only sleep would. I limped back from which I came, snuck past the wolf that had bitten me and the rest of his pack and continued up the train tracks until I discovered safety - a dam nestled between two snowy peaks.

I entered with 6% health. It was looking grim, but I hadn't been here before so there was a high chance I would stumble onto some food. It was also dark, with visibility at a minimum. However, the torch at the entrance took care of that almost immediately. As I made my way further into the complex, I discovered what can only be described as a gift from God - it was a granola bar. 300 calories into the system, slight warmth from being inside - things were looking up. It didn't take longer than a minute for all my dreams to be taken away from me, however, as the devil himself decided to crush what hope I had left. It started as a growl, and grew into a nightmare as a came face-to-face with a wolf that seemed almost as large as I was. A wolf? Inside? Impossible. For a moment I thought it was a trick of the light, possibly a trick of the mind, but not a second later my doubts were gone as I felt the warm saliva of the beast as it tore into my throat and left me for dead in the dam, on a cold and frosty Canadian afternoon.

9/10, a little performance upgrade possibly, (or maybe that's on my end) but this is one of the best survival games I have ever played. It felt complete, and I completely forgot it was in alpha. What these guys have now is a complete game, so whatever they decide to add will make it incomparable to anything on the market.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Made the mistake of leaving the Gas Station an hour before the sun rose.  Could barely see a thing and before I had a chance to light my storm lantern, I heard a familiar chilling growl, followed by abrupt barking.
Instead of making the clever decision of turning around, re-entering the Gas Station and waiting it out til dawn, I began to run blindly through the pitch black whilst the wolves took up pursuit.
I stumbled across a car and now I'm stuck in it, surrounded by a pack of three terrifying black shapes who are on constant patrol.  They keep walking by the windows.  They know I'm here.
And I'm slowly freezing to death.
I love this damn game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Now this is a game worth talking about.

Finally a survival game WITHOUT zombies, ghosts, beasts or anything horrific or supernatural.
just man vs nature

Only having played the sandbox mode (story mode still in development) im hooked.
having only the clothes on your back and the vast expance of a seemingly destroyed canada at your front your only task is to survive.

its a rather simple game, you have the normal hunger, thirst and energy bars that must be kept full, but in this game you also need to brave the elements. snow, water, strongwinds and precarious ice shelfs.
never once have i been so engrossed in finding and looting buildings, not knowing if i will be able to replace the jacket im wearing thats in a beyond repair state or even finding a pair of climate appropriate pants.
in this game the weather is more dangerous then any animal or any beast you will come across in this game or others.
mother nature is a cruel mistress.

i recomend this game to any survival genre fan for this is a unique and beautiful take on a genre i belive to be overdone and over played. well done.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

-You want this game.

-You want this game because you want to experience a blizzard at night and feel the desperation for shelter.

-You want this game because you want to be forced to drink murky water given the wind is ruining every attempt to make a camp fire.

-You want this game because you want to walk into thin ice, break it, and struggle to think what to do, due to the rush of the emergency.

-You want this game because you want to feel terror whenever you hear the howl of a wolf.

But mainly you want this game because you want to feel the survival aspect of the game. You want to be the main survivor, no one else to ruin your experience. you want this because you don't want to face clumsy zombies you want to face NATURE

Don't be a beta tester. Be a survivor.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThe Long Dark is a thought provoking exploration-based survival game.  You find yourself stranded in the northern Canadian wilderness with only the clothes on your back and a few meager supplies that will last you for a short time.  The game's intersting hunger meter (a calorie counter) provides you with an accurate measure of your character's craving for food that makes you feel more determined to actually try and endure the cold.  Speaking of cold, the weather varies from absolute blizzards that can get as cold as -55ºC to crystal clear sunny days where you're lucky enought to get a temperature that's right around the freezing mark.  Just like most people in real life, you need to have clothes warm enough to bear the freezing weather if you plan on making a trek outside for a long period of time;  that is, unless you'd rather slowly freeze to death.  As an additional way to combat the cold, you create campfires, light fireplaces, and even use kerosene lamps to warm you if you are getting too cold.  An ever growing issue in this game is your thirst.  Water can either be unsafe or potable.  Clean water can be found relatively easy as it is  prevalent in the world (Ex: drinking out of toilets).  Unsanitary water can be boiled over a fire or fireplace to clean and be made drinkable.  Soda can be found in most abandoned homes, they contain both calories and help quench your thirst.  Coffee and tea can be made as an additioinal source of liquids as well as containg special properties that make them slightly better than water.  If you're ever unable to find any of these and you have the materials needed to create a fire, you can melt snow into clean water.  Your fatigue is an important factor in determining your survival.  The longer you go without sleep and the more strenuous the activities you do are, the more lethargic and slow your character becomes.  This can be remedied by taking a nap.  If you're lucky enough to find a weapon you can defend yourself from the wolves which are your only real predator in the game.  Wolves are a surprisingly terrifying adversary in a game such as this.  Ammo for your rifle (which is the only firearm available this early in the game) is scarce and you are required to conserve and effiectively use your ammunitions for hunting deer or other smaller game or to protect yourselves against wolves.  Flares are also an effective recource to use in defending yourself from animals.  The Long Dark is overall a great survival game.  This review was written during the alpha and I'm sure there are many more features to come.  I'd easily give this game a 9/10.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Let me share a story with you before my review. It's quite long, but it really was one heck of a ride and I hope you enjoy it as much as I did.

>Crash plane in probably Canada. Cold as hell
>Run down a hill trying to find shelter, fall and sprain various limbs. Limp towards a cabin. Find some stuff.
>Keep walking forever until I see a logging camp. Find more stuff, keep walking.
>Find a ranger outpost, find a few bits and bobs but not much.
>Make a fire for the night and try to sleep under a train bridge. Wake up cold after my fire goes out during the night and I'm getting cold.
>Wander until I find the enterance to a dam facility. Dark as all night inside. Remember I have flares, use one.
>Find more flares and a lamp with fuel. Spend my night scouring the facility for supplies, find some useful stuff.
>I need to find supplies so I don't sleep. Wander until I eventually find my way outside to a balcony of sorts on the other side of the dam.
>Walk down the snowy path to a frozen river. Figure something must be nearby so I walk along it and eventually find a cave with some wood. Getting really, really tired but it's daytime and I don't want to waste daylight, but I sleep anyways. Wake up with a few hours of light left.
>Keep walking until I find a cave system. Figure it leads somewhere, it doesn't. It gets dark so I spend the night there with a fire made of wood I found and chopped in the cave. I toil the hours away sewing my clothes, cooking meat I found on dead animals, melting snow.
>Come daylight I'm ready to roll. Wander until I reach the end of the river. I can't find anywhere it leads to. Nothing.
>Keep searching for some buildings or something, but can't find anything. Getting cold so I decide to backtrack to the dam and try my luck on the side I came from.
>As I ascend the slope to the balcony it gets dark and I get sleepy. A blizzard starts to set in, but I don't think it will be an issue.
>I see another balcony across the dam, so I cross the small ledge of the dams' wall to it. Find some palettes for firewood. >I start freezing to death. I make a fire, add the wood I found and figure it will last 5 hours like it says it will.
>Tired, so I try to place my bed roll down. Not enough room on the ledge so I move it a few feet away into an alcove in the wall.
>Think I'm close enough to the fire so I sleep for a few hours.
>Wake up suddenly. I'm freezing to death. My vison is blurry and my movement is lurching. Frantically make a fire. It fails so I try again. It works. Maybe I won't die after all...
>I heat some soup and make some snow water. Unbeknownst to me, my fire is dying and I'm still barely not dead from the cold. Fire dies. I walk over (Trying my best not to fall to my death) and chop a palette into wood. Takes 45 mins and now my vison is getting blurrier.
>Run to the fire and add the wood. Watch it all get eaten up in a matter of seconds due to the cold. Panic and run towards the door to go inside the dam.
>For some reason it won't let me open it when clicking. I think maybe somehow it's too dark for me to find the door and open it? I don't know what's going on. I frantically chop some wood and try to make a fire. It fails. Too windy. Light my lantern, but it doesn't help. Poof lantern dies. I click on the door like a madman, but to no avail.
>I try to make another fire, it fails. I decide there's only one thing to do. I make my peace. The door has bested me.
>Fling myself off of the dam and fall to my death. RIP.

In conclusion, those 3 and a half hours were the most frighteningly intense and immersive I've ever experienced in any game. I felt the emotions as if they were real. Fear, desperation, hopelessness. I heard this game was good and it was on sale so I bought it. Nothing could have possibly prepared me for how great this game is. It is an absolute masterpiece. The art is beautiful, and the world feels believable. The gameplay is nearly seamless, and it's insanely fun. If you're considering this game, but it right now. I promise you'll love it. It's worth every penny.

MY ONLY ISSUE- I would like to see an option for reviewing and/or saving your journal upon death. I kept a very detailed journal of my ordeal and I was sad to have it dissapear after I died.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A few of the many things I like about this game so far:
- Extremely atmospheric environment and especially weather effects (wind, snow, fog etc)
- Beautiful graphics, the lighting in particular (you don't often feel the need to spend 10 or 15 minutes enjoying an in-game sunset)
- Nights are actually dark, there's no mysterious illumination from nowhere to help you get around as in most other games
- All kinds of neat realistic touches: the more you carry the slower you can move; walking into a howling gale is slower than walking ahead of it; you can hide from the wind behind tree trunks; accidentally walking into your own campfire results in a burned foot (doh)

Very absorbing and often quite tense despite the lack of conventional action". It's easy to find yourself completely lost when the weather turns to fog and snow

recommended: but the sandbox mode is worth paying for already."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'm writing this while we are at Alpha v 0.183, so some things could change for sure.

I bought this on a whim because it was on sale for $10. I was initially kinda turned-off by the graphics
because they seem a bit cartoonish. But as I've played, I've seen they are quite sufficient i.e. serve
the purpose.

A lot of people at this point are complaining about the wolves being too hard. There is an option now
to play without them if you wish. But seriously, they are only hard till you learn by dying a bunch of times
how to handle them. It's a steep and harsh learning curve. Survive or die trying!

It's hard to put my finger on WHY I love this game so much. I think it's because it's a lot simpler than a lot
of other games. I like Skyrim, but I had to read up on it for two weeks when I started. There is not much to
learn with this game as the interface is quite intuitive. How to handle the wolves is maybe the only thing
you will want to google.

I think it appeals to the prepper in me to survive another day, clawing and grabbing against horrible odds,
whether it be a blinding snowstorm with no shelter in sight, or being nearly out of food with a wolf outside.

You CAN handle the wolves. I've learned to avoid them from experience. On my current run, I am 53+ days
in and only fought one once or twice at most. Most of the time you can outrun them. Don't let the wolves
discourage you.

I also have to mention that the audio is stunning in this game. The creak of tree branches, etc.

Bottomline is that you might be surprised how this game stirs you at a deep level to keep trying to beat
your previous record. Try it! Rise to the challenge and say up-yours, Mother Nature!!!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Only in its alpha stage and already The Long Dark is the best survival game I've ever played.  Every choice you make matters.  Every second counts.

What I love most about this game is all the different elements that are combined in determining how long you can withstand the fight to survive.  There's the standard health, but that's really the least of your worries.  In a game where you can literally freeze to death, the thing you should be most concerned about is the unpredictable weather.  On top of that is the ever-present threat of hungry wolves and bears.  Sure, there's deer and rabbits, but if you're willing to downgrade to dog food as means for sustenance, then you can bet those wolves and bears won't even stop to think before trying to take a bite out of you.  Next on the list is the matter of shelter.  You're not always going to be able to hide away in cabins (and for those lucky enough to find them, bunkers).  No, there are going to be times when you're going to have to try and find somewhere to camp out at when fatigue has run you ragged.  The great thing is that fire isn't really an issue.  You have a multitude of options when it comes to making yourself your own little bonfire, and it's not all that hard to do.

Now I'm going to circle back around to that standard health deal.  Water?  Yeah, it's your lifeline.  You can survive a little while when you're starving, but dehydration will kill you swiftly.  Your source of water is melting snow at the fire.  However, just that isn't enough.  You need to boil the water to make it safe, or else you're at risk of getting sick.  Are we having fun yet?  You might be thinking, This game has way too many factors working against me.  It's not even worth it."  Not entirely true (as far as the first part; the second is up to you to decide).  The funny thing is that food isn't as big a worry as you'd think.  Remember those deer and rabbits I mentioned earlier?  Sometimes you'll run across the frozen remains of a deer and be able to harvest some meat.  When you do find shelters
date: then you're guaranteed to find some kind of food (and no
recommended: not just dog food).  And if you get desperate enough
hoursPlayed: you can always eat cattails you find along the edges of waterways.  Of course the level of difficulty plays a big factor in just how hard it is to survive.  My favorite is the difficulty setting in where wolves and bears won't attack you!  Unless provoked... it's not that easy.\n\nAll in all
voteText: this game is really just wonderful.  There's no such thing as too much praise.  The most exciting thing?  This game is still in the alpha stage
helpfulPercent: and there's still a story mode to be explored!"

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW:
Simplifying this review, because some people, apparently, didn't understand what I was saying.
This is not a bad game, but it has a few problems that prevent me from recommending it, at the moment. It will likely improve over time.

I'M AWARE THAT THE GAME IS NOT FINISHED.
With that said, lets get down to business. . .

You are not rewarded for critical thinking or your knowledge of the wilderness.
Survival in this game, seems to be a matter of luck an learning to survive the games mechanics.
Things break unrealisticly fast (e.g. Your clothes will break and fall off from walking).

Want to craft a weapon, like sharpening a stick to defend yourself from wolves, like Liam Neeson in The Grey"? Can't do that. . .  yet? Have to fist fight them with your bare hands (You lose).

There are many survival games but this one is different with its realistic principles. You don't fight with any zombie or other people. You fight with weather, hunger, thirst and yourself. The solitude and the vastness of the world makes the strange feeling you have all the time while playing the game.
It is a lot about making decisions and about learning from own mistakes.

There is no similiar game like this yet and I highly recommend to play the game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

What  a brilliant game.

You start in the middle of nowhere, in 4 foot of snow surrounded by trees with nothing but your clothes. You trudge into the unknown, get attacked by a wolf and die.
New day, new life.
Again, In the middle of no where, but now there is a blizzard, and you can't even see the trees, you head off, with no idea where you are going, and a few hours later, you die of exposure.
After a few episodes like this, finally you stumble on a small cottage, it has candy bars!! And soda!!! and a prybar!!! Happy and prepped, you set off to find some fire wood and freeze to death.

The feeling of isolation is overwhelming and complete. You feel the cold, you feel the hunger and most importantly you feel the desire to keep playing and beat the odds, to give the cold harsh landscape one giant finger, and stubbonly keep bashing away at it. I don't know how they have done it, but the game gives you a real will to survive and keep playing. It's brutal and unforgiving, and that's it's charm.

I have never played a game as utterly and immediately immersive as this one, and it's still in alpha.

In a game genre littered with alternatives and repetitive mechanisms, The long Dark manages to be refreshingly original, and beautiful. How do you manage to make the frustration of getting no where so addictive and fun? Ask Hinterland.

Well played.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've only played for a very short time, I just loaded it up to make sure it ran on my laptop. The moment I started playing though, I recognized that sound. The sound of undisturbed fallen snow, that's been there for long enough to have a crust. That familiar crunch sold me immediately that I liked this game, so I figured I'd play a bit. The wind started blowing, that harsh, cuts you to the bone wind I remember from my childhood, and I started walking. I started off towards a red shape in the distance, noting a deer that ran away as I drew near, and heard what sounded like a wolf howling in the distance. The sun was still bright and my character was already complaining about the cold, so I moved on to find some overturned train cars and a dead body and a deer corpse.

There was no shelter like I'd hoped, so I looted everything I could and hurried on down the path, burning precious calories. The sound of wolves was definite in the distance, making me nervous about the very obvious trail of footprints behind me until I finally stumbled upon a lumber camp. I went in the first building and realised with dismay this trailer would stop the wind, but I was still cold, and no useable food (just a can of peaches). Then hope came in the form of an object on a shelf across the room. I've never been happier to see a can opener in my life.

On a more technical side, my 5 year old laptop handled this game remarkably well on moderate settings. I love the style of the art and the sound design is, well... it reminds me of delivering papers in the snow, and the crunch of knee high snow as I pushed my way to doorsteps, hoping to get done before my fingers went completely numb or too much snow reached the bottom of my boots. As I play more of this I may update but first impressions are very favorable.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Finally, a survival game without zombies, monsters, or aliens.

Short VersionIs it worth $20?
Abso-freaking-lutely. I invested much, much more than $20 over a year ago, and don't regret it.
The game mechanics are constantly being tuned. It will only get better.

Long Version
The Long Dark makes you focus on the things that are vital to a person's personal survival.
Food, Thirst, Warmth, Energy.

This game is hard. Make no mistake. But survival is not easy. You are always battling having enough food and water, having enough materials to maintain your core temperature, and having enough energy to complete the tasks to provide for the aforementioned needs.

The Long Dark captures the concept of this perfectly.

Are the menchanics 100% realistic? No. Of course not. This is a game. It has to be fun and challenging. Despite what you see on TV, Survival is not fun. It's a lot of time consuming monotonous tasks. I would not want to play a game that requires me to only need food once a month, drink once a week, wait 20 mins for water to boil, etc. etc.

So the game requires a bit of suspension of reality.  That being said, the focus on the core survival elements is spot on.

One of the chief complaints is that you burn too many calories.

I suspect those doing the complaining are trying to maintain 100% condition.
In cold weather, the body needs 6000-8000 calories to mantain condition.  That's a crap ton of food. When's the last time you saw a well-fed survivor?
In the game, if you eat nothing, and take care of everything else, you'll live for 4 days before condition drops to zero.  This captures the real-life aspect. Sure, you're hungry, but you can push on for a while before it serioulsy affects you.

In real life lost survivors are never at 100% Maintaining 100% condition is not the goal of the game.

Try this next time you play... take care of everything else, but don't worry about food until your condition drops.  Then feed yourself, ensure all other needs are met, and rest.

I could drone on about this, but you get the idea. The Long Dark is not like other games where you can simply eat a snack and restore your health. It's much more real then that.

About the DevsThe devs are all industry pros, and The Long Dark is their full time job, not something fly-by-night.
They are constantly engaging the community, and putting community feedback into the game.
Bugs are logged and fixed at blazing speed. (For example, a steam user reported a mouse sensitivity issue, and it was hotfixed within an hour)
There will be a game. Baring a geomagnetic global event, or world war 3, Hinterland has guaranteed a game release.


The only thing you need to ask yourself is, do you want to be part of developing this great game, and making it better?
I hope so. I didn't regret it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I absolutely recommend this game.
When you're walking down the snowy road during a massive storm, cold and hungry and close to being dead, but suddenly find a dam just to your right, so you hurry inside. Happy yo be alive, you're starting to lay down your bedroll when you hear a growl. Quicly you pull out your rifle, which has only one bullet inside. In an next to absolute darkness you point your gun at the doorway, waiting. Sudden movement. You shoot and miss but the wolf was scared for a moment so you grab your bedroll and quickly get out in the hurricane. There's no way out. There is a little tent right next to the building. As your last resort, with the world blurry, you collect some sticks and make a fire next to the tent. You lay down the bedroll and go to sleep being absoultely sure you won't wake up. But you do. Sick,frozebitten and hardly alive, you wake up and continue surviving.
Amazing atmosphere, rare gem of a game.

Still there are some problems.

-There is still no storyline yet which means two things.
+ It adds to the grim atmosphere of an inevitable end.
- When that feeling is getting old, it's difficult to be motivated to play non-stop.
- The survival system is harsh. You're supposed to keep track of things every second, which ruins the discovery aspect a   bit. You get hungry, thirsty and tired
- There are dumb rules like you can't start a fire indoors, but you can fish and do other stuff until you die.
- The cooking system is poor.
- The loot is still rather poor in quantity. I get the same items all the time.
-  Why can't I craft an arrow head straight away or just sharpen one end? Seems dumb.
- Why is there no mapping system? It would be great if you could make a map in-game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is great! It really gives you the feeling that you are going to die. Lots of great effects and game mechanics. The devs put alot of care into the survival aspect of the game. There are plenty of things to be careful aboot. like spraining your ankle and getting lost in the cold dark fog of night as the wolves that smell your blood get closer, and closer and closer then BAM!!!!!!!!! GET OFF ME WOOOOLFFF AAAAAAHHH....GRRR ARRR GRRROOWL arroOoOooo...WHACK WHACK WHACK!!!! YIP YIP YIP!!!! TAKE THAT YOU SOB!!!! After such an encounter you look down at your invisible feet and see your blood staining the cold white snow...You find an underground bunker...Thankfuly theres a bed, some beans, water and a first aid kit. You patch yourself up just to squeeze some more time in your pathetic lonely life. You can hear the wind howling as you huddle in your bed and go to sleep. Its 7:47 a.m. Time to get moving. What a nice day! I should go find some more supplies. You stumble upon a watchtower that overlooks a frozen body of water. you find a rifle and a box of rifle rounds. Great! now I can defend against predators, Is it getting windy again?

You WILL die! you WILL get lost...Oh boy will you get lost. There are 3 areas that connect to each other and lots of dead ends.

I give this game a cool canadian 9/10. Will give 11/10 if they add ALOT of stuff. The devs have skills and they need to add as much as possible to this game. If you like suvival games you should buy it. I challenge you to try and make it 10 days on the hardest difficulty :P You will feel like survivor man but you will want to cry when you die! Get this game!

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Its Time to update my review! April 03 2015.

I wrote my first review after some beer so it was a bit silly. Now I would like to make a better shorter review.

First thing I'll say is the devs are very good at what they do. They care about the community and respond fast to bug fixes (barely any bugs :D) They recently updated the game giving it a really nice boost. It has become apperant to me that the game will grow at a happy and consistant rate. This game and its devs definitely deserve your support. It always leaves me wanting to go back to it to continue my playthrough or even restart if I fail to survive. I could go into detail about why this game is so good but I dont want to spoil anything for you. Just know that if you like survival games the $20 is 100% worth it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Even at this early stage in development, this game is brilliant. I won't deny that it can get boring fairly quickly, but that doesn't matter in my opinion. The few hours you spend playing the game before you get bored are magnificent.

I start a new sandbox game. Mystery Lake. I know a few locations, but I don't know the map. I immediately begin exploring, hopefully coming across a jacket to ease the icy chill in the air. The weather isn't too bad, so I'm able to relax a little. I follow the train tracks, making a few slight detours when I spot a wolf skulking around. Eventually I come across a derailment, red cars toppled in front of me. The winds picked up now so I think it'll be a good time to huddle down and get warm for a few hours before continuing to find some decent shelter. I step into the train car and stare into the corner. A frozen body is in the corner. I quickly check his inventory, feeling slightly guilty, but I'm going to need whatever he's carry more than him now. Discovering an energy bar and a soda, I retreat to the opposite end of the car with my prize. Huddling down out of the wind I study the body. Will this soon be me?

There's a snow storm outside now, and not even the car is protecting me. I need to move or die. I stumble out into the arctic temperatures and blindly pick a direction, praying to come across some decent shelter. Suddenly, I hear a howl. Black shapes materialise out of the snow and pad towards me. Wolves. I sprint now, the snow storm the least of my worries. I'm getting tired, hungry, and thirsty, but I can't stop. To stop would be suicide. I continue onwards, my vision starting to get blurry. My movements become sluggish. I'm going into the long dark.

Suddenly, I see it. Almost right in front of me, a hut on a small hill. Hope flares inside me as I try and sprint up around the path to the front door. I can barely walk now, I know my conditions frighteningly low. But I made it. The Trappers Hut. I'm safe.

Until the food runs out.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Bought this game on sale, it was the worst, best choice I've ever made.

I proceeded to open the game. And then:

> Started sandbox on the hardest difficulty.
> Proceeded to walk until I found a dam.
> Entered the dam.
> Total silence.
> Searched through various lockers and got supplies.
> Walked to a window, and -
OH, there's a hole over there, which means anything can get ... i n s i d e ...
> Started to panic.
> Heard a noise behind me and turned around quickly.
> Saw a black shape moving around in the darkness.
> Ran and hid behind lockers.
> Peeked out and -
The face of a wolf was staring right at me. It growled and ran at me, giving me what was likely the biggest scare I've ever had since I played Amnesia: The Dark Descent for the first time.
> Immediately noped out and closed the game.

Total play time: 5 minutes.

11/10, would scream again.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Not knocking i know this game is still under construction but its needs some adjustments
its a decent game. but for something that bases itself about a realistic survival game it has some holes in it, for one defending yourself from wolves shouldnt be so complicated, Weapons shouldn't be so difficult to find either. once you find the hunting knife you should be able to craft a spear from branches or other wood you find in the wilderness. the weight limit on gear you can carry it should increase as time goes on if you are maintaining enough calories your strength would naturally improve and your body would adjust to what is demanded from it.

fading into the dark? ok developers you have 3 days you can live without water and your body can last 3 weeks without food. if you're in a bad situation you shouldnt fade away in your sleep unless you're freezing to death.

so some adjustments to be made
*death by dehydration is after 62 hours of no water or food consumed that isnt dry, canned goods and meats all have some kind of water content or juice that will help with hydration, even if you drink the blood of a fresh kill.  sounds nasty? its survival.

*death by starvation in real life is 3 weeks, if you keep it to the same amount of time as dehydration {62hs} then you wont get any complaints from me.

*corpses everywhere but you cant move a single one. ok no im not going to suggest canabalism though it would take the game down a darker path. but no, in a obvious fact if you find a place to use a shelter longer than a few hours to shake the cold off and  search for supplies when you find a corpse you should have the option after checking him to drag him outside number one reason being corpses stink and if youre using the stove and heating the air inside that cabin over freezing then he will thaw and continue decomposition which will eventually cause your character health issues.

*fashion weapons from what you have around you branches, scrap, bones. you gave us tools now we just need to be able to use them.

*wreckage, you're a bush pilot that went down in a crash safe to say he didnt parachute out. majority of small aircrafts do not carry them. so if before you start your search for shelter you have to treat a broken bone sprain or injurty that would add to it but wreckage and depending how damaged the plane is you should be able to go through it fine parts you can repurpose to help survive pull fuel from the tanks. or even use the plane as temporary shelter.

i like it and the concept but some of these issues are just driving me up the wall

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Probably one of the best Early Acces games survival games I've ever played.
I love walking around exploring the wilderness while looting houses, caves, buildings, the game doesn't really have alot of bugs either, when i think of it I've only found two or three of them. The game is really fun, you can challenge others for example with how long you survived, there is three different locations and the map is fairly big in my opinion, alot of places to explore and things to do and see. There is alot of content added already and the developers is one of the best ones I've ever seen for such a game, they always keep on updating and bringing new content to the table. This game has NO zombies instead your worst enemy is nature itself, the weather can be really dangerous but so can the bears and wolves, just be careful where you walk and try not to get their attention. So far there is 2 ranged weapons in the game there is a craftable Bow and a lootable Rifle. You can find loot almost anywhere in the game but the best clothes you can obtain is the craftable ones. Now It's up to you to survive as long as you can, i will give this game 9/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The Long Dark is a first-person survival game. A geomagnetic event has caused your character's plane to crash somewhere in the snowy Canadian wilderness, and armed with only a small handful of supplies, you must do what you can to stave off death for as long as possible.

Unfortunately, death comes in many forms in this game. Due to the fictional geomagnetic catastrophe in-game, the weather has gone into a permanent winter, with random snow, fog and winds which vary in intensity from mild" to "I literally cant see 5 feet in front of me". The event has affected wildlife as well
date:
and some- especially of the 'wolf' and 'bear' variety- will attack you on sight.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

You can find yourself in some pretty nasty situations in this game. On my first trip to Pleasant Valley, I arrived exhausted, over-loaded, and the sun was going down. The wind started picking up, but I ignored it. My character was too busy checking abandoned cars for candy bars and matches. Before I knew it, he was in the middle of a ferocious blizzard. He hopped into the nearest the car and tried to wait it out.

The temperature dropped lower and lower as the storm persisted into nightfall. The wind howled all around, and my character began to freeze. Holy cow...he's going to die out here... I realized. I'd helped him survive for over 100 days, and I was about to lose it all. He lit his storm lantern to try to stay warm. He curled up in his sleeping bag and took little naps. The night crawled on, and his condition grew worse and worse by the minute. By the time the storm finally abated, hypothermia was setting in. He crawled from the car and used one of his precious matches to light a small fire with some sticks he had collected.

He huddled beside that fire and fed it one stick at a time while the wind did its best to blow it out. When dawn came, he abandoned the fire and staggered along the road looking for better shelter - a shack, a house, a garage...anything.

It was hard to see with his blurry vision, but he found what appeared to be some kind of an abandoned farm house. He made his way inside and stumbled around the house. Upstairs he found a bed, and crawled gratefully beneath the blankets.

He slept on and off all that day and the next, and bit by bit, he recovered enough to leave the house and collect some kindling. It was a nice sunny day, and he was able to save the last of his matches by starting a fire with his magnifying glass. He melted snow and boiled enough water to stay hydrated for a few days, then decided he'd better do something about food.

Luck was with him, and he was able to chase a wolf away from a fresh kill. As he leaned over the dead deer and pulled his hunting knife from his belt, I thought, alrighty - everything's falling into place. Looks like surviving in Pleasant Valley isn't going to be that tough after all.

Five minutes later, he was dead. Another blizzard rolled in while he was breaking down the deer, and I was fiddling with my cell phone. I looked up just in time to see him fading into the long dark, and that was that. I stared at the screen in horror. There's no save to revert to... no retry button... no Phoenix Down to tickle his nose with. GAME OVER.

That's The Long Dark in a nutshell. This isn't a game in which you frolic about the hills, or hit the save button just in case what you're about to do turns out to be as stupid as you think it is - but you want to try it anyway...

There are no safety nets. No second chances. You have to constantly be on the lookout for danger. You relax, or get distracted… you die. So you listen to the wind. You keep an eye on the sky. You check the temperature. You look out for fallen trees you might be able to clamber up just in case there’s a hungry wolf over the next ridge. You hear one howl in the distance, and you crouch and count your bullets, or ready a torch and hope it’s more scared of fire than it is hungry. In the easiest mode, the wolves and bears act like they would in nature. If you leave them alone, they'll leave you alone. In the normal and hard modes, a geomagnetic event has made them loopy and aggressive. In Stalker, the hardest mode, there are wolves everywhere. It can be a challenge getting through certain areas unscathed. In their eyes - you're a sloppy joe in pants - if you still have pants by that point.

A few other points:
- The graphics are stylized but attractive.
- The community's pretty good. Most active players are helpful and friendl.
- The developers are communicative and active. They still monitor the board to weed out jerks.
- You can craft and cook items utilizing natural resources.
- It’s a lonely, melancholy game.
- After surviving for long periods, you can get stuck into routines. Fortunately there are five different regions. You can travel to another region if you get tired of the one you’re in. Each one has its own personality and challenges.
- Each game is different. You may have found a hatchet in a dilapidated little hut on your first run, but on your second run – there’s nothing there…
- You rarely spawn in the same place twice. In Stalker, you may spawn twenty feet away from a wolf while it's still dark outside and the temperature is well below zero. Or maybe you get lucky and spawn in the Trapper's Homestead and find a rifle hanging from the gun rack.

Early Access Review

Some pros I have to say about this game:
1. Best survival game ive played in a long time.

2. A survival game thats not based on zombies and the fallout of mankind.

3. Learn real survival skills used in the real world.

4. You feel like a real survivor in the real world playing this game.

5. I have learned playing this game that wolfs are fluffy and bears have emotional problems.

Some cons I have about this game
1. This game is insanely dark (pun! and true!), because its so immersive, with the sounds and artwork, and the countless sad stories you will see.

2. Why am I the only live person around in Canada?


All in all, amazing job by the devs, one of the best games ive ever played!

11/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The concept of the game sounds amazing and is the reason why I purchased this game for 14.99 (Halloween Sale).

The game started off fun for the first 30mins, however I realized how mundane and repetitive the game is after about an hour. Also, it doesn't feel like the game rewards me for my skill, critical thinking and creative ways of approaching the situation. Instead, it feels more luck based then anything.

In regards to the mechanics. Starting with the hunger system, good lord man, no one can get that hungry and eat that much food in one day. Also, the conditioning mechanic on items......I've had knives, can openers, rifles, hachets and other items presented in the game. Those items do not break apart after a few times of me using them in real life. Lastly, the fact I can't wear multiple layers of clothing is quite fustrating, because if I were in that situation, I'd be wearing layers upon layers of clothing to the point where it is not cumbersome. Another thing which is quite annoying is how fast your hunger and thirst rise. If this character ate this much before the plane crash, his fatass wouldn't even survive the first hour.

But, I do understand that the item condition mechanic of the game is suppose to be a way to make you go out and look for materials to repair your say, hunting rifle or knife.  Or that food supplies go out faster to give incentive to go out and hunt a deer or eat some canned goods. It's there to make you move about and explore more versus holing yourself up in a cabin and piling up a massive supply cache. (That's what I would try aiming for.)

This game has the potential to be amazing, but as it stands it's not as realistic as it claims to be and gets way too reptitive too fast.

I'm going to give this game a 5/10 atm, until futher notice. I do realize this game is in alpha so changes can definitely happen.

P.S. The price of the game was reasonable so it doesn't bother me much. I hope the money I put towards this game helps the futher development of the game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

There I was: day 2. I had finally made it to the hydroelectric dam. I was stocked on food, water, and had plenty of tools at my disposal. All I had to do was search the dam for some supplies. I was gonna do it; I was gonna survive forever. I had already been through not one, but TWO wolf attacks. I had sprained an ankle, but got right back up. Blood loss? Yep. Infection? You bet. All in just one day too. I was a master at survival.

I had been to the dam my first playthrough and it proved to be very resourceful, and it was a very safe place too. I could imagine starting up a life with a wife and kids here. No joke it really was that safe--or so it seemed. As I was meddling around looking through the locked lockers (which I could open because I was prepared and had a prybar) I notice something move in the shadows. I was scared initially but then I remembered reading about this game having A.I survivors and was hoping we could help eachother out. Maybe this was even the wife I imagined having a life with here.

As I turn around to introduce myself and try some of my world famous pick up lines- I am unpleasantly greeted by the ugliest goddammed wolf I have ever seen, I hope for a flash of a second that it hasn't seen me. Nope. It saw me. I scream. I run. The wolf catches me. I'm thinking: It's all good I've survived two wolf fights befo--

Mauled by Fluffy the Ugly
You survived 1 day 3 hours and 50 minutes.

11/10 I will avenge myself

*drink grape soda

*start getting really thirsty

*sleep more

*Sprain my wrist and ankle, get major bruising and bleeding trying to fight off the wolf
*get away
*now dying from thirst, hypothermia, and blood loss and can't sprint
*limp away
*start getting followed by two more wolves
*LIMP FASTER
*fail to limp faster
*give up and lay down my bedroll
* go to sleep while being surrounded by the wolves
*die of blood loss in my sleep

10/10 would die in my sleep again.
