reviewText:
Early Access Review

The Long Dark, what a great game!  I've been waiting for someone to do something like this since I played Metal Gear Solid 3: Snake Eater.  This game will get a curious person hooked instantly.

In my first play thorough I found myself on a hill next to the logging camp in Mystery Lake.  I ran to the trailers because I figured with all the snow I'd freeze to death fast with what little clothing my character spawned with.  I had great luck with gear in that play through.  I found two rifles, several knives and hatchets, but after 5 days I found 'the door' to Carter river. Unfortulately I didn't have much tinder and of course as soon as I walked out the door a storm hit.  My character survived 2 more days back there looking for a way out but ended up freezing to death lost on the river.

I've since earned my 50 day badge, I even came pretty close to 100 days before I played after a night of heavy drinking.  I ended up trying to see how high I could jump from ledges and ended up falling to my death on the side of a mountain.  Lesson learned, don't drink and survive.  :)

There are several treacherous places on this map, if the wolves don't get you, the weather or starvation will your first few hours playing the game.  It's not one of those games that's so damn hard you'll get frustrated and lose interest either.  Patience is as much a virtue in the long dark as is caution.  Over time you'll craft clothes and collect what you need to make a bow and arrows.  You'll learn to conserve calories and let the wolves do the hunting for you by following one around crouched down until he takes a deer, and then you'll take him after he takes the deer to get a double meat, gut and hide harvest.

A few things to know if you want tips:

1) The ravine takes you to the next area, don't go that way till you've explored Mystery lake and learned the game's survival basics.

2) A decent set of maps can be found here: http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=530202531

3) Snare traps are a great way to feed your charachter.  Make at least 10 snare traps but preferably 20 or more because after a while they break down, and need to be harvested and rebuilt with new cured gut.  Your return on the gut you use to build them is at least twice and more often 3 times what you'll spend to make them.  Easy calories, set where you see rabbits and forget, check them early the next day.

4) Fish are heavy and offer little calories for how much they weigh.  It's a good idea to cook the fish you catch right in the bob house and store the fish in the bob house so that you can have meat spread out on the map in case you run low on food while your out.  You won't be upset if you spread food out around the area you choose to make camp.  Storms come in fast and without warning.  Stashing food here and there will help you survive longer.

5) Save processed foods in good condition for as long as you can.  Processed foods are lighter in weight than the stuff you can catch and are great for traveling from zone to zone.  Eat the stuff that's going bad when you find if for easy calories, but save the good stuff if you can.

6) Rose hips are great for throwing on the ground in the snow.  They make for an easy to find trail if you're on your way home from your regular routes when a storm hits.  Rose hip trails saved my guy's tail more than once.  You'll need hundreds of them to make a full trail.  I managed to make a trail from the camp office to the first bob house in my last play through.

Other thoughts for the devs:

Don't take the following negatively, you guys made a kick ♥♥♥ game, I love it.  But I'm a critical prick and need to voice my opinion so here it is:

A zippo lighter, flint and lighter fluid would be nice.  Who uses matches these days anyway???  We should also be able to craft some sort of friction fire starting system out of sticks, birch bark and branches or find flint and use that with a knife or hatchet.  For more info see Dual Survival" watch Codey the giant hippy make fire from almost nothing every time.

Google "Fire starting tools" you guys could add plenty of items for starting fires from flint magnesium blocks to those rods that shoot all the 3000f sparks (not flint) when struck with a knife.

Our charachters should level up and be able to carry more weight over time.  Adding a frame pack to the clothing and different levels of bags would be a nice addition to the game.

An adult human can survive 3 days with no water
date: and 3 weeks with no food if he/she is sitting around and was well fed before their starvation.  Please loosen up the food and water requirements
recommended: we're surviving in the cold not running marathons.  I'm aware that we burn more calories trying to stay warm in cold places
hoursPlayed: but three steaks a day?? Really?? I'm a ski bumb and ski in New England and Canada
voteText: it's not that cold.  I've been out skiing in -20F weather; after 8 hours of that you'll look forward to a hot Irish Coffee and a warm fire

Running and other strenous activities (work) should lower the effects of the cold weather.  Keeping active sould be another way to survive the cold.

MORE BULLETS PLEASE!!!

The trapper's cabin should have reloading tools and supplies in addition to the work bench so that the old .303 bolt action fir stock rifle can be used more often or those prepper caches should have multiple cases (1000 rounds per case) of ammo.  Bullets come in boxes of 20

reviewText:
Early Access Review

My review concerns only the Sandbox mode of the game, since there is no story mode yet. Also I always play on medium difficulty.
A few days ago I decided to give the updated TLD a shot. What can i say: annoyingly addigting.
Simple yet very, very addicting. Also infuriating.
Imagine spending 10 hours (IRL) gathering resources, crafting stuff, getting the best possible clothing etc. You're getting really into the game. 28 ingame days go by, you're getting proud of your achievement, aaaand then you fall to your death while crossing the ravine. Just magical.
This is what happened to me, and though I got really close to just Shift deleting every trace of the game, somehow it lured me back into its' chilly atmosphere to brawl with hungry wolves and saw some clothes.
I can't recommend the game enough, though it requires a lot of patience and practice to master. It's kind of like the little cousin of Dark souls.
Big big thanks to the developers!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is an outstanding title in the survival genre. Why? It creates a unique atmosphere in an open-ended, realism based, beautiful environment with a challenging sandbox gameplay.

Have you ever romantically thought about the experience of living in a lonely wooden cabin, far from the civilization, in the icy north of canada? Can you imagine this ambivalent mood, being in a beautiful, but also hazardous wild nature. Do you want to feel the pulse of the wilderness to experience your own limits? This is the atmosphere, the game is build around. It's not about fear or depression - it's about living at the limits and the willpower to survive.

The game achieves this by a very unique and own game art, realistic game mechanics and the beautiful northern setting with stunning varying light based on weather and day-night cycle. The realism of the game adds more depths to the decisions you make. There is rarely a strict pattern or some kind of best practice"

recommended: to decide if a risk is worth the reward. Even your bad decisions may bring you an exciting experience. You will die often in the beginning. But everytime you start a new game

getting a feeling for the dangers out there and how to withstand them.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This has to be one of the best games I have ever played. Yet, action-wise, there is very litle. This is all about survival and survival depends on the tactics you employ within the game. There are no 'buddies' to ask for help. No one you can telephone. Make a wrong turn, wonder off into the forest with night falling, and you are dead. Simple as that. It's all about decisions and making the correct one at the point you are at is the essence of the game.

There are no real spoilers in the review - but there are a few tips that could be useful for beginners. Be warned.
...
...
...
...
In fact, the first few times you play, you are likely to end up dead very quickly... There is no real game help, as such, and it is a struggle to understand what is required of you. However, give it time and it starts to make sense.
When the game first starts, you are dropped in a random location and it could be day or night. I suggest starting on the easy level as wolves don't attack you. In some respects, this is more accurate as wolves tend not to attack humans.
The first thing to do is find shelter. You are unlikely to survive the cold of the night (or the day) if you are out for too long. This can then be used as a base.
There are buildings scattered about to scavenge and hidden caves where you can find a few scraps.
Journeys need to be planned. Never, ever, go out with just a couple of hours of light left. Darkness comes in rapidly and you are liable to get disorientated and die of hyperthermia. Also, weather can change rapidly and you need to know that you can make it back. Pay close attention to your surroundings and make a map ( I count steps).
Explore each area thoroughly to find the exit. Carefully time when you leave the exit area.
This is the beauty of the game. Everything needs to be calculated carefully to survive - just as in real life.
Another nice feature is the lack of other people. Clearly, they were there at some point but for reasons not given, you could be the only person alive on the planet. To meet other people would spoil it and wisely, the developers know this.
After all, what is more terrifying than being totally alone in a hostile environment? And that is the cleverest part of the game - the shear lonliness.
So why is the game so compelling if there is no action, as such? Well, you live and die by your own actions and there can be no excuses if you do die. Therefore, everything is down to you the player and we all want to survive, right?

I treat the game as a real life simulator. Should the big freeze ever come, I fancy my chances. Well, maybe a little bit more than most.

Buy this and enjoy one of the most beautiful and yet scariest games ever written (without a monster - or is 'cold' the monster?).

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nIn a genre of tedium, mediocrity, and illogical design, The Long Dark is the diamond in the rough. From the moment you start your game, you're thrust into a place that does not want you alive, and I'm not talking about animals, they can't hold a candle to the harshness that is the weather. One bad decision and you're completely lost a zero visibilty blizzard with small hope for survival. Survival is not a matter of chance but a matter of wits. Supplies are running low. reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is great...but the only problem is, it's addicting. I'm currently working on getting all the achievements, and am already on my fourth run.

My first run (very proud of this) I lasted seventy days, decided to go shoot a bear, got mauled by a bear, somehow survived thanks to medicine, bear died from my gunshot wound, and then I froze to death while trying to harvest his meat. I learned my lesson...never try to harvest all the meat from a bear at once.

Next run, I wondered what it would be like to jump off a bridge. Let's just say it hurt...a lot. I survived 6 days.

Third run, I decided to go off-road and I fell into a ravine out of which I could not get. Being stuck, I froze to death...again. I survived 33 days.

Now I'm on my fourth run (yes, I do have a life, if you were wondering) and I'm predigiously proud of surviving for 109 days so far. But, considering my luck, I'll probably be dying very soon.

So, in summary, while this game is still an Alpha, I have had yet to encountered a bug in the game (well, say for being stuck in the ravine and not being able to get out, but I will blame that on my own stupidity). The art style reminds me a bit of Nightmare Before Christmas and the game mechanics are very simple for a newbie like me to understand, and yet the game has a lot of strategy in it. I personally can't wait until the full game comes out. Now, I have to get back to the game...who's betting I die in five minutes...oh dear, that bear is lumbering towards me...excuse me while I run for my life...

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Incredible game. For Alpha, this game far outclasses many fully developed games. That said, there are some minor, nitpicky things it could work on.

Pros: +
Cons: -

+Extreme realism. This game depicts a survival scenario in an incredibly realistic way. Not too hard, not too easy.
+Wolves. The wolves make sure you never quite reach the top of the food chain.
+Graphics/audio. The graphics are beautiful, charmingly cartoony, and the audio's attention to detail really sets it apart.
+Wildlife. The AI is perfect for the wolves, deer, rabbits and birds.
+Fluffy.

-Wolf fights are a little too hard to win. (I know they are in real life, too, and it does add to realism–but purely in terms of gameplay it can detract from the experience when a wolf is encountered in early game when you have no means of defense.)
-Time seems to pass too slowly with too little to do, dragging days out.
-Fluffy.

Realism: 10/10
Graphics: 9/10
Audio: 8/10
Combat: 7/10
Fairness: 9/10

OVERALL: 9/10
Worth $20, easy. Spend your money here, if you're gonna spend it anywhere.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is the most addictive and un-bugged early access game I have played! The details are amazing, like ducking behind trees and along banks to lower windchill, or spraining an ankle more often due to carrying a lot of heavy stuff in your backpack.

There are so many small details and polishings that just immerse you into the unforgiving world of The Long Dark.
The devs are also very attentive and present on the forum, which is reassuring.
All in all, this is not an early access game that feels unfinished or unpolished - and it only includes the sandbox! This game will go great places.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI never thought another game could rival my love for and time commitment to Spelunky, but I may have found that marvelous game's equal in this early access gem! Of course they are two COMPLETELY different games (aside from both having permadeath), but I love it when a game captures my imagination to the point where I'm thinking about it long after I quit the game. Along with the stellar and challenging gameplay, the look and feel of the world Hinterland has created often causes me to just pause and take a screenshot. This game is beautifully designed! The sandbox mode is great, but I'm especially stoked for Hinterland to finish Story Mode. The only thing missing is full controller support which I'm sure they will add later. And don't be scared off by the early access status. The game has never crashed on me, and I have never lost a saved game. I'm certain this will end up being a 200+ hour time sink for me!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

(Alpha Review, Sandbox Mode Only)
I've had this game for awhile now, I pledged enough money to get the alpha before it's early access on Steam. Personally I love this game, it's not your traditional survival game, there's no zombies or aliens, it's you agaisnt the elements and the wolfs. Currently the game is only sandbox mode but later the developer (Hinterland Studio) plans on adding a storyline campaign. Hinterland Stuidos are constantly updating the game, fixing bugs, and improving the overall experience. They're great when it comes to feedback and even personal dislikes.

Sandbox mode has a ton of replayability, every time I'm thrown into the world, I'm in a new area and I'm scrambling to find a familiar landmark. While attempting to survive you need to worry about food, water, wolfs, overall condition, and even clothing. Every decision you make, makes you second guess yourself. While trying to stay warm and keep your condition manageable, you also need to keep moving and find more supplies to keep yourself alive. It's part luck, part skill, and part making the right moves at the right time. While traversing through the beautifully done landscape you find yourself dodging wolfs, checking your condition, the time and even the weather. I personally can't get enough of this game, and I can't wait to see what the developers have instore for the storyline campaign.

I can say with confidence this game won't be left by the wayside like some other early access games. I've been a victim of developers abandoning games after they were released on early access Steam but I highly doubt this game is going anywhere. Hinterland Studios is a new company with this game being their first release but if you do your research into the team at Hinterland you will be blown away. Huge names that are worked on games like: The Far Cry series, the Saints Row series, Warhammer, Red Faction, Star Wars: Knights of The Old Republic, Mass Effect, God of War, and the list goes on and on. These people are NOT new to making games by any means, and it shows with The Long Dark. I've only had to opportunity to play the alpha but I'll say it's one of the best alpha experiences I've had.

I hope this review has persuaded you to purchase this game early access. I will do another review once it's fully released. I hope to see this game hit huge milestones as I'm a huge supporter of this game and the studio. Thank you for taking the time to read this review.
-Bay Area Buggs

reviewText:
Early Access Review

TL;DR -- The Long Dark is indie development, Early Access, and PC survival gaming done right; you will enjoy your harsh survival experience with this game.

Pros:
- immersion. The crunch of snow underfoot and the fog of your breath will make you feel like you're there.
- permadeath. This game brings the challenge back to PC gaming that has been missing for a while.
- femshep. Jennifer Hale voices the female character. Sorry, no bionics available.
- challenging. It is a struggle to survive, but they have since added some gradation to the diffuculty level with three settings to choose.
- regular updates
- vindicates the 'Early Release' business model. The 'Early Release' concept is hit or miss (Ex: DayZ SA) and is the topic of a lot of debate among PC gamers and interested parties. 'The Long Dark' plays like a beta or even a release candidate, although they call themselves an alpha. It's easily worth the $20 tag on it right now.
- roadmap. More areas are coming. Maps are coming; I find the lack of maps kind of exciting, there is a thrill of exploration to be had.
- survival without zombies. Although I could play a hundred zombie shooters and be fine with it, I have to give credit to a novel concept of man-vs-environment in today's arena that is full of zombie shooters.

Cons:
- will test your gamer might. You will die.
- [This is now fixed and smoothed with weather cues to alert you to oncoming bad weather] weather model. Sometimes it goes from nice outside to foggy to blizzard with little warning.

In summary, 'The Long Dark' is probably a $30 title than you can get for $20, it's a great alpha, it will provide hours of entertainment and seconds of terror, it's a unique pc game survival experience that's worth your time and your cash.

=== 9/6/15 v256 ( hotfix v258) update ===
[read this to yourself in Cartman's(tm) voice]
Dear Diary,

It's been days since I've stepped out of my apartment. Thankfully, the Chinese place delivers.

I can now hatchet things up to fuel fires and cook wolf meat. And I have wolf meat because I can make a bow and arrow and headshot them as they charge me. Do I not look like Death Incarnate? Please Hinterlands, my erection can only get so big. And the old ones tell of a mega-update due this month. Gods have mercy, because Hinterlands will not.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is so immersive. At times, I have to just stop playing because it is exhausting being constantly focused on surviving for hours on end. Do I have enough food? Is my water supply sufficient? Will the weather turn foul while out exploring? Are there wolves in my path? Can I avoid them or must I fight?

The game only saves when you sleep, enter a shelter/building or become injured. Death is permanent with all saves erasing when you do die. Save scumming is impossible so every time I venture outdoors I am looking out for possible dangers. It's been a learning experience as I have avoided reading guides or looking at videos. The first time I died venturing out in the wilderness at night. I quickly lost my sense of direction. It is much colder at night than during the day so I froze to death. All my other deaths have been due to wolves. Generally wolves are just a nuisance. They telegraph their intention to attack from a long ways off and are easily scared off by fire. It is when you are weak from hunger, thirst, fatigue or the cold that wolves can make an easy meal of you. Even when you are in good shape if your fight with a wolf leads to being wounded gravely you better have first aid gear available. If not you will likely bleed out.

This game gets you thinking about what you would do if in the same situation. Would you end your life early to avoid the slow death of starvation or would you fight will all your might to survive no matter how much suffering you endured? You can't really hold it against the person in this situation who takes their own life. Starving or dying of thirst are horrible ways to die. Freezing to death is perhaps a bit less horrible but you do suffer quite a bit until hypothermia kicks in. No need to mention the horror of becoming the next meal of a predator.

You are stranded in the Great White North. You have few supplies and must scavenge for anything which improves your lot.

What would you be willing to do to survive?

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The Long Dark - Alpha

Slowing fading away of hunger in an abandon car was not the way I was going to die.  The blizzard had been going for two hours, and only the sound of my stomach growling kept me from trying to wait it out.  The last shelter I had seen was half an hour ago and the chances of finding it in the pitch darkness were nil.  My shivering was becoming constant.  No, I would not die here in this car.

Opening the door and lighting my last flare, I knew I could end up a frozen slab of meat on the side of the highway, or worse; a warm slab of meat for a wolf or bear.  Who knows, maybe dying warm would be better...no, follow the road, there is always civilization at the end of a road, but which way?  To go back was certain death, but to go foward was to make progress.  To what exactly I could not say, but it was further from death, further from the dark.

Shivering and walking at a limping pace, the sight of my own breath was a constant reminder that I was freezing to death, and if I didn't stop my sprained ankle would never heal.  If only the storm would let up for a just minute I could find my way...my condition was only getting worse.  I did not bother to pick up fuel for a fire anymore, what was the point?  No, this would not be how it ends, this is not how I die.

I think of where I have been so far, what little I have learned about surviving in this barren wasteland.  How to start a fire, what wood is the best to use, and what clothes can protect me from the wind.  I thought about the last cabin that I last slept in, it had everything I needed.  A pot belly stove, bunks with thick sheets, and most importantly four walls and a roof to protect me from the wind.  There was so much food in it, the cans of soda, jerky, even a cooked fish.  The moment I walked in I knew I had been saved; most of the food was gone within the day.  There was no choice but to leave the cabin if I was going to survive, even had I known I was going to sprain my ankle I still had to leave.

The flare has now died and I keep walking in the dark knowing there is no going back.  All of a sudden I was hung up on something in the darkness.  Remembering the matches, I lite one and see at my feet is an overturned row boat on a frozen lake.  There must be a cabin.  I rush around in the darkness lighting matches frantically and see the small simple structure.  Entering the cold room I rush to the stove and start an emergency fire with my last acclerant.  The fire starts quickly giving me my first respite from the cold.  The dimly lit room is bare of items but under the bunk is a dusty forgotten MRE, I have hit the lottery.  Eating the packaged meal immediately the darkness slowly begins to subsides.  I purify the melted snow on the fire and drink my fill of water.

The crackling fire's warm glow begins to fill the room with heat, but it will be out in a few hours without more fuel.  I need to rest if I am going to get more wood.  I go to sleep in the bunk taking in all of its warmth.  Upon waking up the fire is out but the room is filled with light.  Eleven hours of daylight left and I have survived for three days.

I go outside to find the storm has ended and the morning sky is now a pale gold.  There is a cabin is out in the middle of the lake and I am going to need more food and fuel if I am going to survive any longer.  I start walking towards it picking up whatever loose firewood I can find along the way before stepping onto the lake.  Today could be my last day here, then again it might be tommorow.


But with every day I spend out here, I find it easier and easier to live on the edge of 'The Long Dark'.



20 minutes later I was mauled by a wolf and bled to death.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First game ever.

I'm outside. The snow storm is wreaking havoc. It's freezing, but happily I spot near me a large building. Lucky me. I enter the dam. It's dark. It's gloomy. I can hear many, too many, unknown noises in the distance, barely audible, which adds a shiver along my spine. It seems safe nevertheless. I walk slowly into the main room instead of going back outside in the cold ; I'd rather keep myself warm, like a fly desperately attracted by light. It's even gloomer here. Nothing happened... I feel safe now. I enter the room with the command panels. I scavange for food and supplys. After all, I know how to survive. Probably. I will need those things sooner than later anyway. I stop when I find a flare. I smile widely. I will be able to keep wolves at bay. I hear something. Footsteps. Not mine. I turn vividly my head ; I think I saw something, thought followed immediatly by a growl nearby. Adrenaline rushs through my veins, the heart is rapidly pulsating. I drop the flare.

I see IT now. Large. Black. Running toward me. I scream and try to get out of here. I collide with one of the tables on my way out. The wolf jumps then on me, is jaw wide open. I feel bitten repeatedly. I bleed. I kick. I punch. I bite. Whatever ! Everything is a blur. I start to loose consciouness. I die.

It's been all in all around five minutes of playtime. I cannot describe you how much I was immersed in the game and how much loud I screamed when I saw Fluffy, the iconic wolf.
A tensed game time.

I love The Long Dark ever since.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

An amazing survival game that is constantly updated and worked on, with plenty of content to keep you busy. Here are some pros/cons:

Pros:

- NO ZOMBIES: really, I'm sick and tired of this cliche that plagues this genre.
- Not action/combat oriented: apart from wild animals you will only fight nature and your needs.
- Amazing atmosphere: even if you know there's no zombie to jump on you, you'll still get uneasy feelings when going through an abbandoned place
- Realism: there are very few other games that emulate real survival so well. Everything from hunger to weather or wildlife behavior is spot on.
- Constant updates and feedback from developers: this is clearly not one of those alpha/EA games that is abbandoned after the first cash grab
- Incentives to explore: the game is designed in such a way that you cannot jut bunker down in a cabin and live there indefinitely. You NEED to explore to survive and it's alaways a hard choice to leave your cozy base" to brave the unknown.
- The game is harsh: one moment your condition is 100%
recommended: then you make 1-2 mistakes like you decide to butcher a deer even if it's frozen and there's only 1 hour of sunlight left
hoursPlayed:
then a wolf attacks you and you're maimed and can't find your way to your precious shelter.  The cascade/butterfly effect can kill you even after 30-40 days of survival

Cons:

- No HUD to display the hunger/thirst/energy levels. While this is intentional (for immersion)
voteText: I'd like to have it as an option.\n- Needs a bit more wildlife variety and more crafting recipes."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is brilliant.

The game spawns you into a random location on a map, and then the clock starts ticking as you try to survive as long as possible. The catch is not only are you trying to find the important aspects of survival like food and drink, but you are also being hunted.

The game spawns wolves who are just as hungry as you. The wolves will hunt in packs to try to find their next meal, which may be you. This keeps you on your toes constantly as you never know what may lurk behind you or around the corner. It is very unnerving and really gives the game a creepy atmosphere.

The fight for finding food, water, and shelter, as well as trying to fend for your life give the game the desperate struggle for survival it was trying to achieve. The maps are big with plenty of places of interest, and the gameplay will keep you coming back for more!

Oh, and don't die. The game has permadeath, and I mean PERMADEATH. It will delete your save the second you die automatically. Every second is a fight for survival, as well as for preserving all your hard work up to that point. I go back and forth if I like this feature or not, but the stressful and desperate atmosphere it creates is definitely worth it. Pick this game up now! I can't wait to see what the future holds for it already has enough to keep me occupied for months to come :)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A thought provoking and realistic survival game, you wont find mutants, zombies, dragons or any other unrealistic crap here!

Even in it's current state (no story mode yet, just solo sandbox) I'd compare it with 'The Road' when it comes to the mood and atmosphere. The sound of the wind is your only companion in this game, only to be occasionally interrupted by the spine chilling howl of a wolf, or wolves. This game will scare you, whether you're walking through the forest after a blizzard, exploring abandoned houses or winding your way through the dreaded 'Carter Hydro Dam' (I'll let you play the game to find out why :D) you will be on the edge of your seat. Things can and WILL go 'south' in this game very fast. In my most recent game I was warm, well fed, in perfect health... I decided to go foraging. After a while walking through the snow I came accross a black bear, I had 3 rounds in my rifle, took the shot (I was running low of food stores) but I didn't kill it, I was then mauled and left in the snow to bleed out.

It was my stupid decision but it shows that you have to be so careful in this game. Supplies are scarce, you are your own worst enemy, you have to deal with tiredness, health, hunger, thirst and of course warmth.

I highly reccommend this game, as I said at the start it's thought provoking and has great atmosphere. This game really makes you appreciate the things we often take for granted in our day to day lives.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A survival game that is pure survival. No zombies, no nuclear wastelands, none of that. Just you vs Mother Nature and her elements.

In The Long Dark, you play as a bush pilot who crash lands in the middle of Canada's harsh wilderness in the event of a geomagnetic disaster. You'll need to scavenge for food, water, meds, and tools to help you stay alive to see the dawn of the next day. You'll also need to take account for body temperature, caloric intake, your hunger/thirst, fatigue, wind-chill, wildlife, and other environmental factors. This game will have you making decisions and one wrong decision will see to your death.

Can you survive to see another day....or will you succumb to the long dark.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

the long dark is a challenging and rewards no holes barred experience in wilderness survival, its highly unforgiving and cruel at times but through your failures you find success next time around, you must learn to take rsiks, acess danger, ration resources, and learn to navigate the wilderness in order to survive in this harsh climate. players must be willing to reflect on their game up until their inevetable failure, acess why they died and start again. the game is also visually solid with a unique art style that mixes cartoon with hand painted art and the audio while minimalist is enough to sell you on your environments.

however the games controls need refining and those attempting the 50 day achievement challenge should be made aware that the conditions to achieve it come down more to random luck that true skill with even experience survival game players probably only going to achieve around the 30 day mark. and the game has some issues with level design such as being able to clip through rocks, at one point i got stuck inside of a tipped over train car, and animal AI pathing suffering from minor bugs involving walking into walls or totally ignoring your presence at all times

i also feel that there should be a way to hunt for food beyond a rifle, such as makeshift traps, or melee weapons. this would improve the quality of gameplay considerably

the long dark can easily walk its way though to a 7/10 from me in its current state and could easily score higher if updates improve the game more

reviewText:
Early Access Review

What to say about The Long Dark that does it justice?

Unlike most other 'survival' games out there in the market, do not be expecting to swing axes at Zombies and other supernatural beings. Your enemy in this game is the weather, wildlife (Wolves / Bears) , fatigue, thirst and hunger.

Simply walking around with no enemy in sight can cause your health to start deteriorating if you are being careless about how cold the weather is. When you are starving, the sight of even a small handful of herbs or a degraded packet of candy will get you excited.

Expect to build fires, evade wildlife, monitor the weather like a hawk, inspect every nook and cranny for food / water / medicine - expect to hurl yourself into a cabin with a wolf or bear on your tail like your life depended on it. (Which it does!) Expect to traverse up large mountains in the hope that there may be a shelter somewhere. Enjoy the beautiful sunlit and moonlit views of the Canadian forests whilst reminding yourself that you need to keep moving.

Expect to flounder in the darkness and traverse through mines with the kerosene in your lamp trickling away.

If you can plan ahead, if you can adapt to harsh situations and if you can handle doing as much as possible with as little as possible in your possession - you will relish this title.

This is an intelligent game designed for intelligent gamers. It is a true masterpiece and example of not only what a survival game should truly be about, but also how an Early Access title should be developed.

Hinterland Studios actively and consistently interact with their members on the forum and listen to inputs about any bugs and feedback about the game. And all along, they still remain true to their core vision of the game.

I cannot recommend this game enough. There is plenty of content in the game and it barely feels like an Alpha release.


------------------
Some key notes about the title;


* One life. When your game is over, it is over.
* Ammo is scarce.
* The weather WILL dictate how much you can explore at any given time.
* You can craft gear, which includes warmer clothing, weapons and food harvesting.
* There is item degradation. All repairable... if you have the materials.
* There is no map". You learn by exploring and memorising.
* What you can carry is limited. Whilst you can go over your 'maximum' weight
hoursPlayed: hunger and movement penalties.\n* The game has a learning curve which would be considered steeper than most other titles - there is a bit to take in
voteText: there is no game manual - and it can be unforgiving. This is a game that intuitively makes you discover by yourself.\n* You will be monitoring your four stat bars and your health bar a lot in this game if you want to succeed.\n* There will be a lot of exploring where you do not get attacked for long periods. This is normal. (And to be honest
helpfulPercent:
a welcome thing!)
------------------



The only things I would consider as "CONS" for this title is that it's in Alpha - so you naturally want more content and there are pockets of bugs you can discover. (I don't come across very many though...) Also
votesHelpful:
once you get proficient at surviving (takes a while to get there) it can be a bit lonely and repetitive if you aren't exploring around the maps.

So far, the game is great. It is a difficult survival game and accurately portrays real life survival. Still, like all early access, I am left with wanting a little more out of it.

Specifically, I find the game visually understimulating. Let me clarify. The scenery and art work are amazing. My problem is that every action I go do, I have to watch a loading bar tell me time is passing rather than show me that it is. Like when I eat a candy bar, I want to see myself take a few bites out of it. Instead I hear a few crunching noises and measure my progress on a bar. When I go scavenging for wood, maybe show me chipping away at a nearby tree. The only action I don't mind watching is sleeping.

Right now the game has so much potential. I just still worry that the developers will dip out too early on this project.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I spent my first day looking for food and clothing. I found warm clothes, but barely any food. Night was coming upon me and I didnt see any shelter. I started running and found an abandoned dam just as the sun's glow had left the sky. The inside of the dam was extremely dark and I had no source of light other than a lone flare. I used the flare and started exploring the (supposedly) empty dam. I found a knife, food, matches, a crowbar, and a lot of medicine. I had just about explored all the rooms and hallways of the dam, when suddenly my flare died out. It left me completely blind in the darkness.  I brought up my inventory to use my matches when, from the pitch black, I heard a growl. Of course I ♥♥♥♥ my pants (not literally) and quickly exited out of my inventory to try and helplessly run away from my unkown pursuer. I ended up dying to this pursuer, which turned out to be a huge ♥♥♥ wolf.

10/10 Better atmosphere and scares than a real horror game can deliver.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Best Early Access game I've ever purchased!


At first I was going to wait until I had more play time to write this review but I think 10 hours is a good start. First of all, the game is EXTREMELY immersive. However I wish the soundtrack played more than it did (because it's amazing), I think it only plays at certain times. The graphics are really great and different from most games.

The survival aspect is great, people think the wolves are OP but really they aren't (only fluffy, he scares me).  The more things you use like clothing etc the more it decays which isn't really too realistic but it forces you to scavange, explore, and repair your items often.

The Mystery Lake map is big enough to keep you interested and Hinterland has now added about what? 4 more zones?  I only have 25 hours on the game and the longest I survived was 2 days! You can sprain your ankles which requires painkillers and rest (somewhat like real life). You can get food poisoning from bad venison or wolf meat even if it is cooked! You can get dysentry from drinking tainted or unsafe water. I really wish I could describe the epicness of this game but I am a bit tired lol, if you're wondering if it is worth the 20$. IT IS! Especially with all the updates the Devs have release in just the past FEW DAYS! This game has much more to be added including a story mode. So yes, if you like survival games and want to see if you can survive the Canadian Wilderness, buy the game! :D

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Pros:- Open world survival.
- Very good graphics and the graphics also suit the game.
- Random Item Spawning, items spawn in a different place every time.
- Well made AI Enemies.
- Many different items and places to explore.
- The devs add maps regularly, they will always keep you interested.
- Story Mode will be coming out soon, as to how good it will be I can't say.
- Not Another Zombie Survival Game.
-All language types can be found on the Workshop.



Cons:- After surviving 2+ days you will start to run out of supplies and it will begin to get to hard since nearly everything can kill you.
- Worlds are not randomly generated, items will spawn randomly but the world and levels will always be the same.
- No Multiplayer.



Conclusion:This game is an Open World survival simulator that has very nice graphics that suit the games style. This game is currently not multiplayer but they are bringing out a single player campaign. The AI in this game are very will made, the voice actor also has just the right feel about his/her voice in the fact that it fits the style of the game. Sandbox Mode if very fun to play and will keep you coming back to explore the new maps that the Devs add all the time.



Overall Rating: 7/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So my plane has crashed and I am alone, cold and hungry.   Sadly I am dressed for 4 hours of comfort on a routine flight from Anchorage to Yellowknife, not for comfort wandering the greater Canadian waste.

Though it is late in the day, fortune is with me.  As I orient to my surroundings I notice a frozen fellow face down in the snow.  Apparently, his name was Max.  He clearly wouldn't be needing them anymore so I borrowed his hunting knife and hatchet.  Nearby I find a hunters blind and some meager food supplies.

But then the luck ended.  It was dusk and night was closing in and, as fate would have it, a monumental blizzard rode along with the dark.  I started treking in the dim dusk, seeking I knew not what.  As the wind and the cold clutched at me, I staggered on until i saw the dim outline of a building.  I was cold, tired and starving when I finally found solace in a small hunters cabin.  It's meager supplies barely sustained me until morning.

For the next 16 days I wandered the Mystery lake area in search of a rifle to fire the 30+ rounds of rifel ammo I've amassed.  It would be the edge I need if I am to triumph over wilderness.  I've fended off every wolf attack, finding most later after they have succombed to the wounds my hunting knife left them.  I've lived well on plentiful venison, having stolen the kills of wolves after carefully stalking them, as well as my own kills with my makeshift bow.  I've trapped rabbits and I've fished the lake and I stand now, hearty, healthy and well equipped by Mother Nature's  bounty.  I no longer fear wolves, though I avoid bears.

Finally I realize I have depleted all of my resources and my last arrow was lost in my most recent hunt.  With some small amount of anxiety I realize I must leave this place, or die here.  And so I set out for the coastal highway.  I gather my most crucial supplies, fully repair all of my best equipment and strike out.

For 4 days I trek, through ravines and over hills and down cliffs, until I come to the monstrous frozen lake of the coastal region.  I set out across the lake. I am being impatient, I know, but a promising group of buildings  in the distance has allured me.  I am encumbered, I sought to bring as much to my new area as possible and have collected more along the way.  I realize the going is too slow, I've consumed too much food and starvation is closer than I had anticipated.

The worm has turned.  Fortune has looked away from me, presenting me it's back.

Half way across, the winds kick up, temperatures drop and a blizzard sets in.  I become disoriented.  Now lost, I am unable to see and unsure of my bearings, I move towards the outline of what appears to be a fishing hut I had been aware of before the snow hit.  But alas, Fortune had fled fast from me now.  The outline was not a hut.

It was a bear.

Terror gripped me as the foul beast decended.  Helpless, he mauled me repeatedly, shredding my carefully constructed clothes and llacerating my flesh repeatedly, before leaving me all but dead.

As the bear shambles off, I slowly come to my senses and fully realize my peril.  I've sustained tremendous injuries.  It is all I can do to stem the bleeding and stumble to the REAL fishin hut nearby.  Exhausted, physically traumatized, starving and numb from cold, I set about striking a fire in the pot belly stove commonly found in fishing huts.  The world spins about me as I evaluate my options.  I musts eat soon and I must rest -- or I will die.  I clear the ice fishing hole and cast.  No bites.  I am desperate now.  I cast again.  I hear the agonizing so und of my line snapping.  I dig through my gear and find I have no more tackle.

So I lie here, death slowly overtaking me.  Shortly before fading into darkness, I notice the rifle in the corner.  I take it in my hands.  21 days in the Canadian wilderness I've spent looking for a rifle.  And now as my lifeforce leaves, I hold that which I have sought.

If you should ever find yourself stranded in Canadian wastes and stumble across a fishin hut on bay in the coastal region, don't be surprised to see a wry smile on my frozen face as you pry the rifle from my hands.

And may it serve you well.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The absolute BEST survival game ever created. The immersion is absolutely stunning, there is just something about unreal engine that makes you completely absorbed into the game. The devs are some of the kindest, warmest canadians of all time, who listen intently to their community and are constantly involved with making the game as good as possible. This is the model Early Access game, and don't let heaps like dayZ or H1Z1 put a bad taste in your mouth, because these devs deserve every single bit of money they earn.

The game itself completely breaks the monotony of regular survival games in that there is no end game item, or one that immediately makes the game easier to play. the focus is completely on the gameplay of survival, which is done incredibly well. It isn't the prospect of getting better guns or items that keeps you playing, but just the process of surviving day to day which makes me keep coming back to this game. The graphical style they chose for this game is just phenominal. The artstyle immediately draws you into the world, all without putting extreme intensity on your rig. The ambience and soundtrack are nothing short of perfect, adding to the immersion immensely. Now content-wise, I alone spent upwards of 30 hours just on the first realm, and by the date of this review, there are 5 regions available to explore. I just finished the second region in 20 hours, just in time for them to announce Storymode for 2016. I am sure that if I got back into it, I could easily top 150-200 hours on only sandbox. Now onto bugs, they are very, and I mean VERY rare. I don't even think I ever even got a CTD. In all my playtime I can't recall a single bug or glitch that took me out of the game, or messed with my progress. It is extremely well polished, which you don't get much of for Early Access.

Bottom line, buy this game, but experience wise, I would reccomend you don't play it until 2016, when storymode comes out. I for one really wished I waited on playing it, because apparently Storymode will use many portions of the sandbox maps, which would spoil some exploration experience for me. waiting until storymode will promise you the best experience. Also, from my own personal experience, play the game on Stalker mode (the hardest). This is the only difficulty I've played on, and its one of the most punishing survival experiences out there, besides maybe Stalker Call of Pripyat's MISERY mod. You will be sneaking and fighting for you life every single day, and the rifle doesn't immediately promise to save you. This right here is an excellent game, and a model for all other survival games to take note from.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I am planning a trip to the Great White North soon and purchased Canadian Life Simulator 2016 to prepare me for the experience.  We all know how brutally cold it is in Canada but here are some things I learned from the simulator that you may not know.

1) Canadians may be polite and very good listeners, but that is mostly because they are all dead.
2) Dead Canadians are so polite, you can even store 10kg of food inside their dead bodies.
3) Canadians eat over 7lbs of meat a day, which is probably why they are all dead.
4) If you visit Canada, be sure to take a good multi-vitamin with D and Calcium in it because your bones brittle up just being there. I like to SAVE memories of my travels in video format but in Canada it is customary to sprain a wrist or ankle which promps the simulator to save the memory for you. Convenient but painful.
5) Emergency preparedness training in the US stresses being willing to drink even the water out of the toilet tank in an emergency. In Canada they just drink straight out of the toilet bowl. Try it!
6) Because of free trade and so much Chinese-made garbage flooding the N.American markets, hatchets only last about 50 chops before they break and you have to get another. Likewise, clothing can wear out in just a month.
7) Rabid wolves are a huge problem but since the Canadian wolf has almost as much meat as a 700lb buck, your diet will mostly consist of wolf.

They are so many other differences between Canada and the rest of the world that are illuminated by this simulator, but I don't want to spoil it for you.  Buy it and find out for yourself. You get to loot corpses as well as buildings so it kind of felt like home at least some of the time.

ps- We all know it is ABOOT time for the story mode to come out; I for one can't wait! I hope the devs don't RUSH the story out and call it a TRIUMPH just because they promised a spring release.  Spring comes in July in Canada, EH?

This is a game that works for me on nearly every level. I've spent 25+ years working in the outdoors of the Pacific Northwest so this was like playing in my backyard. I am not going to talk about all the aspects of this game that are great but will highlight a few. Here's the only negatives (?) imo.
-Some players may not be satisified with the art / graphics. Personally I think they work, are simple and quite beautiful.
-There are some oddities with movement over snow drifts / ice that I think are just minor glitches. Why, occassionally, can't I step over a 4 drift on a road?
-The rifle mechanics are a bit confusing. I have owned and used a .303 extensively so I'm not blowing smoke when I say a wolf shot in the chest at 10 feet is
recommended:
going to be knocked off it's feet. EDIT: Since writing this review I have one-shot 23 wolves in a row. Curious...
-Black bears normally do not attack when shot. 95% of the time they run away from the direction the pain originated from. In this game they attack 80% of the time. And they move at the speed of light. They cover 25 yards (the distance I typically shoot them) in about a second. ?? I've been charged 6 times in RL and as dangerous as that was I can tell you: bears are fast BUT not that fast.
That's really all I can say that is remotely negative.
I can tell you that the basic stats of keeping your body temperature up

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've owned this game for several months now and as a member of the Hinterland forums (anyone interested should definitely check the forums out; the community is wonderful plus you can easily stay in the loop of things: http://hinterlandforums.com/ ), I can confidently state that the devs are definitely looking out for and listening to their fan base.  With the most recent update released yesterday, it is very clear that they are taking into consideration every bit of critique, suggestions, and bug reports that the community has to offer, within reason (meaning that anyone who comes up suggesting they add zombies to the game won't be taken seriously, haha).

The game itself is gorgeous.  The art style, ambience, music and everything else is breath-taking!  There's even a thread at the forums where people can post their beautiful screenshots of the game for others to enjoy ;)  And while it is still in alpha, meaning it is guaranteed to have balancing issues and bugs, the team is devoted to ironing out everything as best as possible.  This is probably the most stable alpha I can think of because of this, in fact.

In short, with everything the game has had to offer in the past and now, I will definitely be giving this game many, many more hours of play!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I am in love.
This is it. This is the game I've been looking for. And the best part, it isn't even complete yet.

Let's get started.

I've had this growing interest on survival games for quite a while now, and as such, I've been looking for survival games everywhere to try out, and not more than one or two have captivated me (I could name which, but doesn't feel right on a review of another game). The Long Dark gripped me in, and oh boy, did it grip me tight.

The graphics are amazing, has a great feeling to it, and not too cartoonish, or too realistic. Very well polished.

The soundtrack will keep you interested, and every sound will keep you on your toes, wondering if there's a wolf nearby, or a storm coming. Basically, death is on every corner.

The design itself is just brilliant. I've had the chance to play about 6 sandbox games, and I decided to go in blind"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is hauntingly beautiful and harsh.

In my first two hours I stumbled upon an abandoned dam, explored it, locked myself out of fire escape during a blizzard and nearly froze to death. I literally fell into a Coal mine which saved my life. Burning coal and scavenging supplies off a dead corpse I slowly recovered from Hypothermia. The next day I left the mine seeking food and was chased by a black bear. I found a rifle in an abandoned truck and managed to bring down a deer. The bear showed up again and I warded him off using a flare taken from the miner's corpse. I'm currently holed up in a farmstead on Day 5....

^ None of that is scripted gameplay. It's a wonderful sandbox with just the right amount of pressure, not too stressful, but urgent at times. Some of the locations are downright spooky. Highly recommended.

Early Access Review

One of the few Early Access titles that I'm happy with.

Updates are frequent and carry a lot of great content, it feels like the game will be quite polished when released. As to the title itself - I don't think I've played a game that had such great atmosphere. It's a bit unique, it feels like you're writing your own adventure in the sandbox mode even though there's a story mode planned in development.

I definitely got my money's worth out of it already and I can see much more cold gaming evenings in the future with this one. :-)

Highly recommended for all the survival genre fans but not only those. There's something great about this game that I can't quite put into writing that makes me come back to it now and then and I enjoy it every single time.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is a revamped review of The Long Dark.

Like my Darkest Dungeon review, most early access games will either remain unpolished or the state of the game will become less shape than before.

The Long Dark however is a different story, It's one of those early access games. That patches as you go along, while also providing the developers feedback along the way both good and bad. While there is no story mode, Sandbox mode provides you a glimpse as to what you will be experiencing within story mode once it's released.

You can see just how hardcore" the game is. This is in a sense a true Hardcore Surivial game. Sure people can play it on easy
date: but where is the fun in that? For the true Long Dark experience play on medium or hard. And you can see why The Long Dark remains a very highly postive game. All you have is your senses and wit as you surive the candian wilderness. There is no compass

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Man,I really like this game a lot. I know it's still in Early Access, and there will be a lot of changes still upcoming (the story mode is the one I am most looking to personally), but the game in its current state is still absolutely a ton of fun. You basically crash land in an Arctic area, that was previously inhabited but now abandoned (I expect the reasons for this will be revealed through the story mode). You are woefully unprepared for the weather conditions and have to find better clothing, equipment, food, and water in order to survive another day...and more days beyond that. The environment is reasonably vast. You can definitely explore all the areas the game has to offer, but since you also have to manage your food, sleep, water, and so on...it will take a while or many playthroughs to do so.

The character management is pretty simple and yet clever. You basically monitor your calorie count, which indicates your need for food, your dehydration levels (need for water), your restfulness (as in, you will have to sleep sometime), and your body temperature. All factor in fairly equally as far as your survivability goes. You can find places to rest and recover, can find gear such as can openers, hatchets, etc...to increase your odds. You can also obviously find food (in various state of freshness....the worse condition your food is in, the more likely it is that you will get sick if you eat it). There is medicine to be found, and even some weapons (hatchet, knife, hunting rifle, flares), that will be necessary, as there are also wolves that view you as a tasty morsel, lol. Additionally, there is a pretty intuitive crafting system in the game which allows you to break down, repair, or create items. This becomes very important as the days progress.

So, that just scratches the surface of what this game has to offer. You are fighting hunger, the cold, wolves, dehydration, and weariness in order to survive from one day to the next. The decisions you make will impact how long you survive each day and are very meaningful. Even the most mundane act can have real repercussions.

The game does offer an easy mode so you can get the hang of things before going for full survival. Easy mode features more resources and you can turn off the wolves hostility as well (so they just run away from you instead). It's not a bad way to get your feelers out in this game. However, the game really shines as it is intended...resource management and survival.

I very much recommend this game, even in its early access state. By far my favorite game in the genre presently, with a lot more potential to come on top of what is already provided.

9 out of 10.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is my edited review to commemorate the 1-year mark since The Long Dark (TLD) came out on early access. That's not to say that the game is neglected. Quite the opposite. In the year since the game first hit Steam Early Access there have been 49 major updates and hotfixes. That averages to nearly one update per week for a year. Hinterland (the devs) have done the opposite of abandoning TLD.

The game is beautiful and immersive. The sounds are gorgeous and occasionally bone-chilling. The devs consistently look at what the players request while not doing anything that would compromise their artistic vision for a lovely game. They have said that they are working towards a thoughtful single player, story mode experience, and while TLD is still only available in sandbox alpha everything they do to the game appears to be moving towards that goal.

You can die due to freezing, falling, failing to light a fire, wolf, bear, bear and then wolf, falling off a cliff while running from a wolf, falling through the ice, starving at your campfire, dehydration, exhaustion, food poisoning, dysentery, exhaustion or... you know, stuff and things.

The game wont hold your hand and it's not a quick fix. And I love it. At almost 400 hours of of game time, I'm still not bored with the game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The Long Dark is a magnificent game, but beyond that, it's an engaging and fulfilling experience.

You can put yourself in a frantic push for every minute of survival, or just soak in the aesthetic of the Canadian wilderness.  Each iteration plays and feels different, and the rogue-like style of death makes every decision matter.  The gameplay is exhilarating, the visual style gorgeous, and with regular updates from the good folks of Hinterland Studios, you can't go wrong.  I've enjoyed every minute I've put into this title and look forward to spending many more.  That said, this game isn't perfect.  A range of possible strategies for long term survival exists, but use of the rifle so thoroughly outclasses everything else that gameplay tends to revolve around it.  But this game is still in Early Access and the developers are quite active, so quite a bit can be changed and honed.

The best part of this game though, and the reason I play, is that infinite survival is impossible.  That may seem a strange statement, and I know some people would love to see the game changed on that point, but hear me out.  Every time you begin, you know you will die.  There is nothing that can be done about that impermanence, about death.  Now, you can choose to curl into a ball, to let life pass you by, or you can choose to live, to fight, to find beauty in the harsh landscape and nobility in yourself.  I've never played with mechanics that so powerfully counterbalanced realistic nihilism with idealistic determination, and so I congratulate Hinterland on their work.

That got a little philosophically dramatic, but I stand by it.  Overall, I deeply enjoy this game and look forward to watching its progression, and offer my sincerest recommendation to potential buyers.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

An absolutely outstanding and true-to-life survival experience. Few other games share the superb atmosphere, realistic weather, gorgeous art style and the feeling of your survival being down to you alone. This game really makes you feel like you are in the moment. The setting is perfect. Both the danger and beauty of nature is fully realised thanks to glorious sound design and a lovely painting-like graphics, allowing you to appreciate both the majesty and harshness around you. Your character, barely holding their constitution together as an evening blizzard begins to tear away at their homeostasis, faces a truly overlooked factor in most survival games: the elements.

If you want the most real-feeling survival experience out there, I can't recommend this enough. This is Early Access done right. The Canadian wild commands respect, which you will learn first hand.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I used to play this game when it first came out. I died. All. The. Time. And the world was much much smaller - 1 map to be exact. I liked the concept, but got bored and frustrated (frustored? borstrated?) and quit and haven't looked at it since.

When it went on sale recently, my husband pointed it out to me as the type of game I usually like and asked if I owned it. I said I had and mumbled something about not bothering... He brought it up again the other day, asking if I had seen if there had been any changes or updates since I played it last.

So I cracked it open...and have been obsessed with it for days on end. I had to apologize to hubby for advising him against getting it when it was on sale. But it's on his radar now. His only disappointment is that it is only single player and we can't survive together (we play 7 Days to Die together extensively, for example, as we favor co-op survival).

The game is Alpha, so is under active development and some of the mechanics and balance may be off in some players' opinions. For myself, I find it enjoyable, and have found that the addition of the new maps, and three different game modes/difficulty levels, have given this game whole new life and an opportunity for gamers of many stripes to enjoy playing. If you are not a fan of inventory management as a primary element, then you may not like this game. Your inventory is weight based, food and tools spoil over time, and you are battling the elements and mother nature (wolve and bears, oh my!) for survival. A large chunk of the tension of survival in this game hinges on having to make tough choices about what to carry with you and what to leave behind, what to repair or to scrap and harvest the resources, what to use now or try and preserve for later (with the chance it will degrade beyond reasonable use in the meantime). It's a complex combination of factors to consider, which I find compelling, but is essentially inventory management. So just be aware.

Also, this game will NOT offer you running around, banging out shiny items on the toolbench, hack n' slash melee, or shoot 'em up guns blazing. This game requires a lot of patience. Resources must be gathered over time, hides and wood cured before fashioning into needed clothes and tools. There are no endless bullet stashes, or a promise of ever finding a gun. But if you find a gun and bullets, you might have two rounds to your name and they are precious--you can't make any more bullets, and your gun will wear out eventually. Tools and clothing degrade with use and must be repaired often to maintain them. If your hatchet breaks, you can't make another. Animals are predatory and will tear your precious clothing and cause bleeding and infections--I need not tell you medicines are scarce and also lose efficacy/degrade with time, and natural remedies can be hard to procure. Eating spoiled food can give you severe food poisoning, leaving you bedridden for hours on end. Frequent blinding blizzards can turn you around, leaving you lost and struggling to stay warm enough. And if you can't find adequate wind shielding you can't start a fire to save your life (literally). Running will tire you out, make you hungry and thirsty faster, and resources are limited. If you're too tired and come across a hungry wolf, you won't be able to run away, so you preserve your energies should you need them in a pinch. Getting across this desolate, snowy terrain can be slow and even boring at times. Funny enough, it adds to the atmosphere for me that you must trudge, with purpose and restraint, toward your next shelter because to rush it risks death.

The graphics are lovely--something between a watercolor painting and paper cutouts. The ambient sounds and occasional music really add to the atmosphere and are not at all intrusive. In fact, keep your ears pricked because you may be able to hear that storm whipping up. When you are indoors, you can hear the shutters rattle, indicating a blizzard has swept through, so stay inside if you want to live. Even the quietest snarl or howl can indicate a wold is on your tail, so drop some meat as a decoy and get outta there fast. Make no mistake, the weather is a character itself in this game, and you want to get to know her voice.

I look forward to seeing how this game evolves. As of this review, Story Mode has not been released. They have been promising it would drop by the end of 2015, which is coming up fast, so I am keeping my eyes peeled for some storied content in the near future. In the meantime, the sandbox mode is more than entertaining, and I recommend survivalist gamers give it a try.

reviewText:
Product received for free

Early Access Review

I don't even know where to begin with this game.

I'd heard about it a while back and I saw it, thought it looked kinda interesting, and then never bothered picking it up. My friend recently gifted it to me and if I could I would have been willing to spend up to $45 or so for the experience this game tosses at you. The only thing I can say now is that I regret not picking it up sooner. It just hits me in such a way that I can't explain. Everytime I'm walking slowly down a road and there's nothing but cars to the side and burnt houses around, and that ♥♥♥♥ing guitar picks up I just get so into it and feel like I'm actually a survivor.

The Long Dark is a gem among early access games and deserves so much attention. I knew this as soon as I'd put in a good hour. Let me start off by saying that the immersion that this game delivers is phenomenal. It has a great tone and world design to be used for story telling. While the game offers no tutorial and this can be a positive or negative thing, I personally loved it. All it did was make me genuinely want to learn about the game and the world itself more, and as I did, I felt myself get better at it and feel more confident about surviving. The longest time I've survived so far on a character is 30 days counting and there's been numerous points throughout that timespan in which I thought I was going to die and got anxious doing something because I genuinely felt like I was the person wandering through the world. Each time I spotted a bear in the distance or a pack of wolves, I felt like they were a genuine threat and therefore considered my options. Do I try to sneak around them? Do I head in the opposite direction? Do I have ammo or a weapon to fend them off just in case? This doesn't even just count with the wildlife but the environment as well which I cannot stress just how important in a survival game. Every time I saw a side road leading off of the main highway I seriously considered my options. Did I have enough food and water with me in case it's a dead end? Do I have enough daylight left to make it back to the main road if there's nothing down this way? Will I have enough firewood and tinder to create a fire if need be? When I would be staying in a cabin for the day due to a blizzard, I would genuinely consider my options then as well and think to myself if I had enough food to survive the night before I would be able to scavenge for more supplies? The game pushes you to think about these options in a way that I've never felt another survival game do before.

The game does an incredible job at atmosphere and aesthetic and is downright GORGEOUS from every early sunrise and darkening sunset to each howling blizzard or each bright sunny day. The more you're willing to immerse yourself into believing you're truly surviving in the world, the better job it does at delivering a truly special experience. There was a point in which I'd found a safe and when I was trying to crack the code, I actually leaned in on my monitor as though I'd be able to hear the clicks better without realizing it. When there's a blizzard in the game and all you can hear is lonesome ambient guitar music playing and the wind howling in you ear, you feel genuinely alone and feel cold. When you enter a cabin and all you can hear is the wind beating against the house and the creaks of wood echoing, it creates a sense of fear and paranoia because you know that there were people who are probably long dead that used to live here. When you’re walking through a cave and all you can hear is the vast echoes of your footsteps against stone and the hiss of your flare, you feel genuinely cautious.The fact that the game is able to pull this off is absolutely stunning. And above all, you genuinely feel like you're a survivor in this new world. You begin to grow attached to your character and genuinely care for them and begin to wonder if you can truly survive the wilderness. The game does an excellent job at small little stories you can pick up on when you're not expecting it. For example you can find a cave in which there's a small campfire with food beside it, or you can be walking through the woods and find a frozen corpse of a man with an axe next to a deer corpse, insisting he died of hypothermia while trying to get food. It's all of these little things that come together that truly help create an enjoyable experience and make me want to get out there and explore the world in front of me. When you walk through a town you begin to really have thoughts of, I wonder what happened to the people that lived here. I wonder what the story of the people who made it out is" and it's like that for nearly every place.

The only two downsides to this game for me at least are there's been few bugs in which I would climb a rock and randomly sprain my ankles or wrists for no reason and it's pretty immersion breaking. And secondly
date: there's no randomly generated maps and all loot spawns are always the same regardless of if you were to make a new character or not. If they were to add randomly generated loot and maps
recommended: I could play this game for literal hundreds of hours not to say I already plan to
hoursPlayed: but it would definitely help with the game in the long run and keep me coming back to it.\n\nIn short
voteText:
this game is truly something special for the person that wants to immerse themselves in a world where they feel like they're truly a survivor in the wilderness with nothing but their own decisions on what's best to help you survive the long dark.
TL;DR

Pros-
Breathtakingly beautiful
Incredible sound design
Is a true to it's roots "you versus the wilderness" game
Downright one of the most immersive games I've ever played
Decent amount of replayability with new characters you can create and difficulties to choose from
Devs actually seem to care about this game

Dependent on you-
No tutorial
Pretty unforgiving

No story mode as of this review

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Started the Sandbox Alpha. Pitch black. Wolf growls. Die of blood loss at 18 in-game minutes. 10/10

---

I am a Kickstarter backer and active video maker for the game and this Sandbox Alpha is something you rarely see. You get attached to every playthrough and want to live, explore and survive as long as you can.
Dying is unforgiving and it will make you annoyed but you will start again and not get bored because the game wants you to try again and survive. The key point here is how long you survive, not do you survive, because you will die no matter what. Bugs get fixed, new features get added, bugs get fixed again and you just keep on trying to survive.

The art is magnificent, the sound is magnificent and recently, the loading times are magnificent as well. The harvesting mechanic will need more work as it is a bit unrealistic(you harvest the same amount of cloth/leather no matter the item condition). Repairing works relatively great so far.

The UI got a very sleek update and you can choose between a male and female voice in the Sandbox, both being the leading male and female voice actors from Mass Effect.

Good game, good devs. Alan's cave sucks.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The Long Dark is a sandbox survival game if you don't know already but it isn't like the others, there are no zombies or mutated creatures you have to look out for and there are no full out automatic weapon action sequences nor is there really any action game features for the most part. But that is what makes this game amazing and unique. Nature is your enemy. This game does a damn good job at nature being your enemy. And it does it whilst making it fun and interesting. Striving for a (for the most part) realistic wilderness survival experience, it suceeds.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
It does so all with a beautiful, breathtaking soundtrack and stunning and simplistic visuals.
I highly recommend this game to anyone really.
Upon starting the game up I knew I was going to love it. And oh boy do I love it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

In the frozen wasteland of the formerly prosperous country of Canada, you alone must survive The Long Dark. This winter seems endless, so it's not a matter of if you survive it; it's a matter of how long. The Long Dark is a game developed and published by Hinterland Studio, focusing primarily on surviving in Canada after a climate disaster. Right now it's in early access and the story mode isn't complete, but its sandbox mode gives more than enough to talk about.

The objective of the game is simple: you're abandoned out in the middle of nowhere in a random location and you must find a way to survive. The world is freezing and you must find food, shelter, water and keep yourself going for as long as you possibly can. While this sounds pretty straightforward, it isn't because there are plenty of factors in the game that can kill you and if you're unfamiliar with the game, and when starting out you're going to have a bad time.Full Preview[www.noobfeed.com]

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis is one of the best survival games I've ever played.  I was apprehensive about it at first because of the cartoon graphics, but after only about 15 or 20 minutes of play, I was hooked.  Anyone who liked The Road by Cormac McCarthy will totally groove on this game.  The best thing about it is that it's well balanced and believeable; meaning that if you do something stupid, you die, but if you are careful, you can survive for quite a long time.  Much like I'd imagine a real life apocalyptic survival situation to be.  The crafting isn't extremely difficult, but not easy or guaranteed when you get what you need to do it.  Another plus is that it isn't glitchy, like a lot of other early access games.  The controls are intuitive and follow industry standards, so you don't need to spend any time going through some boring tutorial.  In short, if you are looking for a survival game that you can get into quickly, presents a real, but achieveable challenge and never crashes, well this is it.
