reviewText:
Early Access Review

Excellent, exciting game that will push towards the edge of survival, your first life will consist of you blindly navigating the light uninhabited national park in the Canadian wilderness blindly. with nothing but a box of matches, first aid supplies, and the chloths on your back. you must trek this land, finding remnants of human civilization and clench the limited items you find for just to survive another day of life. pushing you to decide life and death decisions, do you stay in a cabin you found and face starvation, or hike through a blood freezing blizzard hoping to find something, anything edible. Although you will find nothing but the frozen bodies of other human beings, you are not alone, the howls of wolves, just as hungry and desperate as you are will send chills down you spine as they see you as prey

As of alpha v128 there is only one map, and once you know where all the locations are at via the railroad tracks surviving becomes much easier, looking forward to the possibility of a new map that is complete wilderness and be able to craft things living off the land, and crafting in general, and maybe start with nothing but a Hatchet, then it'll be the game equivalent to a book by Gary Paulson, plane crash and all!!!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

What is The Long Dark?
The Long Dark is first-person open world exploration-survival game that occurs in the canadian wilderness after a global disaster.
Your job is to survive as long as you can by gathering food and drink that you can find in the various cabins and huts scattered around the map.

What am I surviving from?
Nature and all its threats (What threats? -> Animals such as wolves & bears, and the most natural threat of them... the cold)

Is there a crafting system?
There is a crafting system, but as of now its quite simplistic.
To craft items you'll have to find a workbench. (Some location spoilers: Trapper's Homestead, Camp Office, Carter Hydro Dam, Forestry Lookout (Mystery Lake) - The Fishing Camp, Quonset Gas Station, (Coastal Highway) - Pleasant Valley Farmstead (Pleasant Valley)) Workbenches are used to craft clothing, weapons and first aid, items such as coats, a bow, arrows, mittens, etc.

Cooking system
To cook, you must start a fire either outside or inside cabins/huts at stoves.
You can also melt snow to water and boil it.

First aidThis is needed when you have food poisoning or a wolf/bear has attacked you and caused injuries.
To use first aid you'll have to press tab (default button) and click the medical kit in the selection menu that will open.
Afterwards you can choose which injury you would like to treat first.

Fatigue and ColdThese can be seen by pressing tab (default button) in the bottom right of the menu that opens up.FATIGUE:[/b]
Your fatigue will be increased after performing various actions (such as crafting, harvesting, etc.) once the bar on the tab-menu is completely filled you will no longer have the ability to sprint, (untill you have slept and you are no longer exhausted) in extreme cases your vision will become blurry and condition will decline untill you have rested, theres also a slight chance of dying by fatigue.

COLD:[/b] Cold consists of Air Temperature, Windchill, Insulation of clothing and Wind protection of clothing.
Your overall temperature is the air temperature plus windchill minus the effects of clothing on windchill and temperature. As the cold bar on the tab-menu you will get warnings and verbal complaints of the cold. If the bar completely fills up you will start losing condition which can lead to death if not looked after.[/list]

ClothingYou can craft clothing and find clothing.
Repairing clothing requires cloth and a sewing kit and can be done while accessing your inventory, selecting the piece of clothing that needs to be repaired and pressing action"
date:
this will bring up a menu saying harvest and repair. It speaks for itself that you'll have to click repair in order to repair the piece of clothing. Harvesting clothing will give you cloth.

Thanks for reading trough my review.
Please leave comments if you think I should have added even more :)

~ Hobo"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

With story mode soon to be released, I thought I might actually sit down and write a review for this game.

The Long Dark is the best survival game I've played in years. There's a certain sense of desperation that you sometimes feel when you're playing this game - you might be out in the cold, with your character's condition steadily decreasing, and you hear a howl. So you look around, and on the crest of a nearby ridge is a dark silhouette. It's a wolf, and suddenly the situation becomes more dire. Your character moves slowly when their stamina is drained, or if they are injured. Sometimes escaping from predators is not as easy as it sounds or seems. The elements are deadly too - navigating through fog or a snowstorm can be a challenge, if you aren't prepared.

The world of the Long Dark is a lonely world indeed. Searching through abandoned houses is always interesting - while searching for clothing you might stumble across the empty bedroom of a child, toys still scattered across the floor. You'll walk along lonely coastlines and across frozen lakes, through deserted settlements and climb up windswept mountains. When exploring new areas, you never really know what you might discover. The frozen bodies of those who could not survive serve as a warning and reminder of the post-disaster world the Long Dark takes place in.

Every major update adds something new and interesting to find. I look forward to the upcoming story mode. Thank you for this game, Hinterland. Thank you.

10/10

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI bought The Long Dark as an Early Access title in December 2014, because I liked the overall setting (Winter, Single-Player, Survival), the independent developer Hinterland introduced themselves as experienced game developers (veterans of the industry"
date: "AAA titles") and the goal was to develop the first episode of a narrative story in about 3 months time
recommended: while offering a Sandbox as a playable testing environment in the meantime.\n\nThe atmosphere and setting of the game are really great. The artistic style is consistent
hoursPlayed: fitting and most of all very pleasing. Hinterland have taken some liberties in portraying wildlife and occasionally favored game design over realism
voteText:
which I find is nothing to complain about.

But 18 months and three failed release dates later it is still in Early Access and without any released episodes of the announced Story Mode. It's difficult to tell how long it'll be until Story Mode is completed because Hinterland have stopped giving new release dates and engaged in a rigorous "it's done when it's done" approach.

There are quite a lot of people who seem to be fine with playing just the Sandbox for all this time
helpfulPercent: stating that they don't want or care for the Story Mode. However
votesHelpful: I actually bought this for the narrative story and Sandbox simply doesn't hold any interest for me anymore. You can't actually do that many different things in the current game and just trying to survive for one more day without achieving anything else than surviving for one more day is simply not my cup of tea. This is especially true since many of the in-game activities are represented by abstract progress bars that simly show the passage of time. You never actually see your character repairing
votesTotal: crafting
votesFunny: eating
commentsCount: harvesting or cooking. The maps are also static
column16: so after some time you know the environment like the back of your hand.\n\nAfter having failed the most recent release window Hinterland published a roadmap for the future development in April 2016
column17: containing development items categorized into "0 - 6 months"
column18: "6 - 12 months" and "12+ months".\nUnfortunately
column19: Story Mode is not a part of that roadmap.\n\nThe roadmap was recently updated
column20: after 2 months had passed. It seems they are trying to put 4 of 27 items of the "0 - 6 months" category into the June update. The remaining items are in the same category as in April
column21: meaning what was thought to be 6 months away in April is still 6 months away in June.\nSo instead of one big change to the anticipated release date once a year
column22: there are now several small ones. It might look better because instead of announcing a change to the planned release date
column23: they are simply not updating the planned duration until completion
column24: but the effect is still the same. With this approach I'm afraid the roadmap will take years to reach anything close to completion and Story Mode may not be coming for quite some time.\n\nWhile it might sound great that a developer is actually delaying a product because "it's not ready yet"
column25: I cannot recommend an Early Access title that keeps postponing its release on the sole premise of always needing more time.\nSadly
column26: it seems The Long Dark is following the poor tradition of broken promises and seemingly endless development phases that plague Early Access."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Ohh it's creepy...there's this wolf see, Fluffy, and long story short he randomly appears in the dam (baffles many people how he got in, aside from possible window entrance) but he tends to be the #1 cause of death for players.

BUT, there's a bigger story than that...

I've concluded he's a ghost wolf, died in this dam during an accident while working the night shift. He was security, and his life was pretty good. He had a wife, couple kids, and good health. He enjoyed playing tennis at the local YMCA and building snowwolves with his kids on weekends. But one night while patrolling, one of the valves blew off it's place when to much pressure built up in a damaged pipe, and it got Fluffs (as his friends called him) right in his head. He held out for a little, but unfortunately there was too much internal bleeding. He was a dedicated security officer, and in his death he believes he's still on that night shift. Looking for trespassers, taking justice into his hands against thieves. We rage out on him, I do myself, but is he not doing his job? Is he not more dedicated to his work than we are to surviving? Fluffs, wherever you are...please let me hear you coming so I can bolt out the door X(

Anywho...Good game, though I recommend it despite many frustrations I do warn that it's early access and thus frustrations will be common. If you don't like that, throw it on your wishlist and give it some time.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

UPDATE (5/31/15): As per the developer's comment below, I revisited this title, and even though they claim that many of my 'Cons' have been addressed, I did not find this to be the case - the review still stands as-is.

Details for haters: Menus are still clunky (a few new ones were added, but its the same format). It is still a numbers game, and you still magically know all of your calories at any given time. Maybe the weather numbers were removed (I don't remember seeing them this time). To be fair - I did not melee fight any wolves - I killed some with a rifle, though.

I got my money's worth out of this and all, but to tell you the truth, I am just not feeling it. ITS SOOO CLOSE to something I could love, but yet so far. I love the idea of surviving the environment, and not zombies, but this just feels too tedious to be much fun. The graphics are also amazing, and in fact, probably the high point. It really does make you feel like you are out there all alone.

Pros
1. Graphics are killer good
2. Atmosphere is very submersive, best I've seen for this kind of game
3. Fresh idea that is welcome in survival games (no horror or zombies, I'm in!)

Cons
1. Menus are terrible - all weird drop down boxes and statistics, and terrible for controller support to-boot
2. This is too much of a 'numbers-game' where you have to fight counting calories and how much stove time you have left
3. THINGS ARE SO COUNTER-INTUITIVE - you can dehydrate yourself to death while you sleep. I mean c'mon. I could go on and on for this point, but those that have played it certainly know what I am talking about
4. The wolves are actual enemies that leave something to be desired for me. The combat is really silly, and is basically just spam-clicking
5. You magically have statistics on the weather (degrees, etc.), and actual calories consumed, but do not have these numbers for other things

Overall, it just feels too clunky and tedious to keep me coming back. I also started to really dislike the developers on the forums. They are *too* involved - they should stick to reading the stickied threads for ideas or troubleshooting. Once they get into bickering, they only stand to lose on a long enough timeline.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First of all, I am going to admit I do have a bias on this game already because living in Northern Canada and getting a game on surviving in it already makes it 10/10 for me. But, I digress and will try and keep this fair.

The Long Dark was recommended to me by a friend and I have to say, I am not disappointed by it. I loved the artstyle from the get-go because it's minimalistic and aesthetically pleasing but it may not work for everyone. For example, the buildings have an almost comic-book style to them which I enjoy but your mileage may vary. As for the actual gameplay, it's very easy to get into - very straight forward on what you have to do - but it gets very difficult very fast.

For example, I kept assuming you need a fire going when you rest so you don't freeze to death (using my real world logic) but this seems not to be the case. Within the first day I used all my accelerant and tinder plugs and no idea what to do after. I went out to forage, got hit with a blizzard and died. Cue clucking of tongue and an annoyance to make it past the first day.

But I admit, once you get the hang of it, it does become fun. Some people may not find calorie counting and foraging wood and lighting fires to be all that exciting mind you. Which this game has so if you want something more fast-paced, this probably won't do it for you. But for me, taking notes on what I'm doing, planning for the day or even just poking around outside for a minute and running back to shelter is fun. The fact that it's located in the wilderness of Canada - a place used rarely in games - just makes it better and I cannot wait for the Story Mode.

Overall, again, I give it 10/10. The game is getting more content as the days go on so that's a big plus as it has changed from when I first downloaded it.

Also, Jennifer Hale. I mean... that right there. Alone.

Try again  Freezing. Starving, Die while cooking food.

This game never ceases to amaze me.  The art style is beautiful and really gives the game its atmosphere.  Ever been out when the snow is falling lightly on the ground and you feel the crunch of the snow beneath your feet?  That is the feeling this game gives you.  It is the ultimate game in atmosphere.  The wildlife is dangerous but not all that common so most of your time is spent just surviving and trudging through snow in the beautiful wilderness.  This game is man vs. nature, not man vs. enemy. Also, permadeath in this game is awesome.  The rare encounter with animals makes it so much more terrifying since if you die, you die for good.

Early Access Review

Ok, so it's been arround 1 year since i got tLD. And at last, it runs like it should.
So i can finally go back on a previous review i did and can actually recommend the game now.

The concept is pretty neat, different from most survival games since literally every other one includes zombies or similar types of enemies. In Long Dark the worst thing to fear is nature itself and cold and that causes a pretty good sense of urgency to get food/calories and make players weight the possible risks/rewards of going out looking for food or materials.

However, the character does seem to get tired excruciatingly quickly... Almost seems like you need go sleep every 5 minutes... It's a bit of a nuisance. And so is the walking speed, feels like a snail could easily leave us eating dust.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you like survival games, you'll love this one.
You have to survive alone, in the cold of the north canadian, in an abandonned city were wolves roam looking for fresh meat.

The game is providing a really great immersion, cool graphics (not fancy technical graphics, but I like the art :)) and fun gameplay mecanics.
I really like how Hinterland tried to do something not too much realistic, so the game keeps his fun. I think they found a great middle ground between fun mecanics and realistic mechanics. I like how I can track a wounded beast with its blood trail (for the realistic detail side) and how I can read how many minutes my fire camp will be up (less realistic but you won't rage because your fire wasn't strong enough and you didn't know).

Also, this game is continually improved, and Hinterland's team is doing a really great job at delivering patches, hotfixes, and  reading community requests without destroying the spirit of their game.

Keep up the good work Hinterland ! The game is already awesome as it is, I can't wait to see the story mode :)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It is an awesome single player exploration game with the probably most beautiful, great, and creative art style a game has ever used. It has realistic light and shadow effects combined with cartoony textures and modelling and some athmospheric music in the background and awesome athmosphere, it would almost be a feel-good, cheery game if it was not for the apocalyptic-wolfs-are-going-to-eat-you setting and the occasional frozen corpses that have a nom taken out of their arms.
9/10, and I have not even discovered much yet. It is so awesome, just to walk along a railtrack with a snowstorm breezing onto you and the sky and area being dark gray-ish at just 12pm, enjoying the athmosphere before hearing a wolf howl and growl on you and noticing you do not have any flares left thats where you get scared and run for your life .
I hope you nerds will find a place in your heart to buy it and support the developer.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The Long Dark is a great game which has a funny way of sneaking up on you. Right now only the sandbox mode is available so your objective is to survive for as long as possible by gathering food, wood, tools, clothing, etc. and by STAYING AWAY FROM WOLVES. Seriously, don't get near those things, not even with your rifle. You'll get bitten to death. Oh, and don't go out at night, you'll get bitten to death IN THE DARK.

All of these survival stunts take place in a beautifully portrayed Canadian winter, and I mean this seriously. The developers haven't gone for photorealistic graphics but for a more impressionist approach with vibrant colours and more simple shapes. The game has made me go WOAH!" several times because the landscape was so beautiful that you forget the hunger and the wolves for some brief seconds.

There are some very interesting game mechanics that are the core of the game. Temperature is of the utmost importance so you are able to rip some clothes in order to improve others
date: skin animals to get leather or fur
recommended: etc. All of these actions are done inmediatly in real time but require an investment of in-game time (Which can be optimized by using the right tools) and that's the main point of the game: Invest your time wisely because your hunger
hoursPlayed: thirst and fatigue are going up continuosly.\n\nMy favourite mechanic of all is the climate. Let's say you're save in a cabin but then you need to go outside for resource gathering

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Update: I hate writing negative reviews, and as soon as this gets out of early access, I'll do my damndest to give it a good review!


It's really close to being awesome, but some horrifically stupid hangups get in the way:

- It is nearly impossible to defend yourself from wolves over the long term. In real life, I would grab a big stick and use it. Not in The Long Dark; no, you can't use your axe or find any intelligent way to ward the wolves off after your flares run out.

- I survived for nearly a month and only found half of the ingredients needed to make a bow and arrow. It's ridiculous that you need to find 2 different types of rare tree saplings just to make a simple bow. How about making a spear instead, or even just a pointy stick?

- Clothes degrade at least ten times faster than they do in real life.

- Thirst accumulates faster than it does in real life.

- Hunger accumulates faster than it does in real life (but is much closer to accuracy than thirst, and it drains accurately while sleeping)


However, the temperature balance seems polished and well-implemented, and the ambiance and art style are nice. The main complaint is that the constant threat of wolves is not offset by the common-sense ability to pick up and use a freaking stick, or maybe not be so damn picky about your choice of bow and arrow materials (alternately, maybe maple and birch saplings shouldn't be rarer than the lost city of Atlantis).

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThe Long Dark is the pinnacle of survival games. No zombies, no radiation, just you and nature. Ahead of you lies the vast Canadian landscape, where the only thing you can rely on to survive is yourself. The game creates a sense of pure terror as you struggle to survive, discovering the bodies of previous souls lost to this harsh land. As you hunt, fish, and gather other food and resources in the snow, you begin to see what really drives humanity forward, and that, is instinct.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I am inside the Forrest Lookout.  I have enough meat to last for a little bit, and some water as well.  I am out of firewood, though, and the temperature outside feels like -56 degrees. So, what's the plan? Do I go out and start my day exploring and gathering some wood? Or should I hunker down another few hours and see if this weather passes... one choice or the other could mean death.

A true enough survival game with no visible bugs, but limited content.  It is relatively slow paced, which makes it more relaxing and calming until the wolf jumps out from behind you and tries to kill you. This game is quite enjoyable for what it is currently: a sandbox survival game with a pretty small, static map.  Your spawn is randomized, but the map is static. So, you will get used to it pretty quickly.

The game features a lot of ways to die and is actually quite hard.  This is a good thing.  There are no zombies and/or other players to kill you, and it is still pretty hard. A lot of people are saying it is too hard and unrealistic.  In some ways, perhaps, but in other ways not so.  I think it is actually more realistic than people think because very few people have actually experienced any type of arctic survival before.

I actually enjoy the game as it is.  A lot of people are calling for base building, MP, PvP, etc, to make yet another Rust/DayZ clone.  I am looking forward to the devs bringing out the SP story mode and additional maps, which already seem to be promised or in the works.

Overall, a good alpha SP game that I hope stays SP and just adds more variety to the maps and adventures/stories in the future.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The Long Dark is a FPS game that really secludes you and makes you really feel what your character is feeling. From scavenging, hunting, exploring, and even building fires, you will really find this game beautiful with an amazing aspect of being in a winter waste land with no zombies but having to face Mother Nature. The more you play this you will really get into it and become better. My only huge problem is that you can get cold very fast.
--------------------
Pros:
*Very nice sandbox
*Amazing worlds
*Lots of things to find
*Beautiful aspects
*Really realistic
*Huge lands to explore
*Can do anything
---------------------
Cons:
*Have to unlock new worlds by exploring hugely
*Cold meter gets annoying at times
*Have to scavenge a lot at start
*No story mode yet
*Stamina bar takes a long time to regen
*Hard to craft items at start
--------------------
Don't let the cons get over you, though.
Get this game if you really want to experience a game that embraces you in a survival aspect of no zombies but only Mother Nature herself as the main problem.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I woke up in a clearing, just ice and snow around me. A few rocks here and there. I walked up a hill to get my barings to be met with a spectacular view of the surise. That's when some of the snow collapsed and I fell about 4-5 metres and sprained my ancle as a result. It didn't seem like a big deal at the time. I limped my way over some more hills then found a hut with an energy bar in it. I hadn't eaten in so long so it felt good to have something in my stomach. I continued on my way. Still limping since I didn't have the first aid to heal myself and I needed to find some supplies before I stopped for the night.

I then found myself in a blizzard. The wind was beating down on me as I limped toward more endless snow. Each time I saw a rock I pictured it as a hut and got a glimps of hope only to see it as it truely was. A mirrage, the illusion of savior.

I was getting cold, real cold when I finally found my way out of the blizzard and to a small clearing when I could make out an old train track and a building in the distance. That's when I heard it. A slight grumble of a wolfs breath. I looked around slowly, feeling around my pockets for a knife I had found early that day. But I was too slow, everything went slow when I saw the wolf pounce towards me. All I could think about was how funny it was that I had survived a fall from a cliff, starvation, dehydration, getting stuck in a blizzard with no fire wood. I survived it all only to die here when my salvation was in sight.

The wolf burried its teeth in my neck and for once since all of this happened I was finally warm. My blood felt like a hot shower as it covered my body. The wolf jumped off me and I rolled over. Tryign to stand. Red blood tainting the beauty of the plain white snow.

My vision was blurry then it all when black. No more hunger, no more cold. Just warmth.


I did all of that surrounded by some of the most beautiful art I've seen in a game for a very long time. 10/10 would bang.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I just want to say thank you to the developers. Its obvious you care alot about your product.
I died 5 times in the first 3 hours, mostly getting myself stuck in snowstorms. It takes a good deal of planning to make sure your not going to get stuck out in the snow, or attacked by wolves in the dark.
When you've finally found the rifle or rounds for it, downing a buck is the most satisfying feeling. No worrying about sustenance for at least a week, if you ration. Make sure to build a fire nearby though, or by the time your done harvesting it you'll be frozen stiff.
Im not gonna make a long review but I'd say this is one of the most rewarding games you could play. Also it's a better hunting simulator than most hunting games on the market now.
I've played around 70 hours, and have not made it past 11 days.

4/5 needs a little work on the crafting but overall a very atmospheric, realistic experience.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis is an amazing game and is really worth the money. The initial scramble for resources is thrilling but the struggle to maintain survival when all loot has been used is also hard. The different gamemodes allow for suited gameplay, whether you wish to simply explore the map (Pilgrim), become equal parts hunter and survivor (Voyageur) or be a hardcore survivalist (Stalker) there is a gamemode for everybody. If there were to be one problem with the game it would be that often after about 20 minutes of gameplay the game freezes and I am forced to lose my progress. Hopefully the developers will look into this and fix it but otherwise a really, really great game!!!

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nOne of the great early access games to come out in recent times for me.  There is only sandbox mode right now with a story mode to come. The game is challenging as you have to plan out your every move.  Do I hunker down here for the night without food?  Or do I take the risk pushing on through a snow storm?  If you like survival games, then buy this one for sure.  It's not a game I play all the time, but everytime I pick it up for a few days/week I enjoy it greatly 10/10.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

When I started the game for the first time, I was amazed. Beautiful art work, the sound of wind blowing... It was beautifuly clear day, I had no idea where to go, so I just walked by some frozen river. I arrived to Mystery lake, started to look around. I ran to the Camp office, set up base, and because snow storm started outside, I went to sleep... Next day, I somehow arrived to the Trapper's homestead. Entered it... YAAAAY!!! There was a rifle, bullets, safe wich contains more bullet, knife... The best loot what I can have in game. Looted the place and went back to the base camp. After few days surviving,  I ran out of supplies, so i went scavenging... Found a dam... Entered the dam... Started looting it... Then suddenly wolf jumped on me, I had no idea how to defend my self 'cause it never before happend to me, so I was just pressing all possible buttons... I died... Survive 8 days and 18 minutes... What a great expirience!

PLUS:
+ Amazing art work
+ Amazing sounds & music.
+ Only you and mother nature
+ NO ZOMBIES
+ Permadeath, you really need to try hard to survive
+ Tons of loot
+ Big world to explore

MINUS:
- Gets repetitive after you get used to it
- Waiting. All actions you do is just wainting. Forage wood? waiting... Harvest meat? waiting... Craft an item? waiting... This really needs improvement.
- To be completely honest, there is nothing to do after you have tons of supplies and gun: wake up, go hunt, kill a deer, cook it's meat, boil water, go to sleep... Wake up, eat, drink, sleep... Day by day, until you ran out of meat, then you have to go and kill another deer, and agin...

After all, This game is beautiful piece of art. It is fun, but as I said, it gets repetitive after some time. I recommend.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've noticed that the survival game genre has flourished in the last several years with many indie games coming along. I think part of that is the Zombie fad, but not entirely. There is a harder core sort of gamer that wants gritty realism whose not satisfied with guns guns guns.

Welcome to The Long Dark.

This game will kick your ♥♥♥. If your stupid, you die, that simple. If you /think/ you have a chance at survival.

I love the premise of the game, the sun sends along a gift and turns off all electrical things on Earth. You, a bush pilot, manage to land your plain in the remote Canadian wilderness. Now what? Now you survive, or you die, a lot, before you start to learn just how gritty and realistic this game gets.

Personally I love that, don't cut me slack, I've done god mode enough its boring.

The graphics are stylized and really lovely, theres an artistic flair here not found in other games in this genre. The sound is good, not spectacular. It will make you feel powerful lonely at times, and thats sort of the point.

After four attempts I managed to survive 20 days and am working on deerskin boots. The crafting and repair system is good, you have to find items needed and a place to do the work, and the game doesn't drown you in items. Sure, at first you'll find lots of candy bars and cans of beans, but they only last so long and you have to start thinking long term. Also, fire making skills are key, as would be the case in RL.

If you wan't a casual game, this is NOT for you.

If you wan't a game you can chew on, pitbull like, just to make it past a week...this is for you.

System Specs: CPU: i7 4790K, Graphics: GTX 770 Mem: 16 gigs

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Awesome Game, Something i have been waiting for a long time. The most interesting thing in it for me is how well they implemented fighting for survival. Other survival games(Early Acces especialy) focus more on building stuff and fighting mutants/zombies/whatever while this one is more realistic. It simply focuses on our basic needs like food/water/body temp. and really makes it challenging while in others its only an addition.
Pros(+)
- Finally good game on Unity Engine(both graphics and sound)
- Surprisingly innovative
- Low price compared to other survival games
- Quite immersive (especially when u're lost in a blizzard)
- Huge world
Cons(-)
- No jump button
- You need too much food(my character's daily need is arround 4kg of meat or up to 8kg of fish)
- Too many wolves ( Its just stupid as u go for around 10mins u will surely meet at least 2 wolves on your way, It would be better if they were in groups or at least a bit more clever)
All in all as in every survival game you can find yourself sitting in one place and having stuff to survive for over 20 days. Then you starts wandering why should i keep playing as i'm quite safe here. Then you get bored and start exploring leaving a lot behind. - what i ment by this - for now you can't be rescued and there is no plot in game(as far as i know) so only thing you can really do is explore this dangerous but beautifull world. Yet still for me it's experience worth 20 euro!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

An extremely fun and addicting survival sandbox. No zombies, no aliens-just everything Mother Nature can throw at you.
After an EMP blast, your plane has crashed into the Canadian wilderness. As you progress you'll find others who weren't as lucky to stay alive as you: they were frozen or starved to death. The maps are large and filled with detail: the devs really put alot of detail and time to this game. The game is constantly being updated and the devs listen to the people who play it. The artstyle looks incredible and everything is well balanced. The game is extremely stable and even my 750Ti can run it on Ultra at 60fps.
10/10 highly recommend.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The game is absolutely gorgeous, the artistic style lends itself beautifully to the environment. This coupled with the great environmental audio (howling winds, snow crunching underfoot, etc.) really has a great immersive effect.

Honestly there have been times walking through mountains in Pleasant Valley that I've stopped to look out over the beautiful scenery even though I was freezing my ♥♥♥ off and the sun was setting and it might kill me. Or the desperation when you're trapped at night in a blizzard dying of cold with just your storm lantern and 10 ft of visibility just praying you find shelter soon because if you stop to try to harvest wood for a fire it might kill you. All the while the wind is howling in your ears, snow is crunching under your feet and you're breathing ragged and shaking from the cold. Oh and you walk/run slower into the wind. Those types of details are the best.

It looks like once story mode is released (Spring 2016 is the latest word) the price will be bumped so get this game now. The sandbox mode alone is worth it, I honestly can't wait for the narrative they're planning to bring. The episodic nature should also be really interesting.

And a final note: Don't ♥♥♥♥ with bears. Bears will ruin your day.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've been waiting for some time for this game to come out and saw that it was on sale on Steam for only $10.00.   I normally try to avoid investing in Alpha games as they seem to take years to complete and a lot of developers cut and run and never finish their product.  Kudos to Hinterland!
My first experience with the game I played it on medium difficulty and lasted 20 or so days without any kind of problem as I have played many survival/ resource games before.
I turned it up to stalker difficulty (Hardest difficulty). Now this is certainly my kind of game:  Real survival.
Artistically it's beautiful, the dark unforgiving environment was exactly what I expected for a survival game I rate it a 10/10.  Emersion is about 8/10 and it is certainly a playable game even though it’s Alpha.  Out of 36 hours played- I’ve fallen though the world once- That happened after I sprained my ankle from a bump in the snow. This was the only real bug I’ve found and I was able to recover after multiple saved game loads.    The game has only crashed once on me so my rating for general game stability would be 8/10- which is great for an alpha.
It isn’t a perfect balance… for example:  In Stalker mode you almost never find anything in file cabinets, you would think you would find just a little more paper….  Other than that you might find one item for every four boxes or containers you search though.
I can tell you that after 36 hours- I’m not bored with it.   There’s lots of content and places to explore, and there are no quests in this game.  Simply surviving hour by hour and day by day and making it from point A to B is more than a challenge.  Getting down to 3% health in the middle of a blizzard with 99% fatigue all because of rusty can of pork and beans…  and surviving it with quick thinking…  Glorious/Rewarding.
Frankly Speaking- I think this game has the potential to be the best realistic survival game on the market today.
voteText: 7 of 9 people (78%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So far, The Long Dark is looking excellent. It's a proper survival horror game, as in: You might not survive and that's pretty horrible.

Gameplay: At the time of writing, only Sandbox mode is available. The mechanics of interacting with the environment are exactly what I ache for in many games, i.e. When I do something that would be sensible in a situation in real life, it works in the game too. Freezing? Get in the lee of that rock to get out of the wind. Yay, it works!

The game itself kind of includes its tutorial organically. At the start, you have no stuff, so you don't have to worry about what you can do with stuff. As you acquire stuff, you can play with it and learn what it does.

It is a little frustrating that there are some features you'd hope will appear in the final version that apparently don't work yet - like fuelling and starting the oil generators with you can see attached to many of the cabins, but it's still alpha and there's plenty of time for more actions of this type - the ones that seem obvious and sensible to the player - to be added.

If you're easily frustrated by death, you might dislike this game, but as it stands, competing against yourself to see how long you can last is a main mechanic of sandbox mode.

Atmosphere: Really good atmosphere, especially through sound and lighting. The constant howling of the wind makes you feel cold and alone, while I got a couple of good jump-scares from a sudden burst of incidental music and my own character mumbling to herself.

Story: Storyline-mode isn't available yet, but there is a lot of good potential for when it is. You can already surmise a number of things about what happened simply from what you can see in the game - dinner still in the ovens, oddly placed corpses... if they stick with the vibe of Show don't tell" it will be excellent.

In summary
date: pretty good as it stands and can only get better. The only reason I -wouldn't- recommend buying it on early access is that this game deserves to cost more - I think the devs may have underestimated what it will cost to do everything they will want to with the game."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Important note on realism: Hinterland does not aim for the game to be completely realistic, but rather a game that is balanced between game-play and realism. Some elements are therefore not in line with the real world (for example the degradation of items goes a lot faster). There is (currently) no intention of making a separate game mode that is as realistic as possible, although there are talks of mod support to enable this by the community.

I bought The Long Dark because I have been searching for a realistic survival game / simulator for a long time. Even though it is not meant to be entirely realistic / simulator, it comes very close. So close that I can state it is the best game I have ever played. I have played a lot of games for many years (a lot outside Steam) so this is quite impressive considering it still is in early access. The game-play is fantastic and is a must for any gamer that is into survival games and crafting. I don't want to spoil it for you, but there are times where I am trembling of fear and excitement. The immersion is so great that I sometimes forget I am playing a game. It is visually stunning and the sound is even better.

The game is constantly changing and new content is added regularly (big update each month and smaller ones in between). The developers are enthusiastic and committed and are willing to listen to the community, while maintaining their own vision. While there is currently only a sandbox, story mode is planned for release at the end of this year (which includes great voice actors like Jennifer Hale). The price will probably go up at that point, so buy it while it is still cheap.

The Long Dark will not hold your hand and there are no tutorials. It is very intuitive, but you have to use your intellect. There are three game modes. One which is forgiving and primarily to explore (Pilgrim). One that is exactly in line with the vision of Hinterland, challenging but fair (Voyageur) and my personal favourite, brutal and unforgiving (Stalker). I love the challenge in the game (or any game) as there is nothing better than to recover from your near dead experiences. Most people will die, some a lot. As it is permadeath you will lose your hard work. If you don't like dying or to lose your progress, I would suggest waiting for story mode (but be ready to pay more if you don't buy it now). I however love permadeath and (almost) impossible games, which is why I play games that have this (Faster Than Light, XCOM, Don't Starve etc.). Always on the highest difficulty and with permadeath on if this is possible. The Long Dark has a difficulty mode for every kind of player, which is a big plus.

To conclude, this game is so amazing that I bought a new Xbox One just to play The Long Dark. I bought the game for my low-end laptop, which was below the minimal requirements. Surprisingly I could play it extremely well until last big update. I felt so sad and empty when I could not play any more that I just had to do something about it. It is all worth it as I am 100% sure it will be a huge success (unlike other early access games). If there are any doubts or questions, feel free to send a message or post on the forum. Hinterland, me and the community are happy to help.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

EARLY ACCESS 23/09/2014

One of the greatest survival games I have played even in its current state.

This game is a great simulation of surviving in a cold winter mountain top, you must hunt for food or let the wolves do that for you since there aren't guns just laying around everywhere. You will have to either melt snow on a fire and boil it to get water or actually find some. You will need to forage for wood which takes aslong as you want but you may come up empty handed.

-Gameplay-
The game puts you randomly on the map and lets you survive how you want whether that be crawling up to a corner, putting a fire down, rolling out your bed and waiting although you will find that as the night approaches you will not want to stay there as your fire won't last long enough through the night and the cold wind will freeze to death, or close anyway. Tab opens up many options for you too choose from, ranging from inventory to foraging.

-Conclusion-
The game looks and sounds fantastic and I can guarrente that this game will become so much better as the game develops. The only thing I dislike is the calary metre as it drops too fast in my opinion and even drops as you sleep and when you have to sleep through the night you will need ALOT of food to keep it up.

I give it a 9/10 for being fun, unqiue and realistic and definately worth the purchase!

YouTube Video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Cf_WlIdNdVg

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I was doing well. I started in a cave to the south and almost immediatly found a rifle on a body frozen into the canyon ground. Excellent, this will make things much easier. Leaving the canyon, I found myself at the Camp Office. A good place to stay after I stocked up on food and firewood there. I even found some bullets. The next day I started to explore the lake, pillaging the cabins for their precious food and supplies, returning once again to the office, my home. On day three I made it to the hunter's homestead, killing a wolf along the way and skinning it.
On day four I decided it was time to go to the dam. Rifle at the ready, I opened the door. Nothing. As I start to open lockers, I hear a growl. The dam wolf starts ferociously biting at me as I struggle to fight it off. Eventually, I am the victor and the wolf scurries off down the corridor. Now the hunt is on, I take out my rifle and vow to remove the menace from the dam, and make it a new safe haven. I creep slowly down the hallway, the sights of my rifle in line with my eye. As I round the corner, I hear another growl, I aim, and I fire. I miss. The wolf attacks and I manage to kill it with my knife. Then I notice I only have one percent of life left and I'm bleeding out. I access my medical kit as the world starts to black out around me. I'm dead.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

In this game you can listen to Jennifer Hale slurp tinned peaches - the heck else do you want?

But seriously, this is a lovingly crafted game with punishing and brutal survival mechanisms, and evocative atmosphere dripping from every pore - some of the most gorgeous environment design I've ever seen. A moderately successful kickstarter game, it's immediately apparent to anyone giving it a fair chance that this is a true labour of love from a talented development team. One without the other would be an unfortunate miscarriage, but such is definitely not the case here.

And yes, that is what Canada looks like all year 'round.

Please be warned that it is not a hardcore hunting or survival simulator, and takes a few liberties with animal behaviour for the sake of game balance and flow that folks looking for a 500% realistic wilderness survival experience might find off-putting.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Survived 6 whole days cooped up inside an old house with nothing to drink but toilet water and smashed cans of beans. These wolves.. they're not.. normal. They know you're afraid..

The first day started normal, with just a lone wolf in sight. I managed to scare it away with some flares I found. The next day.. It got worst. The lone wolf from yesterday came back with with a pack and chased me down. I threw flares at it, but they ignored it. They're getting bolder. I ran inside the first house I see and stayed there for a day so the wolves would go away. I've made a big mistake.

I opened the door to go out scavenging, but instead got pounced by 3 wolves. I fend myself as long as I could, throwing flares, but they were just useless against them now.

Day 4. Food is running low.. ran out of clean water and can't start a fire without firewood. I had to go outside to get some. But that would be suicide.

Day 5. Their pack is getting bigger. 12 wolves I counted. Circling around the house. I cant take it anymore.

Day 6. I died from starvation. Better than getting mauled by wolves I guess.

10/10 would starve to death again,

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have taken sometime to play this game myself and I decided that I should write a review here so that it would be helpful for those who read it and decide whether to purchase this game or not.

Get to the point, right now the game is in 'Early Access' so it is not really complete. However, personally, only what the Early Access has offered now worths the money.

The very first thing that can be accounted as pros is the the game's very own concept. It is a new dimension of 'survival game', unlike many mainstream survival game lists which involve zombies and mutants to horrify you, this game is another story: just you against the 'Mother Nature'. You are on your own, among the cold, hunger, thirst, tiredness, or even danger from wolves. All you need to do is 'survive'. It sounds simple and uninteresting, but believe me this game is well enough even with this simplicity in this game genre. No safe place with lots of supplies (unless you choose 'Pilgrim' mode). You need to take risks with your own actions. Everything is by yourself.

The gameplay ... I don't know if I should classify it as a pro or con, but it is mixed. You can never expect anything from each playthrough; when you restart, everything except the regions will be resetted. This gives you the survival experience to some extends. For example, you might find a rifle, the only 'real' weapon in the game, without any bullets before you find one bullet miles away, or you need a can opener but still yet to be found; what will you do? which way? where is it going to be? Everything which other survival games may overlook matters in this game. You need clothes to keep you warm, raw food, if not cooked well, can be a threat when eaten, or you can even hurt your legs if you do not watch your steps (which happens to me a lot lol). These are some of the situations that I found and I need to give the 'thumb up' for the developer's careful planning so as to make this game as realistc as possible.

However, there is something that still bugs me; the wolves. They still lack realistic movements: too repetitive and can be easy to deal with as you get get used to the game. Even though the developer has mentioned something about the wolves, their movements and some behaviors, such as how slow or fast it should be in different situations, are needed for consideration *for developers*. I hope if the wolves are readjusted in the right way it would gives me more exciting experience. Nevertheless, even with this comment I still find dealing with wolves sometimes hard anyway. (I heard that more wildlife will be added, so it might be the solution for this problem as well.)

If you are fans of survival game and need a new dimension on survival experience, I suggest you that you buy this and try it once or wait for sometime until the full release comes (Story Mode, I'm really looking forward to that!).

My last warning ..
Beware of the wolves

reviewText:
Early Access Review

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_XLFszBn-uw

TLD Credits:

David Hayter (Solid Snake - Metal Gear)
Mark Meer (Cmd. Shepard - Mass Effect)
Jennifer Hale (Cmd. Shepard - Mass Effect)
Marianne Crawcysk (writer of L.A. Noire, Driver, Far Cry 3, Appleseed Alpha)
Raphael Van Lierop (Project Lead - Relic Games, Blacklight, Ubisoft, Activision)
Alan Lawrence (Lead Designer - Saints Row 1-4, Freespace 1-2, Red Faction 1-2)
David Chan (Audio Director - Bioware)

Now that I have your attention...let's explain the credits more in depth and why The Long Dark is a great foundation for an amazing final product.

I have been waiting for years, if not decades for a game that makes simple man vs. nature survival the primary focus rather than simply a secondary after-thought. The Long Dark by Hinterland Games delivers a the closest thing to being Survivorman that has ever appeared in a game. They also designed TLD from the ground-up to work seamlessly with the Oculus Rift. The have a dev kit in their studio as of last month in fact.

As of this review the game is currently in Early Access (v.119). It was the result of a Kickstarter campaign less than a year ago by Hinterland Games. The concept is you are a small plane bush pilot in Northern Canada when a Coronal Mass Ejection occurs (CME - similar to a solar flare). This causes all electrical components worldwide to fail. Unfortunately, this also caused the plane you were flying in to fall out of the sky into an unknown area in the frigid winter of a forest. You lived through the crash...but will you live through The Long Dark?

Hinterland Games was founded by Raphael Van Lierop. Raph, as he's known on the forums, has over a decade of AAA game creation experience. As a creative director, narrative director, producer, designer, and writer on multiple award-winning game titles including Company of Heroes and Warhammer 40,000. His former studios include Relic, Ubisoft Montreal, Blacklight and Activision.

Rapheal had the desire to create a first-person raw and realistic survival simulation with a deep story mode. The big box studios said it wasn't marketable" enough. So he took his skills and experience and left. After easily surpassing his Kickstarter goal with his vision of The Long Dark
date: he grabbed some other highly experienced industry professionals. This inclused David Chan as Audio Director from Bioware. Next to join the team was Alan Lawrence. Alan was the lead designer on Freespace
hoursPlayed: Red Faction
voteText: Red Faction 2
helpfulPercent: Saints Row 1-4 and many more. Together the group started Hinterland Games. Their first project is The Long Dark. With plans for future expansions and sequels in the form of seasons. This should be similar to The Walking Dead game series in delivery.\n\nRaph didn't stop there
votesHelpful: he wants a deep and rich story to go with the realistic survival experience. So he invested a substantial amount of the kickstarter funds into hiring Marianne Krawcyzk as the writer. She wrote L.A. Noire
votesTotal: Driver
votesFunny:
Far Cry 3 and Appleseed Alpha. Together Raph and Mirianne will have the story mode out by the end of 2014 with many NPC's characters created from the original Kickstarter backers likenesses.

What else did Raph want for his survival game experience?? How about GREAT voice acting... Mark Meer and Jennifer Hale from Mass Effect. And maybe even a guy named David Hayter the former Solid Snake from a little franchise called Metal Gear. I guess Sutherland wasn't available...his loss.

So if you are jaded like I was/am on Early Alpha games that alway overpromise and underdeliver

reviewText:
Early Access Review

You want friends to play with and kill other people with guns? Nope. You want to be naked and kill someone with a rock? Nope. Build something while naked and with friends to kill people with rocks? Nope.

Any survival game you see this days is about Zombies, A post-apocalyptic world, MP or All of them combined. The Long Dark is quite a different.

You're going to be surviving by yourself. You will die horribly or just stupidly. You can survive for a week and just die embarassingly from freezing because of a blizzard. You can get eaten by wolves. or just starve to death in a matter of I don't know. A few hours? This is what a survival game is.

It has a lot of potential. I can go on and on about what they should add. But i'm pretty sure most people have that covered.

Love it! <3

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First off, if you're not open to the idea of beta-testing, don't bother going for the early release; way too many people are ♥♥♥♥♥ing about game mechanics that haven't been fully fleshed out nor balanced. That said:

This game is mostly about exploration and resource management. Your only enemies are wolves, the cold, starvation, dehydration, and hopefully other survivors later in development. You will constantly be fighting an uphill battle to find food and supplies. Unless you have a stockpile far too heavy to carry, you will need to be on the move from location to location as you loot, scavenge, and hunt. The combat system currently is very undeveloped with you only being able to fight off wolves with your bare hands or using rifles (no using that hatchet/hunting knife/prybar against them, although hopefully soon they'll implement this). Avoiding combat with wildlife is actually pretty easy as long as you're aware of their locations; mainly just giving them a wide berth, or throwing lit or even burnt out flares (much less effective) too spook them. At this stage in the game, if you have food poisoning, you WILL die; there is absolutely nothing you can do about it as your condition will deplete fairly quickly. If you see that warning, do yourself a favor and just hit load (Save points are when you sleep in a bed or bedroll).
Overall the game shows a lot of promise and is very unique (pretty much the only post-apocalyptic game I can think of that doesn't feature some sort of sci-fi or supernatural flavor. The full game will have multiple maps and goals beyond just survival.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you're looking to buy this game, here's a list of all the pros and cons.

Pros:
- Challenging to some extent
- Beautiful art and sound combination - very imersive
- Semi big maps (Sort of feels like the skyrim but instead of just having one huge main map and tiny sub maps, every map is linked together)
- Quick access user interface (everything you need is in the screen when you open up the view you want)
- There are moments when it is terrifying. There are no jumpscares, long dark uses that psychological horrorific fact that you're all alone.
- Good crafting system (but need some improvements at some aspects)

Cons

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Day 46: I found a bag of Beef Jerky in a little cable off the beaten path, probably some kid's snack on a hunting trip with his uncle. Or at least that's what I imagine. Its been over a month since my plane went down, and the only people I've found are frozen corpses being picked over by the wolves. It seems the only thing I can do anymore to keep remotely sane and inspired to stay alive is to talk to myself during the long hours.  Oh, I had to put the spare wolf pet somewhere out of sight, I woke up in the middle of the night about two days ago to get a drink and about had a heart attack, the light filtering through the windows made it look like a wolf had crashed thru the window and gotten inside, I nearly wasted a round of my rifle ammo.

That's about the only positive thing I have to say today, I'm stuck in that little cabin off the beaten path. There's a snowstorm right now, my leg is bleeding profusely, I tore my hat to pieces in order to make a bandage, but I have the sinking suspicion that a bear's mouth isn't the most hygenic place in Canada. So yea, it's probably infected. I'll have to treat it when i get back to the gas station. Might be difficult walking thru the snow with a bum leg and no pants. ... Funny story behind that actually.

I spent days hunting deer and drying their pelts in order to have some warm pants, and the bear ate them, and a bit of my leg as dessert.

It sounds so absurd to say it out loud... the bear ate my pants. Its like one of those things you learn to say in highschool spanish to make the teacher have a headache ...

something something mis pantelones ...

*a blood stain signs the final entry in a small journal laying next to a half naked corpse leaning in a corner of a little cabin off the beaten path.*

--

Really its a fun game where the experiences that kill you are just as fun to talk about as the experiences you survive. Hinterland is doing great with keeping the game coming along with updates and bugfixes. They have an amazing team that really is interested in player feedback.

The game has immense replay value, even in its unfinished alpha sandbox mode.
Great graphics that I can only describe as water color cell shading ... ish.
I like that they're not trying to carbon copy other survival games.

I've got nothing negative to say about the developers. Nothing negative to say about the game.
Honestly I think everyone should play this game at least once.

I guarantee the first time that you're ripped apart by wolves after barely surviving a blizzard after finally finding a box of crackers after panically searching houses for anything to eat will be 1000% times more enjoyable than experiencing those things in real life. ... at least, maybe like ... 1010% more enjoyable even.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The Long Dark is a beautiful, immersive game.  In it's current state you can spend a lot of time enjoying the two connected maps in Sandbox mode.

The gap between difficulties is vast however, and the amount of loot is laughably small in Hard whereas in Medium mode I was swimming in gear and calories early on.  I explored and looted both maps but eventually became bored.  There is plenty of replay value with Hard mode, however, and a new map will definitely bring me back regardless.

I have high hopes for this game's future and believe it's worth picking up in it's current state.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A survival game set in the wild canadian North (we sure have been getting popular lately, haven't we? :D), The Long Dark is still in early access but already has plenty of qualities to justify buying it right now. It's got atmosphere. It's challenging. And the biggest threat to your survival isn't always as obvious as you might think. Most of the time I died in this game, it was because of poor preparation and getting lost in a blizzard while trying to find my way back to a shelter. It's a game where smart decisions and patience truly pay off, and I can't stress enough how much I love games like that.

There are three difficulty levels right now. ''Easy'' allows you to play simply for the atmosphere and wild animals won't attack you, which makes the whole experience more peaceful, if ridiculously easy. The ''Normal'' difficulty is not a walk in the park by any stretch of the imagination. Every day is a struggle against time and the elements to procure food, tools and equipment, and fuel for fires. In fact, it's so tough and gritty I haven't bothered to try the ''Hard'' difficulty yet. I assume you just die of dysentry or scurvy as soon as you start the game. :P

The game can get a bit boring when you're starting to build up a good supply of stuff. It can also get rather stressful in the early game when you're trying to avoid overly agressive wolves while fighting against the clock in mad sorties across the wilderness to ''maybe'' find that tool you desperately need. Despite that, The Long Dark is a promising game that has a lot to offer and will probably have a lot more to offer as it develops.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game will make you feel desperate, cold, and alone. You will feel fear. You will feel anger and rage. You will feel cornered. You will feel triumphant. You will sometimes feel victory. You will always eventually taste bitter defeat.

Ration your meals. Conserve your energy. Consolidate your resources. Plan for every eventuality, for every emergency, and you will survive. I made it 200 days. You can too. And I highly recommend you try.

starting fires without matches - using what nature provides such as the fire bow method
collect pine needles from trees - makes a great hot drink
more weapons - add in some crude weapons such as a club or spear
making arrowheads by flintnapping would be fun
more animals - add in carribou, arctic fox, lynx, beaver,
add in rope for climbing and climbing game mechanic
add in a tent - simple shelter to keep out of the wind but wolves can attack you through it

all in all this game very fun and worth the cost.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is a real Survival That is just how survival should look like - without any phantasy elements. Today there are a lot of survival games but most popular are about monsters and zombies. Wait... what??? Zombies?? You serious? Is it realistic??? Here  - we don't have all that kind of stuff. Instead we see beautiful nature, unpredictable weather, angry wolfes who are in costant search of fresh meat... just as you in fact) 9/10 (because nothing is perfect)
P.s. Piligrim, hm - just to check the picture of the game and maybe to explore the locations (but I prefer to do it while wolfes are chasing me)))
Voyager - nice!  less food, faster waste of calories, angry habitants of the forest and bad weather dominates.
Stalker - yeeeeah, that's how we survive! Damn I just realized my man has only tiny socks on his feet.... breezing

reviewText:
Early Access Review

TL:DR
Definitely worth getting. In the beginning challenging, afterwards still an enjoyable experience. Maybe wait for Story mode though, it was announced for spring 2016 but is delayed at the moment. And I do believe that this delay is for the right reasons.

if 95% of early access games are a downer, this one is part of the 5% that know what EA is about.
Challenging, atmospheric, tense, immersively beautiful, progression (at MINIMUM for the first 15 hours of gameplay on every run, and you wont get there with the first tries).
decent
fair explorable area with a 4-5 maps.
good learning curve
___________________________

Oviously there are some things which can still be balanced differently  but hey, during the first 15 hours or so you wont even notice.
And there are also things which you might envision to be there which aren't implemented (atleast for now, they do a good job of adding stuff) but generally the game already offers a fair amount of choice and a decent amount of content.
Now then, let's take a closer look:

I have seen this game about a year ago. It hasn't had that many reviews back than and i had to make decisions. I had played a number of early access survival games back at that point and was generally disappointed in the genre as it didn't live up to my expectations. So i decided for another early access game which wasn't about survival and proved to be a perfect hit. I tried a couple more early access games but lost this one vastness of the steam store, while i turned more and more sour in my opinion towards early access, untill about 4 days ago. And I currently 40 hours in, I should get back to studying.

With all the heart that Hinterland is putting into this gem, The Long Dark feels cold, as cold as the land in which you are stranded. It's ruthless and death lurks about everywhere and everywhen. But after a day stalking and exploring your way from hut to hut (only applies to one map), running for your life, freezing half to death you finally take shelter. Dusk has already come and it is starting to get a lot colder. There, struggling to get a fire started, you hear your belly rumbling, your lips dry of dehydration. Finally you manage to light up a small fire. You melt some snow in the last light of the day and take a zip. You heat up your canned food just assuming that you wont have any meat yetand a feeling of gladness, relaxation sets in for a moment. Your struggles payed off. You are still alive. Alive but tired. And thus the moment passes. You go to bed to wake up to another day to explore the world. To gather what you need in order to be unbound from the luck of scavanging, to sustain yourself.

All in all i can only recomend this game. it is definitely worth the 19 € it is currently priced at and already feels like a solid game. But wait there is more! This game actually uses the alpha! I personally can't wait for story mode which is soon to come!

9.5/10 from me

Cheers!

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI previously downloaded The Forest. The gameplay I managed to get out of it that wasn't clouded with lag and bugs was pretty decent, but not as realistic or challenging as I expected. I held off a hoard of cannibals with a tennis ball and a fireax. I previously downloaded the Long Dark. I haven't played much, but what I have played has ran very smoothly on my sucky HP notebook. Very challenging, and I can't seem to survive more than a couple of days at a time before freezing in my sleep or being mauled. I wasn't expecting much realism, but I entered the game and spent the first 10 minutes or so going through all the menus seeing the dozens of things I had to keep up with to avoid from meeting death. Very fun game, runs nicley on old PCs as far as I'm concerned, and once you finally do pick it up it's hard to put down. I wish I could have come into this game with no prior knowledge of it, as that would have made it much better. If you do want to download, don't look up much other than controls for an amazing experience. There are about a thousand different ways, and maybe a couple to survive. Download The Long Dark.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I waited a while before buying this in a sale and it is so worth the full price. The game has developed in an amazing way from 2014 and continues to do so. The game idea is a good one. No zombies, no mutants or any other creatures of nightmares. It is just you and your wits vs. mother nature. The graphics and visuals are amazing Hinterland have done a brilliant job with their expansions and improvements. The weather effects have improved so much I have to wear a shawl or jumper while playing because it makes me feel cold (My computer is near the radiator too!)

I like that there is no tutorial and that the player is 'thown into the deep end' as it were, which I think adds to the experience.

I have had no major problems with the game, the last minor one was fixed very quickly by update. Hinterland certainly knows what their doing. Although I can't wait for the game to come out finished I am prepared to wait for a game that could be well beyond our expectations when finished.

I am looking forward to the updates hinterland have planned in the upcomming months, all of which look good. I hope that they add new regions to explore (A small town would be nice,I wonder if they could add candles and a way to make them?).

I would recommend this game to anyone and everyone!

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nNever understood all the negative reviews about this wonderful game but nevermind about that. The game itself is a unique, survival, atmospheric and at certain points somewhat horror-like type. I've never seen something like this before and also the cartoony graphics makes it even more interesting and unique, which is a big plus from me. I've recently heard that the developers are working hard on the Story Mode and it got me really excited. At first i wasnt really convinced about the game, the price was again a problem, of course I could have refunded it but still got me thinking wether it's a good choice or a complete waste of time and money until i've played it...it got me wanting to play even more and more, it's a great timekiller, always new stuff to do and endless possibilities. I absolutely love the dedication of the developers, when they say they wanna do something, they do it, this shows that they care about us and they are trying to keep the game alive, which is fantastic.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The game is early access and still in development. This review is based on build v270 and roughly 240 hours of gameplay. At the time of writing this review, only the sandbox mode was available. A story mode which will feature a coherent story is scheduled for release in 2015.

It's a first person survival game set in a Canadian Winter wilderness after a geomagnetic disaster. All electric devices have ceased functioning, whether there are other survivors is unclear (NPCs have been announced for a future update). The player has to battle the adversities of cold, hunger, thirst, fatigue, wild animals and health issues, while exploring abandoned leftovers of civilization. No zombies, no arsenal of super-guns, no vehicles. Just the player against nature or, well, a model of nature.

The game pleases with superb art style and sound effects. Sunrise, sunset, starry night skies and the landscape in general are simply beautiful to behold and have been made to look a bit like oil paintings. Everything creates an atmosphere of beauty, but at the same time loneliness and urgency. The player needs to scavenge abandoned houses, cars, forestry lookouts, factories etc. to find means to survive as long as possible. And if you learn the mechanics of the world surrounding you, it is possible to survive for a very long time.

The developers keep up a steady pace of updating and honing the sandbox mode, also adding new regions from time to time (there are now 4 major regions, each with its own feel"). They are super-friendly and give feedback to even the strangest comments from players. There is a dedicated community at the developers homepage (Hinterland Games) which is worth checking out.

This game is not for everyone - it does not take your hand. You have to explore it
date: and the higher difficulty modes may frustrate people not used to overcome obstacles with patience. But for me
recommended: only the sandbox mode is one of the best games I have ever played. And I have basically played almost all the landmark games since 1983. I can't believe I only payed 20  € for this gem. And it's not even finished..."
hoursPlayed: March 30, 2015

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I bout this game yesterday thinking, Oh this could be interesting." I was wrong. I was VERY wrong. This game is exceptional. Beyond excpetional.

I started a sandbox
recommended: and named her Abbie. Abbie and I started in a lighthouse and from there we spent the better part of 13 hours exploring
hoursPlayed: scrounging supplues
voteText: and escaping the local wildlife. Eventually we found ourselfs at the Trapper's Cabin and I decided that this would make a great home for Abbie. We went in and were very surprised at all of the gear left behind
helpfulPercent: there was even a rifle to but all the bullets we found along the way to use. Abbie and I then went about gathering firewood
votesHelpful: hunting deer and bunnies
votesTotal: and making foraging trips for better clothes from the Mystery Lake.\n\nOn the 10th day
votesFunny: We were about gathering firewood and a bunny passed by
commentsCount: so Abbie equiped her bow and we started chasing that little bunny down. After a few minutes and many misses
column16: we finally managed to hit that little rabbit and moved in to harvest it. Little did we know that there was a bear right around the rock the rabbit had died at. So Abbie quickly equipped the hunting rifle and took a shot
column17: but it was too late the bear was upon her. She fought as hard as she could but the damage was done. Even though the bear had left her alive
column18:
we were far from home with no healing items to speak of. This was Abbie's last moments. We tried to stumble home but she collapsed in the snow dead.

Never have a felt such heartbreak at losing a character. All the work that we had put into trying to build a home was all for naught. The fact that I had connected so much with a character who I never even saw the face of just shows how amazing this game is. I could not recommend this game more.

TL;DR
First character mauled by a bear after 13 hours. 10/10 Would get mauled again.

reviewText:

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Excellent atmospheric and sometimes truly terrifying game.

Bleak, yet beautiful, with a unique style perfect for this sort of gameplay.

Just challenging enough to make you want to keep going while still retaining that real sense of danger.

Captures a sense of isolation and pressure perfectly, rewards you for exploration and experimentation. When you inevitably die it very rarely feels unfair.

All in all, this game is an amazing experience anyone interested in survival should enjoy.
