reviewText:
Early Access Review

I want to preface this review by saying that I'm not normally one who writes reviews in the first place. But this game changed that.

If you like survival games, this one seems to be the pinnacle. I've never before played a survival game that is as much fun or tense. Lemme give you a recount of my first three games.

Game 1: Woke up in the middle of the night, in a blizzard. I had no idea where to go and began freezing fast. I realized I had a flare and popped it as quick as I could. I began to run through the woods. As I reached the end of my rope, I saw a small cottage in the distance and I ran for it as quick as I could. I made my way inside and found some food. I waited a day or so until I ran out of food then ventured outside once more....
...
and directly into the jaws of a wolf. I died, due to lack of food and preparation. I nearly ♥♥♥♥ myself when the wolf jumped on me.

Game 2: Woke up during the day, afternoon I believe. The weather was relatively peaceful, and I managed to find a group of houses. I picked them apart then chose one for my own uses. Upon slightly stocking it over the course of a few days, I ended up making a fatal mistake by leaving to go exploring. A blizzard hit, and I couldn't find my way back in time before I froze to death.

Game 3: By far my most successful one. Woke up around 9 am. I ventured from mystery lake to coastal highway along a set of railroad tracks. When I reached coastal highway I fell off of a cliff and ended up spraining my ankle. I hobbled along until I heard wolves behind me. I moved as quick as I could and at last spotted a cabin. I stayed there for a day, resting my ankle until it was functional once more. I began exploring a series of fishing villages, plundering what I could from the worn down houses. I found a gas station and began stockpiling it. A week passed in game, I had a good thing going.

And then those ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ wolves moved in. I don't know if there is a pack tendency, or if they are randomly placed, or if they aren't supposed to move from one zone to another. But suddenly I had four wolves scratching at my door. I had found a rifle, but only had three bullets. I knew flares would scare them off, but not for good. But then I realized that they were taking down deer in the area. Then I formed a sort of symbiotic relationship with them. I wouldn't kill them and they killed deer, soon after which I'd go and carve the carcass up. I began stockpiling more food, and more, until I had a hefty amount. Day eleven rolled by, and I decided that I wanted to check out some of those ice fishing shacks I had spotted on the horizon. I geared up and made my way out to one.

So begins my fatal mistake.

I arrived at one and was relatively unharmed for a day. Then a wolf happened by. I had one bullet left, at this point, and I used it on the wolf, figuring it was the only one. Not the case. Three more soon arrived, huddling around the ice fishing shack. I knew that I was on borrowed time by this point. I spent three nights holed up in that shack, (earning the achievement for spending three nights outdoors), then made my peace with whatever God is out there, and I stepped outside. The moment I did, I was pounced and killed. Surviving an epic 15 days and 7 hours.

It was amazing.

Pros
Good survival aspects such as calorie count, which drains as you preform heavy tasks such as harvesting wood, skinning animals, running, etc., and a tempurature gauge (including windchill!) to help you monitor how much body heat you have.
The game feels balanced enough (for an early access game, no less) that you don't feel helped along by the mechanics, but they are fair enough to where you can, if you're smart, find or steal enough food for yourself to survive. That's what it boils down to in the end, food.
Weather effects are amazing, and there's something to be said for being trapped in a building for three days because there is a blizzard outside.
The game is beautiful, it reminds me somewhat of The Telltale games. It has a sort of handpainted, almost comic book look to it.
The sound design is fairly well done. Wind whips around buildings and wolves howl in the distance. At night it's peaceful, houses settle as you're in them. The sound design further helps the idea that you are indeed, very much alone in this world.
A minor crafting system is implemented, meaning that it should expand further in the upcoming months.
The dev community seems very into the game and seems to be actively working on it.
Cons
It is in early access, so the game is not completed, first off.
Some bugs.
Occasionally you'll be spawned somewhere, in the middle of the night, in a blizzard, with no way to survive.
Animal behavior is erratic and, sometimes, downright weird. Though I imagine that'll be improved with time.
Very small area to explore once you've done it.I am aware that this is early access, and I don't begrudge the game for it. At the end of the day it is an amazing early access game, and one that I would wholeheartedly tell everyone to support. It has an enormous amount of potential, and I would love to see this game be taken further.

tl;dr: Great survival game, still in early access, buy it anyway.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

BUY THIS GAME

This game is incredible, and its developers have put unparalleled effort into making it so unique. Everything from the graphics to the game mechanics contribute towards the game's unique atmosphere and mood. Honestly, I would pay 60 bucks to get this game in its final state. It inhabits a frightening, lonely, and unforgiving wilderness and forces you to make life and death decisions, take risks, and face your doom countless times in any given playthrough. Surviving and succeeding is difficult but feels extremely rewarding. The maps are large and diverse, offering room for nomadic play styles and more settling playing styles. There are too many good things to write in this review, so just play the game to find out.

It is not without flaws, however. At its current state, it is lacking in some content, although I am confident that the addition of story mode (and hopefully co-op at some point maybe?) will fill in that gap. Sometimes, however, the games mostly successful realism"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A somber and lonely trek through the northern Canadian wilderness after an unknown geomagnetic event has put paid to most of the world, The Long Dark shines in its austerity and stylized visuals. Gameplay is largely devoid of 'enemies' save the elements and the player's own entropy. Wolves and bears make an appearance, but they are best avoided- not engaged.

Still undergoing development, the game lacks a story mode or campaign, but the sandbox is a blast nonetheless. I took a chance on this Early Access title, and I'm glad for it.

Since my purchase a few months ago, the game has evolved in content including playable area (more than triple its initial offering), game mechanics, and depth. The developers' are fully engaged with their game community and much of the aforementined growth has been rooted in player feedback.

TLD is a win.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThe Long Dark is an interesting game to me. With a story mode due somewhere in the future, the finished product of this game might be something fantastic. The game looks great and as opposed to facing Zombies or Humans, you're completely by yourself trying to survive in the wilderness. Wolves and the freezing cold weather will be your main enemies, and they will not be easy to take on all alone, but that is what makes this a strong survival experience. It's great to see a survival game where nature will rip you apart in every way possible if you're not always working hard to be prepared.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

UPDATED REVIEW JANUARY 2016

In my original review I stated that this game had potential if the developers stuck to it. My 130+ hours of playtime show that it's a game that I managed to stick with - and the developers have not only met, but exceeded my every expectation so far. The game is still only sandbox at this point, but now has many regions, added wildlife, a crazy amount of added items, crafting and so much more. With story mode on the horizon, expect an updated-update-review in the future. This has now become one of my most played steam games, and is an example of early access done right. Slow and steady, with constant communication and updates.

Even still in early access, the sandbox represents one of the most immersive, realistic and FUN single player survival games available.


ORIGINAL REVIEW, WRITTEN SEPTEMBER 2014

This game is early access and has little content to it right now. At the time of writing this, it has but one static map. The starting point and the loot that you can find is RNG, but from a small pool of locations and a small pool of items, survival is really not that difficult once you've had a few trial and errors.

This game needs a lot of things. It needs more content, more maps, more items, more animals, it needs more realism and more balancing - but the foundation is absolutely rock solid.

I don't usually like commenting on early access games, but in this case I'm recommending it for one main reason - I played 13 hours without even realising. I survived over 20 days (on my 4th playthrough) before I had to quit (I didn't die). It didn't feel like 13 hours. It felt like one or two. It is immersive, it is addictive, it has genuine atmopshere and had a weird combination of both being relaxing and gripping at the same time. I don't know how trudging through the snow for an hour became both challenging and fun - but it did!

I also love the art style, the brief voiceovers and the very brief music on top of being one of the most bug free beta-games I've ever played. I think it's worth supporting these developers.

Of all the early access games I've taken a risk on, I think this one has the most potential if the developers can stick with it. From the updates and forum interaction so far, I'm very hopeful.

Even if you're not interesting in backing games in early access - keep an eye on this one for the future.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is one game I wish never goes below €5 anywhere.
This game... It'll blow you away if you give it the chance to take a deep breath.
If I hadn't paid for this game as much as I have, I would've closed it after my first, maybe second inevitable death.
I'm glad I gave it multiple chances, really glad. Every time you retry, you make more progress.
Before you even realize it, you've survived your first night and even more to come.
As many have mentioned, this game has a great atmosphere and really drags you in within the first half an hour. Engaging music, neat graphics and this game plays very risky with light and dark but does so very well.
Everything is up to you, realism is at it greatest here.

To address some issues that I saw from other users;

Yes, this game is hard. If hard games aren't your taste, then don't even bother.
Yes, if active action is required in a game for you, this game will be boring and I would not recommend it to you.
Yes, this game plays with time skipping, but it does so to stay true to its realism. If you consider what the developers have tried to create here, you would definitely not mind the time skipping when chopping branches, boiling water and much, much more. The game tries to stay as close to real life realism as possible, time skipping is inevitable.


But if you can appreciate realism, passive action and many, many retries, look no further.



Looking forward to the story mode!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Game makes you never wanna go on a hike ever again, 10/10

Seriously though. I have NEVER played a more atmospheric survival game. The immersion factor of the world is unbelievable, and being in it not only has you on the lookout for its more wild inhabitants, but also has you looking for dangers like hunger, thirst, exhaustion and the weather itself. Speaking of weather, the game beautifully displays the changing of its many dynamic conditions available. These conditions, whether it be snow, fog or the powerful wind whistling in your ears as you trudge through the world, all convey the sense that it IS a fight for survival, and you'll need to do everything you can to win.

In its current alpha state, the game is VERY good. Although some systems need refinining, some optimization issues are present, and some more stuff needs to be added to make it a complete package, the game is still VERY fun and worth a buy for anyone looking for a game that will make you consider every possible decision, regret every time your fire goes out, and make you dread every howl you hear at night.

This was only on my first run, so if I come across anything else worth noting soon or in future updates, I will update my review.

EDIT 1: So, I've put a lot more time into it. As I've played there are some more notable things I haven't talked about yet, and my opinions on what could make the game even better.

The systems. There are systems in this game you'd struggle to find in a modern AAA games, such as the different things affecting your ability to buld a fire, the amount of calories you have in your system, and the likeliness you'll be able to succeed in crafting (although this feature is rather undercooked at the moment. When you're cold, you can't do things effectively. When you're tired, good luck carrying all the gear you picked up. Hungry? Better check how old that venison is or else you might succumb to food poisoning. Things like these make the systems in the game feel fleshed out and more realistic, for lack of a better word, than other survival games on the market.

Now, as much as I sound like I have no problem with this game (though the features that are currently present DO undermine any problems I have) there are some cons to the game, and ways to make them better.

1. Map size- The map is not as big as I would have originally hoped. Now, I know this is only the first  map of many, but I had memorized the layout by my third life (which was very short). After you've memorized it, the exploration factor which I loved in my first couple hours started to fade.

2. Combat and item use- Combat in The Long Dark revolves either around taking your foe out at long-range with a rare hunting rifle, or letting them jump on you and hopefully building up you attack power, and punching them off this way. I feel there should be a way to use a hunting knife or hatchet during a close quarters situation to be able to kill a wolf. I know, in real life you probably wouldn't be able to react this way when a wolf starts chasing you, but it gives players with low health and other status effects, i.e. starvation, exhaustion or a sprained ankle, a chance to survive a wolf attack instead of running away. And it doesn't have to be easy, just something players can do for a last chance.

3.  Inventory- Lastly, inventory can sometimes be a pain to manage. Although it gives you a feeling you need to take what you truly need to survive, I sometimes wish you had more of a carrying capacity, or maybe it could fluctuate depending on your condition. The capacity DOES however change based on what status you're at, but the change is only made between when you're exhausted and when you aren't.

These things will change, I know, because it's still in Alpha. For the content you get right now, the game is still worth every cent you throw at it, and I'd highly recommend it in it's current state.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

After playing this game for the first time, I've decided that I love it. The way the gameplay and the atmosphere feels simply amazing. The game design concept is simular to Shelter with it's lovely art. It feels so realistic walking around in the world explorning, searching for supplies and watching out for wolfs. Even though this isen't a horror game it still feels so scary (thanks to the atmosphere) that you're ready for anything. And I love this game because there are NO zombies in it (seriously guys, there are way to many of them already) only cold, wolfs and starving. And the Developers are constantly updating the game to both improve it and to add new things. And this is only Early access, the story mode isen't available (which will be when the full game is released) and yet there are so many things to do, to explore. This is my favorite survival game by far. And I've played loads of them. The Forrest, DayZ, Don't Starve, Shelter, pretty much all of them.



Pro's

-Huge amount of detail has been put into the game, level design and art.
-Huge map to explore (three regions)
-Pure survival, no zombies or unnatural creatures
-Crazy amount of items, food, clothes, craft items, weponds, tools, etc.

Con's

-Can become a bit boring when you find yourself a food and water supply on day 1 and then you basically don't have to move your ♥♥♥♥ for a very long time.

I give this game 8/10 for it's lovely design, gameplay and atmosphere.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is a first day review. I've only played TLD about 4 hours at this point. I had to quit out of my 3rd playthrough, in which I have been alive for about 3 days, in order to go to sleep (in real life). However, I didn't want to do this. In fact, I really wanted to keep playing... scavenging... scraping by...... surviving.

This is the magic of The Long Dark.

I was hesitant to make the initial purchase, but I went with my gut and I have not since, in any way, shape, or form regretted doing so. This game is unforgiving, ruthless, and requires constant thinking and moving - or you die. And die you will. But this, however pointless as it sounds, is what makes the sandbox mode (the only mode available for the early access) so damn appealing. Each time you start over, you begin to pick up on things you didn't previously. You learn how to manage your resources better, how to assess and prioritize which needs should be met, and all the while you watch the clock and count the hours that go by with intensity and hope, however small that hope is - to live just a bit longer... to hold on, to find a way.

The Long Dark is absolutely amazing and simply downright a blast to play. I can honestly say that it has me excited and hooked already. I'm looking forward to the Story mode, but for the time being will be completely satisfied with hammering away at the Sandbox.

As of this moment I'd probably give TLD an 8/10. Well done, Hinterland Studio. Well done.

I got this today for review for croatian gaming portal and couldn't wait to lay my hands on it.

So after a few tries, some ups and downs and one unpleasant Fluffy encounter, I decided to share my thoughts. :)

First of all, unlike all those boring zombie survivals, this concept is excellent. From graphics, atmosphere, music... And it will just get better since it's early alpha.

My first Early Access game that I bought was Starpoint Gemini 2. And I'm thankful for it cause the devs were, and still are, so active and friendly to the community that they actually showed everyone what Early Access is all about.

It seems devs are reading these forums too, and I'm glad for it.

Things I'm missing at the moment is map (Ihave that awesome guide someone posted along with the map and it really helped me), but I know map will come laters.

I had NONE crashes and NONE performance issues whatsoever. The game is, at least for me, perfectly stable and smooth. Good work on that considering it's still alpha.

Highly recommended and I can't wait for future updates and features! :)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'll admit, it was the unique art style of The Long Dark that initially drew me in.  I loved the way the lighting seemed to work with the stark contrast between the whites and browns of nature and the reds and chestnuts of man man objects.  There is no denying the game is absolutely gorgeous, and it succeeds in making you want to kick down your front door and go exploring.

However, you had better pray that you can find a hammer and nails to reattach that door before the sun goes down.  The beauty of The Long Dark is also it's most dangerous aspect.  It's easy to get lost in the wonderful landscape that Hinterland Games has crafted, but underneath a black night sky with plummeting temperatures it is only a siren's song.  Wolves will stalk your trail, seemingly alert to your deteriorating condition.  Sometimes, the only way you will know their presence is through their foreboding howls, following you as you desperately seek shelter from the freezing cold and brutal wind.

Eating food, staying hydrated, rested and warm are essential to survival in The Long Dark.  You will find supplies like candy bars, pork & beans, beef jerky and military food packets to help you stay alive.  The attention to detail is delightful even if it stands in the way of your best case scenario for living another day.  Canned food requires a can opener to access, unless you want to smash it open and risk losing some of the food.  Your character will make remarks when he/she is hungry, thirsty, cold or tired and you would do well to take care of these ailments before they start affecting your condition.  When your condition meter reaches 0%, you will finally succumb to the Terrible Outdoors.  The Long Dark will give you stats on how long you managed to survive and what you died of before sending you back to the main menu.

The alpha version of the game features a Survival sandbox, with a story about a Geomagnetic disaster coming later with the full game release.  For now, purchasing the Early Access version helps the studio identify and fix issues with the game, and helps them fund the overall project through release.

If you love open world games with gorgeous visuals, unique gameplay, and you have the desire to see how long you would survive in the middle of nowhere with limited supplies;  The Long Dark is for you.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The Long Dark.No monster, pure survival. Yup, 4 kata itu merupakan kata kunci. The Long Dark merupakan game yang mengetes bagaimana kemampuan survival lo ditanah dingin Amerika bagian utara. Suhunya bahkan bisa mencapai -20 derajat celcius. Kalau lo suka game bertemakan survival, mungkin sebaiknya lo baca dulu review ini baru beli.

Review ini gue tulis berdasarkan early access dan 5 jam gameplay.

Score total = 7 dari 10
Storyline:Gak ada. Katanya sih nanti bakalan dikembangkan lagi. Maklum namanya juga masih early access.

Grafik:Standart 3D cartoon. Kalau lo liat screenshot yang ada di steam store, mungkin lo takjub dengan berbagai macam scenery nya. Tapi perlu di ingat, itu merupakan scenery lho. Kalau lo terjun langsung kedalam game, lo MEMANG bakalan melihat scenery seperti itu, tapiiiii.... kalau lo liat objek yang ada disekitar lo, lo bakalan sadar bahwa tekstur dari objek disekitar lo bertekstur kartun. Bisa dibilang low budget The Walking Dead Telltale. Nah, animasi yang ditawarkan juga sederhana... kebanyakan yang bakalan lo lihat adalah panel loading loading progress.. pas makan, lo gak akan melihat karakter lo memasukan makanan ke mulutnya, tapi panel loading progress. Mau minum? loading progress. Mau menyalakan api? loading progress. Mau looting? loading progress. Mau crafting? Loading progress. Emang sih terkesan simple tapi kalau hampir setiap action yang kita lakukan adalah loading progress, rada bete juga kan? Kalau lo gak masalah dengan loading progress, its okay. for me, its kinda big deal. Walau pun begitu, lo bakalan merasakan pengalaman yang cukup real. Badai saljunya itu bener bener DINGIN banget. Lo kerasa deh bagaimana angin berhembus dengan cepat dan jarak pandang lo berkurang akibat kabut. Serius. Gue hampir aja mati ditengah badai salju. Gue mencari rumah untuk berteduh dibawah derasnya badai salju. Nyawa gue udah 50%. Akhirnya gue duduk dibawah batu besar berharap badainya berhenti. Tapi karena nyawa gue udah turun drastis, gue nekat! Eh gak nyampe 20 detik, ternyata disebelah gue persis ada rumah. PERSIS lho. Badainya bener bener top banget.

Sounds:Salah satu aspek paling keren di game ini. Suaranya bener bener ngebuat lo kerasa banget dinginnya. Badai, salju, jejak kaki, binatang liar, kayu yang terbakar, kabin yang ditiup angin kencang, semuanya itu bener bener keren dikuping gue.

Gameplay:Survival, looting, and crafting. Yup, ini bumbu manis banget untuk para gamers di tahun 2013 keatas. Seperti yang lo tau, ini game bertemakan survival ditengah wilayah salju yang liar. Spoiler alert: Lo pasti mati. Yup, ini adalah tipikal game yang gak bisa dimenangkan. Game ini hanya mengetes seberapa lama lo bertahan dipadang salju yang liar. Kalau lo udah gak tertarik, lo bisa berhenti membaca review ini disini. Nah, untuk looting, didalam game ini lo musti mencari berbagai macam kebutuhan dasar hidup dikabin kabin peninggalan penduduk sebelumnya. Lo musti mencari makanan, minuman, baju, tool, dan fuel. Yup secara keseluruhan itu tadi adalah kebutuhan lo didalam game ini. makanan, minuman, baju, dan tool udah jelas yah. Nah fuel ini penting karena mau gak mau lo bakalan kedinginan dan satu satunya cara supaya gak kedinginan adalah lo musti bisa menyalakan api. disini, api gak cuman buat menghangatkan badan aja tapi juga untuk memasak daging mentah. sip, selain looting, lo musti juga pintar pintar crafting. sejauh ini nih, masih sedikit banget item yang bisa lo crafting. bahkan ya, gue udah bisa menebak end game nya seperti apa: sepatu rusa, sarung tangan rabit, dan jaket bulu serigala. Oh lo bakalan mati kehausan. trust me, you will be dehydrated.


Kesimpulan:Yup, game ini masih early access. Secara masih banyak banget animasi yang bisa dikembangkan tapi malah dibuat panel loading progress dan item yang bisa dicrafting nya juga sedikit banget. Tambah lagi gak ada storyline dan fakta bahwa lo pasti mati itu yang membuat usaha lo dalam survival rasanya jadi sia sia.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis game, even at this early stage is a totally engrossing experience. I've never felt more vulnerable and alone in a game, than here. The Canadian wilderness is beautifully realized, and the atmospheric effects of the environment pull you in so effectively, you'd swear you were really lost in the barrens. Scavenging for supplies is at times both stressful and rewarding, and the threat of wild wolves lurking around the corner keeps you on your toes. Though that's not your only enemy, as the weather can change from sunny and clear, to blizzard conditions with no visibility. Haunting and moody, this game has the potential to be one of the best gameplay experiences in a very long time, and I know it was money well spent for me. Bravo.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Very polished for an early access title, The Long Dark, it a fun thought slightly limited game. Once you’ve played enough to memorize the maps the gameplay can become stale, though the introduction of a story mode in the final release hopefully will change that.

The items needed for survival are generated through the map randomly which spices up the gameplay, but I wish there were more enterable buildings and shelters. Maybe more will be introduced in the coming updates.

Ending on a very favorable note, the developers are transparent and really make you feel like you’re being heard. There is no radio silence like some early access games.


Overall, The Long Dark is a favorable experience and worth a buy. It is one of the best survival games out there at the moment and I’m excited to see what the full release has to offer.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is somthing of a niche at the moment. It is a survival game which doesnt hold your hand learning everything; yet the intuitive controls and crafting system makes learning fun.

You will die a lot in this game, half the timeby negligence, the other half by wolves (as of now you can turn off hostile wildlife) and really is a trial by error sort of scenario. For example I was on day 18 and was travelling between maps (a pretty cool feature) and was crossing a bridge and was looking at the view when I fell and died.

You wouldn't even know its in Early Access. I havent come across any bugs or issues yet. The developers are clearly devoted to the game with the frequency of updates while making the game at its current stage the best it can be.

Overall great game, get it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Right straight off the bat, this game is brutal. In my 2 hours of gameplay at time of writing I've died twice and been attacked by wolves 4 times. Yet I've enjoyed every minute so far, and it really feels like I've played for much much longer.

The mechanics are rather simple, and therein lies the games strength. Keep yourself rested,warm,fed,watered & out of trouble to survive, everything you do burns calories, so make sure you have enough to stay fit.

The world is stunningly realised and if wandering around aimlessly wasn't so fatal, I could spend a long time exploring the initial map the sandbox mode currently has available.

Time for a few minor gripes. Whilst you do need a lot of calories to survive in the cold (approx 6000-8000 a day) the game does burn through a considerable amount more than that. I checked when indoors, with a 'feels like' temperature of 19C (i.e. typical room temperature) with all my winter gear on, I was burning 200+ cal per hour, so almost the expected cold requirement, only at room temp. Whilst increasing this value for gameplay reasons is understandable, I have basically spent my entire play time so far both hungry and eating almost constantly.

My only other gripe is the wolves, and the systems designed to combat them. There are a lot of wolves, and they are very aggressive (pretty much attack on sight) and can be warded off with flares. But if they attack you, the only course of action is to frantically punch them, which can get slightly silly if you have a knife on your character.

Wrapping it up, overall an enjoyable, robust experience (especially for early access) that could do with a few minor balancing changes to avoid having to eat near constantly just to prevent your hunger level getting worse. Also as it's in the trailer it's not much of a spoiler, yes there is a wolf in the dam, his name his Fluffy, and he respawns.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you like in depth, realistic, good looking games then I garuntee you will like this one! The long dark is by far in the top 5 survival games I've played, with its cartoony look it still seems to put other games looks and graphics to shame. The scenary is just one of the most beautiful thing I've seen in a game before. This game has a very neat inventory system that is very in depth in the sense you can forage for wood and it will give you the amount of calories you will burn along with the wear it will do to your items, you can also repair your clothes with a sewing kit, or even harvest cloth from your clothes these are only 3 of the things you can do from your in depth inventory system.

This game is only in alpha and it is already a stunning game I can't imagine what this game will be like when it is fully finished and has storymode and multiplayer. All in all I'm not a real big PC gamer but this game always keeps me on the edge of my seat. I really recommend this game to anyone I garuntee it is a great acturate realalistic survival simulator and you will not waste your money!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So in 2013 I did a race that was considered one of the toughest mountain bike races in the world, The Tour Divide.  It extended from Canada to Mexico over the Continental Divide, unsupported.  We started in Banff, Canada and rode out from there where we were left to our own wits and survival.  Everything I had for the next month was on my bike and that's how I lived.

The Long Dark, while you're not on a bike, is a bit like the race.  You're constantly wondering if you have enough food, enough water, was there a predator lurking about (not wolves, we had to worry about Grizzlies).  In the game, you do this, you figure stuff out and it's fun... depressing, but fun.

This is the first game I'm actively avoiding all videos, how-to's and spoilers because I want to figure it out on my own, take my time and enjoy it.  The artistic beauty, grim deaths and isolated gameplay really throw me back in the Tour Divide pushing my bike up the side of a mountain in the middle of the night, alone and freezing.

As a casual gamer who lightly plays games, I cannot recommend this enough.  I feel drawn in and cold" when I play it and it's a haunting comfort to hop in and play.

It does come with a few snags and that's mainly performance on my Macbook Air.  It gets a little sluggish in fullscreen but runs fine in a smaller window.  I don't mind.

(Also if you're interested
date: I wrote a book about the Tour Divide race which has some similarities to The Long Dark.  You can find out more at http://www.softpedaling.com)."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The game is very survivalist in nature, moreso than any other game I've played in the genre. You have to keep aware of your calorie balance, body temperature, hydration, and sleep schedule while balancing the risk/rewards of exploring or sticking around a safe point. Unforgiving in a good way without being too obtuse in how your health is affected by actions, sprained ankles are the biggest bother.

It's nice to have a survival game where crafting or house building is not a part. This one is essentially up to your senses. The game's a bit rough and patches ♥♥♥♥ with a lot, but it looks promising so far.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have been following this game since the Kickstarter last year. (Which I backed)
I had pretty high hopes for this game and it showed great potential.

As many other reviewers pointed out, when this game first released into Early Access it was almost unplayable. You froze within minutes of starting, or you died of hunger within minutes of starting, or you ran out of calories within minutes of starting, or you died of thirst within minutes of starting or you get killed by a wolf within seconds of starting. Yes, seconds. Once a wolf had you in sights, you might as well restart because there was no escaping or surviving. If you managed to somehow survive a wolf attack, you would quickly die of infection or bleeding out. Why in the hell can't you use your hatchet or hunting knife or rifle to kill it when it attacks you?!? Cooking the food did no good. You still got food poisoning even after cooking the food. RIDICULOUS! Sitting ONE inch away from a BURNING FIRE didn't even help warm you up a single degree, even while you're using one of the pits inside the house. How does a fire in a house not warm you up past 40 degrees?!? Especially when you're basically standing INSIDE the damn fire.

But since the latest update, they have addressed ALMOST ALL OF THESE ISSUES! Calories don't burn QUITE as fast. Still really damn quick though. You definitely don't freeze as fast. A fire finally seems to warm you up when you're sitting next to it. Hunger takes a TINY bit longer to kick in and thirst is pretty easy to quench so long as you have even the tiniest amount of water. The wolfs no longer home in on you like a heat-seeker missile. You can actually run away now, but only IF you are far enough away. Cooking the food finally seems to help from getting food poisoning(ABOUT TIME).

They still haven't addressed being able to use the HUNTING knife or Hatchet to fight the wolf off. You still have to fight it off with your bare hands, which is ALMOST impossible. Seriously, why have a HUNTING knife if you can't use it when you get attacked?!?

The game is beautiful and the artwork is amazing. The sounds and music are both really good. It just needs some minor tweaks to help make it a lot better.

I'm glad I waited until after they did a few updates before I did this review, because if I hadn't then it would have just been all negative. But instead I waited to let them get the updates out. This way I got to try it both BEFORE and AFTER the updates. The game has IMPROVED VASTLY with these new updates. I really hope they continue to listen to feedback and make adjustments accordingly. So far, it's working out pretty well.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Not being one to review games on public forums such as STEAM , I was so impressed by this one that I though it high time I started.

The Long Dark is indeed a game about survival.. but also funnily enough (at least at this stage) an exploration into what it is to be human. The mechanics are simple and quite mathematical in nature.. warmth, hunger and thirst vs time and resources, however given that routine is often interrupted by disease or wolf attack the game makes you head out of whatever comfort zone you've created to search for the rarities that make life sustainable.

I found this game ultimately eventuates into posing the question why keep going?" and those steam achievements certainly rank high in the game's longevity. More importantly I found myself thinking .. "would I keep going?" surely there is something in our makeup that makes gripping onto life with every last ounce of strength...  a game mechanic that is both powerful and compelling.

I was an alpha backer of minecraft
date: the most amazing part of that experience was the journey I took with that game (and Notch) as it evolved into the massive beast it has become. The Long Dark is evolving
recommended: and I think part of the attraction I have to this game
hoursPlayed: is the oppportunity to follow the bread crumb trail that the developers scatter as this game flourishes into maturity."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Just finished a 40 day run. Died from food poisoning after eating rotten meat.

I don't usually buy Early Access Games, but I wanted to give this one a shot after reading the excellent reviews. The artwork appealed to me, as did the fact that it was a more realistic and zombie-free survival/exploration game. As it stands, although highly enjoyable, this game is probably not worth the full $20 just for the sandbox mode, simply because the gameplay is rather limited in scope at the moment. But I think that once story mode is released it will be a more well-rounded game.


Pros:

Great artwork and overall atmosphere

Simple concept that works

Highly immersive


Cons:

Gets a touch repetitive at times

Lacks missions or goals, other than just survival

You can never win"... you always die eventually


Final verdict: An excellent game
date: but you may want to wait for it to be finished unless you don't mind sandbox-only gameplay."

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThe Long Dark tells the fantastic tale of Will Mackenzie.  Will being a pilot who flies cargo planes full of rubber dog ♥♥♥♥ through northern Canada finds himself stuck in those very woods in the Norhern Canadian wilderness.  Not only that but he appears to be the last person alive on Earth.  Apparently what happened was there was a global disaster where it's freezing cold all the time and everything is broken and this leads to wolves taking over the world.  These aren't ordinary wolves no, these are magic wolves.  They appear out of nowhere and multiply like cockroaches and will kill you on site.  Thank God Will has plenty of fuzzy Canadian winter hats laying around and more then enough normal gloves to wear.  I almost forgot the abundance of canned sardines Will get's to eat because apparently Canadians can't get enough canned sardnes, those things are freaking everywhere.  Overall not bad but the finished product has a ways to go.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Day 1: I have nothing but a box of matches as I huddle behind a pile of logs to stay out of the wind. I try to light a fire, but the blizzard keeps blowing out my tinder. I don't dare leave the relative safety of the logs and freeze in the storm, but I can see the direction of the snow being blown around me is starting to shift.. I don't have much time before I freeze, so I start sprinting through the blinding snow in hopes of finding shelter. After what seems like days, I spot something red whipping in the wind. It's the Canadian flag, and it's in front of a small cabin. Safe at last.

Day 8: I've recovered from the minor frostbite, and have been fishing through a hole in the ice for the last few days. Between foraging for wood and melting snow for water, I've built up quite an appetite. The salmon and trout have kept me full, but the axe I found in this cabin is almost about to break. So I stock up on fresh water and tinder, and I head out into the wilderness for another place to stay.

Day 10: I've found a hunting cabin with a rifle!! Sadly, I can't find any bullets.. But the weight in my hands give me a sense of security, false as it may be. But now I'm determined to change my fortune. I won't just endure the environment anymore... I'll thrive in it. I just need a few rounds to start eating some tasty wolf meat.
Tasty wolf meat.
Wolf meat.
Meat.
Me.

Day 12: There's a forest lookout on top of a mountain. Rangers and Mounties have guns, right? Probably bullets too.
As I start my ascent to the top of the mountain, I hear a wolf howl. God damn tasty wolf, all full of meat and ♥♥♥♥... It could be anywhere. What are the chances of it being on this pat--- OH ♥♥♥♥ it's turning the corner in front of me!
Now it's just me and the wolf. I slowly drop the rifle and bring out a flair. It lights and hurts my eyes, but it's the only thing I have to potentially scare it off.
The hair on it's back stands on end. I can hear the growls start to intensify. It's about to charge, but just as it leaps forward I throw my flair at it and hear it yelp in surprise. It runs away from the stick of life-saving white-phosphorous, and I am inclined to run after it. It won't be scared for long, and it can catch up to me if I run down the mountain. My only hope is to make it to the forestry lookout before it regains it's wits.
The sound of wooden stairs beneath my body weight was a welcome change.

Day 29: Well, I'm a master hunter now. I found bullets in the lookout, hunted that wolf, and ate every ounce of meat off his body. Tasty wolf meat.
Since then I've killed several more wolves, and have had the luxury of fast exploration now that my boom-stick assures me safety. I've found knives, hatchets, tools, and more clothing and canned food than I know what to do with. My run in with fluffy at the dam might haunt me for a while, but at the moment I'm far away from that place. Some kind of Coastal Highway. My current living conditions have been fairly pleasant. There's a garage with a convenience store that still had some snacks, but I've found plenty of bullets in the surrounding cabins, so deer and wold meat is never far away. I think I'll go get more of a stockpile from the other surrounding cabins.

Walking on the road I see a black shape over a hill, but it quickly dissapears behind a tree. I investigate, but come up empty. No paw prints, no wolf. But what's this? A dead deer on the side of the lake. I can still feel it's body heat residing in the carcass... but I didn't kill this deer. A quick 360 scan and no sign of a predator. Ah well! I got 12lbs of meat off this deer. I can eat happy for a week and make it to a full month!

But as I walk towards the garage, the wolf (presumably the one who took down the deer) turns the corner and charges at me. My rifle round pierces it's hip, but doesn't kill it. I feel it's teeth on my neck. I'm meat to it, and I know what hunger does to a living thing.
But my knife meets it's ribs, and it jumps off of my in fright. But this isn't over, you stupid wolf. You're full of calories that I NEED! But this deer meat is slowing me down, and the wolf is now too far away to risk shooting at it. I'll probably miss.

So after I drop the raw deer meat on the ground I start my pursuit. The wolf keeps it's distance, but I'm waiting for it to turn it's flank to me so I can get a larger target. It's been 29 days and 12 hours since this plane crashed, and with this deer and wolf I'll surely be able to make it to day 40 in that garage. The thought of turning away this wolf-meal is unimaginable right now.

Gun in hand, I bring the rifle stock to my shoulder. My cheek pressed firmly on the butt of the rifle, I aim down the sites. My cold finger begins to gently squeeze the trigger. I can't miss.

Something hits me. Big. Black. Hungry.
It's a wolf. That ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ had a pack with him.
Biting.
Wolf.
Meat.
Me.
Meal.

The Long Dark...


Game is 15/10.

Seriously, it's the only thing I play anymore. They could leave it untouched and I'd be happy, but the thought that they're adding more to it all the time is seriously the best thing ever. Get it.

Food for thought: A hunting sim would be a cool mod, DLC, or workshop idea though. Like you start off in the trappers cabin with a bunch of fire logs and MRE's, plenty of bullets and tools. Just to kinda have a game mode where you could screw around and shoot stuff. I'd love to shoot at the crows, but in the current sandbox if I miss and waste a bullet it's a terrible loss for me, so I don't if they're food sources or not.

Maybe survival books that could give the player more crafting ideas? I mean, they're all over the place in Canada. Everyone has at least one. And there are some pretty cool (albiet advanced) traps out there for birds and such.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I really love this game. Because it's smart, and it treats me as a gamer, and as a developer as such.  There's nothing hand holding about the survival, there are no explicit tutorials, it doesn't assume I'm 12 years old and have never stood out in a forest in my life.  It's smart, And it's challenging.  A tremendous amount of the survival comes from how you play it, the game is never unfair, if you died, it's because you made poor decisions, or as is often the case in real survival, one fatal misstep that led to a cascade of errors.

The Long Dark is gorgeous, smart, and an engrossing play.  I don't know why you're still reading this and not buying it already.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The Long Dark is everything I wanted Skyrim to be. I loved Skyrim. I still do. But I wanted more realism. I wanted to feel like every little choice really mattered. In Skyrim, you can run through the snow in your underwear, and the only thing you have to worry about is stumbling across a wolf or troll, but you can usually cut them down with a chop or two.

Not so with The Long Dark. The Long Dark, even in its alpha stage is as intense and challenging as a game of chess against the game world itself. Every move you make has consequences. Every little thing you do or don't do could mean life or death.

You are a survivor of a plane crash in the Canadian North. You have the shirt on your back, a pair of boots, and a few bits of food. You're in a blizzard in the middle of nowhere, and there are wolves on the hunt. Go.

Maybe you see a cabin in the distance, in the blinding cold and blowing snow. Maybe you find a hatchet. Maybe you find nothing at all. You're slowly freezing to death, but you must find some wood. Do you have enough calories to go out foraging? But if you don't, how will you melt snow and boil it to get clean water? You're thirsty too. Very thirsty. And the clock is ticking.

It's this kind of intensity, this kind of challenge, where consequences loom behing every little choice that's missing in almost every other game I've ever played. It keeps you coming back, again and again, even after you died so many times in the bitter cold. You keep coming back because you learned something, and you just might do better the next time. You just might survive a few more days.

A good game rewards you. And this is something that's beautiful in The Long Dark. Because every little choice matters, because every hour of survival is bought with intelligent choices and lots of luck, that one scrap of food or firewood you find in a cabin is worth more than gold to you. You almost want to cheer. The rewards are doled out like breadcrumbs down the trail of life, and you keep searching for the next one. You keep fighting for your next hour of life.

You're also rewarded by levelling up skills. You become better and better at making a fire after a few days. You improve in repairing and crafting new gear.

The crafting system is interesting and engaging as well. You find an old pair of pants or a sweater that you don't need? Harvest it for cloth and use it to repair the gear you're already wearing. Patch that hole the wolves tore in it. Fix up your hatchet with the scrap metal you found in a locker. Cobble together a pair of deerskin boots with the hides you've scavenged off of a carcass in the woods. It's all so involving, and it only adds to the sense of reward. I made this! And it just might help me survive a few more days.

The music is creepy and intense, but it only comes on occasionally, when something of consequence is going down. Otherwise, there's only the wind and woods, creaking trees, squawking crows, and your own breath.

The graphics are stylized. It's not a realistic world. It's somewhat cartoony, TF2 style. But it's not a flaw. You can see for miles on a clear day, and everything looks beautiful, like a painting you've somehow wandered into, a painting that's trying to kill you.

And thank God, there are no zombies. I'm sick to death of zombies. This game pits you against the real world, a world unpolluted by all the survival horror cliches that have been done to death in by every other game in the past ten years. (Guitar Hero: Zombie Edition? Go f*ck yourself.)

If I had to complain about anything in this game, I'd say the item lists need to be expanded. There are only five or six types of food. A couple of each type of clothing. Tools, weapons, gear--they all need to be diversified. After a few hours of play, I'd discovered pretty much everything there was to be discovered. I was no longer being surprised. The rewards were still rewarding, but I would have been thrilled to walk into a house somewhere and find some new article of clothing or type of food I'd never even seen before.

The wolves are too over-powered at times, and you spend a lot of time just walking around in very wide circles to avoid them. Some items, weapons, or defense that might give you a bit of an edge on them would be awesome, especially if it took a hell of a lot to earn it.

I got stuck in a hole at some point, between two boulders by a bridge. The walls were too steep, and I couldn't get out. I was worried I'd be stuck there and lose my week's worth of gear. But I somehow managed to go into crawl mode and wiggle and squirm until I glitched right through the ground. then I was walking under the earth. All of this could have been avoided with a simple jump function.

The game is still in alpha, so all these things will surely be fixed over time. And all these things are forgivable, considering the massive amounts of fun I'm having. It's looking like the devs at Hinterland are putting out an update every couple of weeks. I look forward to the new developments. New regions to explore. New animals to hunt and be hunted by. Maybe even a multiplayer mode, where you can team up with a buddy or two and face the elements together, or hunt each other down in a last-man-standing survival showdown. That would be too amazing for words.

All that is yet to come. For now, I recommend this game to anyone who likes an intellectual challenge in their game play. You'll be hard pressed to find this much intensity in any other game you can pick up for only $20. If you enjoy a game that makes you think, strategize, and plan every move in order to win, you'll love The Long Dark. If you're more the mindless hack n' slash type, you might still like it. There is excitment, there is atmosphere, there are scares and thrills. But mostly it's about slow, methodical puzzle solving, where every move could mean a miserable death, bleeding out in the dark, with an empty stomach in the cold bitter snow...

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Instantly The Long Dark makes you alter your play style different. Everything can take a toll on your character such as spraining an ankle while walking down a steep slope or getting sick from unboiled water. For this current state of the game it is truly at a solid and sets the foundations for a lot of further potential.

My only concerns are that the current level is relatively small and perhaps the developers should reconsider the possible of a Coop or Multiplayer option. While The Long Dark offers a great & unique experience, I worry that without a multiplayer function, it's replayability is limited. However it's possible that once development reaches a further point, the extent of more content might solve this problem in it's self.

Overall it is highly worth checking out and worth every bit of the $19.99 price tag

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Fricking great game! Awesome survival mechanics, very brutal. Even in just alpha, it's great. Totally worth the money to back the game. If you like awesome survival games, BUY IT. Every time someone buys the game, it goes towards making it even better.

Update: The Game is even better now! This latest update added a lot of stuff to it, including difficulty levels, and a new map to explore/survive. Still no story mode yet, but the sandbox is just as fun if not even more fun. Totally worth buying/backing.

Update:Once again they have improved this already very good game. With this most recent update, they've added a HUGE new area, and several other new features, including but not limited too; BEARS. Harvestable plants. And new crafting recipes. They've also greatly improved they AI and rebalanced the calorie usage and crafting requirements, and have also updated the inventory system, which was a major improvement. It is however still almost impossible to find a fricking rifle. XD Really REALLY good game. I'd easily pay $30 just for this. They could sell it as is without the story mode and I'd be perfectly happy. IT IS A MUST BUY.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Let me start by saying that I only have had about an hour on this game when I am writing this. (Ultimatley this is just a testament as to how highly I think of this game.) Also I am very limited on some aspects as I use a not so decent laptop for my PC gaming right now.

Anyway though, this game took me by suprise. I saw the videos adn thought that it wouldn't honestly be that great, despite it only being in Alpha. Turns out that it being in Alpha still is a GREAT thing. While bugs and the such do arise (natural) I find it to be worth it. The mechanics of the game are beautiful and the gameplay itself, while slow-paced and (for your first few attempts at the game) quite unrewarding you will soon find yourself knowing where stuff is and where to go next. The graphics are indeed very nice and the artstyle used is just jawdropping to me. My absolute favorite part is the game itself though, and its gameplay. Instead of throwing zombies or cannibals (Mmmhm Forest and 7 Days to Die) at you like crazy, your primary threat is nature itself. You find yourself quickly on the verge of freeaing to death after spending adn hour harvesting 9 KG of venison and let me tell you, you do not wana go out like that.

Overall I simply love the game and the fact that it is in Alpha only makes me happier that I bought it. I now get to see the game evolve into something that could truly be worth way more the standard price of 20.

I r8 8/8 m8.
Would waste 5/6 bullets missing deer again.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The best part of this game is the fight against the elements: the cold, the hunger, the dark.  Getting stuck in a fish-hut on a frozen lake in a seemingly endless cycle of blizzards and blinding, heavy fog. Getting lost in the forest in the middle of the night when you're only 500 meters from home but you can't remember which way you came from.

It's very satisfactory to craft better clothing from deer hides and rabbit fur. To find medicinal plants. To find a cave that protects you from the icy wind and make a lifesaving fire. Then make a nice, hot herbal tea that revitalizes you.

The art style is beautiful and evocative. There's much to explore: forests, lakes and mountains, settlements, abandoned mines and highways.

And then there are the wolves. They ruin everything. Your clothes, and your fun. Fortunately, you can play on a mode called Pilgrim where the wolves (and the bears) don't attack you, so you can focus on survival rather than stealth.

The game is quite stable and runs well.

In sandbox mode there is a lack of positive goals, but there is a story mode still to come.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

My review of
----------------------------------------
FINNISH COMMUTE SIMULATOR 2015
----------------------------------------
As being a Finn, this doesn't do much for me. Dont get me wrong, its awesome game. Its just that freezing temperatures, finding snacks in the forest and fending off wildlife is just something we do day-to day basis here.
I would say graphics-wise this game is very realistic. When the wind freezes your eyeballs right in the sockets, world does look a little cartooney.
Since this is early access, i understand some features are still missing:

- Scraping ice off your car windows with a dull scrape
- Taking off/putting on your clothes not implemented yet its now instant, when it should take more than 30 minutes
- Too much to do. There isnt really anything to do in the winter
- Snow is always snow, and not that wet ♥♥♥♥ that its 80% of the year
- Add summer that lasts 2 weeks, when we dont get that much snow. (Midsummer festival excluded of course, it always snows then)
- Simulated depression with lonely suicide is missing

Otherwise, it does a good job simulating typical Finnish commute.
Now, if you excuse me, i have a few wolf bites to take care of, i just came from work.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The Long Dark is a first person, open world, survival game being developed by a rather new company called Hinterland. I bought this game back when it was very, very new. And there was, and still is a lot of potential for this rather unexpected gem. I don't often write reviews on Alpha/Beta/Early Access titles, and typically, when I do, they're because you can tell the'll be utter ♥♥♥♥♥.

I'm pleased to say, that I've yet to be disappointed by Hinterland Studio. The Long Dark, in its current state, has only the Sandbox Mode, an open-world survival that we're all too familiar with, with three difficulties, and the obvious absence of a story-mode. Survival games are now so common, like your failure to potty train your dog, you can't walk more than two feet without stepping on ♥♥♥♥♥. And often, this ♥♥♥♥♥ brings about a revolted feeling of disgust and you urgently rush to the washroom to clean the filth away.

In otherwords, since the rise of Minecraft, there's been a few gems in the Survival genre, but the majority have been such massive disappointments, you'd think that the only service their dev-companies could do now, is to beat themselves in the face with a club labled bankruptcy. It seems so irritating, to be taunted constantly with these games, of the next-generation survival"
date: only to discover that its only usefulnes is to help fix the unlevel table in your dining room.\n\nI spent the majority of my time at first

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Day 29.
I had survived off nothing but dog food and a couple of granola bars for days, survived several bouts of hand to hand (Paw?) combat with wolves, survived dysentery, survived food poisoning from eating meat off a ravaged deer corpse, Fluffy the friendly wolf hugged me too tightly in the dam, I was mauled by a bear, I fell off a ledge and damaged my ankles, went back with a rifle and murdered the aforementioned bear out of spite, taking its pelt as a trophy and placing it next to my sleeping bag every night.

Then I got caught in the mother of all blizzards in an unfamiliar area and had to take shelter in a car, as the total whiteout made me lose all sense of direction and the windchill was at factor turbodoom. After all the trauma, bada**ery and lonely nights spent next to my campfire and the skin of Bozo the Bear, it was nature itself that did me in. I slowly froze to death in the passenger seat of a purple lada whilst sobbing quietly and eating chocolate bars with the last of my strength.

10/10, would (And will) shamefully freeze to death again.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI love this game I'm so serious I'm so invested in this game. I don't know why I love it so much more than other survival games but. Maybe it's the simple but beautiful graphics. Maybe it's the depth of realism in that you die easily to a lot of stuff. Really, I think, it's everything. The detail of wind in your ears, fog rolling in, wolves howling, the sunset changing colors... After almost 50 hours and numerous files and deaths, I still find things I haven't before. I am still awed and humbled by the beauty of this game. Bravo, Hinterland. Bravo. You are Da Vinci; this game is the Mona Lisa.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Rank: 8/10
Recommendation(s): Stop playing other “survival games”, play this instead.
Major Theme: The Canadian take on survival games.
Bought at Price: $5.49

What does survival mean to you? Many players who think of this term immediately think of Ark, DayZ and Rust. Little do they know, survival (at least in its hardcore sense) should be about a battle between the environment and yourself. Player vs. Player survival games are notoriously hard to balance between new players who find themselves punished constantly by long term players with the best items/armor/weaponry.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=645019223
The Long Dark is certainly the Canadian take on survival games. I’m proud as a Canadian to have this game demonstrate the ingenuity and worldview of my Country. Throw out the whole player vs. player mechanic and focus on the actual source of difficulty in a survival game – the environment.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=645019317
I’ve jokingly said to a few people that this is the Canadian citizenship test. More seriously however, I’ve brought up the fact that the simplistic graphics don’t take away anything from this title. If you find the game too hard, set the difficulty down and just enjoy the art of the game.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=645019257
Game mechanics are original, and well thought out. I like this as it’s a path less taken. I don’t think The Long Dark will gain a foothold like DayZ or Ark, but it certainly should be known for not taking the easy route.

There are still a few issues I have with the game, but Workshop support certainly makes me a lot more comfortable knowing that if things aren’t resolved, someone from the community will resolve them.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The Long Dark finds a very happy place between the artistry of an indie exploration game and the authenticity of a simulator.  It is daunting, engrossing, beautiful, and surpirsingly sensible.  The challenge of survival in a rugged winter wilderness will make you grin in earnest at the discovery of months-old sardine tins, and cringe at the pitter pattering sound of wolf paws on packed snow.

Can't wait for the full release.
voteText: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI bought this game over the objections of a close friend and I am glad I ignored his advice.  Love this game!  For me the weather, from snow storms to the cold is a bigger threat than the wolves (once I figured out how to make bandages that is), the icy silence of my boots on the snow and ice is a constant companion to the mournful howling of the wind.  That aside I wish there was a tutorial of sorts to show me how to craft snares, boil water etc.  Steam guides and blind dumb luck have been the only reason I made it beyond day 5.  I really dig the survival aspect of this game and I realize it's in Alpha still but I do wish surviving was a little easier, or resources a bit more plentiful, or maybe I should just play more and try not to suck.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI can't stop playing this game, furthermore, I don't want to stop. It just keeps getting better and better. Maybe I've spent too many winter nights in a tent or read too many Antarctica tales, but this game to me, appeals to a basic human need...to be tested. Not by how many zombie ninja robots you can kill or by how many fighting combos you can preform with your mouse buttons but in a way that feels real, you must survive in a world devoid of basic human comforts. A world that many of us could not survive for very long. You must be thoughtful, cautious, you must think ahead, you must plan for the unknown, and all along at the back of your mind in each game is the most realistic game mechanic of all, if you die, all your planning and thoughtful preparation will be for naught, and you will be dead (unless you want to start all over again, which I've done happily about 50 times). Thanks Hinterland!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Now before i start my review, Yes i know i only have 2 hours of playtime but i have learnt how to play the game and how to survive.

The Long Dark is a post apocoliptic survival game, it involves crafting and scavaging inorder to survive which is what i found most appealing about it. When you first start up the game you are greeted by the Hinter Land Games logo, (Looks very sexy) My first time playing the game i knew nothing about it. I clicked start new and i had spawned in. I walked around for a bit trying to find a shelter. A dam is what i found full of all sorts of items i was excited to get my survival gaming back but there was a problem... a big... problem... i forgot that while i was on my way there i had sprained my ankle and cut my leg. so i died... didnt last long but hey i kept on playing. I started up a new game on the map for advanced players (forgot the name of it) i got attacked by a bear and ♥♥♥♥ my self the animation for being attacked was like nothing i have ever seen before it was like i was playing amnesia i thought i was all of a suddern playing a horror game but boy was enjoying it. i managed to survive the attack and run away and bandage my self up at a nearby farm. I found my self a rifle found the bloody bear and killed it with my bear hands... ( see what i did there c; ) I have now survived for 2 days and 24 hours and 31 minutes, I need to find shelter and i feel like im being followed...
The long dark is by far one of my most enjoyed games i have ever played it is a mix of intense survival and the horror of being followed and hunted! i would rate this game a 10/10 for its amazing creativity Hinter Land did a bloody job well done on it and i can't wait for story mode!!!!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Oh look, a first person survival game on Steam that isn't complete tripe. This game is really difficult and a lot of your ability to survive depends on your perseverance and persistence to learn maps, resource management, and weapon locations. You will die a lot (I have not survived very long at the time of this writing). You can play as a dude or a dudette (yay!) and in both cases, you are subjected to utter hell on earth. Unlike other games, which rely on biochemical warfare, nuclear weapons, or zombies to craft apocalyptic hellholes, this one uses freezing cold. Take it from a Coloradan who used to do outdoor education for elementary students, the cold can and does suck if you are not properly equipped.

You start out with your standard survival stuff: fatigue, hunger, thirst, health, and a meter detailing how cold you are or aren't. Lanterns are useful and are rather plentiful in the world, so pick them up. Starting fires can give you warmth, but also consume resources and may fail at the expense of those resources. Water must be purified before hand, or else you will get sick. The main problem I had was locating food, which is difficult to find and can go bad (like in the real world). You need to constantly be moving between shelters and raiding things, which is hard because there are wolves and now bears (have not faced them yet) to harass you. This game is dangerous trial and error, but the most enjoyable kind.

If you want a realistic and challenging survival game, check this one out! The visual styles are really nice and remind me a lot of graphic novels with a dash of Telltale. And hey, if you play the lady, you get to have Ellie from The Last of Us as your narrator. You can't lose. ;)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If I recommend this game? the answer is: YES YES AND YEEEEEEEEEEEEES.
Each update this game gain more and more I fall in love with it, the developers work really hard to make this game the best and they already gave the idea of what the story mode will be with the teaser they showed (I feel so hyped for 2016 right now).
So first things first as is said the game isn't about zombies or player versus player survival, this is the intimate thing, you can face others people and survive ? or zombies ? good but in the long dark this doesn't mean anything, here you have to face the nature, you can kill things ? welp sorry but you can't kill the cold, neither the thirsty or hungry, here you need to always keep yourself warm, with food and resources or: it's over.
The game is really challenging and the better you get more you will want to explore and get better gear and of course if you do a mistake: game over. So if you are like me and love survival games who are always challenge you and is a true survivor, bought this game, is worth it!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Forty two days since my plane went down in this arctic hell. The wind broke long enough for me to venture outside, my growling stomach told me i had little choice. The deer i'd been tracking slowly moved along picking out what bit's of vegetation it could find, ever wary of it's surroundings. I saw my opportunity arise as it stopped ears perked in the opposite direction of me. My rifle came to my shoulder slowly as not to spook the deer, my breath slowed finger on the trigger slowly squeezing back. For a second i could swear i  caught motion out of the corner of my eye, then it happened. The wolf sprang barely giving me enough time to pivot in his direction. My shot was true and i caught him mid chest. No deer for dinner tonight but i find i'm getting used to the taste of wolf.

Let me say that rarely do i ever see a survival game that has pulled me in so deeply, immersed is a word that does not do it justice. Ive actually found myself talking to myself as i move along warning myself not to get too focused on the road ahead and to scan around as i go. Nothing about this game is linear or boring. The graphics are stunning and the dynamics of the game itself work incredibly well. Bravo dev's bravo!

If i had anything to request or add to the game it would possibly be allowing the hatchet or hunting knife be used as a weapon itself and maybe adding an option for scrap metal to be heated in a fire for use in making the basic items for tools weapons etc. One could possibly assemble a crude axe that way etc. I see great potential in this game to evolve into not only a urvival game but a hybrid crafting one as well. The elements of basic survival alone make the game more than challenging for any player, adding a primitive crafting system could only enhance the experience.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I had just finished raiding the lower dam. My rucksack full of loot, I opened a door that led outside from the depths of the dam. I took a glance down and around the ravine, didn't see anything useful, and returned to the door... but it wouldn't open from this side. I was then presented with two options. Attempt to cross a narrow ridge and risk a near certain fall to get across the ravine to an entrance to reenter the dam that may or may not even be there, or descend down into the ravine and follow the frozen river. I chose the later. What followed was a disoriented drudge through tall ravine walls and finally a labyrinthian cave that sent shivers up my spine every time I stepped into the dark. I finally emerged from the caves into a moonlit forest being ravaged by a blizzard. To my dread I could hear the yips and howls of wolves in the distance.

This is what I enjoy about the Long Dark. It will throw you curve balls and it requires you to think on your feet and weigh desicions one of which may be life (at least for a while) and the other may be death. You don't really know what's coming next.

Say you're looking for shelter. Do you stay in the dam and risk dealing with any threats that may dwell within to access all those glorious resources? Or maybe the Trapper's Homestead near replenishable natural resources, but far from anything else? Perhaps Signal Hill with a fence to keep out ravenous predators, but beaing secluded on a lonely peak?

Say you're confronted with a wolf. Do you fire your one remaining .303 round and risk a miss? Throw a flare and lose your only remaining light source? Spare a chunk of meat for a decoy and go hungry yourself? Run and hope for the best?

I highly recommed the twisting, turning journey toward inevitable death that is The Long Dark. It's an excellent product and is a steal at $19.99,

I also suggest heading over to hinterlandgames.com/the-long-dark/roadmap/ to see all of the awesome content Hinterland is hoping to add to the game. Also keep in mind, the much-anticipated Story Mode is quickly approaching.

What I especially like as a female player is that you can choose between a female an a male character. It helps to merge in to the game even more. And you really get absorbed by the game: If you played it for a couple hours you will start to collect matches in real live.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is awesome. I'll give it 10 / 10 in the future.

It has one wonderfull thing, which few of today's games have - it's own, specific CLIMATE. You feel it from the first seconds of play. Things which build up for it are:

1. STORY
You wake up in the middle of nowhere, with no weapon, nor food. The heat of your body constantly falling. There's no time to think, you must act. The game pulls you in at the very beginning and keeps it that way.

2. GAMEPLAY
You constantly need to do something. You're either hungry, thirsty, cold or exhausted. At some point it may gets little tiresome, because you wish you had more time for exploring things and this beautiful world, but if you carry on, you'll explore it anyway (Sandbox).
The game is hard. There's only sandbox mode available with one area, but it gave me 10 hours of solid gameplay anyway. I consider full game with story mode and few more sandbox areas will give at least a couple of times this.

3. GRAPHICS
It is made by a renowned artist Hokyo Lim, author of i.a. The Unfisnished Swan (https://www.google.pl/search?q=unfisnished+swan). He's an out-of-the-box thinker.
Sometimes, you feel like watching a very good movie. But mostly, you feel like you're actually there. Standing there at the top of the mountain and admiring views. Some people may consider it looking a bit too fairy-tale-like, but for me it is suiting.

4. SOUND
The sound effects are what builds up the atmosphere and they are very real. At some point even the howling wind gives you chills because it sounds similiar to the wolf's howling.
The music is heard only occasionally, but the moments choosen to play it build up the atmosphere even more.
There are two PC available - man and woman. Man is vioced by the Mass Effect no.1 voice actor Mark Meer. Female - I don't know, but I think she's not a professionall voice actress or at least for me her voices are disturbing.

CONS:
The game got kind of tiresome after ~10h and a few deaths. There's lot of walking in the beginning and tt's also easy to die. If you die you loose your save. So, if you're hunted down on 2nd day due to distraction, you have to replay the whole part before it really got fun. I think it requires some sort of calibration yet.

To sum it up: This game is made by professionals, who left big gaming companies to create offbeat titles. It has great graphics, music, and nice gameplay. When the story mode will be available, it will be unbelievably good. I predict it will deliver one of the best gaming experience in a long time. And I don't mean survival enthusiasts.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nVery awesome experience. (Caution before buying, make sure you got a good CPU, its CPU intensive) What I love about this is that it's not Humans to try to not get killed by, (they dont have them right now, I don't know if they'll be added or not) and to be honest, wolves aren't that big of a problem either. (though if you do get attacked by one, its very devastating)  It's the more realistic things like hunger, dehydration etc. And when I say that you're CONSTANTLY looking for supplies, you are really on the move 24/7.  After seeing waves of zombie survival hardcore pvp games come out, this is something fresh.  The art style is unique and I really love it.  Being inside a cabin with a fire is really cozy feeling, even if it's just a game.  Although some things are slightly unrealistic and at times outrageous, (such as falling a foot and breaking your ankle, not being able to use your knife to fend off a wolf attack, having to boil your water twice, and things breaking after like 10 uses...) I definitely still reccomend it.  If you doubt      your decision, wait until its complete. 8/10, Fun gameplay, great art style, definitely a challenge compared to other survival games

Early Access Review

The game has a ton of potential at the moment. The survival mechanics are excellent and I love the details in this game like how wind speed contributes to how cold you are and such.

The only gamemode playable right now is sandbox. I can't wait until the story mode is finished, it would be nice to do a proper playthrough.

My only gripe is that you can't survive without constantly looting and it's impossible to live off the land. Being able to live off the land and survive indefinitely would be excellent.

After playing a ton of bad early access games, it's nice to see some quality games on steam.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThe Long Dark is a game in which the player has crash landed his plane into the canadian wilderness. If you play on the Mystery Lake map you bound to get killed by a wolf. But if you play on the coastel highway map, let me just say it is like the 31st of October. This game is a really challenge, if you don't find any weapons (gun, hunting knife,etc.) You are going to die. The combat system is very different and it can use some fixing. I stab a wolf 3 times with full power and only takes away 20% out of 100%. Overall this game could use some fixing, but it is in alpha. For being in alpha this game is sick and I recommend it to anyone that likes realistic survival.
