reviewText:
Early Access Review

Coastal Region update: Easier than Mystery Lake in my opinion, and a nice change of pace with houses and their interiors.

As of V.119 this game is extremely fun even if there isn't a large amount to offer. I found it to be a struggle to just get the 5 day achievement (maybe I just suck) but when I did it was so satisfying. Here is my story of that run.

1. Finds Lake and gets warm clothes, hears laughter of dead children
2. Gets mauled by rabid wolf and fights it off, takes meds
3. Gets stuck in blizzard on lake and sleeps in a hut, probably lost a toe.
4. Wanders through blizzard and finds Camp house, sleeps
5. Goes on a hike, sprains ankle twice
6. Finds hunters house with rifle *how do I open that safe?*
7. Becomes a cook
8. *Finds ammo and murders a wolf*... This was enjoyable.
9. Goes into Dam, shoots giant FLIPPING SCARY WOLF HOLY ♥♥♥♥, gets encumbered, spends 20 minutes taking baby steps. Spends the night in haunted dam.
10. Murders damn wolves for no reason, gets food poisoning randomly. [karma I guess]
11. Arrives at Logging Camp freezing and exhausted, probably lost another toe. Sleeps 12 hours.
12. Walks out in the middle of the night and HOLY FUUUUU THAT WOLF HAS GREEN EYES -- Almost dies from scary wolf in the dark, eats, takes meds, & sleeps some more with frozen dead black guy that drops grape soda.
13. Kills that damn wolf, heads to Forestry Lookout at 1 mph.
14. Stuffs crap in metal container, rubs back for awhile
15. Eats fresh meat and clean water for once, has a merry christmas, sleeps for 8 hours. Life is great.
16. Gets food poisoning, and runs out of tinder in a snowstorm. Fml.
17, Sleeps for 12 hours, gets better, forages wood for an hour, finds cabin with dead guy. Yay.
18. Another blizzard, sleeps more, gets 5-day achievement. *success*
19. Gets crappy loot at Unnamed Pond, becomes a bean bandit, gets food poison again. I just wanna die!"
20. Goes in search of mystical Storm Hatch that I found in a previous life
date: eats tons of raw meat and polluted water.\n21. Probably lost a foot by now. Walks back home in storm freezing
hoursPlayed: and poisoned; sprains foot again
voteText: thanks painkillers.\n22. Gets back to house with worthless supplies

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I bought this game for ~$10 during the Steam Sale, and all that is available is the Sandbox mode. With that, I feel it is totally worth the price!

I love exploration games, and this game has a lot of what I love: Abandoned places. It's mainly a survival/resource management game right now, with a Story Mode coming later.

The game is in ALPHA right now (not even Beta), and it's very fun so far. The developers are still working on fixes and features. They are also considering suggestions for additions to the game and Sandbox Mode. Who knows what will be here in the future, but I'm going to call it: $10 is worth the game right now, as an unfinished Alpha.

Will it be worth $20 in the future with the Story Mode? Possible. The art style is very cool, and some real nice voice acting. I expect there to be plenty of care with the story mode, so I'm staying positive.
voteText: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is my story of an experience which happened later on in the game, a few parts are fictional to provide more immersion.

One cold day I was traveling to a place known as the Desolation Point, the wind was howling and wolfs where strafing through the cold wasteland.
I heard about this place called Hibernia which was some kind of wale processing facility before the geomagnetic storm happened, I thought it might be worth a visit, maybe I would find some tools there, a saw would come in handy...

As I was making my way to Hibernia I saw a bunch of wolves and even a bear guarding it, maybe the smell of the wale meat was still hanging around. I really wanted to get to this place, I only had one bullet left and I had the feeling chances are of finding some more in this abandoned factory. As I came closer and started to walk slowly across the frozen sea, trying to make as little noises as possible, the wind turned and carried my scent towards the wolves. I pulled my gun off my back and as soon as I had my finger on the trigger I already heard paws and claws on the ice behind me, I turned around and looked the wolf right in the eyes, it was baring its teeth and growling. I slowly started walking backwards, the muzzle of the gun pointing towards the wolf but it did not seem that it wanted to attack me and my pulse started to normalize, but suddenly I ran into something, the chicken wire fence surrounding this place got me caught. More wolves where approaching in the distance and I had to make a decision, do I run towards and past the wolves or do I use my last bullet... The sound of a gunshot is incredible loud if you haven't heard any cars or planes for a few weeks, it made all the other wolves flee, perfect as I needed to gut the wolf because a man has to eat if he wants to survive in this cold hell. It took me almost two hours to skin this poor thing, I didn't want to shoot it, but it was hungry and it was either him or me...

My heart just stopped when I heard the breathing of something really big behind me, a big black bear stood not even 5 meters from me, I did not hear him coming because I was so busy pulling the pelt off this wolf, the smell of blood must've caught the bears attention. I slowly stood up, a mistake, the bear made a jump and his paws threw me to the ground, I was feeling his steamy breath in my face and I passed out...
Was it the 350kg of pressure on my lungs, the pain of the bear digging his teeth into my shoulder or the fear which made me pass out? I don't know. But as I woke up It took me a few seconds to remember what just happened, I had pain everywhere and my vision was blurred, I looked around and saw my attacker who was just a few meters away feeding on the corpse of the wolf, I was lucky he liked that better then me.
I dragged my body a few meters away as the bear noticed me and stopped eating and turned around and started walking towards me, with shaky hands I pulled out a flare and light it up. That was the best thing I could have done, the bear stopped and was afraid to come any closer.

I barely made it into the factory and blood is pouring out of my shoulder, luckily I've found this bottle of antiseptic which burns like crazy but at least my wounds wont get infected.
I can barely see anything because of the pain and its also very dark in here, it looks like a mattress is laying in that corner, time to rest a bit...
The few pieces wolf meat I was able to grab before the bear surprised me will be very useful to keep my stomach filled for a few days while I recover from my wounds.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It was a cold morning when I loaded this game up. I had the day off and the blinds were drawn. As I pulled a sweater on and sipped some tea, I felt the chill as I loaded the Mystery Lake sandbox mode (the only mode available as of yet).

WIth no map and a few supplies, I found myself in a cave that led out into a clearing, with snow blowing. I managed to find a few cabins along a lake, with some food to keep me going. I ate too quick, and stretched myself too thin in the first day. The harsh realities of survival set in quickly. You need to make calm and calculated decisions. Evaluate your needs and priorities. The game builds an amazing atmosphere, reminiscent of being out in the forests of northern Alberta myself. Hearing wolves call, and seeing a buck off in the distance, going about it's life in a world devoid of humans. The short days and the blowing cold outside the window.

This is a game that will addict you. It will give you the urge to stop down at your local MEC or REI to shop for a pack saw and a Coghlan's pocket can opener. You'll crave pork and beans in a way you never thought possible.

For all its simplicity, this game is an enjoyable experience. Hinterland has delivered that experience with simple aesthetic that transfers a complex atmosphere. One of emotional and physical desolation that instills in you the desire to survive.

An update: I brought this game out again after about half a year collecting dust, and they've made some great improvements, added new areas, refined a lot of the mechanics and crafting.

I can not stress enough: one of the best things about this game is it is *not* procedural. Somebody actually put work into crafting the environments, and they're crafted well because of it. It does not look like an AI hit copy-paste. The artwork and modelling is fantastic, something a lot of the crafting/survival games right now lack.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The best survival experience I have found in a game yet.

It is challenging without feeling entirely unfair.  When you fail, you can generally look back at a moment of poor decsion making.  The game play is fairly simple with a basic gathering / crafting mechanic.  The hunting is one of the best I have played with wounded prey collapsing from their injuries at the end of long trackable trails of blood droplets.  The combat system is more of a struggle system and does a fair job of capturing the desperate feeling of being mauled by a wild animal.

I wish I knew who to thank for this quote, It is like living in a painting that wants to kill you."  And it is like that.  The game is gorgeous.  Every sunset and daybreak warrants a screen capture.  The sound effects are splendidly encompassing.  The music is subtle and lovely.  This is one of the rare games that I feel like I am in another world.

A great game and must buy for any survival game or immersion gaming focused player."

Early Access Review

If you like to drink orange soda while ice fishing and fighting of wolves, BUY THIS GAME!!!

The Long Dark is a great video game that I would definitely buy again and here’s why.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

By far the best Early Access game I've ever played. This game is gorgeous, and simply exploring the vast expanse of Canadian wilderness becomes a main driving point as every new cabin or site you discover is like some sort of picturesque painting. I've amassed a considerable screenshot collection, utilizing the handy HD Screenshot (Hud Disabled) hotkey. The beauty is enchanting, but also deadly--which is another great aspect of this game. No zombies or otherworldly threat. Just nature's bites--the cold and the wolves. Those damn wolves...

Surviving is a great challenge in either starting point, making each decision important since it is life or death with every hour that passes. A lot of games tout Survival" as a selling point
date: but none have managed to really be an enjoyable experience to me until I played The Long Dark. I think the dev team have managed to strike a near-perfect balance of challenge and reward. Note that I've only played this on the standard diffuclty level--I've heard that the hardest difficulty adds more wolves... I'm confident they will change that and challenge the player some other way
recommended: as the wolves are notorious ♥♥♥♥♥♥ in this game. Like I mentioned
hoursPlayed: however
voteText: I think standard strikes a great balance and has been a lot of fun.\n\nBe aware that there is currently no narrative story mode--Sandbox mode alone is worth the price during a sale. Throughout the play
helpfulPercent: you'll encounter hints as to what the story may be... I've had a lot of fun with the minimalism of it all
votesHelpful: and to see that sense of mystery last so long is impressive. I still haven't explored every last bit of the lands yet
votesTotal: and now they are going to double the size of the explorable terrain! So
votesFunny: I'll just leave off with that--I'm impressed with this game!!"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I got the Long Dark when its release first game out, and i played it but not to a full extent until recently. Why i didnt start playing longer until now is a question i do not know. This is one of the games where early access is actually playable for more than 10 hours.
Im currently an eagle scout of BSA so survival is one of my hobbies. This game has a lot of survival aspect to it, for sure. But what got me most playing this is winter. Winter is my all time favorite season. And the worst time to get lost or caught in a natural disaster, is winter. Winter you fight the cold more than anything else. This is why i love this game so much. Its not too easy and not too too difficult. You actually have to look for supplies. Not to mention you start with absolutely nothing so its up to your wits about surviving. Which would be in a real life scenario. Full thumbs up from me.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

For someone who completely lacks sense of direction this is a pretty challenging game.
Decided to leave the cabin around day 2, to explore further into the map. Find more resources, maybe another cabin?
Gone a bit far. Found a hydro dam. It's dark inside, but ok, I've got some flares and found lanterns inside. Loots of loot, cool.
Gathered everything I possibly could, ended up carrying about 10kg+ beyond my capacity. Slow as ♥♥♥♥, couldn't run anymore. Maybe there's a cabin somewhere nearby outside?
No cabin's anywhere. Luckily I've got plenty of supplies, huh.
Found a cave. Got even more loot, now carrying around 20kg beyond my capacity. Can barely walk. Maybe there's a cabin nearby the exit of the cave.
Got out of the cave. Does nobody have a house on this god forsaken place?????? Dropped what I could and consumed some supplies so I wouldn't be so slow.
Day 4 and I have absolutely no idea of where the ♥♥♥♥ I am. Walking in a frozen lake, ended up on the other side of the hydro dam. ♥♥♥♥.
Give up on finding another cabin, just wanna go back to my own, with a bed, and a stove and a safe I still have hopes on findind the combination to. Couldn't find any way into the hydro dam.
At this point, I have absolutely no idea of what I did. Found the cave again, couldn't retrace my steps - seriously, what's wrong with me? - found another exit.
Ended up in pleasant valley. Found hilltop cave. At least I have shelter. Now I'm only about 9kg beyond my carrying capacity. I can finally run, ♥♥♥♥ yeah!
There's a habitation somewhere nearby, hopes up again.
Found a frozen deer, 8kg of meat. Back to carrying way beyond my capacities, slow down again. Almost froze myself, got back to the cave entrance to build a firecamp and rest.
Made it to day 5. Terrified of leaving and not only not being able to find the house, but losing this cozy cave. Geting out of fire supplies thou'.
At this point, I just gave up on getting back to Trapper's cabin at Mistery Lake. I just wanna find another cabin and I'm never freakin' leaving the place.
I'll die there if I must, thank you very much.


Can't wait for the story mode :)
Hope it won't require much of my very poor sense of direction. (Also hope I never need it on real life. Stay strong, GPS. Stay strong.)

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nIf you're looking for a true survival game that will test your wits and abilities, this is definitely it. Using your brains to plan your meals, your travel and managing your supplies is vital and making a mistake can quickly snowball for you. This game is one of the few true survival games without an overarching threat (zombie invasion example) that asks if you could survive under possible conditions that could happen today. Just get it and try it. It'll be brutal but as you learn you'll enjoy the true curve and every run more and more.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The only real survival game I've played.

The long dark is a really phenomenal survival game.
Unlike other games of the genre you actually struggle to survive.

At one point I had survived for about two weeks and things were going pretty well. I had lots of food, I had plenty of water, good clothes and a nice warm hut to live in. I noticed I was running out of firewood tough, so I went outside and had a look at the weather. It looked good enough and I had a couple of (ingame) hours left before dark. After getting myself some firewood, I started to head back and out of nowhere a snowstorm showed up.

I got lost on my way back to my hut and the sun was setting. I wondered around for a while trying to find something familiar but I couldn't see more than a couple of meters in front of me. I realized the longer I stayed out in the freezing wind the less time I had. My character was freezing pretty badly by now.

In a last ditch attempt I went back the way I came where I had seen an old wind shelter. It was just big enough to fit in. I crawled in and tried to start a fire. I didn't have any accelerant with me so I couldn't get it going. I tried again and again. The storm wasn't getting any better. And by now the temperature was below -40 degrees Celsius. I came to the realization that I wouldn't get out of this. By now my character was too cold to even try to light a fire. I lit a match and held it up which increased the temperature inside the small wooden shelter by a degree or so. It was meaningless of course.
I wrote a few last words in the diary and drifted off to sleep, never to wake again.
voteText: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I haven't felt this invested in a game since long ago. I've found my heart pounding a couple of times after narrowly escaping a close encounter with the punishing wildlife, and spent some serious time pondering the best courses of actions (certainly more time than I would in any other game). You need to plan every outing somewhat carefully and be always ready to make a beeline back to wherever it is you call home.
The beautiful art design and the amazing audio really conspire to pull you into the Canadian wilderness to a level that I believe could only be surpassed by the implementation of a VR mode, if at all.
I am really looking forward to the full release and playing what promises to be an intense story-driven survival experience.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Loving the game and the atmosphere.
- Really addicting, can't get enough! 100 days in and still going~
- Beautiful. Nature and the sky. I'm ready to risk to get hypotermia everytime when I see beautiful sunrise.
- Realaistic. Animal behaving is nice, maybe depens on how you like it. I played 100 days on Pilgrim. I felt a little silly sometimes how animals were too scared of you (but wolves are not always hostile in real life either). I made silly move once and provoked wounded wolf..., it made me feel game was back to perfect.
Weather is also amazing, Foggy days, blizzard nights. Just amazing~
- Sounds. I love the sounds when walking on the snow in complete silent and I love so much the sound of own backpack, makes it really feel you carry so many supplies with you. Wind is sweet and bitter when you really need a shelter
- It have it's calm relaxing moments and then those really intense moments. Blizzard at midnight, middle of Pleasant Valley field with no firewood. And too heavy backpack at Timberwolf Mountain. Worth it.
- Feeling when finally returning to the own home base after weeks out.

Going to try play on Voyageur next and ready for more challence.
I can't wait to get storymode released, I still have so much fun in the sandbox mode.

10/10 would sleep again Beneath a Starry Sky

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have backed this from the outset on Kickstarter. I liked the lineup of Dev's and the trailers where eerily exciting.
I won't say the game is perfect yet, but when I'm sitting with my headphones on, and hear every little breeze, breath and howl, I'm in the game.
There is still work to be done on the whole eating/warmth area, but as a EA, I am happy with the gameplay. I have played through so many times, and I still love the feeling I get wham I'm searching a frozen corps, in the middle of the wilderness, and I have visions of hunkering down, and ravaging the beef jerky I just found, to take away the stomach rumbles, and enough to get me to the next place I'm trekking too.

If you are looking for a shooting/hunting game, where you have to go out and hunt deer to eat, then this isn't for you. As a Survival Sim, the Developers have dome a great job, to make you believe that you tare there, surviving, having to repair your jeans, before you head out to forage wood, so you don't freeze to death.
I for one, am very happy with this game, but it is a really different learning curve to any other game you have played. There is a system to surviving, and once you find that, you will be wanting to get back to it, to beat that 20 day run. Can you make it to 30  . . .??

I give it a thumbs up, because I'm excited to see where this is going, and considering we are 5 days in to it, and its EA, there is a LOT of room to move and make this such a beautiful world to explore.
The soundtrack, voice overs and Art is worth the look, and price of admission :D

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Do you think you have what it takes to survive the frigid Canadian wilderness? The Long Dark will challenge you in so many ways, yet it still manages to provide a calming and captivating experience.

I am glad I finally found this gem in a plethora of Early Access titles that usually range from being mediocre to downright awful. Currently the story mode is under development and I can't wait for the final release, but honestly I am having so much fun in the sandbox mode where each of your adventures has its own story anyway.

I admire Hinterland for frequent updates and hotfixes and generally appreciate where this game is heading. If you are like me and want a REAL survival game without zombies or monsters, I fully recommend it!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The Long Dark is an post apocalyptic survival game where you are thrown into an isolated world after a plane crash.
There currently is no story mode at the current moment but there is only currently a sand box mode where the only objective is to survive and live in the wilderness. The Long dark can either be a beautiful and relaxing experience seeing the many alluring locations and places you can see will leave you in awe or you can have an intense and will breaking experience with bears and wolves lurking in the places where you won't expect and food and supplies being scarce. You can choose various places to settle in and make a home , my personal favourite being the Trappers Lodge which has a good chance of spawning a Hunting rifle with and coems with a good amount of storage and a nice cozy fireplace for keeping warm during snow storms and boiling water. The Long Dark is a great game to get if you like taking a nice break from multiplayer games and just want to unwind and rest and take in the amazing places you can visit or if you want a good difficult challenge this game is still the game for you.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Day 1:
I awake to find myself in a frozen wasteland. Alone, cold and getting colder. What do I do? I need food, water, shelter. Trudging through the thick snow, I decide my best bet is to find some high ground and hope I can spot something that may be of use. As I reach the peak I see a small wooden structure next to a pond. Eagerly I rush down the side of the hill, hoping that I may find something of use. Inside is a can of beans, and not much else. Quickly I collect my prize and scavenge a small bundle of sticks that may be I can use for a fire if I can't find some place to hold up for the night. A little ways in the distance I see a flock of crows cawing, and circling over something. I decide to check it out. There in the snow bank, right under where the black birds hover is a man, dead. Covered in ice and snow. Most likely lost his way in a storm, looking for shelter or food, the same way I am. Is this my future? No, I won't end up like him. All I need to do is find some place to hold up and eventually, surely, help will come. I search his body, no time to pay respects. The sun is setting and I need to move. Maybe he has something that will help me avoid the same outcome as him. A smile spreads across my face. A pocket knife! Jackpot! I need to move now. I think I see something in the distance.

Night 1:
The house must have belonged to a trapper. Inside was a rifle, with a couple rounds, and some wire traps for small game. I've never hunted in my life, but necessity demands that I learn on the fly now. I tore the cabin apart, scavenging whatever I could use. I'm so cold though. Snow clinging to almost every inch of my clothing. It took a few tries, but I was able to get a fire started in the stove in the corner. Good thing I had those matches on me during the crash. There's only a few left though. I'll need to be careful how I use them. Right now these are the most precious tools to me. Each small stick is precious to seperate me from death. As I warm myself by the fire, I decide to melt some of the snow to give myself a small supply of drinking water. As the water boils I also use my newly found pocket knife to open the can of beans. Heating them on the fire I gulp it down as soon as they're done. Back home this would barely pass as a snack. Here it's a gourmet meal. It's time I get some sleep. In the morning I need to hunt. Other than a small package of jerky and a candy bar I found in the cabin, I'm not very well stocked. Hopefully my first hunting trip will pay off.

Day 2:
Maybe I should've watched somet hunting shows when I was back home. It occurs to me I know almost nothing on how to hunt and trap. I set up the wire trap in the woods, but unless a rabbit just happens to strangle itself in it I don't think I'm going to have much luck. I'll come back and check in awhile. In the meantime I'll try to track down one of those deer I saw yesterday.

The trap is empty. Go figure. My stomach is growling. The candy bar did little to slate my hunger. What the hell am I going to do? I pick up the trap. Maybe I'll have better luck somewhere else? What's that? Out the corner of my eye I see movement. A buck! Holy ♥♥♥♥! No way! Maybe someone up there is looking out for me after all! I crouch trying to hide my presents as I bring the rifles sights up. I've only ever fired a BB gun before, but it's the same concept right? I line the sights up, centering them near the deers heart. I let out my breath slowly, as I go to pull the trigger...

Night 2
The irony isn't lost on me, even as I sit here, the Long Dark creeping in on me. My head hurts, I can hear my own heart beat pulsing in my ears. I killed the deer. One shot. It went down like I was an expert. I even was able to skin it, gut it, and harvest the meat, something I never thought I'd ever do. I had a feast all laid out in front of me. Yet in the end it wasn't lack of food or shelter that will do me in. Fire. God damned fire. Something that the earliest man knew how to use somehow eludes me. I couldn't get the fire started again. I had two matches and both times the fire only flickered and died. I have no way to start it. In a panic I ran outside to go look for something to start it with, but it's midnight and a storm hit. I can't see a foot in front of my face. I'm lost, I think I've been going in circles. I don't remember where the cabin is. I chuckle as I think of how bad I am at this. I couldn't even survive 2 nights on my own. No ones coming for me, there won't be a rescue party, and in the end I'm destined to die here in the snow. I close my eyes and wait for the end. I just hope that the darkness comes for me before the wolves do.

PROS:
-Fantastic survival simulator, even at this early stage of development. Already have put 4 hours in and will continue to put in more.
-2 large maps
-Each playthrough feels different
-Challenging. 2 days is the longest I've survived so far
-Great atmosphere, and feeling of lonliness and isolation
-Wolves stalk you, and at night their eyes glow and makes you feel like you're in The Grey." A+ for that.
-No map. I count this as a pro because you have to rely on your own memory of where things are. When storms hit you can quickly become disoriented and lose your way which is thrilling.

CONS:

-The coastal highway map feels a bit too easy. I came across a town with several houses and have found a virtually endless supply of food
recommended: and great clothing. Not to mention it's next to several fishing spots. When your supplies are in abundance the game loses it's sense of adventure and danger
hoursPlayed: and thus loses a large amount of fun\n-Items are randomly placed every game
voteText: but structures are not. This means you can eventualy learn the map and find all houses quickly just from memory. Though it's random what you'll find
helpfulPercent: knowing where to look eliminates some of the challenge of surviving.\n-Only animals you'll currently see are deer
votesHelpful: rabbits
votesTotal: and wolves. Here's hoping we see some new fauna additions in the future.\n-Not a lot to do when you're well fed
votesFunny: and stuck inside during a blizzard. A way to level up your abilities with out having to repair/craft something would be nice

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Day one.

It is cold, so very cold. There is however a small mountain, weary of the weather, I already tire of the snow and it's obstacles and in hope, there is maybe a cabin just up this slope.

Growling, I hear growling.. The predatory eyes of another hungry being that is not I. the gleam of the carnivore's fangs quickly strikes me with fear, it is as if the hungry, angered gaze of this wolf grasps my heart and does not let me go. With courage, I slowly take a step back, the snow creaks underneath my soles. With a sudden rush, the wolf leaps at me and it's fangs delve with hunger and anger in against my neck. I try to hit, to fight! But it is all too much, too late..

The sweet lullaby of growling is what carries me to The Long, Dark slumber...

10/10, would die again in the first five minutes of playing this game.

The long dark is currently in Alpha and features yet a variety of ways for you to survive, and a variety of ways for you to die!

There is fall damage, dogs/wolves will chase you, you can even die from food poisoning. Tools are your best friends in this game, they really are. And then there's this creepy, really bad feeling that the dead people I find might just rise to the occasion..

Pro's:
Great, immersive level design.
A very nice soundtrack.
Sound effects make sense and there are warning cues for various things.
Realistic use of fuel, firestarter and chances.
Horror potential.

Con's:
It is not released yet.
While the sandbox is fun, you should probably hold back for now unless you want to actively support the game in it's early stages.

But really, I had another attempt right here and I actually survived for some time! Check it out!
http://youtu.be/UitQ7wdtoSk

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I hardly ever buy early access games, not because I don´t trust them, but because I know I´ll find glitches or things that I won't like and therefore, be unfair with the concept or the game itself. The Long Dark is one of those gems that still has dust and mud all over, but you know will be worth in the end. I so far have found a couple of glitches like wolves getting stuck inside a tree or even myself getting stuck where I should be able to walk and pass freely. Despite glitches and difficulty (which can be extremely high at times) I loved the game. I'll be brief with the review:

a) Graphics 8/10: good and different. If you're looking for detailed textures and realism this ain't for you
b) Gameplay 9/10: frustrating at times (killed by falling from the edge of a mountain when walking at night), foolish at others (spent a week eating cooked meat, drinking water, and sleeping 12 hours in a row), but overall balanced. Make sure you get some experience before trying hard mode
c) Sound 8/10: effects are pretty good. Wind, wolves, even drinnking water sound good to me.
d) Replay value 9/10: you'll find yourself trying over and over again till you kill those mother***** wolves or find better resources
e) Concept 10/10: the idea is amazing. Co op, bigger maps, more loot, more crafting chances, less wolves, more guns and ammo, these are some ideas I'd like to see in the future.

MY VERDICT: Worth a try

reviewText:
Early Access Review

For an alpha, this game is already amazing.

Sick of zombies?  Me too bro.  That's one of my favorite things about The Long Dark; it's unique.  Your biggest enemies are the elements, wolves, and your own human needs.  Hunt for food, boil snow for water, find better clothing to stay warm.  It sounds simple, but it's surprisingly difficult to keep yourself in homeostasis.  True shelters are few and far between, and you will find yourself wandering through a blizzard because you ran out of food.

Check out a short gameplay video from the latest update for an idea on how this plays.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=o8EGLtGMtVA&list=UUyejDs7HftG00dQkl5thUow

So as stated right above this text this is an early access review, from early alpha, and this might go the way of Takedown: Red Sabre or the dodos. But here's my impressions from right now.

This is the world's finest Siuntio-simulator! If you don't know what Siuntio is it's the small town where I live in Southern Finland which is known for it's... nothing really. reviewText:
Early Access Review

Ever since the Wilderness Survival maps for Warcraft 3 I've been craving to see a game similair to it.  I randomly found a trailer for this game about a year ago, and even then when it was pretty under the radar I was stoked to see it come to fruition.  I was very hopeful that this title would turn out well, but equally worried that it wouldn't be up to my expectations.  This game finally did it for me.  Survival at its core.  A harsh environment can be the most dangerous thing out there.  Some of the situations you encounter will catch you completely off guard.  You'll feel quite comfortable with your current setup and then something will go horribly, horribly wrong.  I made it to seven days so far, and even that was pretty impressive for me. My character was constantly freezing everytime I went outside for a large portion of my run, and towards the end I had finally found some warm clothes to replace my nearly broken clothing; and I also managed to find a sewing kit to repair what I did have on!  I had just entered a fishing hole to search for items and knew where my destination was after I left there.  But fate chose to laugh at me, and moments later before I had a chance to look outside a monstrous storm began.  Incredibly short draw distance and incredibly low temperatures left me too my demise.  I was walking in the long dark, lost completely.  It was saddening, yet satisfying.  I had come so close to dying so many times, and just barely made it through it and found myself getting comfortable with my new set up each time.

Positives:
+ Feels like almost every moment can be your last.  Each decison you make counts.
+ Amazing art direction
+ Good graphics, yet small file size
+ Tons of replayability
+ Crafting is not overly-complicated, and straightforward
+ Constantly changing meta due to Early Access changes as well as randomized locations for events; it makes the game feel like the environment can be harsher or more forgiving at times.


There's just a few things I'm still hoping for from this game that would bring it to perfection:
- More animations, less loading bars.  I'd much rather see myself making the fire than seeing a loading bar as it progresses.
-  Ability to use more items as weapons.  If I have a prybar, a hatchet, and a hunting knife, it's going to break immersion if I can't use any of these to help fend off the wolves.  Noise can be used to scare off wolves, and I'd love to also be able to use these weapons to create enough noise to scare them off as well.
-  I love the number crunching for staying alive, but to be honest it kind of ditracts from the immersion.  If I just knew the character was hungry/thirsty that'd be good enough and probably better for the overall game.  We can't quite number crunch in real life unfortunately.  We don't know how many calories are in products unless labelled, and we don't know how many calories are currently in us.  These numbers matter, but that feels like it should be back-end and something the developers really know about and the players don't.  As a solution, perhaps if the player becomes severely dehydrated they end up becoming delerious, and can even go far as passing out? There's plenty of potential in removing the number crunching.
- More interactivity with the environment.  I'd love to chop down a tree myself rather than clicking on a 'forage' button.  I'd also like to be able to incorprate plants/bushes for tinder
- More options for hunting animals, more trap types, larger animal variety,
- SHOVEL, seriously, there's so much potential!!!  Imagine you could stack up snow and create an igloo or snow fort in case of emergency.  There are real life situations where you can dig yourself into a hole, cover it, and survive; I'd love to see that implemented.  We've got to be able to create our own makeshift shelters.  Perhaps small leather tents we can construct as well.
- This game screams co-op experience.  It may be ideal to only have one friend available for the current set up, but I'd love to see a team of four as well.  Something about trying to survive together just feels right.  Of course for the sake of balancing issues I would suggest only certain maps be available to co-op.
- This one seems stupid but it's just a given, it's a survival game, and I don't think it detracts or makes the game silly or less serious by adding it; they should definitely allow you to drink your own urine.  Were in desperate need of fluid and on the verge of death, yet were too good to drink our own urine?  Come on.
- Fall damage is a bit high in my personal opinion
- On warmer days, have randomly placed thin ice
- Raw meat seems to be okay with sitting out for days, while convienent for balancing, it's not exactly accurrate.  At the very least there could be containers outside of cabins to place them in to freeze, but not completely freeze over.
- RARE Hostile/friendly AI human
- Skiing poles as rare items to help scale steep heights,
- Snow shoes as rare item to traverse deep snow with less fatigue.
- Ability to carve wooden weaponry like a club or spear
- Perhaps this is nitpicky, but I want to be able to see my feet/arms

Overall: As an early access title this game easily earns an 8/10.  I'd love to give it a higher score, but it needs to keep expanding and have more content first.  There's a lot of promise in this game, loads of potential.  I'm already having a ton of fun with it. They've tapped into a lot of it already, but I'm really hoping they manage to keep this up.  I hope it takes them a long time to feel satisfied enough with the project to consider it a full release.  But in the mean time, support these devs, buy their game and enjoy!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Day one.

It is cold, so very cold. There is however a small mountain, weary of the weather, I already tire of the snow and it's obstacles and in hope, there is maybe a cabin just up this slope.

Growling, I hear growling.. The predatory eyes of another hungry being that is not I. the gleam of the carnivore's fangs quickly strikes me with fear, it is as if the hungry, angered gaze of this wolf grasps my heart and does not let me go. With courage, I slowly take a step back, the snow creaks underneath my soles. With a sudden rush, the wolf leaps at me and it's fangs delve with hunger and anger in against my neck. I try to hit, to fight! But it is all too much, too late..

The sweet lullaby of growling is what carries me to The Long, Dark slumber...

10/10, would die again in the first five minutes of playing this game.

The long dark is currently in Alpha and features yet a variety of ways for you to survive, and a variety of ways for you to die!

There is fall damage, dogs/wolves will chase you, you can even die from food poisoning. Tools are your best friends in this game, they really are. And then there's this creepy, really bad feeling that the dead people I find might just rise to the occasion..

Pro's:
Great, immersive level design.
A very nice soundtrack.
Sound effects make sense and there are warning cues for various things.
Realistic use of fuel, firestarter and chances.
Horror potential.

Con's:
It is not released yet.
While the sandbox is fun, you should probably hold back for now unless you want to actively support the game in it's early stages.

But really, I had another attempt right here and I actually survived for some time! Check it out!
http://youtu.be/UitQ7wdtoSk

reviewText:
Early Access Review

For an alpha, this game is already amazing.

Sick of zombies?  Me too bro.  That's one of my favorite things about The Long Dark; it's unique.  Your biggest enemies are the elements, wolves, and your own human needs.  Hunt for food, boil snow for water, find better clothing to stay warm.  It sounds simple, but it's surprisingly difficult to keep yourself in homeostasis.  True shelters are few and far between, and you will find yourself wandering through a blizzard because you ran out of food.

Check out a short gameplay video from the latest update for an idea on how this plays.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=o8EGLtGMtVA&list=UUyejDs7HftG00dQkl5thUow
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A great and challenging survival game with well balance mechanics.

Died within 24 game minutes my first time playing (24ish real seconds). Spent the next two hours dying, a lot.

If you like survival games I recommend jumping straight in with the hardcore mode. Anything less and the game doesn't really pose much of a challenge. Also, try to avoid looking stuff up on the internet. It's quite rewarding when you slowly figure out how things work and you'll kick yourself for your previous stupidity when you do. Really gives you the sense of being some inept survivor stuck in a weilderness that you have no idea how to survive in.

Has taken me around 20 gaming hours to finally craft all the available items and get to the point where I'd say I'm an accomplished survivor. I did nearly give up at one point, after a wolf surprise attacked me after around 10 days of game time (around 8 hours real time) and killed me but I persisted and later figured out better ways to survive wolf attacks with some pre planning.

There are a lot of tips I'd love to give you, as looking back I realise I spent many hours doing things the wrong way or not understanding a concept that meant I was dying more than I had to, but this is what made the game a challenge. If you can accept that you'll inevitably die many many times but each time you restart you'll be a little better and get a little further, then you'll enjoy the game immensely.

Sometimes it can feel like you're spening most your day constantly eating, drinking and sleeping just to keep yourself alive, with only a little time in between to explore. This did very nearly put me off, so be prepared to hit a point of frustration and battle through it. Once you get the hang of it though, you'll learn how better to keep your energy up and make efficient use of your time.

Only one info I will give is that the sandbox has three maps. These maps are interconnected from within the game. I assumed they were three entirely different worlds. It was nice to realise that once I was starting to understand the layout of the first map, I could actually walk to a new area entirely and so the fun of exporing would begin again.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

$20 is a steal for this game cause its only gonna get more expensive the closer it gets to version 1.0

Survival.  Straight out.  There's no one out there but you and the animals.  The game tracks your hunger, thirst, body temp, medical ailments(sickness/injury) and calorie intake and usage.  Failing to manage all of these correctly will result in the death of you.

Inventory.  This is your mini game to keep you occupied while trying to defrost your tootsies.  Clothes, food, water,  weapons and miscellaneous supplies all have a purpose and must be maintained to survive successfully.

Animals.  They're out there and so are you.  These towns are only big enough for one sheriff so show them who's boss.  But be warned.  A failed skirmish with a hostile animal can result in fatal injuries.

The environment.  This is the star of the show.  It will stop at nothing to kill you with its sudden storms, blistering winds or vast wilderness where one wrong turn could cost you more than just time.  I was in fog so thick I literally didn't know which way to go and I ended up getting lost.

For a survival game this is top of its class.  Don't let the art style throw you off.  This is the most realistic survival game to date.  No game makes you feel the desperation of scavenging like this one.  Just hoping to find something to eat or drink.  The relief of finding shelter just before nightfall to keep from freezing to death.  The fear of running in to a small pack of wolves as they feast on a dead animal carcass.  Or the absolute dread when night has fallen and you have inefficient supplies to make a fire.

How long can you survive?

10/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The game is NOW definitely playable in Alpha mode. They've added some more content and depth to the game, and the biggest factor of all, they finally increased the character's endurance when running (although there is still a lot of running/walking/traveling in this game).

Day 23
I'm on my way back to the dam's control room to collect a bunch of items i dropped since i couldn't carry them all back in one trip. After filling up my inventory, I begin to head back when i notice that this door is actually usable... I use this new door that leads to the back of the dam. Once out, I begin to look around to get a feel of the new environment. To the far left i see that there's another platform that may hold some promising items. To get across I'd have to hug the dam and tip toe across the protruding ledge. A few steps onto the ledge and I fall off the ledge onto the dam itself (the dam isn't completely vertical but at an angle)! I take only 15% damage, sprained my wrist (of course never my ankle when falling for some reason), and my clothes are a little ripped, no serious harm done. I'm off the ledge but still on the dam, so I take off all my clothes to prevent any damage to them. I take little jumps down the dam, slowly but surely. Eventually, I make it all the way down and begin to find my way back up to dam's door so i could try again. I tiptoe across the ledge once more. Yes ! I'm across the long part of the ledge. Now all i need to do is turn the corner. There's 8 more steps I need to make before i can be safe on the platform. Sure enough I fall again ! This time the injuries are more severe. I'm left with 12% hp left ! But I will not give up ! I head across to the other platform once more. Success ! I scour the platform and find nothing of value. Brrrrr... It's cold... What is this?! I'm suffering from hypothermia! FML I FORGOT TO PUT MY CLOTHES BACK ON !! My hp is slowly ticking down... After putting my clothes back on, I race across the ledge once more, to  the dam's back door. WTF !?!? I LOCKED MYSELF OUT OF THE CONTROL ROOM?!?! WHO DOES THAT ?!?! I'm panicking ! My life's slowly dropping by the percent. Down to 8%... My vision's blurry and my character begins to wobble. He's blacking out and coming back. I attempt to make a fire, but no, it's too windy ! I run around the place looking for cover from the wind ! I travel down the  mountain on a path and finally manage to get the fire going, but am left with 4% hp. I throw some logs onto the fire and warm myself up entirely. I check the time, there's 4 hours left. I've got to reach some kind of shelter before nightfall or else i'll freeze to death. Perhaps I messed somthing up and the back door actually does open? Still blacking out and wobbling, I decided to head back up to the back door to check again. I take 4 steps. OWWWW, burning damage inflicted !! I WALKED OVER MY OWN FIRE ! IS THIS HOW I'M GOING TO DIE?? KILLING MYSELF BY WALKING OVER MY OWN FIRE??!!? Thankfully, I'm left with 2% health and minor burns... I travel upwards, towards the door, but alas, the door does not open... The only way to go is down the mountain and follow the frozen river. My character's still disoriented, I'm having trouble walking and navigating my way through this maze of a river. I take every turn, only to be led to a dead end. It seems like there's no way up and out of this river system, so i push through looking for some kind of exit... I finally reach the end.... I found the tunnel system. It seemed to be the only way out, so i went in. Bad idea. 10 Steps in and i literally could not tell which way was up or down. I see a frozen corpse. Ha, i guess he'll have a friend pretty soon. I personally, begin to get motion sickness. I'm lost and i honestly can't tell if i'm going forwards into the cave or going back to where i came in from..... I give up... I exit the game and decide to reload from my last save spot (where ever that is i do not know). It happens to be the moment i entered the cave. I quickly turn around and exit. Surely there has to be another way out of this river system.... Welp, time to go online and look for a map ! There's no map. I did however, find out that there are two entrances/exits to this river system... The cave and A MFING WINDOW ON THE OPPOSITE PLATFORM TO THE DAM'S BACK DOOR!!!! I begin my journey back through the river/maze.... I'm beginning to feel tired... I'm forced to drop some inventory.... A dead end.... Another one.... Eventually i see open space. There's no mountains ahead. Sure enough, the dam appears. I travel up the moutain pass and reached the back door. Okay... I could barely cross the ledge at 100% health.... Now i've got to do it at 2% health.... I'm still wobbling, my screen is still fading in and out. I tip toe across the ledge and make sure i hit every wall there is to hit. I'm safe on the platform. I search for the window and slide my way inside of the dam. I recognize this area.... It's the deepest room inside of the dam and darkest..... I'll need a light source through the entire dam... I have a few matches and a flare.... I light the flare and race my way through the dam. I pass through the piles of items that i was supposed to retrieve. I pass through the door that started the entire journey. A few more minutes and i reach the front door of the dam. I drink and eat as much as i can. I check the time, less than an hour left of daylight ! It's a race against time ! I leave the dam with nothing but the clothes on my back and the single flare which only has 30% of it's original life left. I'm outside and it's dark. The time says less than one hour of daylight, but that's only referring to the temperature... I walk straight until i see the railroad. I place my feet on the railroad and look towards home, but i can barely see now. It's too dark ! I walk backwards, i've lost the railroad ! i look left or was it right? I see the way that isn't home and look the opposite direction. I see the bridge and railroad so I begin to walk. It's a long trek home. My flare dies out. The icon that tells me i'm suffering from lack of sleep appears. I march on. I reach a checkpoint, the trees that have been cut for lumber. I see that familiar corpse on the left side of the tracks.I reach the next checkpoint. The derailed carts. I walk around the carts and around the branch that blocks the way. From here on it's a straight path until home. I literally can not tell If i'm moving or not. I can only trust that i am. I march on. Waiting for some sign, for that opening in the mountains to the left that signifies that my cabin is there. I march on. Finally, i see the opening ! i see the black silouhette that resembles a house. I recognize that flag figure flying proudly atop the house. I run towards the house to the side i know the front door is on. I put my face against the side of the house and move left and right searching for the door. Is my face even against the wall or is it on the fence of the front porch?! I don't know, i can not see ! I try the back door which has no fence to protect it. I can't find that one either ! I back off from the house, trying to position myself to where i know the back door is, but i lose the house itself !! I see nothing but blackness. Am i touching the house or is it the mountains behind the house?!? I can not tell.... In time, i'm able to see that familiar silhoutte once more. I reposition myself and check my inventory to see if there's ANYTHING that can light the way... Apparently I left some matches in my backpack !! They must have been too light to throw away ! Thank god I was too lazy to toss them out ! I light a match against the wall of the house and am able to find the back door.... i light another match inside of the cabin so i can locate the stairs.  finally i'm safe at last.... I rest for 6 hours, not wanting to die of thirst or hunger. I wake up well enough to sleep for another 12 hours. Alas, I am home and rested, ready to journey once more...

reviewText:

Without word of a lie, one of THE best game's I have bought on a whim. I wasn't sure if it'd be that great. But I have instantly fell in love with this game. Do it! Just...do

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Get this game right now if you like survival games, you will definitely get your money's worth at full price and it often goes on sale if you're cheap. I myself love survivals a lot and have had this game for a while. It can be a bit challenging, but half the fun with any survival game is that it challenges you.

Pros:
+ Really beautiful art style. Amazing looking for how simple it is.
+ Being able to survive for a long time has a really rewarding feeling that is hard to get in many other survival games.
+ Game is very stable despite being an EA title. I honestly don't recall running into a single bug and it doesn't require a top notch PC to run.
+ 3 difficulty levels have been added, no longer are you forced into one difficulty.
+ Lots to explore if you want to. Quite a large world, but you don't have to play all areas if you don't want to, though I'd say that's half the fun. More maps coming as well.
+ Steam workshop allows for player made language packs.

Cons:
- Can be very easy to get lost if you're not 100% familiar with the map you're playing on.
- Sometimes you get really crappy spawn luck and you either have to try to deal with it or start over. This is pretty much not an issue on easiest difficulty as resources are so common and wildlife doesn't attack.
- No tutorial yet, so some things can be sort of confusing at first.
- No customization at all, which is a con for me since I do love customizing things.
- When you die, it's over, you have to begin anew.

Neutrals:
= Very little music, which could be good or bad depending on the person playing. I don't mind it so much, it helps to hear stuff around you.
= Sometimes the sound effects are a bit irritating because of the repetitiveness, but overall they're not too bad.
= I'm not a big fan of the inventory/conditions/crafting interfaces, but they're functional.
= The environment can be very cruel, even on easiest difficulty. This can be a big con for people new to survivals and not good at managing themselves in-game. To me it's just part of the game, though, so at worst this is a neutral point for me.
= Map setup doesn't change each play through, other than actual items you pick up (though some locations have exclusive or almost guaranteed spawns so they need to be checked for certain items). This can be both good and bad because it makes the maps predictable once you're used to them, which hurts replayability a little, but also allows replays to go smoother.
= No story mode for the moment, but that is in development.
= Development has been a bit slow lately, but it's not a huge team and there's a lot to do in the game in it's current state, so I would still argue it's still a worthwhile buy.

---

The pros greatly outweigh the cons in my opinion. It does get frustrating when you've made good progress and some random fluke of a thing kills you, but for some reason that doesn't make me stop playing it, when most games would frustrate me to the point of not being able to play again by doing that. Perhaps those with rage issues should pass this game up, though.

I highly recommend that anyone new to the game uses the community made maps. None of them are 100% accurate and you may need to make note of the differences yourself, but they will give you a pretty good idea of where you're going at first and eventually you won't need them because the maps don't change each playthrough. I still find them useful though for planning where I'm going to go when I start a new game or for when I have to stop playing, I can cross off the locations I've visited so I don't forget.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I was introduced to this game by my cousin. I was reluctant to try it at first but when I finally got it and started playing I was immediately blown away by the imagery and design. That was and remains to be my favorite part of the whole game. The graphics and landscape design aren't incredibly realistic but I believe that is what makes this game stand out. To me it's like everywhere I turn I'm looking at a beautiful painting that someone made with their own hands and imagination.
Besides the imagery, I am impressed with how challenging the game is. There's no cutting corners here. I must admit, I am a known rage quitter, but I have yet to quit this game. No matter how many times my throat is ripped out by a wolf, I just want to keep trying, because unlike many other games this one is not monotonous. It's not trying to redo the same level over and over again every time you fail. Every time you die you come back in a completely random location with completely random gear. The whole world is shuffled.
I have nothing negative to say about this game, in all honesty. If you like survival games and you have an appreciation for the outdoors and snowy mountain peaks, you will love this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is a very promising game if you like certain types of gameplay. Let me clarify what type of gameplay this game has so you get the idea of whether you want to play it or not.

---------------------------------
At this CURRENT moment the game only offers the ability to play in sandbox mode. In this mode you spawn in a random area at a random time of day. The goal is to survive as long as you can and that's about it, however, it's not as easy as you'd always assume. The loot around the area is also random so you may be lucky or unlucky as to what you will find. I don't think you can be soo unlucky that you will die right from the start but you may not find something as valuable as a sewing kit.

You have to deal with many issues in this game such as starvation, dehydration, fatigue, injuries, freezing, etc. There is food within the game as random loot as well as raw meat from animals which you can cook on a fire. Having something to drink can be random or you can melt snow to get water and you will need to boil water to purify it for safe drinking unless you have a water purifier. If you carry too much weight you will get fatigued very fast as well as running around everywhere and burning your calories which is another thing in the game. Depending on the quality of your items and what they are changes how well you can survive outside for extended periods of time and being by a fire isn't going to help you if it's windy and freezing outside so going indoors is always a good option.

This alone wouldn't be much of a challenge but there are also wolves in the game and they are quite brutal. If one attacks you then you must build up strenth then attack it which can do 3 things: hurt the wolf a little, hurt the wolf enough to make it run away, or kill the wolf. If you are very tired and run into a wolf you are screwed because you cannot build much strength up at that time and you will be overpowered and killed.

The weather can be mellow, windy, or there may be a blizzard which will freeze you VERY fast if you are outside.

There will be more options and there will be a campaign but at the moment there is only sandbox survival which is still fun.
---------------------------------

The art style is nice in this game and is different. The sounds are great and this is an overall nice game. Should you buy it? Completely up to you but at the current state $20 is a bit much but there is more content coming and I've been seeing 1-2 updates a day since launch so things are actually getting done and I believe my money was well spent so far.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have only played the game for an hour...but let me tell you it has been one nervewracking hour (in a good way).  I have had only had one life in this game and in the short time I've had more fun than many survival games have given me in many hours.

I spawned in and the sun is just rising behind the mountains.  Snow is gently falling and I can see a clearing down the side of the hill I am standing on.  I make my way down and find it's a tiny encampent for loggers.  After searching through the trailers I find myself with a few cans of soda, peaches, and a new jacket.  Not a bad take.  Returning to the wilderness I begin to trek into the unknown.  After making my way through the woods and following a railroad it gets quite dark and I realize the sun is actually setting.  Now with a sense of urgency I begin to scramble for shelter.  The wind picks up and the snow begins to fall heavy on me.  I find an abandoned hydro dam and take shelter inside.  It's pitch black so I light my only flare to give me some sense of comfort.  After finding a crowbar I begin breaking into lockers and after finding some beef jerky and a knife I hear a menacing growl.  I turn around just in time to see a rather large wolf lunge at me and pin me to the ground.  After a brief struggle the wolf is now dead and I'm bleeding all over the place.  Turning the place upside down I managed to find some bandages and antiseptic and am able to treat my wound.  Fearing another wolf attack I head back outside and seek shelter elsewhere.  Walking around the darkness for what felt like hours I found a lookout tower.  This is my current shelter.  I managed to get a fire going and got a good nights rest.  Tomorrow is a new day and I can't wait to see how it unfolds.

This game even in its current lacking state is awesome.  The sense of immersion is unrivaled.  Going inside the dam was truly unnerving.  The echoes and emptiness in the halls set up the tension that built up to the wolf attack perfectly.  Wandering around in the dark as the storms began to roll in made me feel helpless and that's what a survival game should aim to do.  It's nice to see a survival game without zombies and this game offers a great challenge and a fantastic sense of immersion.  Get it. Play it.  Enjoy it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I woke up in the middle of a blizzard, freezing and disoriented I looked around me, only able to see a few feet ahead in any direction. As I started walking forward I questioned myself, did I choose the right direction? All around me are trees and snow, wind and doubt, in the distance I see a shape taking form, a sign and guard rails. As I get closer I see the remnants of a road winding up a hill on my left, the wind is getting stronger and I can tell im moving slower, im taking a gamble there is shelter at the top of this hill. As I clear the top of the hill I see an outpost, 30 – 50 feet in the air atop a winding red staircase.

Struggling to make it to the top of the stair I fall through the outpost’s door and into one small cramped abandoned rangers post. Rifle on the table, 5 shells on the floor, some kindling by the stove and an energy bar. I lit a small fire in the stove, but without proper clothing I never really warmed up. Taking some snow from outside I melted it on the stove, but before I could get it to boil the fire went out. I ate the energy bar and grabbed the rifle, made my way back into the howling wind, down the stairs and started descending down the hill.

Im starting to freeze to death, no food, no shelter, no heat, it doesn’t look good. I follow the road heading away from the outpost atop the hill, the wind starts to die down and I can see further into the distance now. Round a small hill to my left and see a building in the distance built into a mountain, ive lost track of the road, lost under the snow, I head to the building. Under the snow I see something red, I get closer and see it is a dead fox, half eaten, mostly frozen. I have no tools, nothing to cut the meat, I have to abandon the carcass and pray there is food in the building up ahead.

I open the giant metal door, this is a hydroelectric dam, empty and abandoned, dark and silent.  My body is going into shock, I have no food, no water, no way of building a fire. My only hope is to find a furnace and pray there is wood nearby to burn. As I walk into the main room coming through the front door I can see hulking machinery, up ahead, file cabinets to my right, and stairs going down to my left. It reminds me of something out of a horror movie, pitch black with only light from a small window, something is lighting up the stairs, beckoning me. Im dying, I can hear the wind outside starting to pick back up, I head down the stairs in a last ditch effort to find heat, to find what the light is coming from below. I take 3 steps and see a shadow at the bottom of the stairs, it’s a wolf, and it guarding something, meat… I pull out my rifle and before I can take aim the wolf lunges at me, I cant fight back, im too weak. I die on the floor of the building.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Price (regular):  $19.99 (EARLY ACCESS)

Price (lowest): $14.99 (25% off)

My overall rating: 9.5/10
Easily one of my favorite games of all time. Great play value, but could be better.

Value: 9/10
This game can be constantly replayed and has endless fun, the developers work hard on this game and post updates often, adding more value to the game. There is a great amount of good gameplay involved that is SLIGHTLY (0.000005%) impeded by constant wolves, but once you get a knife, oh, then its their time to worry.

Singleplayer: 10/10
Amazing singleplayer. Singleplayer is so far the only mode available, but still one of the best out there in the survival standpoint. All games seem to go for zombies and nuclear fallouts, while this game takes realism to a new level, its just you and the evilness of mother nature.

Co-op: -
No Co-op yet, I really hope that the developers will eventually bring co-op to the table, as there would be even more fun. Its always more fun if you have great friends trying to survive also. Now, lemme get more in depth to why it has probably not been released: Resources. For two players you will either require double the resources, or have them left for dead to survive for mere days. There would have to be a lot more loot on the map or the friends would have to split up, one on Costal Highway, and one on Mystery lake, which would not be as fun.

Multiplayer: -
Same with Co-op, there would be great balancing issues, but If the devs could overcome that it would be so awesome to have multiplayer.

Content: 9.5/10
Hunting, Scavenging, Foraging, Creating Fires, Taking Antibiotics for wolf attacks, this game has already such an indepth system of scavenging and everything. (It even includes infections :D)

Length: 10/10
Extremely long playthroughs are possible with proper management of health, condition, food, water, and a hefty supply of resources. You can probably sleep to day 50 on just one map alone before resources get extremely low.

Story: 8/10
Not much is known about the charachters. I know, they are making story mode. I cannot wait until it comes out, especially since they say it will be in episodes and seasons. If they make me pay for them as DLCs...

Gameplay: 10/10
Very good, open gameplay. Basically an open world that allows for lots of fun.

With freinds: -
No co-op and multiplayer yet. I hope for them very soon.

Graphics: 8/10
Strange and Mixed about the Graphics. Its like they tried to go BL style on some things as it looks like they tried to convert a cartoon to real life (Much like the SFM MLP models and such) It doesn't look as good as it could, but its ok. Graphics will hopefully get a huge overhaul to get more realism, or they will focus on a cartoon-like atmosphere. (I do not know which they will go for)

Physics: 9/10
Physics are ok, every once in a while I have a deer glitch through the rock (No joke I can upload a video of it right now, just add me and tell me to) and other problems. Lemme delve into realism here, because that is what the game is trying to do, you can run up hills, albeit slowly, not as realistic as you would severely hurt your ankles almost instantly, but in this game they survive. (Those are just nitpicking details)

Performance: 10/10
Here is the problem for me: I run on a 8 month old gaming computer that is still better than most out there that are up to date. I cannot accurately tell you how much memory usage or stuff it uses as I do not check. This is what I can tell you: It runs flawlessly, transitions into houses (new levels/maps) are flawless and only take but a second or two, I have not tried crossing into coastal highway nor have I played coastal highway.

Sound: 8/10
Sound is good but maybe a little rough here and there.

Polished: 8/10
Nothing majorly wrong with it but I still have not found the bunker, which is kinda annoying. (Overall great game, just a few flaws. I have heard of wolves invisible, but that is probably a graphics card problem not game problem)

Atmosphere: 8.5/10
The vast landscape gives you a good immersive feel but could be better if they didn't have so much of the same trees making it all feel the same.

Objectives: 9/10
Objectives are pretty basic. Pretty much survive. The sub-objectives of that objective are vast and indephth, so the game is really good because of the mechanics and playstyle.

Clarity: 9/10
No problems with knowing where to go or what to do. (The story line will probably linear and very easy to follow when it comes out. I cant wait!)

World: 9.5/10
Unparalleled world. Massive world (Split in two so far) with mountains, caves, vast foliage, and tons of wildlife to try and kill you. Although most of the landscape has the same trees and plants so a lot of it looks the same. (More diverse?)

Characters: 8/10
Not much is known about the characters. Once the story mode is released my rating will probably go up, unless the details we learn are useless and add no effect to the story or charachters.

UI: 10/10
Great UI, I think It could have a pause feature while in the TAB menu, but that is just me.

Controls: 10/10
Great controls, can change key bindings to personal preference. (All buttons/actions are customizable)

Freedom: 10/10
As much freedom as you could ask for. You can do whatever you want, such as going for a nature hike.

Influence: 10/10
The Gameplay is very dynamic and not linear at all. Your only objective is to survive and you can do that many ways. Scavenging DayZ style, or hunting Forest Gum style (yes I misspelled his name, and yes that was a horrible analogy as it was just meant to be a joke) Could have more maps or loot to make surviving longer possible.

Settings: 9/10
Settings are great, many different Graphic options (have not tried any but maximum) and key binding changing is easy. Audio and everything else in the menue is also great.

Character progression: 6/10
No character progression, other than trying to survive.

Weapon selection: 8/10
Has limited weapons. Shotguns and (better) sniper rifles should all be added eventually. So far only 3 weapons or so.

Customization: 7/10
No weapon or item customization, only repair or harvest.

AI: 8.5/10
For the most part the ai is fairly intelligent. Every once in a while are there weird glitches in the ai. Wolves have howl animation which in my eyes is pretty cool.

Up to date: 9/10
Constantly evolving as it is in Early Access, which is why I am being careful of what I state in this review. Everything might eventually change.

Replayability: 10/10
Entire game as stated above can be played up until forever if you get enough resources. The fun of surviving drives me to constantly replaythis.

Pace: 10/10
You can do everything at your own pace. No one rushes you. (Except for your Hunger, Thirst, Condition, Wolve Population and about 70 other things trying to kill you.)

Repetitiveness: 9/10
I guess some people can find it repetitive to constantly day after day survive in this game, but thats basically how life works, there are rarely any fun moments and mostly just work.

Realism: 10/10
Realism is very high in this game. Must I say more?

DLC: -
No DLCs so far, MIGHT be some for the story, but I will be very sad if they make you pay for it. It it is like a free dlc then I will be happy even though its a DLC.

Achievements: 10/10
Track how long you have survived with achievements. Its really exhilarating and a great feeling of accomplishment. Tip: for extra realism and feeling of accomplishment reset your achievement stats for The Long Dark.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I know that there are some details and aspects that aren't realistic (many are), but the game does, y'know... FEEL real! You will feel a satisfying shiver shake down your spine when you huddle up to a fire after coming in from a blizzard. You will feel the warmth and the cold even though it's not really there.
The best part of this game is you just keep moving, and you can. Games get boring when you stay in one spot all the time. There's so much to explore that I don't even know if I'll survive long enough to see all of it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The long dark can only truly be expressed as its own individual experience. For that reason I can only recommend this game to those looking for emersion and realism, if you don't enjoy those things, turn back now.

I've been playing the Long Dark for just over six months in varying bursts of enthusiasm, despite my patchy play style I have returned consistently, this suggest to me that this is an excellent game, that can give you what I have found in no other place.

This is a true example of what makes a fantastic game, not graphics, guns and hordes of AI, but plain and simple mechanics, mechanics that not only function correctly but ignite emotion in the player.

I hope for your sake this is the type of experience you enjoy.

reviewText:

Buy this game. This is easily the best survival game I've played, one of the most earnest and worthy examples of what an Early Access game should be, and one of my all-time favorite games. reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is a very promising game if you like certain types of gameplay. Let me clarify what type of gameplay this game has so you get the idea of whether you want to play it or not.

---------------------------------
At this CURRENT moment the game only offers the ability to play in sandbox mode. In this mode you spawn in a random area at a random time of day. The goal is to survive as long as you can and that's about it, however, it's not as easy as you'd always assume. The loot around the area is also random so you may be lucky or unlucky as to what you will find. I don't think you can be soo unlucky that you will die right from the start but you may not find something as valuable as a sewing kit.

You have to deal with many issues in this game such as starvation, dehydration, fatigue, injuries, freezing, etc. There is food within the game as random loot as well as raw meat from animals which you can cook on a fire. Having something to drink can be random or you can melt snow to get water and you will need to boil water to purify it for safe drinking unless you have a water purifier. If you carry too much weight you will get fatigued very fast as well as running around everywhere and burning your calories which is another thing in the game. Depending on the quality of your items and what they are changes how well you can survive outside for extended periods of time and being by a fire isn't going to help you if it's windy and freezing outside so going indoors is always a good option.

This alone wouldn't be much of a challenge but there are also wolves in the game and they are quite brutal. If one attacks you then you must build up strenth then attack it which can do 3 things: hurt the wolf a little, hurt the wolf enough to make it run away, or kill the wolf. If you are very tired and run into a wolf you are screwed because you cannot build much strength up at that time and you will be overpowered and killed.

The weather can be mellow, windy, or there may be a blizzard which will freeze you VERY fast if you are outside.

There will be more options and there will be a campaign but at the moment there is only sandbox survival which is still fun.
---------------------------------

The art style is nice in this game and is different. The sounds are great and this is an overall nice game. Should you buy it? Completely up to you but at the current state $20 is a bit much but there is more content coming and I've been seeing 1-2 updates a day since launch so things are actually getting done and I believe my money was well spent so far.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I was walking through a blizzard for an entire day and could hardly see a few feet in front of me, stumbling up hills and across frozen creeks. I finally found some train tracks and followed it until I found a derailed train and a collapsed tunnel, took shelter just inside the tunnel. Realized that I had no wood and it was almost dark, I scrambled to gather some wood nearby and literally minutes from freezing to death I built a big fire, enough wood to last most of the night. I rolled out my bedroll and slept til the fire was out. After I woke up, I finished off my food and drink most of my water and with only the moon as my light I wandered off in a random direction. Wandering past trees, rocks, for what seemed like a few hours I am already freezing again I see an opening and there on top of a cliff sits a hut, the trappers hut. With releif I ran there got inside and started a fire, stoked it to last a few hours, gathered some food and boiled water. After several hours of patching up, eating, drinking, I crash due to my condition being so bad. Woke mid day and scavenged the rest of the hut and now I'm up to day four and after hunting I've got food and water for a while. Now just have to worry about the condition of my clothes!

So far this is my expereince with the first playthrough on the sandbox mode and I'm in total love!
