reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have nothing but positive things to say about this game.

I've played it off and on since it arrived on Steam.

The Dev's are incredibly active with the game and are regularly fixing bugs and/or adding content.  They commuicate regularly and are very accessible through both the Steam and Hinterland forums for help, questions, bug reports, etc.  They are also very receptive to gameplay feedback as they are always seeking to improve gameplay.

As for the game itself, it's simply excellent.  It's challenging and VERY replayable.  Once a player gets the learning/playing curve down, survival is not horribly difficult... as long as you don't make any mistakes.  And mistakes can be costly, sometimes resulting in death.  Death is permanent and ends the play through, which simply adds to the challenge because developing character resources that allow more in game freedom (from the weather) takes a lot of time.

The player is on a constant hunt for survival resources, which includes food, water, clothing while being on the lookout for predators such as wolves (quite common) and bears (fairly rare).  Depending on the game difficulty level chosen, play through goes from relatively easy to incredibly difficult.

The game graphics are not high end/high definition, but are quite nice, and a starry night sky in this game is phenomenally beautiful.

If survival challenge games are your thing, then I highly recommend this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Probably one of the few better early access survival games on steam at the moment.

The bigest issue and complaint iv'e had with almost every indie survival game currently in development is how the enviroment is not a danger at all and instead the only danger is other trigger happy players ,which just turns all those survival games (Day Z,Rust , etc) into just very big PVP combat arenas and not much else, however the Long Dark does not have that problem.

The Long Dark is a single player survival game, so no pesky human players are around to ruin your day instead the things you have to worry about alot and are in  constant danger from is the enviroment and the animals that live in this frosty land.

The game has a very beautiful and unique art style which i can't get tired of looking at, it might not be the most techical impressive game but the devs used such a wonderfull colorfull but at the same time not too coloruf style with some subtle touches on each texture which almost make it feel like you're in a picture book or some sort of animated detailed cartoon but without pulling you out of the game's wonderfull snowy atmosphere, it's really,really nice.

Same goes for the sound design, it's very well done, hearing wood creeking as you slowly walk around a dark house while a strong blizzard is blowing outside makes me wanna just wrap myself around a blanket as i play it.

Now, onto the gameplay.
You have to find worm clothing to make sure you don't freeze in the icy lands of Canada, you have to use a sewing kit to maintain your clothing so it doesn't become useless overtime,you have to gather wood,matches,fuel,old newspapers and use them to create camp fires where you can cook food,melt snow into water and purify water by boiling it so you don't get poisoned, you have to scavange huts and small houses for food,water,tools,clothing,weapons etc etc. but they don't respawn so you have to be carefull on what you eat and what you use since you can die from hunger and thirst very easilly if you don't plan ahead carefully.

At the start you'll be eating anything you find but once you pick which house will be your base and you manage to gather and stock some food into it,It's smarter to start eating food you hunt and save up the canned goods for desperate moments, in the current build you can only hunt with a gun(which is hard to find) or catch some smaller wildlife with a basic trap, however even if you don't have a weapon or a trap you can still get some deer or rabit meat since the wolfs hunt too and often leave a few good slices of meat on the bodies for you too cut off and take back home to cook, oh and you can also fish which requires you to cut a hole into the ice in a specific location with your knife or axe.

In the wild (as i mentioined them before)you have Wolfs patrolling which you have to stay away from as much as possible, if you get caught with just your fists against a single wolf(or more), you're pretty much a goner allready. Knifes and Axe's will help you alot in those situations and if you're lucky enuf to find a gun with ammo then it's the Wolf/s who should be afraid of you then.

You have two fairly big maps to play on at the moment, in the future hopefully there will be more as developemnt progresses, they are also promising a Story mode with some fairly famous voice actors such as Jennifer hale but that's still not in the current build, at the moment all you have is sandbox where you just try to survive for as long as possible and maybe also try earning some achievements to give yourself an objective once you manage to stock up on alot of things.

Bottom line :
The game is still lacking content but the content it has at the moment is enuf to keep you busy for a good few hours of survival fun, it's in my opinion much better then most unfinished survival games we have at the moment and it seems to occasionally go on a nice sale, if you see The Long Dark 50% off then I'd say pick it up if you like survival but for 20 Euros,ahh I'd say wait a bit for more content but even if you get it for 20 Euros i don't think you'll really regreat it that much, specially if you love these survival games and this is one of the few that's atm in a solid fun state unlike other games.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I hardly ever buy early access games, not because I don´t trust them, but because I know I´ll find glitches or things that I won't like and therefore, be unfair with the concept or the game itself. The Long Dark is one of those gems that still has dust and mud all over, but you know will be worth in the end. I so far have found a couple of glitches like wolves getting stuck inside a tree or even myself getting stuck where I should be able to walk and pass freely. Despite glitches and difficulty (which can be extremely high at times) I loved the game. I'll be brief with the review:

a) Graphics 8/10: good and different. If you're looking for detailed textures and realism this ain't for you
b) Gameplay 9/10: frustrating at times (killed by falling from the edge of a mountain when walking at night), foolish at others (spent a week eating cooked meat, drinking water, and sleeping 12 hours in a row), but overall balanced. Make sure you get some experience before trying hard mode
c) Sound 8/10: effects are pretty good. Wind, wolves, even drinnking water sound good to me.
d) Replay value 9/10: you'll find yourself trying over and over again till you kill those mother***** wolves or find better resources
e) Concept 10/10: the idea is amazing. Co op, bigger maps, more loot, more crafting chances, less wolves, more guns and ammo, these are some ideas I'd like to see in the future.

MY VERDICT: Worth a try

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The long dark can only truly be expressed as its own individual experience. For that reason I can only recommend this game to those looking for emersion and realism, if you don't enjoy those things, turn back now.

I've been playing the Long Dark for just over six months in varying bursts of enthusiasm, despite my patchy play style I have returned consistently, this suggest to me that this is an excellent game, that can give you what I have found in no other place.

This is a true example of what makes a fantastic game, not graphics, guns and hordes of AI, but plain and simple mechanics, mechanics that not only function correctly but ignite emotion in the player.

I hope for your sake this is the type of experience you enjoy.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Guide to an immersive  The Long Dark  experience:
Shut off all of the lights.
Crank down the thermostat to 32 degrees.
Put on your warmest winter coat (bonus points if it smells like cedar smoke and wolf spit).
Survive for as long as you possibly can.
Steal soda cans from other people's refrigerators.
Trap and eat the rabbits that live in front of your house.
Kill a dog outside and make a coat out of him.
Start a fire in the middle of the highway.
Start up The Long Dark.
Enjoy your immersive experience
10/10 would wear my neighbor's dog again.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Initial Review - 31/12/2014

I've never purchased an early access game before but was intrigued by the concept of The Long Dark and the overwhelmingly positive reviews it has received so far. Suffice to say I was not disappointed.

The Long Dark is an Incredibly tense, beautiful and engaging wilderness survival game. Although the wildlife and combat are quite limited in the current version, the survival mechanics are very deep as you find yourelf in a constant struggle to stay alive as you scavenge for food/water and try to keep your character warm, healthy and rested,

The difficulty options are neat - allowing you to opt for a more ambient experience, a brutal survival experience or something in between - and it's nice to see you can choose your gender and environment before starting.

There's alot of fun to be had with this game in it's current state (sandbox mode) and I can only imagine it will get better as new mechanics, modes and environments are added.

Recommended for fans of games like Don't Starve but I also encourage players who enjoy exploring vast yet delicate environments to give this a try.

-----

Review Update 1 - 11/6/2015:

Following my review from December 2014, this game has went from strength to strength as the devs have added a host of new environments, wildlife and mechanics. Each update has been of a consistently high standard and I have no doubt they will continue to improve/refine the game as they push towards full release.

Each of the sandboxes has a very distinct feel - forcing you to adapt your survival style as you progress - and the transisition areas between each sandbox are unique and challenging. The bears are a welcome addition as are the new crafting mechanics: such as curing of animal skins (which makes crafting of animal-based clothing a little trickier) and the bow and arrow (which provide a nice alternative to the rifle).

The general balancing has improved alot since I started playing this - providing a good mix of thoughtful exploration and harrowing survival - and the backpack interface has evolved nicely.

The Long Dark is undoubtedly one of the finest products on Steam and surely one of the best examples of Early Access done right.

Highly recommended!

-----

Review Update 2 - 13/2/2016

Following my June 2015 update, the Hinterland team have added even more environments: including the oddly-sinister Desolation Point - where the ominous Processing Station contrasts starkly with the cosy Lighthouse - and highly-challenging Timberwolf Mountain - which requires nerves-of-steel to navigate its lakes, forests, slopes and caves.

New gameplay additions - such as the flare gun, rope climbing mechanics, ability to pick up stray wood and ability to break down items in the game world (one of my favourite additions since purchase) - serve to deepen the already-refined gameplay; nothing feels quite so humbling as finding a cosy cabin in the middle of a fierce storm then being forced to break and burn any remaining signs of humanity in order to stay warm.

Hinterland have overhauled the UI side of the game too with a much improved backpack interface, detailed logbook and stats screen and the ability to create multiple saves at once. You can also choose to start from any region now: a welcome edition for new players who will likely benefit as they attempt to hone their own survival style. You can now play the game with a controller as well as keyboard-and-mouse: the former feels good but the latter remains my weapon-of-choice.

Since my last review I've clocked in almost 100 hours of playtime and reached the peak of Timberwolf Mountain: a great achievement indeed. I look forward to the impending Story mode but even without that feature, this game is already more than worth your time and money.

Essential!
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is an outstanding piece of work for a game not yet even released. The sandbox mode available at early access is a decent game in itself and I am eagerly anticipating the story mode release to add more depth to the experience. I picked this game up during one of the sales and I think it offers excellent value for money in its current state.

In a genre otherwise swamped in zombies it is extremely refreshing to play a survival game where you are simply pitted against nature itself. This is certainly more than challenging enough and although the game is a sandbox, there are plenty of goals that will keep you interested. I spent a fair amount of time gaining the achievements and surviving the toughest settings and starter zones, something simply not possible till you've mastered the game in the earlier areas.

The game adds real peril and fear with the introduction of the wildlife and it's genuinely scary to be trying to find shelter in the darkness and come across a growling pair of green eyes or when you see the bear stand and sniff the air for the first time.

Positives:
- This game is a unique experience in an otherwise very predictable genre.
- It's extremly well designed and balanced feeling very challenging without being impossible.
- It's actually very addictive as the game constantly presents a new threat to your survival.
- It feels like you've genuinely accomplished something when you become sustainable".

Negatives:
- Graphically
date: this game is let down a touch and almost certainly due to a lack of budget when it was needed. As a very good game it shines on its gameplay but it is a shame it doesn't have the looks to match.\n- The game is surprisingly unforgiving in some of its starter locations which might lead to a newer player being presented with a very tough start to the game. Persevere if this happens to you
hoursPlayed: it is part of the charm.\n- Some of the sound balancing is a bit messed up. Most terrifying thing in the game? Bears? Wolves? Nope

I guess it depends if you like the idea of it

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Graphics: 7.5
Gameplay: 8.5
Replayability: 8

At first i was unsure of the game and almost refunded the game but after saying screw it I decided to head back in for my 3rd game, the best way to review this game and let you know of some game elements is through my story so far.

I woke on a small ice island in the middle of what was once the sea. I looked around looking at the sheer artistic beauty of this Canadian wasteland and saw in the distance a small green hut and ventured forth across the ice to it and upon arrival was met by great luck with a hunting rifle and a bullet being inside this small hut. upon exiting i see a large cabin on top of a large island and move towards it cautiosly, luck doesn't last forever. To my suprise i enter the house with no problems and inside find several days worth of supplies, a lantern, 5 more bullets, some better clothes and some food and drinks. I spent the night in this homely cabin and spent the next day exploring other green ice fishing cabins returning to my house at night. Knowing I would have to leave I cooked my raw food and kept my tinned produce for the days walking.

After a short walk collecting a few bits of food and drink from a gas station I venture up a snow track lane and walk off to get to a small ranger station to see my surroundings. I reach the station and look out spotting a new place to discover, but I here footsteps behind me and a bear begins to charge me! I ran from the killer bear and when there is some distance between us I start to fire my gun at it's face striking 4 times before being mauled and thrown about by the bear like Leonardo Di Caprio in the Revenant. After a minute of being maulled in a brutal and beautiful animation i accept my death when the black screen comes only to discover that my clothing may have saved me. I'm bleeding and have just 30 seconds to heal myself. Frantically, through blurred vision, I grab my rifle off the floor and my peaches, the bear just 15 metres away, and sprint to a nearby rock so i can bandage myself. A moments respite.

The bear begins charging again and I sprint down some rocks spraining my ankle, thankfully I see a trailer to dive into for safety the bear right behind me. I get in and rest for a few hours to heal. Upon leaving the trailer I begin to celebrate, my fight with the bear was won! The bear led on the ground dead from blood loss and i begin my newest chapter.

A day later a wolf attempts to attack me but i quickly light a flare and throw it at the wolf scaring it, feeling like Liam Neeson I Crouch down and put a bullet in the wolf's face. The same evening another experience with a bear went much better the last of my bullets in the bear I run into a building and sleep.

Day 10 now I have become a survivor and I now wear the pelts of the bears as my clothing.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Get this game right now if you like survival games, you will definitely get your money's worth at full price and it often goes on sale if you're cheap. I myself love survivals a lot and have had this game for a while. It can be a bit challenging, but half the fun with any survival game is that it challenges you.

Pros:
+ Really beautiful art style. Amazing looking for how simple it is.
+ Being able to survive for a long time has a really rewarding feeling that is hard to get in many other survival games.
+ Game is very stable despite being an EA title. I honestly don't recall running into a single bug and it doesn't require a top notch PC to run.
+ 3 difficulty levels have been added, no longer are you forced into one difficulty.
+ Lots to explore if you want to. Quite a large world, but you don't have to play all areas if you don't want to, though I'd say that's half the fun. More maps coming as well.
+ Steam workshop allows for player made language packs.

Cons:
- Can be very easy to get lost if you're not 100% familiar with the map you're playing on.
- Sometimes you get really crappy spawn luck and you either have to try to deal with it or start over. This is pretty much not an issue on easiest difficulty as resources are so common and wildlife doesn't attack.
- No tutorial yet, so some things can be sort of confusing at first.
- No customization at all, which is a con for me since I do love customizing things.
- When you die, it's over, you have to begin anew.

Neutrals:
= Very little music, which could be good or bad depending on the person playing. I don't mind it so much, it helps to hear stuff around you.
= Sometimes the sound effects are a bit irritating because of the repetitiveness, but overall they're not too bad.
= I'm not a big fan of the inventory/conditions/crafting interfaces, but they're functional.
= The environment can be very cruel, even on easiest difficulty. This can be a big con for people new to survivals and not good at managing themselves in-game. To me it's just part of the game, though, so at worst this is a neutral point for me.
= Map setup doesn't change each play through, other than actual items you pick up (though some locations have exclusive or almost guaranteed spawns so they need to be checked for certain items). This can be both good and bad because it makes the maps predictable once you're used to them, which hurts replayability a little, but also allows replays to go smoother.
= No story mode for the moment, but that is in development.
= Development has been a bit slow lately, but it's not a huge team and there's a lot to do in the game in it's current state, so I would still argue it's still a worthwhile buy.

---

The pros greatly outweigh the cons in my opinion. It does get frustrating when you've made good progress and some random fluke of a thing kills you, but for some reason that doesn't make me stop playing it, when most games would frustrate me to the point of not being able to play again by doing that. Perhaps those with rage issues should pass this game up, though.

I highly recommend that anyone new to the game uses the community made maps. None of them are 100% accurate and you may need to make note of the differences yourself, but they will give you a pretty good idea of where you're going at first and eventually you won't need them because the maps don't change each playthrough. I still find them useful though for planning where I'm going to go when I start a new game or for when I have to stop playing, I can cross off the locations I've visited so I don't forget.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nWhile this game is far from perfect, I have to say it is probably my favorite survival game. You really have to push yourself to find the balance for exploration and hoarding. One of the first things you notice about this game is that it is fantasically, deceptively beautiful. I have lost myself in the art of the game only to find myself wandering off a cliff or into a den of wolves. There are only a few things I have issues with, the main being weapons. This isn't a first person shooter or anything, but one of the only weapons in the game is a hard to find/maintain gun. You can find knives, crowbars, and axes, but cannot use them for defence against wolves. The developers seem to always be updating and improving the game, so this could easily change. Overall, I think this is a fantastic game for casual or intense gamers.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I wrote my original review (included below) for The Long Dark based on only a couple weeks of play, and so I felt it was a good idea to come back and update this review now that I've spent over 85 hours with this game.

In that time, the developers successfully upgraded the engine from Unity 4 to Unity 5 over the course of a few weeks, bringing added multi-core cpu and gpu support and increasing overall performance, therefore increasing the range of computers that can support this game.  In my case, I have been playing exclusively on a custom-built rig with the following specifications:

▪ AMD K10-8750K ~3.7GHz 4-core + R7 APU
▪ Gigabyte GA-F2A88XM-D3H microATX motherboard
▪ Corsair 16GB DDR3-2400 RAM
▪ Crucial MX100 512GB SSD (Windows 7 installed)
▪ Crucial MX100 256GB SSD (Linux installed - at this time The Long Dark is not natively supported in this OS)
▪ AOC E2727SHE 27 LCD monitor w/ 1920x1080 resolution

With the above system I have been able to play The Long Dark using the Ultra graphics setting
recommended: without any significant performance issues aside from occasional
hoursPlayed: slight stuttering in certain interior environments that are using special lighting effects.  I also stream the game from this computer via Steam on my late 2006 MacBook Pro over my local network (whenever I don't feel like playing in my office) with no significant performance issues.\n\nThe first thing that you should bear in mind is that this game gets continuous attention and responsive updates from the development team.  I am confident that Hinterland Games is committed to completing this game and feel that my money was well spent
voteText: enough so that I purchased a separate copy for my oldest daughter when she expressed interest in playing.  A big plus is the rapid release of bug fixes following each new release
helpfulPercent: and special effort is repeatedly made to assist those who have lost their loot in the process of upgrading to the latest version.\n\nThe Long Dark is very immersive
votesHelpful: enough so that I have felt it in my fingers
votesTotal: hands
votesFunny: wrists and arms when the main character sprains an ankle.  This is primarily due to the spectacular voice acting.  Some people may be a little put off by the stylized graphics
commentsCount: but I do not find that they detract from immersion in any significant way.\n\nAfter being punished by my first few tries playing the game in Voyageur mode
column16: I switched to Pilgrim in order to explore the maps and get a feel for how the game should be played.  Upon exploring the majority of the maps (and the new connecting area released since my initial review)
column17: I decided that I was no longer being challenged by the game and returned to Voyageur mode
column18: which has since been a constant learning experience.  My longest run so far has been in Voyageur with 41 days completed at the time of this writing.\n\nThis is a survival game
column19: and as such it approaches survival in a way that (in most cases) makes sense.  Some notable exceptions are the ability to carry a mug of coffee in your backpack without spilling it

column22: however

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'm reviewing the early access version. We are still waiting for the story mode.

This game is a survival masterpiece. Most survival games (or probbaby all of them) lack the reality. I mean let's say you are alone on an island. Is it reallistic to craft an axe, cut some trees and build a house in few hours (or few days)? It would take weeks for one human to do so and I'm in doubt that this would be possible at all (imagine you need to transport lumber - how?). Another thing - you are getting hungry what would you do? In most games you just hand kill an animal which by chance came near you. Too easy.

You won't find such things here. The game is as reallistic as possible. You can't build. You have to relay on what was already built. You can craft only some basic stuff like fishing hook, bow and arrows, skin clothes, torches etc. Hunting is really dificult. Unless you find a rifle (you will still be very limited with ammo though) you will either have to craft a bow (using which is very difficult) or try to get some food by chance. Of course you need to gather wood to boil things etc.

Your main evemy is cold. Until you craft some better clothes you can't stay outside for a long time so you need a lot of planning. You will have to explore with a lot of common sense too - never go out too far without a chance of getting back. You will have to account for changing weather. You have no map, no compass and when visibility drops you are lost in a moment.

This game can give you a lot of fun for tenths of hours even though it's just a sandbox. Survival and exploration in the most realistic way. We are still waiting for the story mode. My guess is it won't be as deep as for example Fallout but still combining the most reallistic survival with a thrilling story can be perfect. I hope this game can be modded in the future so there could be more missions on different custom-made maps.

If you are not sure whether to get this game or not, wait for the story mode. It might skyrocket the fun even more. In one sentence - the most reallistic survival game out there.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The Long Dark is an extremely well put together game, that luckily has a developer team that updates it almost monthly.

The game as of right now is a sandbox survival game where, depending on your difficulty, you are put in a situation that you must quickly find your way out of, or you'll die. From there on out, you are met with the challenge of staying alive, and what a challenge that is. Usually, getting your thirst under control is easy, as long as you have a fire, you have a stable source of water. Then you have to find food. This is where the game can get difficult to deal with, as food can be tricky. Hunting is the greatest form of getting food, however, to do this, you either need a bow, or a gun. A bow can be gotten with a little work, however, a rifle, is a different story. You are left to the RNG Gods when it comes to important loot, and while the map doesn't change, the contents of it does.

The cold is a constant fight, and there are only a few times of day when the sun is out and beaming down enough to raise the temperature above 25 degrees, and usually, these times of day are the riskiest, with the most obvious being a few hours before night. This time is risky, because in this game, when things get dark, they get  dark.  Even with a lantern, or a torch, the night is thick, and the darkness is hard to see through, and most of the time, even with those sources of light, you can't see more than 10 feet in front of you, making stumbling over a wolf a genuine risk that could occur. Blizzards are much of the same, you cannot see 5 feet in front of you, the temperature falls to record lows, and the wind chill gets painful. Hypothermia is a real risk, and it's sometimes best to just stay inside.

The art style is wonderful, and charming. Along with this, it is also incredibly comfortable looking, with a wonderful looking lighting system that works alongside the art style beautifully. The insides of houses are comfortable and welcoming, and the outside is a cold, bitter wasteland, that is just as ready to welcome a poor soul as it is to pull that same soul in to chew it up, and spit it out.

The sounds in the game are minimal, but they work. The ambient sounds are usually few and far between, but they do the world a treat, adding both suspense and interest to it. The music is, as such, also incredible effective. Usually, it only comes when things are either at their best, or their worst. If you find a new place, you get to hear a small bit of music that is there to reward you for finding it. The other times it comes, is when your condition is low, and you're nearing death. The music becomes desperate, and urges you to fix the mistakes you've made before it's too late.

Hunting in the game is a treat, in which you actually have to track animals. If you don't kill it, it'll run away. This isn't the end of the world, however. Luckily, not only do they leave a blood trail, but all enemies have a bleed-out amount, meaning that eventually, they will die. And you can follow that same blood trail to find the body, if you can manage to stay warm enough. Along with this, the medical system is well done, it's nothing to write home about, but it works, and it's interesting. There are checks and balances. Everything can be healed over time, but sometimes, they can't be healed well without the correct medical supplies.

Sadly, with this being said, the fishing in this game is useless, except for a 1 or 2 time situation when you're near a place to fish and desperately need food. It is risky, it's incredibly hard to actually catch fish, when you DO catch fish, it usually ends up being too small to actually sustain you, and the places to fish are few and far between. It's better to just scrap the hook and line and use it for other things to fix other pieces of equipment. The metal is better used other ways.

As well as this, I wish the game had a map system, I'm not even asking for one that holds your hand, but maybe the ability to find maps that detail places that would actually have maps would be nice, and they'd allow your character to draw a map over time, ala Miasmata, after searching around and reconning it long enough.

There are so many reasons to get this game, and with story mode coming (next month?), there's even more. Where other Early Access games are only making minimal progress, this one is leaping ahead, with large improvements every single time. I could sing this games praises forever, and I couldn't recommend it more. If you're a fan of survival games, adventure games, or are interested in what the game looks like, get it. It's well supported by an active developement and as of yet I have found no bugs that have impacted my gameplay negatively.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Awesome Game, Something i have been waiting for a long time. The most interesting thing in it for me is how well they implemented fighting for survival. Other survival games(Early Acces especialy) focus more on building stuff and fighting mutants/zombies/whatever while this one is more realistic. It simply focuses on our basic needs like food/water/body temp. and really makes it challenging while in others its only an addition.
Pros(+)
- Finally good game on Unity Engine(both graphics and sound)
- Surprisingly innovative
- Low price compared to other survival games
- Quite immersive (especially when u're lost in a blizzard)
- Huge world
Cons(-)
- No jump button
- You need too much food(my character's daily need is arround 4kg of meat or up to 8kg of fish)
- Too many wolves ( Its just stupid as u go for around 10mins u will surely meet at least 2 wolves on your way, It would be better if they were in groups or at least a bit more clever)
All in all as in every survival game you can find yourself sitting in one place and having stuff to survive for over 20 days. Then you starts wandering why should i keep playing as i'm quite safe here. Then you get bored and start exploring leaving a lot behind. - what i ment by this - for now you can't be rescued and there is no plot in game(as far as i know) so only thing you can really do is explore this dangerous but beautifull world. Yet still for me it's experience worth 20 euro!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The ultimate survival experience, in a game where you must survive against the frozen Canadian wilderness. Unlike other survival games on Steam that have never left Early Access, the game is focused around surviving, not crafting or zombie defense. Currently, only a Sandbox mode is available, however a Story mode is in the works and the developers keep us posted about it regularly.

The game is highly immersive and contains a fair degree of realism, in Sandbox you must look out for your health and supply stock to ensure you live as long as possible. However, I recommend starting on the Pilgrim difficulty due to the fact that death is permanent and wildlife is otherwise quite hostile - not only are you in the menu but you're also the main course. It could save you a lot of rage and false initial impressions about the game.

Highly recommended - the game is guaranteed to bring out an inner survival instinct you never imagined you had in you - I always have a blast when i'm playing it!

If you fear your computer might be too slow to run the game, they have recently announced a feature-complete Xbox One edition available through the Game Preview program - as an admitted PC elitist, if you see me recommending this on a console is because the game is just criminally good. This is Early Access done right, and we should always support developers that support us. The average user score in the mid-90's or higher speaks for itself: developers listen to feedback and its player base is very fond of it - for good reasons.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Thus far, this is one of the most passionate survival-type games out there. I adore the aesthetic and cannot express how I am drawn to the illustrious open world and the adventure it entails. As it is in Alpha, I have minor issues that, if fixed, could increase my respect for the developers even more so. Some of the gameplay aspects are a bit clunky, such as switching in and out of the inventory and to the personal status section, and having to alternate between them to determine a propeer course of action (that is, in terms of repairing or consuming one item over another based on the player's current condition). It makes the game feel less immersive and unnecessarily slow. However, every aspect of this game with the exception of this is beyond extraordinary, and if you crave a beautifully artistic world or immense strategic planning and quick-thinking survival tactics with intuitive gameplay, then this game is absolutely worth your time and money.

I love this game.  :)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The Long Dark is the most beautiful horror game I have ever played.

The sounds in The Long Dark are the most terrifying. Your teeth chatter because the windchill is hitting -21C. The door shuts behind you and you can hear the angry whistle of the winds outside frantically trying to rip through the ramshackle boards of the derelict structure. You think that you are alone in the structure with the sound of your winded breath, but find another person hunched over at the top of the staircase. Well, more of a decoration than a person. They've been a frozen reminder of your future for at least a week.
You drank your last can of soda before you went to sleep, so you'll need to leave the building and go back to searching for food. If you're lucky, the blizzard will stop, but after your plane crash and being stuck with no viable supplies, you aren't exactly the luckiest person in the world. Then again, up here, you are the only person.


Buy this game.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Although I've just started this game, I have put a lot of hours into it and I am enjoying immensely and heres why.

Each start of a new game feels fresh, a bit desperate (especially if you're not familiar with the map) and intuitively you give yourself a set of goals for what you need to find first. If the map is unfamiliar you first go wandering to find a suitable homebase or shelter at least but after a few attempts at the same map I find that it switches to trying to find the necessary tools of survival such as a rifle (which has random spawn locations) that you can lug back with you to the homebase and safety you know is there.

The next few days can be bothersome because you eventually run into wolves and they can be a chore to deal with but fortunatly there is Pilgrim mode for when I just feel like exploring the world. This has to be on a different character as you can't switch between modes in the same playthrough. It's actually a very relaxing game to just enjoy the environments and the layout of the maps while exploring and watching the changes of the day as time rolls by. There is no fear of danger or even of dying in the cold weather as it is mostly milder and soon you'll be wearing the top tier homemade gear from a crafting table. After exploring in pilgrim mode you can than return to voyager or stalker mode to give yourself a survival challenge where dangerous animals lurk and hunt you, especially if you don't feel like staying indoors for days on end sleeping and starving or dehydrating yourself to get to the next day on the bare minimum and want to push yourself to the next map.

There are currently five maps in sandbox mode. Each with a transition zone in between to explore and challenge. Soon there will be a story mode, and the devs continually add to the game mechanics I hear. From screenshots I've seen the menus have changed which inform your stats. Before it would show the meters filling to indicate the bad things happening to your character; like cold, or hunger. Now they drain which is more intuitive, I think. when fully  drained and things start to go from bad to worse there will be an indicator on screen telling which bar has been drained or is near empty. Icicles for cold, a stomach for hunger, an eye for sleep, and a droplet for thirst. Cold is worst but your condition can drop to 65% before suffering the consequences like getting hypothermia.

I think the fun of this game comes from trying to push your character to the brink and desperatly fighting to come back from it. Living through animal encounters where all your clothes have been torn to tatters and having to go out and hunt anyways because you need those skins for the repairs. Gambling on foraging for even more supplies like meds and bandages or plants when you only have a few more bullets in your rifle or a handful of flares to fend off wolves or bears. And finally when you are on the brink after a bear attack and you hear the sound of your own heartbeat as it slows and your character cant even walk straight as you bleed out. You at least have a chance to use bandages and run for safety but if you don't it can be an epic end to your run.

In short, I really like this game as it is right now but look forward to what else the devs will add. I hope they put in beavers. I want a homemade hat.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I was doing pretty well, surviving for 50 days with everything I could wish for in my inventory, went 'in to the wild' in Timberwolf mountain, too tired to climb a mountaineering rope to Engine cave found a nice shelter from the wind to place my bedroll and rest for a bit.

Two hours later I woke up frozen in the middle of a blizzard, can’t see anything can’t go anywhere, luckily I carry a few logs, setup a small fire to worm myself and try to figure out my condition:

There are enough hours of daylight ahead and I have one more log to burn and some energy bars, I can allow myself to wait here a bit and see where this is going before attempting a retreat to mountaineering hut in a blizzard.

Conserving my last log I try resting for another hour not lighting a fire this time to be woken by a freaking bear tearing through my bedroll!,

And so far I though bears are nice, we had a pretty good you stay out of my business and I stay out of yours relationship (or so I thought).

With 7% condition I bandaged my wounds, setup a fire, made a worm cup of coffee and started dragging myself back to where I believed is mountaineering hut.

Best game ever 10/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Numb

My toes, I couldn’t feel them anymore, I checked them about three times just to make sure they were still there. Entered an old mining cave and found a granola bar, hopefully it would last me a few more hours, tried to go deeper into the cave, but it was dark, too dark…

Whispers of the chilly wind made me nervous, I wasn’t sure anymore if I was just hearing things, so I tried to make a small camp fire, no luck, my fingers, they hurt so badly.

Tied up some cloth onto a piece of wood, tried six times to light up matchstick, it worked thank god, now I can explore the cave. Found a hunter’s knife, a rifle, and some canned goods by a frozen body, the ashes of some logs were scattered around him, a sign of struggle? His arms were gone, frost bite? Flesh freezes so easily.

Luckily I found some coals along the way, hopefully this would make the fire last longer, built a small camp fire near the body, added some accelerants to boost it. Opened a can of peaches using the knife, held it on top of the fire to heat it up, finally some proper food.

Added a few more coals to help the fire last longer, settled up and placed the sleeping mat near the fire, removed the clothes from the frozen body and made a simple blanket from it, anything to keep me warm.

Tried to get some sleep, thought I was imagining things, when I saw it glowing, two orbs in the colour of red, eyes? Grabbed the rifle and the knife, but it was running towards me already, couldn’t aim as it was right behind me, no lights, just following the sound of the blizzard, as I got closer and closer, the wind sounded harsher and almost deafening, reached the gate and slammed it, knocking back the wolf, yeah that would save me some time, ran towards the road, but there was another one that lounged right at me.

Pain

It’s teeth stuck at my hand, biting down hard and wouldn’t budge, my things scattered across the snow, tried to reach the knife but it was too far, kneed it to the side of its ribs, it howled in pain, grabbed the rifle, aimed, ♥♥♥♥ no bullets, didn’t noticed the other one behind it, it tried to lounge at me, knocked him off with the rifle, now it’s broken.

Grabbed the knife and ran along the cliff, a good 6 feet drop? The snow would absorb the impact, I hope, tried to get some space to run and jump, but the wolves caught up with me, heading straight for my leg, it bit me while we fell to the icy snow.

A sprained ankle, a bleeding hand, a broken leg, one knife, and two wolves, if the injury couldn’t kill me, I bet the wolves will. Grabbed the knife and plunged it to my neck, good bye.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Day 1: Daryl Finds himself trapped in a winter wilderness after crashing his plane. His instrumenst malfunctioned and he found that he had no idea where he was during flight. He wakes up in the snow and seems to have a few portions of food that survived the crash. Thankfully he crashed by train tracks, So just maybe he could find some signs of civilization. He goes on ahead and finds a train wreck with crows flying overhead. His stomach drops. and he already knows what he might find.
Several dead bodies litter the area. He is getting really cold and needs to start a fire. He quickly pilfers through the belongings of these long dead men and manages to gather up soome matches and tinder. He tries to start the fire and fails. He should have paid more attention in army survival school. The cold is starting to burn him to his very depths. He is slowly going numb.
After a hour or two of walking he seems something amazing ahead, A cabin! He sprints towards it with all his might, in the happiest mood ever. He may just survive this long enough to find someone who can help him. He goes inside and looks through everything, finding food first aid and flares. He also has a wood stove. Ofcourse another unfortunate thing he finds is a dead body. He cant quite tell the cause of death or how long this man has been dead. Probably awhile. He crawls to the warm bed and takes a two hour nap wrapped in blankets to warm up. He wakes up feeling refreshed. He has enough food and refreshments to last him a bit but he needs more. Either that or he needs to find a way to get help.
He leaves the cabin and sees several small ice-fishing huts out in the distance as well as some deer. After unsuccesfully sneaking up to, and running after some deer, he loots the ice huts and finds some useful things he can use to ice fish. He will need to go back to his hut and put these things together to make a legit fishing pole,
By the time Daryl makes it back to his cabin it is getting dark. He sleeps till morning and goes exploring some more. He finds some cabins past the ice fishing huts, and decides to loot those. He goes to search through a cave and finds a dead man with a knife by his body. He quickly grabs it up and makes his way further through the valley. He took a wrong step at one point, spraining his wrist terribly. He wrapped it up, so as to not bother him.
He hits a dead end in the valley and decides to turn back. He gets back to the cabin and still has daylight to spare so he decides to try to follow the track further, He does so and runs into another circling of crows. He continues to what looks like a train tunnel and maybe another wreck of some sort, but he also hears menacing snarls. Sure enough it is a wolf. He turns and sprints as fast as he can back to the cabin and makes it safely, thinking and hoping the wolf would not follow.
He is tired so he takes a little nap. He wakes up and creates some fishing supplies. HE is going to the ice fishing huts to grab some more food. He leaves the cabin only to hear the snarl of the wolf.
He runs with all is might towards the ice fishing hut and manages to leave the wolf behind him, only to see another wolf awaiting by the hut. IT runs at him, he is already out of breath,s o he has to stand and face the fast approaching wolf. IT jumps at him and bites his arm and knaws towards his chest. He stabs and slashes frantically, and manages a deep cut into the wolfs stomach, IT whimpers and limps quickly away, bleeding out quickly. He is however in the same predicament. He is getting cold quickly. He makes his way to the ice fishing hut and attempts to start a fire in the wood stove to warm up and maybe help him survive. He has no first aid supplies for this deep wound, He fails to start the fire due to fatigue and dizziness. He is losing all his focus now. He steps outside of the hut.
He is walking towards the cabing. Slowly his world is fading to black. This is where it ends he said.
As the whole world fades to black and he falls to the ground, he just hopes that the wolf suffered as much as he did. IT warm now as he fades out, and the world around him disappears...
10/10
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Thus far, this is one of the most passionate survival-type games out there. I adore the aesthetic and cannot express how I am drawn to the illustrious open world and the adventure it entails. As it is in Alpha, I have minor issues that, if fixed, could increase my respect for the developers even more so. Some of the gameplay aspects are a bit clunky, such as switching in and out of the inventory and to the personal status section, and having to alternate between them to determine a propeer course of action (that is, in terms of repairing or consuming one item over another based on the player's current condition). It makes the game feel less immersive and unnecessarily slow. However, every aspect of this game with the exception of this is beyond extraordinary, and if you crave a beautifully artistic world or immense strategic planning and quick-thinking survival tactics with intuitive gameplay, then this game is absolutely worth your time and money.

I love this game.  :)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The Long Dark is the most beautiful horror game I have ever played.

The sounds in The Long Dark are the most terrifying. Your teeth chatter because the windchill is hitting -21C. The door shuts behind you and you can hear the angry whistle of the winds outside frantically trying to rip through the ramshackle boards of the derelict structure. You think that you are alone in the structure with the sound of your winded breath, but find another person hunched over at the top of the staircase. Well, more of a decoration than a person. They've been a frozen reminder of your future for at least a week.
You drank your last can of soda before you went to sleep, so you'll need to leave the building and go back to searching for food. If you're lucky, the blizzard will stop, but after your plane crash and being stuck with no viable supplies, you aren't exactly the luckiest person in the world. Then again, up here, you are the only person.


Buy this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The game is NOW definitely playable in Alpha mode. They've added some more content and depth to the game, and the biggest factor of all, they finally increased the character's endurance when running (although there is still a lot of running/walking/traveling in this game).

Day 23
I'm on my way back to the dam's control room to collect a bunch of items i dropped since i couldn't carry them all back in one trip. After filling up my inventory, I begin to head back when i notice that this door is actually usable... I use this new door that leads to the back of the dam. Once out, I begin to look around to get a feel of the new environment. To the far left i see that there's another platform that may hold some promising items. To get across I'd have to hug the dam and tip toe across the protruding ledge. A few steps onto the ledge and I fall off the ledge onto the dam itself (the dam isn't completely vertical but at an angle)! I take only 15% damage, sprained my wrist (of course never my ankle when falling for some reason), and my clothes are a little ripped, no serious harm done. I'm off the ledge but still on the dam, so I take off all my clothes to prevent any damage to them. I take little jumps down the dam, slowly but surely. Eventually, I make it all the way down and begin to find my way back up to dam's door so i could try again. I tiptoe across the ledge once more. Yes ! I'm across the long part of the ledge. Now all i need to do is turn the corner. There's 8 more steps I need to make before i can be safe on the platform. Sure enough I fall again ! This time the injuries are more severe. I'm left with 12% hp left ! But I will not give up ! I head across to the other platform once more. Success ! I scour the platform and find nothing of value. Brrrrr... It's cold... What is this?! I'm suffering from hypothermia! FML I FORGOT TO PUT MY CLOTHES BACK ON !! My hp is slowly ticking down... After putting my clothes back on, I race across the ledge once more, to  the dam's back door. WTF !?!? I LOCKED MYSELF OUT OF THE CONTROL ROOM?!?! WHO DOES THAT ?!?! I'm panicking ! My life's slowly dropping by the percent. Down to 8%... My vision's blurry and my character begins to wobble. He's blacking out and coming back. I attempt to make a fire, but no, it's too windy ! I run around the place looking for cover from the wind ! I travel down the  mountain on a path and finally manage to get the fire going, but am left with 4% hp. I throw some logs onto the fire and warm myself up entirely. I check the time, there's 4 hours left. I've got to reach some kind of shelter before nightfall or else i'll freeze to death. Perhaps I messed somthing up and the back door actually does open? Still blacking out and wobbling, I decided to head back up to the back door to check again. I take 4 steps. OWWWW, burning damage inflicted !! I WALKED OVER MY OWN FIRE ! IS THIS HOW I'M GOING TO DIE?? KILLING MYSELF BY WALKING OVER MY OWN FIRE??!!? Thankfully, I'm left with 2% health and minor burns... I travel upwards, towards the door, but alas, the door does not open... The only way to go is down the mountain and follow the frozen river. My character's still disoriented, I'm having trouble walking and navigating my way through this maze of a river. I take every turn, only to be led to a dead end. It seems like there's no way up and out of this river system, so i push through looking for some kind of exit... I finally reach the end.... I found the tunnel system. It seemed to be the only way out, so i went in. Bad idea. 10 Steps in and i literally could not tell which way was up or down. I see a frozen corpse. Ha, i guess he'll have a friend pretty soon. I personally, begin to get motion sickness. I'm lost and i honestly can't tell if i'm going forwards into the cave or going back to where i came in from..... I give up... I exit the game and decide to reload from my last save spot (where ever that is i do not know). It happens to be the moment i entered the cave. I quickly turn around and exit. Surely there has to be another way out of this river system.... Welp, time to go online and look for a map ! There's no map. I did however, find out that there are two entrances/exits to this river system... The cave and A MFING WINDOW ON THE OPPOSITE PLATFORM TO THE DAM'S BACK DOOR!!!! I begin my journey back through the river/maze.... I'm beginning to feel tired... I'm forced to drop some inventory.... A dead end.... Another one.... Eventually i see open space. There's no mountains ahead. Sure enough, the dam appears. I travel up the moutain pass and reached the back door. Okay... I could barely cross the ledge at 100% health.... Now i've got to do it at 2% health.... I'm still wobbling, my screen is still fading in and out. I tip toe across the ledge and make sure i hit every wall there is to hit. I'm safe on the platform. I search for the window and slide my way inside of the dam. I recognize this area.... It's the deepest room inside of the dam and darkest..... I'll need a light source through the entire dam... I have a few matches and a flare.... I light the flare and race my way through the dam. I pass through the piles of items that i was supposed to retrieve. I pass through the door that started the entire journey. A few more minutes and i reach the front door of the dam. I drink and eat as much as i can. I check the time, less than an hour left of daylight ! It's a race against time ! I leave the dam with nothing but the clothes on my back and the single flare which only has 30% of it's original life left. I'm outside and it's dark. The time says less than one hour of daylight, but that's only referring to the temperature... I walk straight until i see the railroad. I place my feet on the railroad and look towards home, but i can barely see now. It's too dark ! I walk backwards, i've lost the railroad ! i look left or was it right? I see the way that isn't home and look the opposite direction. I see the bridge and railroad so I begin to walk. It's a long trek home. My flare dies out. The icon that tells me i'm suffering from lack of sleep appears. I march on. I reach a checkpoint, the trees that have been cut for lumber. I see that familiar corpse on the left side of the tracks.I reach the next checkpoint. The derailed carts. I walk around the carts and around the branch that blocks the way. From here on it's a straight path until home. I literally can not tell If i'm moving or not. I can only trust that i am. I march on. Waiting for some sign, for that opening in the mountains to the left that signifies that my cabin is there. I march on. Finally, i see the opening ! i see the black silouhette that resembles a house. I recognize that flag figure flying proudly atop the house. I run towards the house to the side i know the front door is on. I put my face against the side of the house and move left and right searching for the door. Is my face even against the wall or is it on the fence of the front porch?! I don't know, i can not see ! I try the back door which has no fence to protect it. I can't find that one either ! I back off from the house, trying to position myself to where i know the back door is, but i lose the house itself !! I see nothing but blackness. Am i touching the house or is it the mountains behind the house?!? I can not tell.... In time, i'm able to see that familiar silhoutte once more. I reposition myself and check my inventory to see if there's ANYTHING that can light the way... Apparently I left some matches in my backpack !! They must have been too light to throw away ! Thank god I was too lazy to toss them out ! I light a match against the wall of the house and am able to find the back door.... i light another match inside of the cabin so i can locate the stairs.  finally i'm safe at last.... I rest for 6 hours, not wanting to die of thirst or hunger. I wake up well enough to sleep for another 12 hours. Alas, I am home and rested, ready to journey once more...

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Awesome Game, Something i have been waiting for a long time. The most interesting thing in it for me is how well they implemented fighting for survival. Other survival games(Early Acces especialy) focus more on building stuff and fighting mutants/zombies/whatever while this one is more realistic. It simply focuses on our basic needs like food/water/body temp. and really makes it challenging while in others its only an addition.
Pros(+)
- Finally good game on Unity Engine(both graphics and sound)
- Surprisingly innovative
- Low price compared to other survival games
- Quite immersive (especially when u're lost in a blizzard)
- Huge world
Cons(-)
- No jump button
- You need too much food(my character's daily need is arround 4kg of meat or up to 8kg of fish)
- Too many wolves ( Its just stupid as u go for around 10mins u will surely meet at least 2 wolves on your way, It would be better if they were in groups or at least a bit more clever)
All in all as in every survival game you can find yourself sitting in one place and having stuff to survive for over 20 days. Then you starts wandering why should i keep playing as i'm quite safe here. Then you get bored and start exploring leaving a lot behind. - what i ment by this - for now you can't be rescued and there is no plot in game(as far as i know) so only thing you can really do is explore this dangerous but beautifull world. Yet still for me it's experience worth 20 euro!

Early Access Review

Well had 4 attempts at the sandbox mode and just about getting used to the maps, wish game had a compass or had the ability to find one, I seem to get lost a lot....lol

But loving this so far, so much potential and so much hidden mechanics which bring the game alive. Have to stop playing like a game at times and think what may happen in real life (to a degree).

Only suvived 8 days, was going good until a wolf attack and then blizzard straight after, supplies to far away in safe house and slowly drained away. Was doing so well. Just need to get a rifle or bow as I havent managed that yet!

So far probably my favourite survival game, it acts so simple but underneath are a lot of workings. And no zombies...Yay!

9/10 Will keep up to date on devs work and looking forward to the campaign.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is the Oregon Trail of first person shooters.

There's really no other way of describing it.  Though it's not really about getting from one specific place to another, it's about exploring and surviving when the odds are entirely against you.  Hours in you realize so many small choices are life and death: using that cloth to repair your clothing, keeping you warm, or tearing them up for bandages, in case you are attacked.

Or staying where you are, which is safe, but your food sources are running out, or hiking through the blizzard down an unknown path hoping to find game, something to eat, or an abandoned house to raid.

Even the miniscule amounts of ammunition you can scavenge adds to this:  do you use your last three bullets hoping to take down the wolf at a distance? Or do you get closer, improving your chance to hit, but giving it a chance to charge you?

It ook a few hours to fully get the experience, but once I got it, I was hooked.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The first time I played this I didn't realize you could melt snow to drink and panicked I would die of dehydration so went out in a -45C blizzard and found a can of orange soda.
Died of hypothermia.
Kel loves orange soda.

10/10

Got a LITTLE better and just slogged through surviving for 19 days, my current best. It's not a lot, but I have EXTREMELY bad luck and getting to aim a gun and shoot at the same time when my mouse pad locks up up all the time means wolves keep slaughtering me - that and I always seem to leave my shelters at the worst possible times, y'know, like when I'm starving to death to look for food.

Though you can survive without food for a few days, I think the hunger mechanic is a little over the top, I understand all the extra calories you'd burn in such a cold environment and walking on snow and yadayadayda, but it is a little annoying to be starving just hours after polishing off 9kg of deer meat (not all in one go, but tbh I don't think it would've lasted much longer anyway.) This dude must've been in eating competitions and have t-shirts from every steakhouse in the US for how much he needs to eat to stop complaining!

Overall I do really love this game, it's interesting and just plain different, the permadeath is an element I love and hate at the same time, but it really does make the game, you HAVE to survive. Sometimes it's luck, where you start out, which caches are open to you, whether you catch any fish during a 5 hour stretch and whether a big bad wolf will flip it's biscuits and attack you three times in a row so every item of your clothing is ripped to shreds and you're out in North Canada wearing, assuringly, nothing.

Yeah, I'm sure a lot of you will read this and assume I'm horribly bad at the game and maybe I am, but you gotta try it for yourself and see how well you fair! It's like nothing else and you kinda enjoy being such a horrible masochist to yourself.

Good luck out there, it's f***king cold!

I started this game randomly, after reading reviews and watching some of the videos, but while searching for something ... unseen like this, then the comments and reviews took me deeper and said - let's give a try, and thrill that took me away from the first minute is still here.
Now everytime i see Trapper's Homestead it makes such a good and warm feeling, just knowing the goods, that have been stored there from my last visit. All the water and the supplies lying in the boxes and lockers, all maple and birch saplings curing for day after day ..
Very engaging, appealing and immersive nature takes you to a journey you never had in any game.. Can't wait for this awesome project go to it's full with a story line awaiting.
Recommended 100/10 (even knowing it's early access release)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I was lucky enough to come across shelter on my second day... a dam, ominous interior but warm. I began breaking down the crates and shelves within the dam's lower quarters so that I could get a roaring fire and stave off hypothermia. It was then that I discovered the body. In the corner just beside my fire barrel was a frozen corpse, head down in rigid repose. I could not move the fire I had already started, so I would have to deal with the body for the time being. Finally, a place to heat up these cans of soup and get a good night's rest.

I woke up in the middle of the night to snarling. A wolf had wandered into my makeshift camp; or perhaps I had wandered into his. Armed with nothing but a torch, I brandished my tool at the beast in a desperate attempt to drive it off. It worked for a while, but the creature returned. My body screamed at me to sleep, to get the desperate rest I needed to go on, but I knew I could not tear my eyes away from the shadows for a second, lest the wolf take me. Glowing green eyes pierced the shadowy veil around my fire, which I struggled to maintain. My torch was burning out, and still the pair of eyes stared - waiting, watching, growling.

There was little I could do against the animal, and my only tool for driving it back was losing fuel quickly. I instinctively backed into a corner and realized I had bumped into something - the body. The frozen man which had horrified me earlier would soon become my eternal friend, now that the wolf had me. But wait, what's this? You can search corpses in this game? A feature I had not expected could now save me! But only if the man had something on him like a rifle or...

A knife!

The wolf lunged and I fell back, stabbing wildly with my new weapon and screaming at the screen in a moment of defiance. It was him or me, and thanks to my frozen friend I had leveled the playing field. The creature shrieked in pain and fell off me, whimpering and darting back into the shadows. No longer would its eyes haunt the night. After about an hour of hovering over the fire and taking whatever medicine I had gathered prior to the encounter, I heard the beast let out a final cry of pain from the next room. My valiant defense had killed the creature. I won.

Three days later I died to a bear. This game has quickly become one of my favorites because of moments like the one listed above. Could not reccomend it more.
